HEADLINE: Takeovers Are Part of the Game;
Any Hot Toy Can Grow Up to Be a Unit of Mattel or Hasbro

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
When a hot toy hits the market, frantic parents rush to buy it while it is still on the shelf. Toy makers, it seems, are adopting a similar shopping strategy.
Ever on the lookout for top-selling toys to add to their mix, industry giants like Mattel and Hasbro are increasingly looking not so much to their own workshops but to their smaller rivals. If they did not come up with the latest plaything to catch the eye of those fickle 4-year-olds, they simply buy the company that did. 
 "Our industry thrives on new products, and where that comes from is not necessarily always going to be from the big companies," said David Miller, president of the Toy Manufacturers of America, the trade group that this week is putting on the 96th annual American International Toy Fair in New York.
For instance, Mattel, maker of Barbie and Hot Wheels, will soon be the biggest producer of consumer software behind Microsoft, but it is paying $3.8 billion to do so by acquiring the Learning Company. And Hasbro, known for G.I. Joe dolls and Tonka trucks, won the latest toy war with Furby, but only after it bought Furby's maker, Tiger Electronics, last year for $335 million.
"If there is something out there that we think can add to our brand portfolio," said Wayne Charness, a spokesman for Hasbro, "we do everything we can to go get it."
In the fiercely competitive and cyclical toy business, manufacturers and retailers have long struggled with how to achieve the consistent revenues and earnings growth that investors demand. By buying rivals, they hope to minimize the risk of wild earnings swings from new toys that fizzle fast or classics that lose their luster. And snapping up a competitor's expertise or best-selling brands enables manufacturers to respond more rapidly to ever-evolving consumer demands.
That is just what has happened with electronic games and multimedia software, which have become increasingly important to the industry. While the overall industry had essentially flat results last year, with $15.2 billion in wholesale shipments to retailers, the total market for video game software grew a third, to $2.8 billion, while the market for electronic games grew 20 percent, to $456 million, according to the toy industry group.
Seeking to achieve such gains with a wider array of educational and interactive toys, Hasbro and Mattel have been trolling for companies that would give them more of an edge. Last year, Hasbro bought Microprose Inc., Tiger Electronics and the Atari video game division of the JTS Corporation. Mattel, not to be outdone, followed with the largest deal in the industry in recent years by announcing that it would acquire the Learning Company. The deal is expected to close by the end of April.
"Mattel recognizes enormous opportunity in Learning Company's relationships with schools and hot specialty stores like Zany Brainy," said Eric Johnson, a professor at Vanderbilt University's Owen Graduate School of Management. Zany Brainy is a fast-growing specialty retailer that sells, among other things, multimedia educational products.
In addition to gaining even greater visibility at such specialty toy sellers, "Mattel can now leverage its distribution and brands to grow the Learning Company's products, while integrating education and multimedia into its own line of toys and games," Mr. Johnson said.
Consumers are likely to benefit, too. For one thing, toys that once required jaunts to specialty stores will now be more widely available at places like Kmart and Toys "R" Us. And economies of scale usually generated from these transactions often produce cost savings for the manufacturers that in theory could mean cheaper prices at the checkout lane.
Money managers and analysts said they expected the consolidation to continue as toy makers looked to diversify not just through international expansion and internal creativity but also through shopping sprees that combined the creative talents of smaller, niche operators with the huge distribution and other resources of the industry giants.
"Historically this has been a very fragmented industry," said Timothy Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation, which owned 190,000 shares of Mattel last year but has since sold its stake. "There is ease of entry, and it is driven by the creative types. Along with all of corporate America, the toy industry is beginning to benefit from consolidation and the benefits of size, especially with the retail channel consolidating into a couple of very strong hands."
Indeed, without the marketing resources and the influence to secure coveted shelf space at Wal-Mart and Toys "R" Us, one-hit wonders risk being shut out of the game no matter how hot their products may be. And for larger manufacturers, paying for new talent is often more cost effective than waiting for the next Cabbage Patch Kids doll to come from within.
"It's good for the acquired company because they often get a good price and they lower the risk of having a one-shot item," Mr. Ghriskey said. "And it's good for the acquirer because they can fold it right into their existing structure, with few if any additional costs other than the purchase price."
That is the thinking behind a string of mergers the last two years. Besides the Learning Company and Tiger Electronics, other transactions include Radica Games Ltd.'s acquisition last year of Kid Active and the merger in 1997 of Leapfrog and Knowledge Kids Enterprises, a unit of Knowledge Universe L.L.C.
The acquisition by Radica gave the manufacturer of hand-held casino theme games the Girl Tech line of electronic products for girls. Radica also got Kid Active's Girl Tech Web site, which broadened the company's marketing capabilities because it can now promote directly to youngsters who visit the site. And the Leapfrog transaction combined Knowledge Kids' financial resources with Leapfrog's award-winning educational products, like Word Wizard, an interactive system that teaches word recognition and reading comprehension.
To be sure, there are still plenty of independent niche companies left, like Ty Inc., maker of the wildly popular Beanie Babies; Jakks Pacific Inc., manufacturer of WWF Action Figures, and Wild Planet Toys, maker of electronic gear and spy toys. But for many others, giving up some autonomy is a small price for the potential these deals provide to make the most of their products.
In fact, Roger Shiffman, Tiger's president, said that had it not been for the sale of his company to Hasbro last year, Tiger would have been unable to capitalize fully on Furby's potential. Tiger obtained the rights to Furby from the inventor in October 1997 and rushed to get a rough prototype ready for last year's toy fair. Retailers' interest was greater than the company expected, and Tiger soon found itself trying to fill orders in eight months for a million Furbys, which would typically take about two years.
Tiger supplied the concept for Furby, and Hasbro provided the computerized drafting, mechanics, working samples and ultimately the production operations to create the finished product. "They made things happen faster for us and helped us get the product out because of how late we were," Mr. Shiffman said. The Furby frenzy reflects just how these deals are designed to work -- teaming up an entrepreneurial company's risk-taking with a large company's might to push the toy into the marketplace.
Beyond Furby, "We are going to benefit from their international sales, and that is an area in which we were underperforming.," said Mr. Shiffman, who now runs Tiger for Hasbro. And, he said, Hasbro's marketing resources and licensing agreements gave Tiger the ability to create products tied to properties it would otherwise not have access to, like Barney and toys tied to the new Star Wars movie coming out in May.
Mattel, too, has made several recent acquisitions that it says have increased its competitiveness. In its case, Mattel was looking for companies with established brands that also provided strategic benefits. "We've both benefited from the competencies we are seeking and acquired related brands," said Glenn Bozarth, a spokesman for Mattel.
Through its purchase of Tyco Inc. in 1996, for example, Mattel snagged the Fisher-Price line, which is popular with preschoolers. The line includes Blue's Clues and Sesame Street plush products as well as classics like Magna-Doodle and View-Master. Then the purchase last year of the Pleasant Company gave it the the popular American Girl dolls, plus some strategic advantages.
While Barbie is popular with girls between about 3 and 8, the American Girl line expands the age spectrum to girls in their early teens. And the American Girl line is sold primarily through catalogues, allowing Mattel to use the Pleasant Company's expertise in direct-to-consumer distribution to sell its other brands. If successful, the approach would enable the company to be less dependent on key retailers, an increasingly important factor for toy makers, whose business suffered mightily last year when Toys "R" Us slashed its orders to cut costs.
Indeed, Mattel's recent disappointing financial performance, including a 69 percent earnings decline in the fourth quarter of 1998, highlights the need for toy makers to further consolidate in an attempt to reduce their dependence on few powerful retailers as well as the whims of often finicky consumers.
"Toys are an inherently risky business," said Mr. Johnson of Vanderbilt. "The only way to insure stable earnings growth and the kinds of things the Wall Street guys look for in a consumer product company is through acquisition -- to buy successful products and brands to keep diversifying all that massive risk they face."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
INDIA: STATE LEADER QUITS -- The Chief Minister of Orissa State has submitted a letter of resignation, grudgingly taking "moral responsibility" for a recent spate of violence, including the killing of an Australian missionary and his two sons by Hindu militants. The Minister, Jayanti Ballabh Patnaik, gave the letter to his Congress Party leader, Sonia Gandhi. Barry Bearak (NYT) 

THAILAND: AIDS VACCINE TO BE TESTED -- The first large-scale testing of an experimental AIDS vaccine in a developing country will begin soon in Thailand. The trial will involve 2,500 intravenous drugs users, mostly men, in Bangkok. Large-scale testing of the vaccine began in the United States last June. (NYT)
 
 MYANMAR: U.S. SHUNS HEROIN MEETING -- The United States will not attend a global conference on the heroin trade sponsored by Interpol because the organizers chose to hold it in Myanmar, Clinton Administration officials said. Myanmar's record of human-rights violations "made it impossible for any U.S. official to attend," according to a State Department official, Frank Loy. Myanmar is regarded as the world's leading producer of heroin, officials said. Tim Weiner (NYT)
 
CHINA: MACEDONIA RELATIONS CUT -- China suspended diplomatic ties with Macedonia after the Macedonians confirmed that they would establish relations with Taiwan, the official New China News Agency reported. China said Macedonia had violated accords between the two countries recognizing China's sovereignty over Taiwan. (Agence France-Presse)
 
TAIWAN: HIJACKERS HANDED BACK -- Taiwan handed over five paroled Chinese hijackers to the mainland in a gesture intended to ease tensions with Beijing in advance of a planned meeting with a high Chinese official in Taiwan that is expected by April. (Reuters)
 
CAMBODIA: NEW PACTS WITH CHINA -- Prime Minister Hun Sen signed five agreements in Beijing increasing political and economic ties with China, but both sides ruled out talks on a trial for members of the Khmer Rouge, the last remnants of which joined the Cambodian Army in a ceremony in Anlong Veng. (Reuters, AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: INTELLIGENCE OFFICIAL QUITS -- Intelligence Minister Qorbanali Dorri-Najafabadi resigned four weeks after his ministry admitted that its agents were involved in a spate of killings of writers and dissidents. The disclosure intensified the rivalry between hard-line and moderate factions in the Government. Ali Yunesi, the chief military prosecutor, will replace Mr. Dorri-Najafabadi, according to two newspapers with ties to the Government. (AP)
 
ISRAEL: SHARON'S STAR WANES -- In primaries within the conservative Likud Party, Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon, left, who was vying for the second spot on the ticket for May elections, finished in eighth place. After the defection of key Likud members to the new Center Party and elsewhere, several lesser-known Cabinet ministers saw their stars rise, particularly Science Minister Silvan Shalom, now Likud's No. 2. Deborah Sontag (NYT)
 
LIBYA: U.N. APPROVES MECCA FLIGHTS -- The United Nations approved flights for Libyans to travel to Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage to the Muslim holy sites of Mecca and Medina. Air travel in or out of Libya has been banned since 1992 in an effort to force it to turn over two suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: TALKS IN U.S. ON DRUGS -- Interior Minister Francisco Labastida Ochoa is visiting Washington to discuss drug policies this week with Attorney General Janet Reno, Louis J. Freeh, the Director of the F.B.I., and other officials. Mexican political experts said Mr. Labastida appears to have the backing of President Ernesto Zedillo for the presidential nomination of their governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
SOUTH AFRICA: COHEN ON MILITARY TIES -- William S. Cohen, making the first visit to South Africa by a United States Defense Secretary, said the Clinton Administration wanted to build closer military ties with South Africa but saw little chance for rapid progress. In three days of talks, Mr. Cohen will discuss United States initiatives for peacekeeper training and an African Center for Security Studies, which Washington hopes will professionalize the region's armies. (AP)
 
ZIMBABWE: CRACKDOWN ON PRESS -- Condemnation of a crackdown on the press mounted as the editor of The Mirror, Ibbo Mandaza, and a reporter, Grace Kwinjeh, left, were ordered to appear for trial on charges that they published false information. But in a sign that the Government may be taking a step back, the two were freed on bail and charges against two other journalists were dropped. The arrests follow the detention and apparent torture by the army last month of two journalists from The Standard. (AP)
 
EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: ARMS SALES DENOUNCED -- A parliamentary committee delivered a scathing criticism of the Foreign Office for failing to inform Cabinet ministers that a British company had breached a United Nations embargo against selling arms to Sierra Leone, where rebels are fighting pro-Government forces. The committee said the department's top civil servant, Sir John Kerr, "failed in his duty," but Prime Minister Tony Blair said Sir John would not be forced to resign. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
NORTHERN IRELAND: HOPES ON DISARMAMENT -- Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders said the head of the disarmament commission, a former Canadian general, John de Chastelain, was working on a compromise in the dispute over the disarming of the Irish Republican Army and other paramilitary groups. The dispute threatens to delay restoration of home rule power to the Assembly in Belfast by the British Government, which is scheduled for March 10. James F. Clarity (NYT)
 
ARMENIA: TOP AIDE SLAIN -- A senior Government official in charge of security was shot dead outside the capital city, Yerevan. The official, Gen. Artsroun Markarian, a Deputy Interior Minister, was apparently abducted on his way to work. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Luring High Technology Downtown

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems recently signed a 10-year lease for 89,152 square feet of office space in the World Trade Center. Theglobe.com, an on-line discussion and shopping company, signed up for 47,000 square feet at 120 Broadway on a 15-year lease. And Platinum Technologies, a software publisher, took the top two floors at 140 Broadway, a total of 47,000 square feet.
As these transactions suggest, technology-based companies are moving into the bottom tip of Manhattan, an area of the city once better know for high finance than high tech. Building owners, their representatives and brokers are promoting the area as one that already has a thriving community of new media and computer-based companies and is receptive to new entries. 
 The local business improvement district, the Alliance for Downtown New York, is actively using technology, including an interactive Web site (www.DowntownNY.net), to communicate with companies already in the area and to attract new ones. It has formed a unit, called Information Technology District, to provide business development seminars and other services tailored to young, rapidly growing companies.
Alliance officials say that more than 600 information technology companies, from Web page developers to businesses offering computer-based financial and statistical analyses, are in the area below Chambers Street.
Being near similar businesses is important for technology companies, said Lewis J. Cowan, a leasing agent for Silverstein Properties who helped move Theglobe.com into 120 Broadway. "They were not particularly interested in downtown and they were skeptical when I showed them the space," he said. "Their first question was, 'Who else is down here?' "
The answer was in a booklet published by the alliance last year that listed all the technology-based companies the group could find. It also put the information on its Web site.
Like other business improvement districts, the alliance sweeps sidewalks and provides security service, but it is the only one to concentrate on attracting a certain type of company and to use technology to do so, said Sharon Greenberger, the group's vice president for economic development.
"Companies are attracted to a community of software and technology firms," Ms. Greenberger said. "They want to be close to the lenders and they want to be close to each other. That is what we have here, a community in a confined geographic area."
To help bind that group together, the alliance has been working to complete the Community Extranet, a service on its Web site, that will help companies exchange ideas and announce new jobs and internships. Users will also be able to copy software for testing before deciding which package to buy, participate in discussions about products and places and get listings of coming events and exhibitions. The site now lists high technology companies in the district, including telephone numbers, Web links and E-mail links.
The alliance also sponsors free seminars for entrepreneurs on tax and intellectual property issues and raising capital. "The seminars are co-sponsored by the New York New Media Association," Ms. Greenberger said. "They are free, to encourage people to attend. It's important that they see us as a service vehicle and a friend."
Just about everyone agrees that the heart of what boosters like to call Silicon Alley is at 55 Broad Street, an old financial building that was rewired and converted into the Information Technology Center. Virtually empty when the conversion began in 1995, 55 Broad now is "full with a waiting list," said William C. Rudin, the president of the Rudin Management Company, which operates the 410,000-square-foot building.
He said that high technology companies fed on the creative energy of one another and that being in proximity promoted growth. And he said that although Sun was moving its regional corporate offices to the Trade Center, the Sun specialists who are developing new uses for Sun's programming language would remain at 55 Broad "because of the creative environment."
With assistance from the city's Economic Development Corporation, the alliance also operates the Plug 'n' Go program, which makes Internet-wired space available to start-up companies at a below-market rental rate. Now entering its third year, the Plug 'n' Go program includes six buildings; to participate, a building must have at least 20,000 square feet available to rent at $19 a square foot for the first year.
Alliance officials say 14,000 square feet of space has already been rented under Plug 'n' Go since the beginning of the year.
"Downtown is a natural location for many of these information technology companies because they are providing services to the big financial companies," said Cherrie Nanninga, the director of real estate for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the World Trade Center. Since the beginning of the year, Baseline Financial Services and Smart World Technologies have signed leases in the center.
Baseline, which provides portfolio managers with visual analysis of the performance and prospects for stocks, will occupy 58,902 square feet. Smart World, which provides Internet access and helps advertisers find individual on-line sales prospects, will occupy 9,324 square feet.

HEADLINE: Air Force Turns to Ads After Drop in Recruiting

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Faced with an unusual drop-off in new recruits, the Air Force plans for the first time to join the other armed services and pay for national television advertisements to try to persuade young men and women to sign up.
Until now, the Air Force has not had to rely on paid advertisements as part of its recruiting campaigns, since it was able to attract a steady stream of recruits simply with the promise of technical training and experience in aviation. 
 But the Air Force has now been hit by the same crisis in recruiting that has hampered the other services in recent months. From October to January, the service fell 6.5 percent, or 696 enlistees, short of its goal of 10,901. If the trend is not reversed, officials said today, the Air Force could miss its annual recruiting goal for the first time since 1979.
That the Air Force would fall short of new recruits underscores the depth of the problems facing the military as a whole at a time when a booming economy has created plenty of jobs and young people are less willing to join the armed services.
Brig. Gen. Peter U. Sutton, the commander of the Air Force's recruiting division at Randolph Air Force Base in Texas, said in a telephone interview today that the service needed to increase its recognition among young people. General Sutton attributed a waning interest in service to the growing number of young people who go straight into college after high school and the dwindling number of veterans, the fathers and other role models who often inspire young people to choose a stint in the military.
"We're just less visible to young people today than we were in the past," the general said.
The Air Force plans to spend $17 million immediately to buy national advertising time, beginning on Feb. 27 and continuing through CBS's coverage of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament. It then plans to spend $37 million to begin a new network advertising campaign in the fall.
The television advertisements will sharply increase the service's overall advertising budget this year, to $76 million, from $22 million.
The Air Force has produced television advertisements that stations around the country broadcast as public-service announcements, as well as local and national print advertisements. But officials said the public-service television advertisements ran haphazardly and were not necessarily intended for young men and women.
The advertising campaign is mostly intended to increase the enlisted ranks, but a secondary effect, the officials said, was to enhance the Air Force's image. General Sutton noted that in recent years the public recognition of the Air Force's slogan -- "Aim High" -- had fallen off.
All of the services have faced difficulties with recruiting and retention. The Army's recruiting problem appears even more dire. From October to January, the Army fell 2,479 enlistees, or 13 percent, short of its recruiting goal of 19,020, despite a flurry of advertisements and bonuses.
The Navy, on the other hand, exceeded its recruiting goal during the same period after falling short last year for the first time since the draft ended. The Marine Corps also met its recruiting goals.
The Pentagon hopes that an across-the-board raise, as well as specific, or targeted, increases for mid-career officers and noncommissioned officers and improvements in pension benefits, will convince more people to join the military and reverse the flood of those getting out.
President Clinton has proposed a 4.4 percent increase, with targeted raises of up to 9.9 percent. Republicans in Congress have proposed even more, with raises of 4.8 percent across the board and 10.3 percent in the targeted ranks.
In addition to the advertisements, the Air Force intends to hire 270 more recruiters, increasing the total to about 1,200. Last fall, the service, following the Army and the Navy, began offering new enlistment bonuses of $1,000 to $9,000, depending on the specialty and length of commitment.

HEADLINE: Faded Glory on the Gold Coast;
Glen Cove, Relic of the Gilded Age, Plans a Comeback

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF

DATELINE: GLEN COVE, N.Y., Feb. 9

 BODY:
The year began here much the way last year did: with the wind whistling through downtown streets empty except for groups of shabby men walking aimlessly about with little more in their pockets than their fists.
Across from City Hall, Stan Eisenstadt, 75, and his son Bob, 47, waited for customers in their hardware store. Everything was marked down 50 percent, but still nobody came. After four decades in the business and facing a bleak future, the Eisenstadts have sold their corner lot to a developer and plan to close this month. 
 Up the hill, among the duck ponds and the naked sycamores, Paul G. Pennoyer, 78, a grandson of J. Pierpont Morgan, listened as the earth movers felled trees to make way for the new houses being built across the glade, a place where his family once held fox hunts and shooting competitions.
"It makes me sad to see what's happening in Glen Cove," Mr. Pennoyer said. "But I'm not weeping over it. I can't stop it."
Originally the exclusive province of wealthy industrialists and robber barons, Glen Cove was and still is considered the capital of the Gold Coast, a place where the rich spent their summers before anyone had heard of the Hamptons. Morgan built his estate here. So did the oil barons Charles Pratt and Stephen V. Harkness. F. W. Woolworth built his palace next to theirs.
But the butlers and the lavish parties are memories. Some estates were torn down to make way for glorified subdivisions, and those that remain are now museums, conference halls and university buildings. With the opulence gone, few tourists visit this enclave on Hempstead Harbor. Downtown is half empty, and one of the most conspicuous features on the streets are the clusters of Central American laborers waiting for work.
Glen Cove is in the midst of its post-suburban life. Its population of 25,000 has become a gumbo of the rich, the middle class, the poor and the downright poor. With impoverished immigrants knocking at its door and the small businessman walking out of it, old-timers here wonder whether the golden luster of Glen Cove can ever be reclaimed.
The Mayor and city elders are optimistic about its renewal, with some justification. They have their flip charts and waterfront-development proposals, and boast about the new government buildings downtown. But that they are talking about urban revitalization in one of America's original suburbs shows just how far the city has spilled into Nassau County.
"It's become a strange place, more like New York City than Nassau County," said Roger Wunderlich, a professor of Long Island history at the State University at Stony Brook. "It went from rural to exclusive to mainstream to a time now where the mom and pop mainstream are having trouble surviving.
"You have welfare people living near the very rich. You have housing issues and elderly people and homelessness. There is a large minority population and the city seems unwilling or unable to come to grips with its real social problems," Professor Wunderlich said.
Even the Mayor, Thomas R. Suozzi, a man who is rabid about Glen Cove's image, concedes the point. "It's true, we are a suburban town with city problems," he said.
But Mayor Suozzi has a vision for his city and eagerly heralds his accomplishments since taking office five years ago. There is the new City Hall-police station-courthouse complex. He closed down the incinerator. A software designer has set up operations in Glen Cove, and a shabby patch of land that sat barren for 20 years in the middle of downtown has recently been sold to a developer.
His most ambitious plan is a $250 million renewal of the waterfront, transforming it from a hazardous waste site into a seaport and marina to rival those in New York City, Connecticut and Rhode Island.
"This is the Gold Coast, and we want to capitalize on that," he said, dirtying his polished shoes in waterfront mud. "Imagine hundreds of people docked here, eating oysters in the restaurants, listening to music on the waterfront."
Yet the waterfront is miles away from a major highway, and little has been done on the project, his critics contend, calling it a thin sheet masking Glen Cove's more serious needs. They laugh at the Regina Maris, the 90-year-old barkentine that was thought to have helped rescue Danish Jews during World War II.
Last summer, the Mayor welcomed her to the city as a symbol of his efforts to revitalize the waterfront. But last week, officials announced that the vessel may have hauled rocks during the war, but never refugees. She now rests in the mud of Hempstead Harbor, taking on water, drawing more titters than tourists.
"We get a lot of fluff but little substance," said John Maccarone, a city councilman. "The point here is the small businessman is leaving downtown and little is being done to help him now."
The decay of the village center is a problem that plagues much of Long Island, said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. Unable to compete with the super malls and strip developments along nearby highways, small shops are packing it in. And though some bigger businesses have come to Glen Cove, the city has few answers on how to help its independent businesses. "It's a slide that started 30 years ago, and I'm not sure that we have bottomed out," Dr. Koppelman said.
To resuscitate themselves, small villages developed attractions to draw people. Port Jefferson's waterfront and harbor face lift has been successful. Bay Shore is planning an aquarium.
Yet Glen Cove already has the attractions: the waterfront, three public beaches, a yacht club, parks and, of course, the mansions; like Woolworth's Winfield, where the grand marble staircase cost $2 million to build in 1916.
Until Mr. Suozzi came along, no one thought to stitch it all together and invite the outside public. Instead the waterfront rotted away, and many mansions fell to the ground.
One was Mr. Pennoyer's boyhood home, one of several estates that Morgan built for his children. The other morning, Mr. Pennoyer sat in front of his stone hearth, offering recollections of his grandfather's mansion at the tip of the peninsula, where the surrounding waters provided an anchorage for Morgan's black yacht, Corsair. Besides marble and caviar, his grandfather imported Italians to do his labor and tend to his and his children's estates.
"My father said when Glen Cove was incorporated into a city back in the 20's, city problems would follow," Mr. Pennoyer said.
Mr. Pennoyer now lives with his wife in the former horse stable of his parents' 100-acre estate. Just 15 acres remain in the family now, and houses are going up all around them. Some men in tattered clothes sleep in their woods.
"The only immigrants there used to be here were the people who worked in the houses," he said. "They came in old jalopies. Now there are just too many of them. There is crowding in the streets, in the houses, people sleeping in the woods. I have sympathy, but we need to stem the inflow."
In the south of Glen Cove is a neighborhood known as the Orchard, once the Italian enclave, now rapidly becoming a ghetto of overcrowded houses occupied by young men from Central America. There are hundreds here now, and hundreds more come during summer to mow the lawns and rake the leaves of Glen Cove's wealthy residents.
Some of them live 16 to a house; others sleep in the elements. One man froze to death a few years ago.
The city is unwilling to build a shelter for the homeless, because, the feeling is, if you build it more will come.
"People here are concerned with real estate values, not homeless shelters," said the Rev. Patricia B. Mitchell, who retired as the pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in January. "It is true that if you build shelters, others will be attracted to them. That's why we have shelters for animals and not for people in Glen Cove. That doesn't mean there isn't a need for one."
The Mayor and the City Council say that they can appreciate the struggle of the day laborers, and that some services are provided, within reason.
"Basically, they are here illegally, and we do what we can for them," Mr. Suozzi said. "But a homeless shelter is permanent substandard housing and is not an answer."
"Besides, there are a lot of other people in this town. There are legal citizens that I have to worry about, too."
On School Street downtown, Stan Eisenstadt spent the afternoon drooping over his cash register. Next to him is a picture of the Navy frigate he served on 55 years ago. He is too depressed to say much.
His son Bob, who is overseeing the hardware store liquidation, spoke for him.
"My dad spent his whole life building this hardware store, and it hurts him to close the book."

HEADLINE: Productivity Set Fast Pace In Late 1998

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The nation's productivity, the amount that a worker produces in an hour on the job, rose in the fourth quarter at an annual rate of 3.7 percent, giving the United States three years of robust improvement in labor efficiency, and suggesting that corporate America might indeed have become slightly more efficient after years of trying unsuccessfully to improve.
The newest quarterly number, announced yesterday by the Labor Department, is the biggest increase since the first quarter of 1996, when labor productivity rose by 4.2 percent, inaugurating the three-year period of hefty gains. 
 Some economists say that computers are finally producing their promised efficiencies. But most experts say that strong demand in a prosperous economy has forced companies to squeeze more production from their workers, often by running equipment at full capacity.
Chance also plays a role. Productivity is really the dollar value of all merchandise and services produced, divided by the number of worker hours needed to produce it. The dollar value is adjusted for inflation, and since 1995 changes made by the Labor Department to render the Consumer Price Index more accurate have automatically increased the dollar value of merchandise and services, thus helping to raise the productivity rate.
Whatever the reasons for the improvement, the latest productivity numbers are still a far cry from documenting the arrival of an era reminiscent of the 1950's and 1960's, when rapid economic expansion, rising wages and low unemployment co-existed with low inflation. All those characteristics also coexist today. But temporary factors apparently explain them, and not the "structural" changes arising from computer technology.
"It is not clear whether we are experiencing a long-lasting structural improvement," said Edwin Dean, chief of productivity data at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, "or simply an increase in productivity that could disappear when the economy slows down."
Yogi Berra's baseball aphorism, in effect, applies to productivity, said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist: The game is not over until it is over. In productivity's case, the final score -- the rate of improvement -- cannot be calculated until a business cycle ends. So far productivity has improved at an average annual rate of 1.4 percent since July 1990, the start of the current business cycle. This compares with an annual increase of 1.1 percent for the entire 1980's cycle.
This not-yet-final improvement of three-tenths of a percentage point from one decade to the next is not to be scoffed at. "It would produce a significant improvement in American lives if it endures for quite a few more years," said Jeffrey Madrick, a journalist and economist who is writing a book on productivity, "but even then it would not be a return to any kind of golden age."
The productivity number, issued quarterly and covering all business except agriculture, is arguably the nation's most important economic statistic. Only when productivity rises, can incomes and living standards rise for most Americans.
The reason is that productivity measures a worker's success at generating income. A long-distance telephone operator, for example, finds that she can handle 100 calls an hour, up from 97 calls, because the phone company has given her better equipment or extra training. Her productivity has risen by 3 percent. The extra revenue that she now generates in each hour of work can be used by the company to fatten profits or raise wages, or both. Most important, this improvement can take place without increasing telephone rates. A raise in pay, in effect, is not dissipated in higher prices.
Such improvements were commonplace from 1959 to 1973, a golden era. Productivity for all nonfarm business rose at a 2.9 percent annual rate, but then slumped to 1.1 percent from 1973 until 1990. The reasons have never been fully understood.
With yesterday's fourth-quarter announcement -- and a downward adjustment in the third-quarter number to 2.5 percent from 3 percent -- labor productivity for all of 1998 rose 2.2 percent. Manufacturing led, with a fourth-quarter increase of 5.6 percent and for the year as a whole, a 4.3 percent rise.
For the three years starting in 1996, productivity rose at an average annual rate of 1.9 percent. But while the last three years were strong, the 1980's produced an even stronger three-year burst: productivity rose at a 2.3 percent annual rate from 1983 through 1985.
What characterizes the two periods is robust economic growth -- a rapid rise in the output of merchandise and services -- and a scramble by employers to meet the demand without adding labor. Even so, new jobs have been created at a record pace.
"The believer in the productivity miracle," said Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, "has to explain why it has taken so much additional labor to produce the additional output."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
A Little Economic Advice For the Federal Reserve

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is looking for a few good ideas on what to do about short-term interest rates.
In a contest organized by nine Federal Reserve banks, high school teams will compete at regional finals beginning in March; nine winners will present their policy prescriptions in Washington on May 3 and 4 to members of the Federal Open Market Committee, which adjusts interest rates as the need arises.
The students are asked to "in effect forecast where they think the economy is going over the next several months," said Steven Malin, assistant vice president for public information at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
 Citibank is contributing $650,000 in cash and scholarships. The information number for the contest is (877) 333-2454.
No, Alan Greenspan will not be a judge.

HEADLINE: G.O.P.'s Moderates Test Power in House With New Tax Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Casting doubt on the viability of one of their party's main goals this year, a group of moderate House Republicans plans to reject calls for a sweeping income tax reduction and instead is building support for a more modest package of tax cuts, Congressional aides said today.
The group of 11, led by Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, will introduce a plan on Wednesday to scale back the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples; raise the amount of income retirees can earn without losing Social Security benefits and enact other changes expected to cut taxes by $100 billion over five years. 
 The plan is intended as an alternative to one being developed by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the House Budget Committee chairman, that would cut income tax rates over all by 10 percent. Democrats are attacking that proposal as a giveaway to the rich. If fully enacted at once, the cut would reduce revenues by about $375 billion over five years.
The moderate plan, seen as benefiting the middle class, is the first effort by Republican moderates to flex their muscle in the House this year. The party's majority after last November's elections has shrunk to such a narrow margin that passing legislation seems likely to prove a constant challenge. Republicans hold 222 seats and the Democrats 211. One independent Congressman votes regularly with the Democrats and there is one empty seat.
The parliamentary math means that the defection of as few as five Republicans can block the passage of legislation.
Republican leaders in both the House and Senate have been trying to rally the party around an income tax reduction as the centerpiece of their post-impeachment agenda.
Saying a big tax cut would be both good politics and good policy as their party struggles to define what it stands for other than condemning President Clinton, Republican leaders have been spoiling for a partisan fight over the issue.
Republicans say they want to return a big portion of Federal budget surpluses to taxpayers in coming years to energize the economy and check the growth of the Government.
But Mr. Clinton has argued that a big tax cut would imperil efforts to strengthen Social Security and Medicare and deal with mounting pressure for more spending on military and domestic programs.
But as the emerging proposals on taxes by moderates makes clear, Republicans also have to worry about holding together their fractious ranks. Efforts to pass a tax bill last year foundered on disputes between House and Senate Republicans.
At a retreat in Williamsburg, Va., last weekend, many House Republicans expressed reservations about pressing ahead with the across-the-board income tax cut.
From the right, social conservatives have been suggesting that Republicans should concentrate this year on substantially reducing or eliminating the marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code under which many two-income couples pay more in taxes than they would if single.
Repealing the marriage tax, said Janet Parshall of the Family Research Council, which is influential with many conservatives in the House, "should be the backbone of any tax bill passed in this Congress."
Republican moderates said Mr. Clinton's success in portraying tax cuts as the enemy of efforts to insure Social Security's future makes it politically suicidal to press ahead with a sweeping plan to cut income tax rates.
Many of the moderates are from districts where they are vulnerable to challenges from Democrats, and they are eager to avoid the label of a do-nothing partisan Congress unable to address the concerns of the voters. So they are pushing for legislation that has a reasonable chance of being enacted into law.
The maneuvering within the party is likely to intensify in coming weeks as Mr. Kasich, a likely Presidential candidate, decides how to lay out a budget framework for next year. The same process is under way in the Senate, where Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, is working on a plan to cut income tax rates by as much as 15 percent, but to phase in the reductions slowly over the next decade.
"You'll see over the next five weeks a variety of opinions expressed over what size tax cuts we should have, but all Republicans agree we should have tax cuts," said a senior House Republican aide. "The test for Republicans is to bridge those differences and emerge with a common decision we can unite around. To do it with a landslide five-vote majority will not be easy."
House Republicans who have agreed to co-sponsor Ms. Johnson's tax plan include Representatives Charles Bass of New Hampshire, Sherwood L. Boehlert of New York, Vernon J. Ehlers of Michigan, Wayne T. Gilchrest of Maryland, James C. Greenwood of Pennsylvania, Steve Horn of California, Rick A. Lazio of New York, Jim Leach of Iowa, Frank A. LoBiondo of New Jersey and Fred Upton of Michigan.
The plan is close to the tax-cut bill passed last year by the House. It calls for addressing the marriage penalty by increasing the standard deduction for spouses filing jointly to twice the deduction for individuals, or $8,500; currently, the deduction for joint filers is $7,100. The effect would be to reduce taxable income by $1,400 for couples filing jointly and, claiming the standard deduction, a change that would save $392 for a couple paying a 28 percent marginal income tax rate.
The proposal would also accelerate a planned increase in the income limit, above which Social Security recipients begin losing benefits. The limit is scheduled to increase to $30,000 in 2002, from $15,500. Under Ms. Johnson's plan the increase would take effect next year.
The plan would also speed up an expected increase in the portion of health insurance premiums that self-employed people could deduct from their taxes. It would contain tax breaks for long-term health care costs, exclude tax credits for families with children and for college expenses from the effects of the alternative minimum tax, and extend a number of expiring tax credits.

HEADLINE: Patients Lament Imminent Loss of Their Friendly Family Doctors

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., Feb. 9

 BODY:
The parking lot was full at the H.I.P. health clinic here on Route 1, with people arriving to tend to their flus, their children's inoculations or their prescription renewals. But almost all the people bustling in and out had heard that the state had decided that the clinic would shut its doors next month, and most of them were upset.
"I've been a patient here since '77," said Gloria Reaves-Allen, as she paused at the front door before picking up a friend. "Now what am I going to do?" 
 That was the question some 150,000 people will be asking when H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey becomes the largest health maintenance organization in the state to be liquidated. The state has submitted an order to a judge asking that other health insurers absorb H.I.P.'s members despite any pre-existing health conditions.
But that was small consolation to many H.I.P. members who worried about the loss of the continuity they had built up with doctors.
"This is extremely upsetting," said Anne Cohen of East Brunswick, who had brought her 15-year-old son to see a doctor about his sinus problems. "I really dearly loved my pediatrician. He's been with us more than 20 years. He really kind of raised my children."
In an era when many people like to disparage health maintenance organizations for what they say are extreme cost-cutting measures and cookie-cutter services, many of the patients entering and leaving the Edison H.I.P. clinic and another one farther down Route 1 in New Brunswick, spoke of the loyalty they felt toward their doctors and the other medical professionals who have served them for years.
Many H.I.P. members at the two clinics said they were not too surprised that it had come to this. They had read newspaper articles for several years about the health provider's financial problems.
And some members said that many of their favorite doctors had left H.I.P. in the last few months as the fiscal problems grew worse, and had either joined other groups or had formed private practices.
Mrs. Cohen, who works as a third-grade teacher, said that everyone at her school had been talking about what H.M.O. or other insurer they should switch to.
"We talk about it all the time," she said. "People ask each other, 'What have you researched? What do you know about this one?' "
Kerrim Jivani, who has a Baskin-Robbins and Dunkin' Donuts franchise with two partners, said the three of them pay $1,500 a month to H.I.P. for family health coverage. He said that they had chosen the company in 1995 partly because of its fees, and that he was concerned about whether they could find the same quality of care for the same price.
"We'll have to change now," he said as he waited for his wife, who was in the Edison clinic with their 4-month-old daughter. "To which company, I don't know."
Gia Riddick and her daughter, Monique, 9, were leaving the clinic in New Brunswick, where a doctor had examined Monique and diagnosed strep throat.
Mrs. Riddick said that when her employer, Merrill Lynch, held a health-plan open enrollment period for employees last fall, her family had decided to stick with H.I.P. because it had served them so well for almost 20 years.
"I kind of thought they were going to pull through, since the state had gotten involved," she said.
Inside the Edison clinic, calls were being received from members asking what would happen. The attendants at the front desk told them that no one knew all the details yet of what the liquidation would mean.
"We tell them we know as much as they do, which is just what we've read in the newspapers," said Annette Watson, the clinical services manager. "But we're also telling everyone that until they close us down, we'll continue to provide excellent care to our patients."
Ms. Watson was asked what the liquidation would mean to the 35 employees at the Edison clinic. "It means we'll be unemployed," she said somberly.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
AMERICAN AIRLINES FORCED TO CANCEL THIRD OF FLIGHTS

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
The nation's second-largest airline was forced to cancel one-third of its flights yesterday after more than 2,000 of its pilots called in sick. The move inconvenienced tens of thousands of passengers around the country and threatened to disrupt the heavy air travel expected over the Presidents' Day weekend.
American Airlines said that it grounded 750, or 33 percent, of its 2,250 daily flights yesterday, affecting about 75,000 passengers, many of whom waited hours before getting on other flights, or were stranded for the night. American carries about 225,000 people on a normal day. 
 Members of the Allied Pilots Association, the independent union that represents American's 9,200 pilots, began calling in sick on Saturday, after talks broke down over how American would integrate a small airline it acquired in December, Reno Air, into its network. American was forced to cancel 90 flights Saturday. That increased to 500 on Monday before rising higher yesterday.
"My wife isn't very happy about this," said John Rubino, 36, a systems analyst from Dallas who was sipping a beer in a bar at O'Hare International Airport near Chicago yesterday afternoon awaiting a flight. He had expected to return home in the morning after doing business in Chicago. "Our girl is in a school play tonight and I'm not very happy about the chance of missing that. My boss understands about these things. It's harder for a 9-year-old girl."
American and the union resumed negotiations yesterday, but they did not end the disruption. After several hours of talks, the two sides adjourned and agreed to meet again today. In a statement, American called the meeting "helpful."
The union, in a statement, said that "no progress was achieved on our core issues" during the talks.
"The positive note is that both parties are talking again," said Chris Chiames, a spokesman for American. He added that at least several hundred more flights would be canceled today, but exactly how many he could not say.
Strikes are relatively rare at airlines because the 1934 Railway Labor Act, which governs labor relations in the industry, severely restricts when unions are allowed to walk out. Slowdowns and sickouts have occurred at American and other carriers before. For example, during Christmas, flight attendants at Trans World Airlines forced the cancellation of some flights after many called in sick. But no airline in recent memory has been crippled as severely as American has been.
Brian D. Harris, an industry analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in New York, estimated that the disruption had cost American $19 million so far and the figure was rising quickly.
Donald J. Carty, chief executive of the AMR Corporation, American's parent company, said on Monday that the pilots' actions were clearly illegal and that the company would seek a court order forcing them back to work if the talks failed.
But it was not clear whether a court order would have much impact. The leaders of the pilots' union say that the actions of the pilots are spontaneous. While they have avoided explicitly endorsing the job action, they have reminded their members that Federal regulations allow pilots to take themselves out of the cockpit if they do not feel fit to fly.
"American can prove actuarially that the pilots are staging a sickout," Mr. Harris said. "But it is a lot harder to prove that any particular pilot is."
American said that it did not know precisely how many passengers or which areas of the country were most severely affected by the cancellations. February is normally a light travel month. The airline said that it had been able to re-book many affected passengers on its other flights. It also said that it was transferring passengers to competing airlines. The airline was recommending that passengers check on the status of their flight by calling the company's toll-free reservation number and arrive early at the airport.
At airports in Chicago, Dallas, Miami and New York, where American has its biggest operations, passengers appeared to be suffering irritating delays but were not stranded in large numbers.
Chris Hannis, who flew on American to Dallas from Chicago on Sunday to attend a two-day seminar, switched to United for his flight home yesterday. But instead of landing at Midway Airport, from where he departed, he was flying to O'Hare. "They'll charge me another $20 for the extra day of parking," he said. "I think I'll send it to American and see if they'll pay."
Donet Desilus, who runs a tour company in Boston, got as far as Miami International Airport on his way to Haiti when his flight was canceled. "I found this out 15 minutes before the flight was supposed to leave," he said. "They didn't tell us why. They just sent us to a hotel."
 Corporate travel managers, who book airline tickets and make other travel arrangements for corporate clients, said that they were able to handle the disruption by protectively booking their clients on American and another airline.
"It's having a limited impact on our customers," said Don Munro, a spokesman for American Express, whose travel agencies had $19.9 billion in sales last year.
Harder hit were agencies that receive discounts from American in exchange for steering business to the airline. "It's been terribly disruptive," said Paul Metselaar, chairman of World Travel Specialists Group Inc. in New York. "Clients are getting to the airport and learning that their flight has been canceled."
Mr. Metselaar said that the double booking by agencies was causing a shortage of seats on some airlines.
The dispute between American and the pilots was touched off in December, after American bought Reno Air, which is based in Nevada, for $124 million. American said that it would take between a year to 18 months to integrate Reno's 25 airplanes and 300 pilots into its operations because pilots at both carriers needed to be retrained and Reno's jets needed to be refurbished.
But the union says that American is violating their contract, which requires all flying at the airline to be done by its members. They demand that American integrate Reno faster and begin paying pilots at both carriers as if the merger has been completed.
Behind the dispute are years of mistrust and resentment on the part of the pilots, who went on strike two years ago but were ordered back to work after only 20 minutes by President Clinton. Many pilots are still angry that they were denied their right to walk out.
The union says it believes that American's real agenda is to keep Reno as a separate low-cost carrier. Senior pilots at Reno make about $65,000 a year, less than half of what their counterparts earn at American.
American has said repeatedly that it intends to integrate the two airlines and bring Reno pilots up to the salary levels of pilots at American. "There is no reason for this dispute to continue," the airline said.
Most analysts and industry observers agree. With the holiday weekend approaching, they predict that the two sides will reach an accord. "My guess is that it will be resolved in the next couple of days because the financial harm is disproportionate to the issues at hand," Mr. Harris of Salomon Smith Barney said. "But that assumes that rationality prevails."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MANULIFE TO BUY DAIHYAKU INSURANCE BUSINESS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Manufacturers Life Insurance Company of Canada said it would pay 80 billion yen, or $703.8 million (United States), for the business of the Daihyaku Life Insurance Company of Japan, becoming the second foreign insurer to buy into the world's largest life insurance market. Daihyaku will transfer most of its sales and support staff of 6,800 to a joint venture with Manulife, Canada's largest mutual life insurer. Manulife will own 75 percent of the venture, and Daihyaku will own the rest. Deregulation and Japan's weakening economy are providing opportunities for foreign companies to enter the Japanese insurance market, which, with annual premiums of $500 billion, is about twice the size of its counterpart in the United States. GE Capital Services, a unit of the General Electric Company, is already active there.

HEADLINE: Crew and Jackson Assail Pataki For Proposed Education Budget

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Critics of Gov. George E. Pataki's education budget sharpened their attacks today, with the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson accusing Mr. Pataki of favoring prisons over schools, while Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said there was no point in even meeting with the Governor to try to change his mind.
Making an unusually direct foray into state policy, Mr. Jackson told a joint hearing here of the Assembly and Senate finance committees that the Republican Governor was "using our children as political trade-offs," by under-financing schools while building prisons in depressed upstate communities to mollify voters there who need jobs. "These poor schools serve as feeder systems for the prison-industrial complex," he said to reporters after the hearing. 
 Mr. Jackson, who is traveling to several state capitals to lobby for more money for education, compared Mr. Pataki to Orval Faubus of Arkansas and George C. Wallace of Alabama, two Governors who tried to block racial integration of their states' schools, and to Pete Wilson, the former California Governor who tried to build a Presidential campaign on his opposition to affirmative action and immigration.
"We see Pataki in that tradition," he said. "Whether you're blocking school doors in Alabama and Arkansas or simply locking kids out of closed school doors in New York, it's not the wave of the American future."
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, said: "Jesse Jackson's partisan attack is absurd. It doesn't warrant comment. Coming from someone in public life, it's surprisingly undignified."
This year, the Democrats who control the Assembly have turned the annual hearings on the Governor's budget proposal into a platform for lambasting Mr. Pataki, particularly on education, inviting prominent critics like Mr. Jackson and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to testify.
Despite a $2 billion surplus, the Governor's $72.66 billion proposed budget would increase aid to local school districts by only 1.3 percent. It would also eliminate a package of education programs for very young children, including pre-kindergarten and expanded kindergarten offerings, freeze aid to public colleges, and sharply reduce tuition aid to poor college students.
Aides to the Governor point out that in the last two years, under Mr. Pataki, New York has sharply increased spending on schools, and the total, adjusted for inflation and the number of students, has matched the previous highs reached in the late 1980's.
Today, Dr. Crew, who addressed the committees after Mr. Jackson, called the Governor's proposal "a very mean-spirited budget on behalf of children."
When asked why he was not meeting with the Governor during his trip to the Capitol, he said, "At this point in time, there is not enough of a relationship to meet with the Governor."
The Governor and his aides have reacted angrily to accusations that he had cut New York City's share of education aid, or had reneged on a promise to finance early-childhood school programs. They have repeatedly reminded reporters of the increases in education spending the last two years, and noted that while the city's schools still receive less state aid per pupil than the statewide average, that gap has narrowed slightly in recent years.
Democrats who are furious at the Governor's proposed education cuts, and still angry over his veto last year of $500 million for school construction, warmly received Mr. Jackson. But some Republican legislators dismissed him as an outsider whose grasp of the local facts was weak. "He should stay out of things when he has no idea what he's talking about," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, the Republican minority leader.
The Governor's budget proposal came a few days after he appointed a commission to investigate New York City's School Construction Authority, a move that was widely taken as a slap at Mr. Giuliani, his fellow Republican. Their highly public spats over the budget and the investigation have renewed a long-running feud between the two men that was never very deeply buried.
Mr. Jackson waded into the debate over the construction authority, too, calling the Governor's inquiry "more diversion."
In addition to commenting on Mr. Pataki's policies, Mr. Jackson derided the Governor's possible aspirations to higher office. "Big platform," he said, referring to the New York stage, but "small agenda."
Referring to the screaming blocks of type on the front pages of tabloid newspapers, he said, "Sometimes I think the size of New York headlines gives New York politicians the impression that is their size."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Studies on Class Size Offer Mixed Results

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK

 BODY:
If every pupil had a personal tutor, students would undoubtedly learn more than they would in 100-student classes. But studies differ sharply on just how well smaller classes work.
In a new study by the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, class size was reduced to 15 students, kindergarten through third grade, in more than 70 public schools in low-income areas. In data released last month for the 1997-98 year, researchers reported that first-graders scored significantly higher than students in a control group. The study also found evidence of continuing advantages in math, reading and language arts in the second grade. The biggest gains were among black pupils. 
 The Wisconsin report follows President Clinton's 1998 and 1999 budget messages calling for $12 billion over seven years to hire 100,000 teachers and reduce classes to 18 pupils in lower grades.
But the United States Department of Education, in its report last month on teacher quality, found the data on effects of class size to be "somewhat mixed." It is reasonable, the report added, to assume that smaller classes mean fewer disruptions and more personal attention. But a 30-year department study completed in the 80's found no consistent tie between smaller class sizes and higher standardized test scores.
Eric Hanushek, an economics professor at the University of Rochester, concluded in a study last year that the quality of the teacher was more important than class size.
 MICHAEL POLLAK

An unemployed Middlesex County man was charged yesterday with harassing Asian Indians and blacks by purposely walking or "crashing" into them at two malls in Woodbridge and then yelling racial epithets.

 No serious injuries resulted, said Chuck Davis, a spokesman for the State Attorney General's office.
Mr. Rich, 18, of Woodbridge was arrested Monday night in Milford, Pa., and extradited to New Jersey. He was being held yesterday in the Middlesex County Jail on $100,000 bail.

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 3; Circuits

LENGTH: 1608 words

HEADLINE: Buying Is Only a Click (Oops!) Away

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY

 BODY:
SPENDING thousands of dollars used to take some effort. You had to get dressed. Get out of the house. Make eye contact. Count change. It could take days. Weeks, even.
But getting and spending are easier on line, and the membrane between impulse and purchase has grown thinner. Web sites draw surfers toward the shoals of indebtedness, offering novelty, speed, convenience, bargains, unlimited hours, coupons, new deals daily, limited sales tax and helpful suggestions from other shoppers. Simply click on Buy Now, and pay later. 
 As the credit card bills of history's biggest, most touted holiday E-commerce season are coming due and accruing double-digit interest, Internet surfers are shopping before breakfast, shopping alone and picking up an extra book or three -- causing some of them to wind up hiding the resulting credit card bills from their spouses. How did these people get hooked? What is so compelling about the Internet marketplace?
Although on-line shopping still amounts to only a tiny fraction of all retail sales -- 1 percent of consumer sales, according to Joseph Vause, vice president for electronic commerce at Visa USA -- it is expected to match the current catalogue and mail-order share of the market by 2003. And with 99 percent of Internet sales conducted with plastic, compared with 20 percent of conventional sales, the potential to run up a credit card bill is significantly higher.
The temptation to spend money on line can be even harder to resist when a Web surfer taps into the excitement of an auction.
"Ebay is definitely addictive!" Jane Brasovan of The Woodlands, Tex., said via E-mail. She estimated that she had bought 1,500 to 2,000 items, most of them antiques and dolls, on the Ebay auction site.
"I am trying to stop this addictive cycle at the present time," she continued, "as I've spent far too much money and now have a houseful of 'things' that I would probably be better off without!"
In a phone interview, she added: "It's hard to stop. I've tried stopping, but I don't do too well. You get kind of carried away, bidding on something, and when somebody outbids you, you get mad because they outbid you. You go in and bid and know darned well you shouldn't. Sometimes you feel like saying, 'You're not going to get that if I can't get it.' " Ms. Brasovan said she had spent up to six or seven hours at a stretch on the Ebay site.
Allison Ector, editor and publisher of Covert Shoppers Anonymous, an on-line compendium of Web bargains, figures that she spends $800 a month on line, far more than she used to spend when driving to stores near her home in West Chester, Pa.
"It's just clicking buttons," she said, "and it's easy to say, 'Well, I'll worry about this next month when I get the bill.' " She has found herself playing an economies-of-scale game with shipping and handling charges. "When I get to the end of that shopping cart transaction, I've often hit the Back button, gone back and purchased more things, to make it cost effective," she said.
It may be hard to find on-line shopaholics who have become so hooked on new-media marketing that they have resorted to pilfering from their children's college funds or have moved back to their parents'. But there are many people, particularly at the auction sites, who find themselves powerless in the face of items for sale on line.
Debbie Lunden, who collects McCoy kitchenware from the 1940's and 1950's, signs on to Ebay once a day to see what is being auctioned.
"For years I had been looking for a teapot," said Ms. Lunden, director of the McKean County Planning Commission in Pennsylvania. "I knew there had to be one." In October, she found one, and the closing bids were due at 5 A.M.
"I set the alarm and was up at 4:45 in the morning, thinking, 'That gives me 15 minutes to get connected,' " she said. She panicked when she discovered that her husband had packed away the laptop, but she got on line in time to buy the teapot, plus a creamer and sugar bowl, for $97, including shipping -- "a real buy," she said. Ms. Lunden lives in Bradford, Pa., population about 9,600, where the shopping possibilities are limited.
"It was something I really had to have," she said of the teapot. "I'm not a person to get up in the middle of the night, but I had to because that's when the bidding was. I had to make a sacrifice, and it was worth it."
"I'm totally addicted to just surfing thousands of items on Ebay," Gib Bergman, a cook in Sutersville, Pa., wrote via E-mail. Mr. Bergman, a shopper who has bid on scores of items, including knives, Beanie Babies and Elvis memorabilia, at Ebay, continued: "And it is so easy to spend money that you don't have just laying around. It's worse than being an alcoholic -- an obsessive gambler is more like it."
"I'm pretty much an addict," Mr. Bergman added. His wife, Helen, used to be able to restrain him from buying, he said, but no more. "I used to go to flea markets," he said. "You'd see stuff and she'd say, 'That's too much,' but here I'm here by myself. I'll put a bid in on something and later say to her, 'Guess what I got?' It's just like a candy store -- it is very addictive." In 10 years of conventional shopping he could never have acquired the number of Elvis items he has been able to buy via Ebay, he said.
Experts on credit and commerce readily recognize the seductions of E-commerce. Kimberly S. Young, founder of the Center for On-Line Addiction in Bradford, Pa., said the auction sites were exciting -- shopping as entertainment.
"When you're the winner, that's reinforcing," she said. "For that moment, you're engaged, it gives you a favorable high. You're completely absorbed in this, and it's kind of an escape mechanism. You start to think, 'What else do I need?' "
Sometimes clicking fingers take over where the brain leaves off, said Wayne S. DeSarbo, a marketing professor at Pennsylvania State University. "There's so little time to think about what you're doing and rationalize it," he said. "As the result of just a few keystrokes, you're done and gone. For the compulsive shopper, this would provide a quick and easy fix from the stress and anxiety of everyday life. It's a temporary high one gets from shopping. There's little time for rationalization."
Bill Furmanski, a spokesman for the National Foundation for Consumer Credit, said it could be easier to buy impulsively on line than off. "In the mall, it's easier to recommend that you put an item down and walk away, and see if you still need it at the end of your trip, to ease the impulse purchases you make," he said. "On the Internet, it's not as easy. Maybe you should sign off first, and it will still be there when you sign back on."
Splurges on line appear to differ from splurges off line. People watching the Home Shopping Network might end up with many lifetime supplies of cubic zirconia and Ginzu knives. But wired shoppers talk sheepishly of their "Amazon problems": a tendency to spend more at Amazon.com than they had budgeted for books, software and CD's, items that are, if you rationalize carefully, inherently useful for self-improvement.
Many aspects of the Internet encourage impulsive or compulsive buying.
"You're alone, and kind of nobody sees what you're doing," said the founder of Spenders Anonymous, a support group in Minneapolis, speaking on the condition of anonymity, "and when you're into your addiction, you want it that way." For shy people, an Internet auction provides welcome anonymity.
"For a lot of people that are shy -- not the competitive people who go to auction houses and compete with real people -- it's a much safer domain," said Dr. Young, who is an assistant professor of psychology at the University of Pittsburgh at Bradford. "It's anonymous, it's private, and there is a sense of winning."
The Internet can also empower shoppers, said Austan Goolsbee, an assistant professor of economics at the University of Chicago, giving them the benefits of haggling and comparison shopping without making them take the chance of offending anyone face to face.
"You would feel kind of self-conscious asking someone at an airline to run through 100 scenarios for a flight you want to take," he said, so travelers can fiddle with schedules or destination cities more easily on line. "And where you're comparison shopping, it oftentimes makes people feel a little bad for walking out of the store." But no Web site is going to call a person rude for heading elsewhere for a better bargain.
Offering power to the consumer can be the Internet's most effective way to lure buyers.
"Consumers are now in control, and it is so compelling" said Donna Hoffman, a professor of marketing at Vanderbilt University. "It's not the lack of sales tax, not the convenience, not the potential economic savings, that makes on-line shopping attractive. It's just the chance to be in control. The balance of power between business and the consumer has shifted radically. If you're the business, you're no longer in 100 percent control."
Electronic shoppers want convenience, and they want it now. Where they can get it, they're willing to pay for it, plus shipping and handling.
"The modern analogy is the minibar in your hotel room," said Jerry Kaplan, a co-founder of Onsale.com, a discount retailer. "Would you usually pay $2 for a Diet Coke? Absolutely not. But in the minibar in the hotel room, you're more likely to go for it. Here you have people sitting at a computer all day, and a lot of sales take place. They're discretionary purchases due to convenience, where you've eliminated the cost of physically going out and shopping."

HEADLINE: SCREEN GRAB;
A Site for Venting

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
FED up with hearing about the glories of the Internet? Fed up with watching your sister-in-law get rich investing in tiny Internet companies you just know will tank any day? Fed up with Pollyannas singing the economy's praises even as your boss kicks you in the shin?
Or, perhaps, simply fed up? 
 Well, never fear -- there are Web sites for you, too.
What's your pleasure (or pain)? Are you disgusted, in despair or merely disgruntled?
Disgruntled, you say? Then go to Disgruntled and get it out of your system (www.disgruntled.com). There you'll find "an on-line magazine that combines news, feature, satire and commentary about the darker side of the world of work."
The site's creator, Daniel S. Levine, writes, "I invite all takers to use these pages to vent and tell their tales of horror, disgust, frustration, liberation and revenge."
At last! Spill out, sweet rage! You start typing your particular horror story -- you're really on a roll -- and sure enough, there comes your boss, looking for a reason to kick your other shin. Uh-oh.
But never fear. Disgruntled has imagined this exact scene.
"If you are reading Disgruntled at work and your boss is heading your way, just hit the Boss button" -- a green frowny face, complete with cigar. Click on it, and up pops a screen headed: "Our mission is to increase shareholder value," followed by a list of revenue figures. (Hmmm. If you're a writer or artist on deadline, that might not cut it.)
Now click on Readers' Tales, where the categories include Around the Water Cooler, Family Business, Fed Up, Getting Even, Getting Gruntled, Inhuman Relations, Temporary Insanity and Work Is Hazardous to Your Health.
Getting even. That sounds juicy.
Did some workplace nightmare drive Mr. Levine to create this site? Not really. "Listening to some of the horror stories," he said in a telephone interview, "I've come to realize I've been fairly fortunate in my work experience." Then again, when asked about his worst job, he said, "I guess in some ways they all were."
Mr. Levine, 37, a freelance business writer based near Berkeley, Calif., started the site three years ago, he said, because "when I pitched a story from the perspective of employees, editors weren't interested." But in his reporting, he said, he found "people on all rungs of the ladder increasingly expressing frustration."
The site, basically a one-person operation, carries some advertising, from Amazon.com and others, but it is no moneymaker. "The revenues," Mr. Levine said, "have gone from negligible to insignificant." So where can Mr. Levine -- whose book "Disgruntled: The Darker Side of the World of Work" (Putnam) was published last fall -- vent his own disgruntlement? "At myself," he said with a laugh, "for not paying myself enough."
If you still don't feel better after exploring his site, click on this link: Feeling De-Motivated? Click Here to Show It. And you soon find yourself at Despair Inc., which says it employs or works with "a wide variety of writers, designers, programmers and fulfillment personnel, all of whom remain hopelessly dissatisfied with their jobs, their relationships and their lives."
"This chronic state of frustration guarantees that the fruits of their labor won't be diluted with hope, sentiment or good cheer," it adds.
Here you can order Despair Wear -- T-shirts, say, with messages like "I found the cure for hope" or "Another dissatisfied customer." And there's a Despair calendar, with Jan. 12 listed as the Procrastinators' New Year's.
But what if you want to up the ante, to progress from disgruntled to despair and downright disgusted?
Too late. These folks must have taken their name to heart and packed it in. "For Sale: www.disgusted.com," the screen says. "This domain may be available for your project!"
