HEADLINE: PUBLIC EYE;
Little Logos, Big Load

BYLINE: By Karrie Jacobs

 BODY:
THE logo is nothing spectacular. If it were for a private business, an ethnic restaurant, say, I wouldn't give it a second glance. It's just three lowercase letters topped by what looks like a giant circumflex. But this understated, economical symbol represents the United States Government -- the Housing and Urban Development Department, to be precise. The big accent mark is actually a roof.
Usually, branches of the Government represent themselves with something that looks official, which these days means a minimalist rendition of an eagle. HUD is no exception. The logo that still appears on its fax cover sheets is a big bird with its wings abstracted and cropped to resemble a city skyline. But last year, the department adopted a mark that is jeans-and-T-shirt casual. 
 Lisa MacSpadden, the deputy assistant secretary for public affairs, explained that the new symbol was a pet project of Andrew M. Cuomo, the HUD Secretary. She volunteered Mr. Cuomo, a Cabinet member with a $25 billion bureaucracy to run, for an interview about the logo.
But the Secretary didn't exactly want to discuss the logo. "We said first we'd change the reality of the department, then the reality would change the perception," he began. Once he had begun, there was no stopping him. "The reality is about a downsizing, its new system design, its new management structure, its new employees, its new training. Part of changing the reality is changing the culture and the stance, the positioning of the department. . . ."
Mr. Cuomo, like his father, Mario M. Cuomo, does not believe in brevity. But his message, in short, is that HUD's image, which never quite recuperated from the department's losses during the real-estate collapse of the 80's, is being made anew.
The logo, which was designed by the BBDO South advertising agency in Atlanta and first appeared in television spots featuring the consummate nice guys Bob Vila and Tim Allen, is only one facet of the department's new anti-bureaucratic style.
The architecture firm of Gensler was hired to invent "HUD Next Door," a program for transforming departmental offices into storefronts where members of the public can drift in, lounge in comfy chairs, fiddle with computers and learn what HUD can do for them. All that's missing is a coffee bar.
Gensler also designed a logo: a silhouette of a house with a pitched roof next to a squarish apartment building, with "HUD" inset into the base and the phrase "next door" extending into space. Gensler's icon appears on HUD's stores, its new information kiosks and its Web site.
A cheerful-looking departmental booklet issued in December, "100 Questions and Answers About Buying a New Home," displays the BBDO logo on the front and a version of the Gensler logo on the back.
John Bricker, a Gensler vice president, who helped conjure up the "next door" concept, said he didn't understand why the department needed or wanted an additional logo. "I'm surprised by the disconnect," he added.
When asked about the dual logos, David Stanton, BBDO South's group creative director, was tactful. "We would like to have more synergy," he said, and suggested that HUD could "connect the dots tighter."
I'm not surprised that this megalithic Federal agency, so chronically entangled in its own bureaucracy that in January it made the General Accounting Office's list of "high risk" agencies for the fifth year running, commissioned two graphic symbols of its new, approachable nature. Of course, it's not as if either design were going to waste. HUD Next Door stores are opening in city after city. Washington was the first, followed by Albuquerque, N.M., and Buffalo. Stores are due soon in Reno and Baltimore. And the little roof logo will soon appear in a string of kooky television spots by BBDO.
The point of all this creative ferment, Secretary Cuomo explained, is to persuade the home-buying public that HUD is "on our side."
"One of the things we're battling is disenfranchisement from government, negative feelings about government," he said. "Especially the Federal Government."
I have to admit that this is a monumental task for one little logo. I can see that HUD might need two.

HEADLINE: Iraqi Official Gets Approval For Key Visit To Turkey

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The Government of Saddam Hussein scored at least a symbolic diplomatic coup today when it was announced that the Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz, would visit Turkey next week.
A statement from the Foreign Ministry here said that Mr. Aziz would arrive in Ankara on Monday for "high-level discussions regarding Iraq and the Turkey-Iraq relationship." 
 The announcement came at a time when Iraq appeared to be increasingly isolated. In recent weeks, Iraqi leaders have bitterly accused many countries in the Middle East of abandoning the Iraqi cause.
At the same time, the United States has stepped up its efforts to overthrow the Iraqi Government. American planes were bombing Iraq at almost the same moment that Mr. Aziz's visit to Ankara was being announced.
The United States Embassy in Ankara, where diplomats are anxious to prevent Iraq from driving a wedge between the United States and Turkey, issued a restrained statement in response. It said only that Turkey "has its own foreign policy" and that Turkish leaders should "stress to Mr. Aziz the need for Iraq to comply with U.N. Security Council resolutions."
An American official speaking on condition of anonymity, however, was more explicit. "We don't like it," the diplomat said of Mr. Aziz's planned visit. "Why would they give him sanction and access when we're trying to isolate him? It runs counter to what we want to do."
Although Turkey and the United States are NATO allies and close political partners, differences between their policies toward Iraq have broken into the open since Bulent Ecevit became Prime Minister last month.
Mr. Ecevit, a lifelong leftist and self-proclaimed anti-imperialist, has for years expressed sympathy with Iraq and Mr. Hussein. This month, as American war planes flying from the Incirlik base in southern Turkey have repeatedly bombed Iraqi targets, Mr. Ecevit has begun to question their mission.
"The Iraqis are zealous supporters of their independence," Mr. Ecevit said during a televised interview last week. "It is unclear how the American Government will reach its goals to overthrow Saddam Hussein. It doesn't seem to have formed a policy on Iraq. It needs to plan carefully what to do about that issue, and Turkey should contribute to those plans."
Foreign Minister Ismail Cem said that Turkey remains willing to allow American planes to use the Incirlik base and wants Iraq to comply with United Nations resolutions that require it to allow monitoring of its weapons programs.
"We're very strongly asking for full compliance," Mr. Cem said in a telephone interview. "The Americans have their policies, but Iraq is a state and a neighbor of ours. When the leadership of a neighboring state asks to create the groundwork for coming over and having bilateral talks, I think it is normal to proceed with that."
Today, American fighter jets based in Turkey did not respond when Iraqi jets violated the northern no-flight zone, whereas allied jets based in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait retaliated against violations in the southern zone. A Pentagon official said there has been no easing of enforcement in the north as a result of any unease on Turkey's part regarding strikes from its territory.
"We will continue to respond to Iraqi provocations in the north," the official said.
Turkey and Iraq enjoyed good relations before the Persian Gulf war. Since the war, Turkey has lost billions of dollars as a result of trade sanctions imposed on Iraq by the United Nations.
A national election is scheduled here on April 18, and by inviting Iraq's second-ranking leader to Ankara, Mr. Ecevit may be seeking to shore up his support among leftist voters and the thousands of families along the Iraqi border who have lost their livelihoods as a result of the United Nations sanctions.
"Ecevit is under intense criticism for sitting on the lap of the United States and letting the Americans use the Incirlik base for bombing Iraq," said Cengiz Candar, an author and commentator who is a specialist on Middle Eastern politics. "It runs against the image he cultivated over the years as having a distance from the United States and sympathizing with the plight of the Iraqi people and with Saddam. On the eve of the election campaign, he might see that as a weak spot. He may also be hoping to use this as a bargaining chip to get more sympathy and economic aid from Washington."
"For Tariq Aziz, the visit is important because in the post-King Hussein era Jordan may become a base for the Iraqi opposition, and he wants to keep Turkey from becoming another link in that chain," Mr. Candar said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 32; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 560 words

HEADLINE: The Widening Olympic Scandal

 BODY:
The ethics panel drafted to investigate the role of vote-buying in Salt Lake City's successful bid for the 2002 Winter Olympic Games has greatly expanded the scandal's known topography. Although the panel had neither subpoena power nor its own auditors, it still managed to implicate a wider array of Olympic officials in the bribery transactions and to penetrate some of the ruses used to hide the payments. Its efforts need to be followed up by a more forceful investigation.
The panel identified 10 more International Olympic Committee members suspected of trading their votes for money and other lucrative benefits provided by Salt Lake City boosters. That raises the total to 24, or about one-fifth, of the members who have now been linked to the scandal. The panel also found evidence that the United States Olympic Committee helped Salt Lake City organizers deliver on a promise to train Sudanese athletes in return for the Sudan's vote, thus implicating Olympic officials at the national level. 
 But the panel, appointed by the trustees of the Salt Lake City organizing committee, was notably circumspect in pointing fingers in Utah. Its report suggests that the unethical conduct was the handiwork primarily of two or three bad apples on the Salt Lake City committees and concludes that the higher-ups, the trustees, were out of the loop about direct payments. It also characterized the misdeeds as unethical but not criminal. Only inquiries by the United States Justice Department and other authorities with subpoena power will be credible enough to render such judgments.
Nevertheless the investigative leads contained in the panel's report should strengthen the hand of reformers within the I.O.C. and major corporations that spend hundreds of millions on sponsorships and ads and thus underwrite much of the $1.45 billion cost of staging the Winter Games. Both sets of stakeholders should demand that the I.O.C. hire an independent, internationally respected law firm and auditors to take over the investigation of Salt Lake City and all other abuses in the bidding process in recent years. These outsiders should also propose structural changes to transform the I.O.C. from a secretive club accountable to no one into a body that is representative of the world's nations, democratic in its selection of venues and transparent in its business dealings.
Like publicly traded corporations, the I.O.C., with its ever-growing economic power, needs annual audits by outside examiners and strict conflict-of-interest rules. It also needs to clean out the management team that tolerated the bribe-taking culture. Only then can the I.O.C. hope to rebuild its credibility. A ritual vote of confidence in Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C.'s president, by his minions in March will only further damage the Olympic movement.
The John Hancock insurance company has concluded that the scandal has devalued the Olympic rings and the value of the Games for advertisers. While it remains an Olympic sponsor, it is removing the rings from its next annual report, stationery and other material where feasible. Its cancellation of negotiations to place about $20 million in commercials on NBC during the Winter Games contains a not-so-subtle message: Corporate America can, and should, bring its collective clout to bear in reforming the I.O.C. now.

HEADLINE: Rebel Leader In East Timor Moves Closer To Freedom

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 10

 BODY:
With Indonesia's edging toward a new status for the disputed territory of East Timor, officials today moved the independence leader Alexandre Gusmao halfway to freedom, transferring him from a prison to a barred and guarded house.
Clenching his fist briefly in a modest salute, the trim and bearded Mr. Gusmao said he expected to play a full role, from his new home, in international negotiations over whether the former Portuguese colony is to become independent or remain linked to Indonesia. 
 "I am always optimistic about independence in East Timor," he said, adding: "We know that negotiation on many conflicts in the world have run for years. If all parties are not willing to reduce the violence and hatred, the dialogues are useless."
Like a number of other East Timorese leaders, Mr. Gusmao, 52, who has been in prison for seven years for his role in leading a separatist insurgency, has recently argued against moving too rapidly toward freedom or even toward a referendum on freedom.
Since Indonesia invaded the remote and tiny territory in 1975, annexing it the next year, human rights groups say, up to 200,000 people have died in fighting and human rights abuses.
Emotions have grown hotter, and renewed violence has flared in recent weeks as Indonesia has, for the first time, said that it was ready to consider loosening its grip on the territory.
The United Nations, which has never recognized Indonesian sovereignty in East Timor, is brokering talks over the status of the territory, which Indonesia claims as its 27th province.
Foreign Minister Ali Alatas, who met his Portuguese counterpart in New York over the weekend, said last week for the first time that Indonesia would consider full independence if the people of East Timor rejected a new autonomous relationship with Jakarta.
But he said he ruled out holding a referendum on status, a vote that many East Timorese are demanding, saying it could lead to civil war among opposing factions.
Mr. Gusmao, who is popularly known by his nickname, Xanana, has said he was also concerned about the possible destabilizing effects of a referendum. He said such a vote should be held only after a 10-year period of social reconciliation and economic development.
Diplomatic negotiations are focusing on what status to seek for East Timor, how soon and how to determine it what it should be.
"The question now is just to find out how we are going to consult the people of East Timor," said Joao Carrascalao, a former governor of the territory and and an advocate of separation from Indonesia. Mr. Carrascalao has also said he believes that after independence has been granted East Timor would need the presence of a United Nations peacekeeping force for at least two years.
The East Timor talks are a chief product of the "reform" period overseen by President B. J. Habibie since President Suharto's ouster in May.
But like other changes, the opening of debate and the loosening of harsh controls have given rise to new uncertainties and violent confrontations. Separatist guerrillas who had become dormant in the hills grew active again.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE OBSTACLE;
As Threat to Censure Resolution in Senate, Texan Is a Familiar Roadblock

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Comity is the grease that allows the Senate to run. That is why Senator Phil Gramm, who has a propensity for throwing sand in the Senate's gears, stands out so starkly.
His determination to block a bipartisan move to censure President Clinton is completely within character. Year after year since he has been in politics, Senator Gramm, a staunchly conservative Texas Republican, has frustrated his colleagues on matters he felt strongly about, and more often than not, he has gotten his way. 
 Late last year, for instance, Senator Gramm almost single-handedly blocked a Senate vote on a carefully arranged compromise bill that would have lifted some of the barriers separating commercial banks, investment banks and insurance companies. Never mind that supporters of the bill were among the largest benefactors of the Republican Party and that the chief sponsor of the Senate compromise, Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, badly wanted the bill to pass to help in his race for re-election, which he ultimately lost.
Last year, Mr. Gramm led the opposition to legislation that would have raised cigarette taxes and permitted more Government regulation of tobacco companies. Never mind that the chief sponsor of the tobacco bill was his best friend in the Senate, John McCain, Republican of Arizona.
"In dealing with his peers, he often doesn't observe the traditional niceties," said a former staff member who insisted on not being identified.
Senator Gramm's press secretary, Larry Neal, expressed what is doubtless the Senator's self-image: "There will always be a Horatius-at-the-gate element to him." Horatius was a legendary Roman hero who, with two lone companions, held an invading Etruscan army at bay.
The Senator, who is 56 years old and in his 15th year in the Senate, seems to delight in being cantankerous, even when his allies call him a nuisance and his enemies call him much worse. He regularly jokes about his reputation for being mean. He cites the evident affection of his wife, his staff and his dog. And at least once he told a dinner audience that he really did have a heart, adding after the requisite pause, "I keep it in a quart jar on my desk."
At the beginning of the Senate's consideration of impeachment this year, Senator Gramm played the surprise role of conciliator. He and his ideological opposite, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, sold the Senate on a plan that allowed the trial to begin and deferred a decision on summoning witnesses. But now he is back in his familiar position as a roadblock. Most Democrats and some Republicans favor a resolution to censure Mr. Clinton after the vote to remove him from office fails.
To pass, such a resolution would require 51 votes, a simple majority, which might be possible, but Mr. Gramm has vowed to block the vote. Under the rules, it would take 60 votes, probably an unattainable number, to bypass him.
The Senator's opposition to censure is both practical and political. As a practical matter, he said on Sunday on "Meet the Press," the NBC News program, that it would open the door for the Senate to vote censure whenever it disapproved of actions by a President -- when, for instance, "a future Harry Truman fires a future General MacArthur."
Politically, Mr. Gramm said, he does not want to give the senators who voted to acquit the President the "political cover" of being able to say officially that they disapproved of Mr. Clinton's behavior.
There is hardly a more formidable opponent in the Senate, in large part because Mr. Gramm is so smart, so tenacious and so quick on his feet in debate. In an interview last year on another topic, Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, said he expected that on an intelligence test, Senator Gramm, who has a Ph.D. in economics, would score higher than anyone else in the Senate. Coincidentally, Mr. Bennett is a leading Republican proponent of censure.
Mr. Gramm's apparent lack of concern about irritating his colleagues has been the dominant characteristic of his years in Congress. He was elected to the House as a Democrat in 1978 and, in 1981, at the beginning of his second term, he was put on the Budget Committee after signing a promise to Democratic leaders that he would be loyal to the party's budget. Instead, he secretly collaborated with Republicans.
When Democratic leaders retaliated in 1983 by kicking him off the Budget Committee, Mr. Gramm quit the party, resigned from the House, was handily re-elected as a Republican in a special election and then, the next year, was elected to the Senate.
When Mr. Gramm ran for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996, his sometimes abrasive personality came back to haunt him in the early contests in small states where personal contact with voters can be crucial. He finished an embarrassing fifth in the Iowa caucuses and dropped out of the race before the New Hampshire primary, when polls there showed him far behind.
With his Presidential race behind him, Mr. Gramm has thrown himself into the business of the Senate, becoming centrally involved not just in the impeachment trial but in almost all the major legislation before Congress. In an interview last month, he said his main goal this year was legislation that would turn Social Security into a mostly private system in which workers controlled their own retirement accounts.
President Clinton opposes this approach. Mr. Gramm said he was not even thinking about compromise.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
By Any Name, A Rose Is Dear As a Valentine

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS are in luck this week. Unlike other Americans, who are forced to shop for Valentine's Day without any official guidance, we have the annual rose survey from the Department of Consumer Affairs.
Jules Polonetsky, the agency's Commissioner, called a news conference to reveal that local florists raise the price of roses by about 33 percent for Valentine's Day. This correlation between price and demand might seem inevitable to some people -- anyone, say, who has opened an economics textbook -- but Mr. Polonetsky will not stand for it. 
 Besides lamenting the price increases, he has developed a strategy to help New Yorkers avoid, as he put it, "seeing red this Valentine's Day." Pointing to a critical discovery made by his agency's investigators -- that different florists in New York charge different prices -- he outlined a technique for buying flowers.
"Consumers," he explained, "can save significantly by choosing one florist over another."
Could this particular strategy -- the technical term is "shopping" -- have applications even beyond Valentine's Day roses? Possibly, although the Commissioner did not elaborate. Nor did he address another question raised by his agency's research: do the investigators at the Department of Consumer Affairs have a little too much time on their hands?
New Yorkers depend on the consumer agency to enforce laws against fraud, but they generally manage to deal with honest merchants all by themselves. They could probably survive without any of the agency's seasonal price surveys -- roses on Valentine's Day, gasoline on Memorial Day, turkey at Thanksgiving, gefilte fish at Passover.
These rituals have given Mr. Polonetsky and his predecessors publicity as they wail against seasonal price increases, but consumers do not necessarily benefit. If florists didn't raise prices at Valentine's Day, consumers would suffer in two ways.
First, many cost-conscious New Yorkers who now order other flowers for Valentine's Day -- because their partners aren't fanatical about getting roses -- would start ordering them, so there wouldn't be enough roses to meet the increased demand. As a result, some rose fanatics would have to do without.
Second, the customers who buy roses at other times of the year would end up paying artificially high prices to subsidize the customers on Valentine's Day. There's a good reason that prices are higher this week: the roses cost extra to grow and ship.
TO meet this annual peak in demand, growers in the United States, Colombia, Ecuador and Holland must prune their bushes in the late fall to start new growth in time for Valentine's Day.
"By pruning, you're cutting off a lot of roses that would have bloomed before Valentine's Day," Jim Lebberes, the president of Kiamos and Tooker, a flower wholesaler in the Bronx, explained. "So you're sacrificing a lot of production, and you need to recover that lost income somehow."
Then there's the cost of shipping. "Let's say there are five regularly scheduled cargo planes that leave Bogota for Miami and New York every night," Mr. Lebberes said. "They fly north with flowers and return south with other cargo. Now suddenly for Valentine's Day you need to charter another 15 planes, and those planes fly back empty, because there's no corresponding increase in demand for southbound cargo. So each one of those roses is costing you a round-trip ticket."
When you add these wholesale costs to the extra expenses at the retail level, like overtime pay for employees, the 33-percent increase doesn't sound unreasonable. In fact, it may reflect a phenomenon that economists call the "good-will factor."
This phenomenon was demonstrated after Hurricane Andrew hit Miami in 1992 and created a shortage of plywood. Lumber companies refused to raise their prices, forgoing an easy profit because they were afraid they'd offend their long-term customers.
New York's florists presumably show some of the same restraint on Valentine's Day to maintain their customers' good will. With more careful investigation next year, Mr. Polontesky could probably call a press conference the week of Valentine Day's and announce that rose prices are too low. That may not sound immediately appealing to him. But it would definitely be newsworthy.

HEADLINE: For a 2d Year, Governor Promises 'Cranky Yankees' a Tax Rebate

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the budget address today by Gov. John G. Rowland to a joint session of the Connecticut General Assembly, as recorded by The New York Times. The address is given every two years.
The hard-working people of this state have retooled Connecticut for the challenges of the next century. Confidence in the future is high. The business climate is strong. The job market is better than it has ever been before. And state government has done its part. We've done it through steady, reliable efforts to control spending, to reduce taxes, to encourage development, to reform the welfare system, to invest in education and to protect the environment. These are all efforts that every single one of us can be proud of, and I thank you. 
 Some people like to refer to people from this area as "cranky Yankees." And perhaps our plain, stubborn refusal to accept defeat has allowed us to survive the economic turmoil of the first half of this decade. I like to call it Yankee ingenuity. The progress of the last five years has showcased our ability to adapt in a world our grandparents and perhaps even our parents could never have imagined. . . .
Our challenge is to be willing to constantly look for better ways to improve services, to plan for the future, to avoid making government an obstacle to the aspirations of the people. All of which, I might add, is easier said than done.
The greatest challenge we face in the years ahead is controlling the growth of government spending. As our economy continues to grow and to gain momentum, the worst thing that state government can do is abandon the tight-fisted control that we have maintained during the 1990's. At the same time, we need to keep our commitments to the investments that we have made in Connecticut's future: commitments to rebuild our system of higher education, to new school construction, to the redevelopment of our major cities. These commitments stand, and they must stand, because they are the best hope that we have, all of us, to insure that Connecticut's place as a land of opportunity remains for all its citizens.
The budget that I present to you today holds no surprises, because it's based on the principles that I have applied in each of the last four years: low spending growth, long-term investment in education, long-term investment in our cities, a constant effort to improve government to respond to the needs of today, and a continued effort to cut taxes, whenever and wherever possible. . . .
This year's projected surplus is a clear sign that the people of Connecticut have once again been overtaxed. So I am proposing that we use at least $80 million of this year's surplus to issue Connecticut's second consecutive income-tax rebate. If it was a good idea last year, then it's a good idea this year. For those who argued last year that it was an election-year gimmick, here's your chance to prove that theory wrong.

HEADLINE: Budget Offers Tax Credits and Rebates

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Setting a course his aides call "responsible Republicanism," Gov. John G. Rowland proposed a two-year Connecticut budget today that takes advantage of the galloping economy by giving taxpayers a rebate for a second year in a row, but aims to eliminate two state offices that he considers wasteful.
Governor Rowland proposed income-tax credits for tuition and property tax payments, but did not seek a cut in the state income tax rate. Democrats have opposed such a cut, saying that could create problems when the economy turns down. The omission was a reminder that Mr. Rowland has abandoned his drive to eliminate the income tax, which was a campaign pledge when he was first elected governor in 1994. 
 "The greatest challenge we face in the years ahead is controlling the growth of government spending," he said during today's address to a joint session of the State Senate and House of Representatives. "As our economy continues to grow and to gain momentum, the worst thing that state government can do is abandon the tight-fisted control that we have maintained during the 1990's."
Democrats, who control both houses of the state legislature, said the new budget incorporates so many of their priorities that there was an odd dynamic on the floor, with Democrats embarrassed to be clapping so much and Republicans aghast at the largess the Governor was dispensing. The scene reflected the delicate line the current crop of moderate Republican governors has to tread as they try to ease their party toward the center without losing the conservatives who are the party's backbone.
Governor Rowland did pick one political fight, proposing elimination of the state's eight high sheriffs, Connecticut's last vestige of county government. Under Governor Rowland's plan, which would be put to voters as a constitutional amendment, sheriffs would no longer be elected, and their duties -- transporting prisoners, maintaining court security and serving legal papers -- would be absorbed into the state bureaucracy.
The sheriffs, currently five Democrats and three Republicans, have also traditionally been part of the state's political machines, aiding with fund-raising and get-out-the-vote efforts. Governor Rowland said he wants to "end the influence of patronage and favoritism in an agency with a public safety mission." When Governor Rowland originally misspoke and said his change would eliminate "patriotism" instead of "patronage," legislators cackled merrily. He continued with a chuckle, "Some here may suggest that."
Sticking to the moderate themes that helped him win re-election overwhelmingly in November, Governor Rowland devoted about half of his speech to plans for making schools better and colleges more affordable. The Governor was in a celebratory mood, quoting President Franklin D. Roosevelt and for the first time crediting a Democrat, Comptroller Nancy S. Wyman, with inspiring last year's income tax rebate.
Some in his party hope Governor Rowland will be considered as a Vice-Presidential candidate next year, and his budget is in sync with the "compassionate conservatism" of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, whom Mr. Rowland endorsed this week for the party's Presidential nomination. The Senate majority leader, George C. Jepsen of Stamford, said Governor Rowland "both as a matter of policy and politics is finding it more comfortable in the middle than he was parked out on the right."
One Democratic leader even suggested that Mr. Rowland had become a born-again big spender. Representative William R. Dyson, a Democrat from New Haven who is a co-chairman of the Appropriations Committee, which will now consider the budget, said he would work to reduce the spending increase in the budget, 4 percent in the first year and 4.8 percent the second year, to the rate of inflation, which is between 1 and 2 percent. "I assumed that would be the standard," Mr. Dyson said. "At the moment our revenues decrease, we're up a creek here."
Democrats also said they would try to tilt spending toward longer-term solutions in education, health care and job training. "There is a lot of spending, but it's on existing programs," said the Senate President pro tem, Kevin B. Sullivan of West Hartford. "Going into the new millennium, the status quo is not good enough."
The proposed budget is $11.6 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1 and $12.1 billion for the year after that. A final version is due before adjournment on June 9.
The plank that was most surprising to legislators was a state income- tax credit for tuition paid to public or private colleges in Connecticut. The program, which piggybacks on a similar Federal credit, offers families 15 percent off their state tax return, up to $225 for each student. The combination of the tax credit and a freeze on tuition at state colleges would save the average freshman at the University of Connecticut or Connecticut State University $1,800 during four years.
The income tax rebate, which meant an average check of $75 to $120 for 955,000 households last year, will benefit about 200,000 fewer taxpayers this year, because people who owe no taxes after taking tax credits will not be eligible. The change will reduce the cost to the state from $103 million to $80 million.
Senator Sullivan said the change would punish low- and middle-income taxpayers. He said Democrats are likely to approve the rebate, but only if rebates are restored to those taxpayers. Senator Sullivan said Democrats would probably accept 85 to 90 percent of Governor Rowland's budget.
Adopting an idea that long has been pushed by Democrats, Governor Rowland proposed increasing the income-tax credit for property taxes from $350 to $400. "My fundamental tax policy is cut taxes whenever and wherever you can," he said.
Showing his conservative roots, Governor Rowland is seeking to transfer the functions of the Department of Higher Education to the Department of Education, an idea that he has proposed and the legislature has rejected before. He said few jobs would be lost in the merger. "Rather than spending more money on bureaucracy, let's spend it on the students," he said.
Governor Rowland also recommended that most University of Connecticut professors teach one more course each year, which he said would save the state $2.3 million in the first three years.
Governor Rowland, who was criticized during the campaign for his stewardship of the Department of Children and Families, asked for more employees and training for the agency. "The protection of children is the one area I will spare no expense," he said.
Borrowing a device pioneered by President Reagan and now a staple of State of the Union Messages, Governor Rowland pointed toward the front row to salute four citizens who came to the rescue of three state troopers who were shot and wounded in Willington in September.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Tax-subsidized savings may not work out as many hope.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein

 BODY:
THE Democrats, trying to blunt furious tax cutting by Republicans, are flocking to limited tax proposals aimed at promoting individual saving. President Clinton's budget proposes tax subsidies to underwrite the cost of setting up private accounts for workers. Senator Robert C. Torricelli, a Democrat of New Jersey, this week proposed, along with Senator Paul D. Coverdell, a Republican from Georgia, tax breaks on interest, dividends and capital gains. Though politically deft, these plans are economically suspect.
The Administration hopes its plan will deflect attention away from Republican proposals to create private retirement accounts as part of Social Security and to achieve a huge 10 percent across-the-board tax cut. Large tax cuts, say the Democrats, are fiscally reckless because budget surpluses are only temporary Besides, the Democrats argue, across-the-board tax cuts only sound fair. Instead, they overwhelmingly reward the high-income families who pay the bulk of taxes. 
 But if tax-subsidized savings accounts are a sound political device, they are a shaky economic device. Mr. Clinton's plan purports to increase the savings of America's many nonsaving families, but no one knows how to make the idea work in practice. Senator Torricelli's plan, many economists argue, would provide little more than a consumption holiday for higher-income families and do virtually nothing to achieve its stated goal of rebuilding the nation's low savings rate.
Even Jonathan Skinner of Dartmouth College, whose research backs the use of targeted tax breaks to increase savings, describes the Torricelli-Coverdell plan as "wrong means to achieve a laudable goal."
In the United States, the personal savings rate is pathetically low, hovering in recent months around zero. Low personal savings pose two important threats.
For the economy at large, a low savings rate can lead to a low investment rate, leaving the future economy bereft of the factories, equipment and technologies it needs to create high-wage jobs. Low wages would intensify the burden on workers of supporting the growing ranks of retirees. But Mr. Skinner warns that tax-based savings incentives can do little to solve this problem.
Consider, he says, what would happen if, magically, tax subsidies encouraged every household to save an additional $1,000. Under that implausibly rosy scenario, national savings would rise by about $100 billion, or 1.5 percent of aggregate income. That, says Mr. Skinner, would "hardly make a dent in returning the personal savings rate to around 7 percent, the level it hit in the 1970's."
The second problem posed by low saving rates is distributional. Half the population lacks an employer-based pension plan. Perhaps 40 percent have no financial assets to fall back on during retirement. Mr. Skinner points to studies that show for many of these families, consumption plummets by 40 or 50 percent once they retire.
Mr. Clinton's plan does at least address the plight of low-saving families with modest incomes. He would create savings accounts of, say, $100 for workers. In addition, the Government would match a portion of each extra dollar that workers add to these savings accounts. Low-income families would receive a higher Government contribution than would middle-income families.
William Gale of the Brookings Institution applauds its potential. "One hundred dollars invested every year for, say, 40 years could amount to $10,000 by the time a worker retires," Mr. Gale said. "If the worker contributes another $100, matched by Government, the nest egg at retirement could total $30,000."
But Mr. Gale warns against undue optimism. How would the Government prevent families from borrowing on their credit cards to deposit money into the tax-advantaged accounts? Would Congress let people invade their retirement accounts for pressing needs like a medical catastrophe or college tuition? If so, would retirement saving rise at all, or would the proposal act as a trigger for one claim after another on the accounts, including the money the Government contributed?
What's worse, Mr. Torricelli's proposal shows how quickly the impulse to subsidize savings can go haywire. The plan, among other things, would provide a tax exemption for the first $500 of interest and dividend earnings and for the first $5,000 of capital gains.
But Prof. Alan Auerbach of the University of California at Berkeley says it would backfire. The plan cuts taxes on the initial amounts of interest, dividends and capital gains that people earn. In other words, it rewards families for their existing levels of saving. But because the tax savings do not rise as interest, dividend and capital gains earnings rise, the proposal does nothing to persuade people to save more than they already are. "The full benefit of the Torricelli plan goes only to those above the 15 percent bracket and who already have substantial investment earnings," Professor Auerbach said. "Those least in need would benefit the most."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Shows Some Stability, Though Concerns Remain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks meandered narrowly yesterday as bargain hunters stabilized some battered high-technology issues even as most Internet companies continued to slide.
The Nasdaq finished virtually unchanged, down 1.29 points, to 2,309.5, following Tuesday's third-worst-ever drubbing in point terms. But the performance offered little reassurance that the 8 percent retreat from its Feb. 1 record close has ended. 
 Nor did analysts take much encouragement from a bounce in the session's final half-hour that lifted the Dow Jones industrials and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to gains of about six-tenths of 1 percent.
"We're a little concerned that earnings expectations are a little high and valuations are full," said John W. Ballen, chief strategist at MFS Investment Management in Boston. In coming weeks, he said, "You could have a pretty choppy market."
Analysts also expressed concern about the relative paucity of stocks moving higher of late and a persistent erosion among a large number of lesser issues. For example, both the Standard & Poor's 400 index of midsize stocks and the S.& P. 600 index of small-capitalization stocks slumped yesterday and are down more than 8 percent so far this year.
The S.& P. 500, by contrast, which includes I.B.M., Intel, Cisco and other high-technology heavyweights, is down less than one-half of 1 percent so far in 1999.
Competition from rising interest rates is also troubling stock investors, said Mary Farrell of Paine Webber. "It's backed the market into a trading range," she said.
At the close, the Dow's blue-chip industrials showed a gain of 44.28 points, to 9,177.31, with a 6 1/8-point surge in I.B.M. to 168 7/8 accounting for 60 percent of it. J. P. Morgan was the second-biggest contributor, rising 3 5/16 , to 103 13/16 .
Philip Morris, which lost a lawsuit involving a California smoker, was the Dow's biggest drag, off 3 15/16 , to 41 7/16 , on volume of 25.4 million shares.
Many Internet stocks were lower, partly on disappointment that Lycos commanded less than expected in the buyout deal announced on Tuesday. Lycos tumbled another 7, to 87 1/4, after trading as low as 77. Amazon.com fell 2 9/16 , to 97 7/16 , bringing its five-day loss to 22.5 percent.
Microsoft inched up 9/16 , to 160 5/8 , as its chief financial officer, Gregory B. Maffei, told a Goldman, Sachs technology conference in New York that he found skidding prices for Internet stocks a boon as his company explored acquisitions and partnerships in this area.
Elizabeth Bramwell, president of Bramwell Capital Management, said on returning from the conference that the mood was "really upbeat" and added that she was skeptical about a widely shared prediction of a lull in computer-related business following the surge from addressing the Year 2000 computer clock problem.
"It looks as if it will continue to be rolling past 2000," she said, with electronic commerce becoming "an enormous business."
Drug stocks, often a haven for nervous investors, were mostly higher by large fractions yesterday, with Pfizer up 1 3/4 at 126 3/4 and Pharmacia & Upjohn, which reported sharply higher fourth-quarter profits, up 1 1/2 at 54 1/4.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declines outnumbered advances 1,855 to 1,177, with only 19 stocks at new highs and 95 at new lows. Volume was relatively light for the third day in a row, at 721.7 million shares.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bonds Fall Further
 (By Bloomberg News)
Bond prices fell for the sixth time in the last eight sessions yesterday on concern that investor demand is satiated after two Treasury debt sales, leaving little appetite for the auction today.
The benchmark 30-year bond fell 29/32 , to a price of 98 11/32 , pushing its yield up 6 basis points, to 5.36 percent.
The Treasury sold $10 billion of notes due in November 2008 at 4.913 percent, about a basis point less than expected. Investors bid for 2.04 times the amount of notes for sale, higher than at the auction in November -- when those notes were first sold -- though below average for the previous 10 sales.
The issue followed a $15 billion five-year note auction on Tuesday. With today's $10 billion sale of 30-year bonds, the Treasury's quarterly debt auctions are complete.

HEADLINE: Reno Pilots Locked in Dispute Over Seniority at American

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: RENO, Feb. 10

 BODY:
To hear American Airlines pilots tell it, they called in sick and disrupted the airline's operations in order to quickly raise the salaries of Reno Air pilots to American's level.
But the pilots at Reno, which was acquired by American in December, are not entirely grateful. Indeed, the Reno Air pilots are locked in a sometimes bitter, though less publicized, dispute with the American pilots. 
Many Reno pilots support the American pilots in their labor dispute, which appears to have ended at least temporarily today, though they are not participating themselves. And they will welcome the higher salaries that being an American employee will bring.
But they object to the proposal by American Air pilots to "staple" the roughly 300 Reno pilots to the bottom seniority list of American's more than 9,000 pilots, as if the Reno pilots were all freshly hired on Dec. 23, 1998, the day American acquired the airline. Some of the Reno pilots are putting "no stapler" stickers on their luggage, showing a stapler inside the red circle with a slash through it.
"We should not have all our years of service and the quality of life that represents ripped away from us," said Bob Collins, a Reno Air pilot who is also a spokesman for the local branch of the Air Line Pilots Association, the airline's current union. "Many of us are in the last years of our career here and we shouldn't be treated as new hires."
Reno senior pilots make an average of $65,000 to $75,000 a year, less than half that of American pilots with equivalent experience. Although American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, has proposed raising the salaries of the Reno pilots to its own pilots' levels in 12 months to 18 months, the American pilots' union wants those salaries raised now.
But for most Reno pilots, their salaries will not double because they would have less seniority at American. Captains at Reno will become second-ranking first officers or even third-ranking flight engineers, which carry lower pay than captains. Mr. Collins, a captain, for instance, expects his salary to climb to $100,000 a year from $75,000. Lower seniority also means poorer choices of flights, vacations and home bases, meaning many Reno pilots will have to move from this city.
Mr. Collins also complained that his union had not been able to participate in discussions between American and the Allied Pilots Association, the union that now represents the American pilots and that will represent the Reno pilots. "Allied Pilots have basically closed the door on us," he said.
Drew Engelke, a first officer at American Airlines, said the issue of seniority was "under negotiation." He said the union's proposal was that the Reno pilots' length of service would count toward their pay and benefits, although not toward their seniority ranking.
But some American pilots apparently think the Reno pilots are ingrates, in that Reno might have gone out of existence if American had not bought it. "We're going to give you a raise, keep your job and you're asking for the moon," said an anonymous phone call left on the Reno union's voice mail, one of several obscene and harassing phone calls the union says it has received.
The disruption in air traffic spurred by the acquisition of Reno Air is just the latest chapter in the history of the small low-cost airline, which struggled for most of its seven years. Indeed, judging by the disruptions this week, Reno has had a bigger impact on air travel now than ever. Started in 1992 with one leased plane and 150 employees, Reno has expanded to 25 planes and 2,000 employees.
"We accepted lower salaries to get the airline off the ground," said Richard J. Vitzthum, a 47-year-old Reno captain who was the sixth pilot hired.
He said Reno promised that pilot salaries would be raised once the airline became profitable. But for the most part, it was plagued by heavy losses, frequent strategy shifts and service problems. Last February, some 65 percent of callers to its reservation system hung up in frustration before they could get through to an agent.
That same month, Joseph O'Gorman, a retired United Airlines executive, took over as Reno's president. He cut the work force by 15 percent, eliminated unprofitable routes and replaced all 11 senior executives with five of his own choosing. Profits returned. But Mr. O'Gorman decided Reno needed a big partner.
American bought Reno for $124 million to bolster its presence on the West Coast. While American has a strong east-to-west routes, including as San Francisco to New York, it has virtually no north-to-south flights in the West.
The California market is dominated by Southwest Airlines and by United, a unit of the UAL Corporation. United set up a low-priced shuttle service and uses those short flights to feed its cross-country and cross-Pacific flights. Without north-south flights, American could not do this.
"Customers who fly up and down the coast every week may occasionally fly transcontinental and they are inclined to use the same carrier," said Donald P. O'Hare, a 40-year employee of American Airlines, who took over last week as the new president of Reno from Mr. O'Gorman, who left after the takeover was completed.
Mr. O'Hare, who has embarked on a whirlwind trip to meet Reno employees in 16 cities, said almost all Reno workers would be offered jobs at American, though the airline's headquarters in Reno would close and some people might have to move. The Reno name is expected to be discontinued.

HEADLINE: Air Travel To Remain Backed Up

BYLINE: ByEDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Even if American Airlines pilots return to work quickly after a Federal judge's order yesterday to end their five-day sickout that grounded 2,500 flights, travelers can still expect inconvenience and disruption during this coming long weekend.
Still, even a temporary settlement cannot come too soon for airlines, passengers, cruise lines, hotels and residents of the Caribbean, which depends heavily on tourism for economic survival. 
 "This strike was serious stuff, because this is one of the biggest weeks of the year for Caribbean travel and American is the biggest airline in the region," said Michael Youngman, executive director of the Caribbean Tourism Organization. "So even a tentative settlement is an enormous relief."
Effective immediately, American customers can obtain a full refund on all tickets -- including nonrefundable tickets -- they can postpone or reschedule flights without service charge or penalty, and when flights are canceled, American said it would try to accommodate customers on other American flights or on other carriers.
The cruise industry was sweating out the possibility that many passengers booked on cruises from southern Florida this weekend could not get to Miami or Fort Lauderdale on time. "We have 21,500 passengers booked from Miami, Fort Lauderdale and San Juan on nine ships this weekend, and an equal number going home," said Rich Steck, the spokesman in Miami for Royal Caribbean and Celebrity Cruises. "So you can probably hear our sigh of relief about the settlement all the way up in New York."
Most business travelers apparently avoided major dislocations during the sickout, said Norman Sherlock, executive director of the National Business Travel Association. "But corporate members have told me they're going to recast their future travel plans," he said, "so as not to be so dependent on American or any single airline."
Some travel agents viewed the sickout as further evidence of the importance of their services, which are threatened by erosion from the Internet. Rudi Steele, owner of a travel agency in Dallas, did some juggling to get two clients to Los Angeles in time to catch a flight to Hong Kong in order to board a cruise ship. "I got them on a late night flight the night before to Ontario, Calif.," Mr. Steele said, "put them up in a hotel and booked a rental car for them to drive to L.A. in the morning." He added, "That's what a professional travel agent will do for clients."
Michael Boult, vice president for supplier relations at Rosenbluth International, added that while the Internet might be fun for surfing for information, it was of little help in a crisis. "Try calling the Internet and complaining that your flight's been canceled," he said. Early on, Rosenbluth sent a "Flash Fax" to corporate accounts, telling them of the flight cancellations and promising to keep them informed. "Because there were good alternatives early in the strike," Mr. Boult said, "we were able to avoid any serious disruptions."
Airlines say they will do all they can to accommodate stranded American passengers, but added that they do not have spare planes to press into service, as is often believed. Moreover, work rules and airport regulations prevent the scheduling of additional flights except in unusual circumstances.
American Airlines booked more than 1,000 hotel rooms in Miami on Tuesday for stranded passengers, but by and large, the strike seemed to be a mixed blessing for hotels, with no-shows offsetting the number of guests who extended their stay after their flights were canceled. However, the sickout hurt the 1,369-room Hyatt Regency D/FW hotel at the Dallas/Fort Worth airport. "Fifty percent of our business is small meetings, booked 10 to 14 days in advance," said Steve Trent, the hotel's general manager. "We've had cancellations, and we stood to lose a lot more business if the strike continued, because this is a busy season for conventions in Dallas."
When he learned of the judge's order to end the sickout, Mr. Trent had a one-word reaction: "Hallelujah!"

HEADLINE: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS PILOTS IN SICKOUT TO RETURN TO JOB

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
A Federal judge ordered pilots at American Airlines to return to work yesterday, apparently ending five days of widespread disruptions that had grounded more than 2,500 flights, inconvenienced tens of thousands of passengers and left businesses scrambling to find other carriers for their cargo.
The order came none too soon for American, the country's second-largest carrier, which was forced to cancel nearly 1,000, or 44 percent, of its 2,250 daily flights yesterday. It was the worst day yet since hundreds of pilots began calling in sick on Saturday in a dispute over American's recent purchase of Reno Air, a small airline in the West. Without the court's intervention, the dispute threatened to disrupt travel during the Presidents' Day weekend, when flights at most airlines are expected to be full. 
 American said that it expected most of the pilots to return to work. Nonetheless, it said that it would still have to cancel several hundred flights today because of the lingering effects of the disruption. The airline said it expected service to be back to normal by the weekend. It also announced that passengers affected by this week's cancellations could reschedule their flights without penalty or receive full refunds. Page C4.
At a hearing in Dallas yesterday, Judge Joe Kendall of United States District Court castigated both the company, which had sought the court order, and the Allied Pilots Association, the union that represents American's 9,200 pilots.
Chiding them for not settling the dispute on their own, he said: "It's silly for us to even be here. It's like killing a gnat with a sledgehammer."
"If you would look up bad labor relations in the dictionary, you would have an American Airlines logo beside it," he added.
But after listening to both sides, he agreed that the sickout was a violation of the 1934 Railway Labor Act, which severely restricts strikes in the airline industry. He ordered the pilots to return to the cockpit, warning them that he would hold them in contempt if they did not.
Union leaders vowed to abide by the order, which barred the pilots association from making any concerted efforts to encourage pilots to call in sick or otherwise withhold their services. But union officials have contended all along that the sickout was a grass-roots protest that they did not control.
There were 2,077 pilots out sick yesterday, American said. Normally about 400 are on the sick list.
"We are going to scrupulously comply with the order," said Brian Mayhew, a captain and vice president of the union. "That will not remove the elements of frustration and anger that is in the pilot group as a result of the fact that the company is not addressing our core concerns in the negotiations."
The dispute between American and the pilots centers on how American integrates Reno Air, the carrier in Nevada that American bought in December for $124 million. American said it would take a year to 18 months to integrate Reno's 25 airplanes and 300 pilots into its operations. But the union says that American is violating its contract with the union, which requires all flying at the airline to be done by its members. It demands that American integrate Reno faster and pay all pilots as if the merger has been completed.
American Airlines terminals at airports nationwide were largely quiet yesterday, though passengers continued to complain of long delays and poor service from American Airlines personnel. The airline estimated that about 90,000 passengers were inconvenienced by yesterday's cancellations and said that it was doing its best to accommodate passengers from canceled flights on later departures or on rival airlines.
Among the flights canceled at Kennedy International Airport in New York yesterday were five to San Francisco, two to Los Angeles and two to London's Heathrow Airport.
Peter Koumers said he had waited on the telephone for two hours Tuesday night to try to find out the status of his trip to the British Virgin Islands before finally giving up. He and his wife, Jackie, arrived at Kennedy from their home on Long Island yesterday morning with their two daughters, ages 1 and 3, only to find that their 11:30 A.M. flight to Puerto Rico had been canceled. American then booked them on a Tower Air flight departing at 11 P.M.
"We spent 60 bucks to get here in the limo with all the luggage and the girls," he said. "Now they're going nuts. It's definitely a hassle, but we're going to go anyway."
Karla Speed, a caterer from Dallas, and her husband got as far as Miami's airport on their way to Costa Rica to celebrate their first wedding anniversary. After spending the night in a hotel, they were hoping to get on a 6 P.M. flight yesterday.
"We had planned a very expensive trip in a resort and we got a honeymoon suite booked after lots of trouble," she said. "Now it's all ruined. I'm breaking out in hives."
Passengers were not the only ones inconvenienced. Businesses that use American to ship goods around the globe had to make other arrangements, often at a higher cost. Especially hard hit were shipments to Latin America, where American is by far the dominant carrier.
Yesterday's court order still leaves open the dispute over how American will integrate Reno Air. The smaller carrier has been a source of irritation to American's pilots since it was founded in the early 1990's, plying routes abandoned by American when it was suffering record losses.
American laid off several hundred pilots because of the cuts and sold frequent-flier miles to Reno. The union saw the move as an underhanded way for American to lower its costs.
Donald J. Carty, the chairman and chief executive of the AMR Corporation, American's parent, had said that he thought the purchase of Reno would eliminate the ill will and shore up American's presence in the West.
But the Reno purchase only made the pilots more suspicious after Mr. Carty said it would take a year to 18 months to integrate the two carriers. They worry that he intends to keep Reno, which pays its senior pilots less than half of what their counterparts earn at American, as a low-cost airline operating alongside American. And they want to establish a precedent for mergers in case American buys a larger carrier.
The two sides talked on Tuesday but made little progress, the pilots said. They were supposed to talk again yesterday but met in court instead. Though Judge Kendall's order bars pilots from calling in sick in large numbers, it does not order them to be enthusiastic and energetic employees. They can still upset American's operations by scrupulously obeying work rules or refusing to volunteer for extra flying, something on which the airline depends.
"It is doubtful that voluntary overtime will return to normal," Mr. Mayhew said, "until there is a negotiated settlement."

HEADLINE: For Pataki's Democratic Allies, Budget Means Reward Time

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 10

 BODY:
When Gov. George E. Pataki announced his relatively frugal budget the other day, he drew the usual catcalls from Democrats hoping to depict him as the Scrooge of the Statehouse. But the plan elicited mostly smiles from one faction of the Democratic Party's leaders: those who endorsed Mr. Pataki for re-election last fall.
While the Governor proposed freezing or cutting one type of local aid to nearly every city, he called for a 36 percent increase for Buffalo, whose Mayor, Anthony Masiello, was one of the most prominent Democrats to support the Republican Governor. Niagara Falls received an extra 25 percent; its Mayor, James C. Galie, was another Democratic defector. 
 A third Mayor, Edward A. Hanna of Utica, who not only backed Mr. Pataki last year but then became a Republican, did not receive more of this aid but is expecting a sizable chunk of a $5 million fund that the Governor put in the budget to help localities demolish buildings to spur development.
Two Democratic State Senators from New York City who endorsed Mr. Pataki, Olga A. Mendez and Alton R. Waldon Jr., are also slated to get more money for their districts, particularly from a new pool of at least $200,000 that the Governor wants to spend on asthma prevention and treatment.
Rewarding allies with cupfuls from the honey pot of the state treasury is an Albany custom, and one of the best times to view it is after a gubernatorial election, when politicians around the state seek recompense from the winner for their labors on the stump. These budget items stand out even more this year because Mr. Pataki is pledging a new lean regimen for the state, including an overall increase in spending of just 1.8 percent.
The modest growth in the proposed budget, which comes as the state has a surplus of more than $2 billion, has infuriated some lawmakers and local officials, including New York City's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani is a Republican who supported the Governor this time (though not in 1994), but the Mayor maintains that the budget did him no favors and would be disastrous for his city. The Governor has staunchly disputed that assertion.
New York City does not receive the kind of aid that Mr. Pataki sharply raised for Buffalo and Niagara Falls, but in general, the Governor proposed that the city's share of the state budget remain flat.
Pataki administration officials demur when asked about budget items that appear intended for Democrats who endorsed the Governor, saying he has called for selective major new spending where most needed, ignoring political considerations. "We have put the resources where we can have the most effect," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki.
Mr. McKeon denied that Democratic mayors or legislators had endorsed Mr. Pataki last fall in return for promises of government largess after the election. "The reason why these people supported the Governor was because his policies have made cities stronger and our streets safer and kept the economy growing," Mr. McKeon said.
The Legislature still has to approve the budget, and lawmakers could force changes that could subvert the Governor's choices. In fact, some items for his Democratic cadre might not fare so well with the Democratic majority in the Assembly, where the hostility to Mr. Pataki is about equal to the resentment toward Democrats who backed him.
Though the items were deep in the budget and have not attracted much attention, some loyalist Democratic lawmakers were quick to denounce them and say they would come under scrutiny in the negotiations with the Pataki administration.
"If the Governor is in fact doing what a number of us suspect, he is playing a pretty dangerous game of urban aid based on who supported him," said Assemblyman Joseph D. Morelle, a Democrat from Rochester, who complained that the Governor had slighted Rochester in the budget. "It is intended to have a chilling effect on mayors who are exercising their political views, to make sure that they are not very vocal."
The Democrats who supported the Governor said they had nothing to apologize for, asserting that it was their duty to do everything possible to obtain money from Albany for their areas.
Mayor Masiello of Buffalo had several conversations with Mr. Pataki as he was fashioning the budget in an effort to persuade him to raise the amount of aid, but a spokesman for Mr. Masiello said his involvement in the gubernatorial campaign played no role in their talks.
The spokesman, Peter K. Cutler, said the Mayor made his case to Mr. Pataki that Buffalo was managing its money better but needed more help from the state.
"For anybody to criticize the receipt of general-fund appropriations as based on political paybacks is misguided," Mr. Cutler said. "We reject that."
Mayor Galie of Niagara Falls did not respond to two telephone messages left at his office seeking comment.
Mayor Hanna of Utica, an outspoken Pataki booster, acknowledged that maintaining good relations with Mr. Pataki might give his city more access to aid. "How much are you going to get from a governor if you knock him?" said Mr. Hanna, who garnered a $1 million state grant for a recreation center in Utica last year around the same time that he was endorsing Mr. Pataki. "That's just human nature."
Senators Mendez and Waldon said they had been assailed by some Democrats for crossing party lines, but had no regrets.
"It was not a quid pro quo," Mr. Waldon said. "But I am sophisticated enough to know that when you are friendly to someone, on occasion that friendship is returned."

Pentagon Questioning Risks and Goals in Kosovo

HEADLINE: Census Chief Accuses Panel Of Meddling With Details

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The director of the Census Bureau criticized Congressional Republicans today for what he described as their efforts to "micromanage" preparations for the 2000 census.
The director, Kenneth Prewitt, said in an interview that Republicans on the House Subcommittee on the Census had suggested changes in bureau plans like how many census takers should be hired, where they should be deployed, the language other than English in which census forms for a given area should be printed, and the ability of municipal governments to challenge the count of local populations. 
 "If you put all these together, it's as if the subcommittee is trying to design the census," said Mr. Prewitt, whom the Senate confirmed to his post last summer. "It strikes me as a very risky enterprise to try to micromanage the census."
Many of the career professionals at the Census Bureau's headquarters, in Suitland, Md., outside Washington, have long held views like Mr. Prewitt's, but they have generally grumbled in private. The director's comments stand out not so much because of their tone or content as because he chose to make them publicly.
Mr. Prewitt said he was particularly bothered by a bill introduced by Representative Dan Miller of Florida, chairman of the House Subcommittee on the Census, that would permit local governments to review the Census Bureau's work after completion of the count. If a municipality challenged the bureau's count of a given block, for instance, the agency would have to send census takers to recanvass the area.
"It invites 39,000 independent jurisdictions to tell us that they have more people than we found," Mr. Prewitt said. "It's an incentive for anyone to try to boost their numbers for either economic or political gain."
The procedure, known as post-census local review, was used for the 1990 census, and challenges then forced the bureau to revisit 20 percent of the nation's census blocks. Mr. Prewitt and other officials of the bureau said that the process had proved expensive and had found only a tiny fraction of those who had earlier been missed and that as a result, the agency had made no plans to use it in the 2000 census. But Representative Miller said:
"This is something that local officials want. I don't see why the Census Bureau would object. I don't know what they are afraid of. Are they afraid local officials will find a mistake, or do they think they are perfect?"
The Republican-controlled subcommittee is holding a hearing on the bill on Thursday and has scheduled a vote then. Mr. Prewitt said he was particularly upset that no Census Bureau official had been invited to testify.
"I feel almost aggrieved," he said, "that the subcommittee would hold hearings on something that would lead to such a major change in census procedures without inviting the Census Bureau to testify."
Mr. Miller said that discussions about the bill had taken place "at the staff level" and that the bureau's objections had been noted.
Democrats maintain that the Republicans are pressing for post-census local review to throw a monkey wrench into the Census Bureau's ability to produce population counts that can be used for the drawing of boundaries for Congressional and state legislative districts. Bureau officials say post-census local review would add five to six weeks to the time to compile official numbers for such redistricting.
Last month the Supreme Court ruled that the bureau could not use a hotly debated method known as statistical sampling to help produce an official population figure that will be used to determine the number of House seats each state will be allocated.
But the High Court did not explicitly rule on whether sampling was permitted to establish precisely where inside a state people live. Such information is used to draw boundaries for Congressional and state legislative districts.
Experts say sampling will increase the number of minority members who are counted. Since minorities tend to live in areas that are strongly Democratic, increasing their numbers could help Democrats when district lines are drawn.
Most states must have official numbers for redistricting by April 1, 2001. If they do not get the number affected by sampling by then, they will have to use the basic figures the Census Bureau prepares for apportionment.
