HEADLINE: ONE CITY, TWO CUBAS: A special report.;
Miami's Exiles: Side by Side, Yet Worlds Apart

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 10

 BODY:
In a classroom of newly arrived Cubans, Alex Alvarez, a Cuban transplant himself, wasted no time scaring his students straight. "Welcome to the capitalist system," he said. "Each one of you is responsible for the amount of money you have in your pocket. The Government is not responsible for whether you eat, or whether you're poor or rich. The Government doesn't guarantee you a job or a house.
"You've come to a rich and powerful country, but it is up to you whether or not you continue living like you did in Cuba." 
 Such warnings were not necessary 40 years ago, when Cubans fleeing Fidel Castro settled down here to await, some to plot, his downfall. They came from a capitalist system, with enough education and ambition to fulfill the American dream. But Mr. Castro has lasted so long that Miami now reflects different Cubas.
The people from today's Cuba are the children of a revolution that provided social guarantees but limited opportunities. They include those filling out job applications in Mr. Alvarez's class at the Training and Employment Council of South Florida, where he admonishes them, "Put down 'High School, Havana, Cuba.' Do not write 'Secundaria Ho Chi Minh.' "
The people from an earlier Cuba, and their children, have grown into a Miami Who's Who. The mayors of the city and county of Miami, the county police chief and the county state attorney are all Cuban-born or of Cuban descent. So are the president of the largest bank, the owner of the largest real estate developer, the managing partner of the largest law firm, nearly half of the county's 27 state legislators and two of its six members of Congress.
About the only accomplishment Cuban-Americans cannot claim is regaining their country.
"There's an irony and pathos about the situation," a University of Miami sociologist and expert on Cuban affairs, Max Castro, said. "They have succeeded as immigrants and failed as exiles."
That success and failure is etched on Miami, the main repository of Cuban dreams and dissent in the United States, where the news one day can be about a Cuban-American company's shares being traded on the New York Stock Exchange, and the next about the arrest of four aging exiles on a mission to assassinate Mr. Castro.
But the immigration over the decades has made Miami so distinctly Cuban that the cultural clash is no longer between Cubans and Americans as much as between different waves of Cuban immigrants.
With each batch of immigrants who win the annual visa lottery, each of the smuggled boatloads of Cubans that land almost daily in South Florida, Cuban Miami becomes less cohesive, encompassing a people who differ in social class, race, generation and politics, who increasingly come from different worlds.
The first and the latest waves of Cubans, particularly, said a sociologist at the University of Michigan, Silvia Pedraza, "live side by side but remain aloof from one another."
Until recently the Federal Government had an open-door policy for Cuban immigrants, welcoming them as victims of Communism. They still get special treatment. Each year, 20,000 are granted visas by lot.
 
The New Wave
Despite Welcome, A Hard Transition
 Immigrants from Cuba still count on welcoming relatives like Efrain Veiga, who left Cuba as a child in 1962 and now, at 47, is the successful owner of the Yuca restaurant in Miami Beach. Mr. Veiga has visited Cuba twice and regularly sends money to relatives there.
But even Mr. Veiga was startled by his latest experience with a cousin, whom he had helped leave the island, put up in his own home here and given a job in his restaurant.
Mr. Veiga said he was surprised when his cousin balked at working weekends. And the restaurant owner was outright shocked, he said, when one of his waiters showed up for work wearing a pair of expensive shoes he had given his cousin.
"Where did you get those shoes?" Mr. Veiga asked.
"Your cousin sold them to me," the waiter replied.
Mr. Veiga has hired other newcomers from Cuba and found many of them also stuck in the day-to-day survival mode of modern Cuba, where trading shoes for dollars could put food on the table.
"Their life style and way of thinking is different," Mr. Veiga said. "Deep down they feel we owe them something, that we've had it better."
The shock is mutual. Mr. Alvarez's students said one of their biggest surprises in the United States was how hard people work. Another is how "Americanized" their compatriots have become, they say.
"People are so materialistic," said Olga Rodriguez, 40, who came legally last year with a son, 22, and daughter, 15. "It's like they have the dollar sign on their forehead. It hasn't happened to me yet. I offer rides to classmates in language school even if I have to go out of my way."
Eduardo Marquez, 30, arrived in the United States after a year in American refugee camps Panama and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Only one of several distant relatives offered to put him up when he finally got here in 1995, and then only for two weeks. He said no thanks.
"They think we all steal," he said.
Mr. Marquez, a painter and sculptor who sold his art on the streets of Havana, said his relatives had also painted too rosy a picture of life here. "I thought that this was a wonderland, that you'd kick a rock and money would fall out," he said. Instead, he has bounced from job to job while struggling to start a pest control business.
Mr. Marquez does not regret leaving Cuba. The island, however, still has the pull of the 7-year-old daughter and a brother.
"I'm not political but from a human standpoint, they're killing of hunger the people, not Fidel," Mr. Marquez said, explaining why he opposed the American trade embargo of Cuba. "People here think that in Cuba a group could get organized to take Fidel out. That's really easy to say with a full stomach."
 
The First Wave
A Cuba Recalled, Then Recreated
 It is true that many older exiles have lost touch, living off of memories that may or may not be accurate. But full stomachs have not tempered the craving for their homeland of those who settled here in the 1960s, fleeing the radicalization of the island and fearing political persecution and Communist indoctrination of their children. They have recreated pre-revolution Cuba here, renaming streets after Cuban martyrs, reactivating Cuban social clubs, trade organizations and businesses, filling supermarket shelves with "Cubano" versions of coffee, cheese and bread.
In this parallel Cuban universe, Jose Lopez-Silvero, 78, and Alfredo Blanco, 80, president and vice-president of the Sugar Producers of Cuba Inc., which represents those whose companies were nationalized by the Castro regime, can say exactly how much their former sugar mills are producing today and how much the workers earn. They have not seen Cuba since they left in 1960, but their information is all first-hand, gleaned from recent arrivals and letters from Cuba. Their ties, while no longer familial, remain emotional.
The former sugar producers want to recover their nationalized properties, which had been with some families for generations and which they regard as stolen. Their group also has a plan for restoring the sugar industry to its past glory in "post-Communist Cuba," one of many reconstruction plans hatched all over Miami for the moment Cuba gains its "freedom," as if Mr. Castro's four-decade rule has been just a temporary setback, a bad dream.
In their long exile, Mr. Blanco, a retired sugar trader and executive, and Mr. Lopez-Silvero, a retired corporate legal consultant, have supported the 37-year-old American embargo. They blame its failure to induce democratic change in Cuba on past Soviet subsidies and what they deem lax enforcement of its toughest provisions.
They have seen change come close -- before the Bay of Pigs invasion failed, after the Berlin wall fell -- only to be let down. Now, they say, it is only a matter of time.
"Castro has to die some day," said Mr. Blanco, who is eight years older than the ruler.
Many of the early immigrants' children, however, are not waiting Mr. Castro out. Fed by their parents' nostalgia, aided by the contacts allowed with Cuba and driven more by curiosity than patriotism, they help fill clubs that feature bands from the island, and the charter flights to Havana that leave several times a week from Miami International Airport.
Richard Blanco, 30, a civil engineer born in Madrid to Cuban exiles and raised in Miami, visited Cuba in 1994 for the first time. He said the country did not differ much from the descriptions he had heard growing up, "except for the poverty," and he felt totally at ease. Last year he published a book of poems that laid out some of the feelings of his generation. One poem, "Mail for Mama," reads:
"Monthly, you would peel eggshell pages,
The white onionskin paper telling details:
Kiki's first steps, your mother's death,
Dates approximated by the postmarks.
Sometimes with pictures: mute black and whites,
Poor photos of poor cousins I would handle
Looking for my resemblance in the foreign
Image of an ear, an eyebrow, or a nose."
 
The Next Wave
Other Ethnic Groups Dilute Cuban Flavor
 While Miami's Cuban population evolves with American-born generations and newcomers, other demographic forces at work are changing the face of Hispanic Miami.
Cubans are still the single largest Latin American group, making up about 60 percent of the total Hispanic population, which accounts for more than half Miami-Dade County's population. But while the Cuban influx was accompanied by the flight of local whites, it coincided with the arrival of other Hispanic immigrants.
The Latin Americanization of Miami is slowly chipping away at the dominant Cuban identity. In Little Havana, storefronts advertise Salvadoran corn pancakes and waitresses hail from Honduras and Peru; on the radio, only one of three stations continue Cuba-oriented talk, and the area's highest-rated Spanish-language station is Colombian.
But if the voices are more diverse, and even politically moderate and liberal Cuban-Americans have come out in the open, Miami's political discourse and much of the media coverage is still largely defined by hard-edged conservatism. At times the city has the feel of a bubble suspended in time, where issues are debated as if Mr. Castro had just taken over, where "communist" is still the ultimate insult.
Polls have shown that a majority of Cubans here oppose even beginning a political dialogue with the Cuban government under Mr. Castro, a position zealously guarded by Cuban-Americans whose influence in Washington was personified by the founder of the Cuban American National Foundation, the late Jorge Mas Canosa, a man Presidents consulted on policy toward Cuba.
That unwavering stance, coupled with an image of political intolerance and violent episodes of right-wing extremism, has won the exiles little international sympathy. Mr. Castro, some political experts say, has proven far more shrewd at public relations than his opponents.
"We're seen as a narrow-minded," said Professor Castro, the University of Miami sociologist. "The one political success has been to turn U.S. policy in a hard-line direction, and that hasn't worked because it has the negative connotation that it hurts Cuban people."
Cuban-Americans like Bill Teck, editor of the magazine "Generation N," a term applied to bicultural Hispanics members of Generation X, said his readers and staff differed on Cuba policy issues but shared a frustration that so many see Cuba through a romantic prism, blind to its political prisoners, its lack of democratic elections, its human rights violations.
"What we talk about is the failure of the cause of a free Cuba to permeate the pop culture," said Mr. Teck, who was born here of an American father and a Cuban mother.
But among the younger generations, the conservative message has become less strident.
Alex Penelas, the Miami-born, 37-year-old mayor of Miami-Dade County and an politician many here expect to someday run for President, has inherited the conservatism of his parents. His father narrowly escaped a death sentence for plotting against Mr. Castro in 1960, said Mr. Penelas, who blames Mr. Castro for his never having met his paternal grandfather, who died in Cuba.
"I'm not convinced of this generational gap people talk about," said the Mayor, who is fluent in both English and Spanish.
Unlike many of his elders, however, Mr. Penelas has bicultural sensibilities. He said he would not have snubbed Nelson Mandela for his friendship with Mr. Castro, as Miami's Cuban leadership did when the South African leader visited here in 1990. The incident, which included the withdrawal of an official welcoming proclamation, prompted a three-year black tourism boycott of Miami-Dade County and worsened feelings of alienation among blacks here.
"I would have met him, given him the proclamation and use the opportunity" to give Mr. Mandela his opinion of Mr. Castro, he said.
And although he has lobbied for traditional Cuban-American causes like the embargo, he has also reached out to black constituents, championed gay rights and taken up the concerns of the numerous ethnic groups who now call Miami home.
Cuba still beckons, however. Mr. Penelas envisions "migration challenges" when the Communist Party loosens its grip on the island, as Cubans here expect after Mr. Castro's death. But he also sees an economic bonanza for Miami in trade and tourism if the embargo is lifted.
Mr. Penelas also expects to play some role in Cuba's transition to democracy, plans shared by many other Cuban-Americans, which some predict will create new conflict as a post-Castro Cuba is reshaped. But like most Cuban-Americans, naturalized or native born, he would stay put in Miami.
Less than 30 percent of the about 600,000 Cuban-Americans here would move to the island, polls show. This is where more than half of all Cubans in the United States have chosen to live, where the old have doctors, pensions and offspring, and where the young find opportunity and their own roots.
Miami, after all, is home.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 40; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Still Life Still Challenges: Updating the Old Masters

BYLINE: By MARGARETT LOKE

 BODY:
D. W. Mellor has had several lives in photography. He began to collect photographs in 1969, soon after receiving a degree in economics. He ran a photography gallery in Philadelphia from 1979 to 1982. For 30 years he was a freelance photographer who took mostly color shots. Since 1993 he has been working on his own black-and-white photography, focusing on a genre that would have daunted a lesser soul: still lifes inspired by the Old Masters.
In his photographs, about a dozen of which are at the Yancey Richardson Gallery in SoHo, Mr. Mellor shows a firm grasp of Old Master components: darkness and light, rhythm and balance, texture and geometry. A few choice dinner table objects are left casually but artfully on a plain old wood table. The natural light picks out of the enveloping darkness the glint in the glass, the shine in the silver, the textures on the skin of fruits and vegetables, the polish of the table. 
 Mr. Mellor reproduces in precise, exquisite detail on photographic paper what 17th-century painters recreated in precise, exquisite detail on canvas. More astonishing is Mr. Mellor's ability to produce black-and-white prints whose sumptuously subtle tonalities echo the luminous colors one would expect in, say, an old Flemish still life.
Because they follow a set of formal stylistic conventions, 17th-century still lifes are superficially similar yet strikingly dissimilar when viewed closely. At a glance Mr. Mellor's images appear to have a sameness. Up close it's another matter.
Take, for instance, "Still Life With Conch Shell, Amsterdam" (1998), "Still Life With Florentine Glass and Two Glasses, London" (1997) and "Still Life With Twist, Venice, Italy" (1995). The objects in each of these are arranged in a kind of triangular formation. But the internal dialogue of the images differs among them.
Despite a silver conch, an ornate metal goblet and a crystal wineglass, the first of these images has an almost spartan feel, an impression reinforced by three groupings spread sparingly along the length of a table. On the left is a large empty metal platter with a calligraphic twist of lemon peel balanced on its rim, the silver conch placed behind the plate. The second grouping includes a peach, a large toy marble, a wineglass, a goblet and a sugar shaker. At the right of the image is a lone marble. Supplying a note of age-old solidity is the edge of the table, the light detailing the wood grain and every nick on it.
The image taken in London, focusing as it does on an ornate goblet in cut glass and silver, is a luxurious still life. Centered in the picture is a cluster that also includes an elaborate but smaller wineglass and a lemon half balanced on the rim of a silver plate. To the left is a secondary cluster of a fluted glass, a metal plate, a pear and grapes.
"Still Life With Twist," however, carries a jumbled message. There is a lovely translucent sliced fruit in the foreground and the textures of the other fruits are nicely captured. But a lemon peel is much too artificially hooked from the lip of a wineglass and around the stem of a metal goblet. And a small classical statue of a nude leaning against a pear is a jarring touch.
Such a strangely dissonant note also appears in "Still Life With Standing Fork, Pacific Palisades" (1996). Lined up on a table are grapes piled high in a reticulated silver basket, a peach on a plate and an old fork standing on its tines. The tip of the fork handle may be roughly aligned with the top of the basket handle, but the balance in the image is off, and the fork improbably standing on tippy toes is too contrived.
But these are only a few minuses in a show that is mesmerizing in its radiant stillness. The highlight is "Still Life With Broken Glass, Amsterdam" (1998), with its superb balancing of textures and the play of light on the various surfaces. On the same table shown in "Still Life With Conch Shell" are a 17th-century drinking glass, a reproduction of which is broken and lies on its side against a metal plate with a single marble on it. Completing the arrangement is a half-peeled lemon, its cut peel spiraling toward a knife.
The anomaly of the broken glass works here, its jagged fragments a textural contrast to the whimsical curl of the lemon peel. Adding a mysterious note is the reflection on the intact drinking glass, which seems to indicate a long room with windows on either side.
While Mr. Mellor's still lifes show the influence of Josef Sudek, a number of whose still lifes are on view in a separate section of the gallery, four of Mr. Mellor's assemblages included in this exhibition can be said to be a homage to Frederick Sommer, one of this century's most inventive photographers. Like Sommer, Mr. Mellor photographs images he has created by combining elements from assorted materials, including old etchings and found objects like pieces of wood or plaster. Like Sommer's surreal assemblages, Mr. Mellor's are puzzling at first sight and require close study.
"Les Taurocathaspies, Bryn Mawr" (1997) includes segments from an etching of boys on horses and bulls. Because the long and narrow print was too large for Mr. Mellor's 8-by-10 view camera, he first cut the etching into strips. Two years later, in an abandoned church in Greece, he found a piece of wood whose painted surface had long disappeared. The etching strips he wanted in his image fitted exactly on the piece of wood.
The Sommeresque energy is very evident in "Les Taurocathaspies," which shows the boys and their animals seemingly riding upward on a rugged terrain. While boys and animals are bathed in a light that is broken into shards, all about them is a murky abstraction of black splotches interspersed here and there with light gray parallel lines.
Two 1996 companion pieces, also using fragments from etchings, are "Apollo, Bryn Mawr" and "Last Judgment, Bryn Mawr," which powerfully sum up the story of Marsyas, a skilled flutist, challenging Apollo to a contest and losing. As punishment, Apollo had Marsyas skinned alive. Against a beautifully floating background of indeterminate materials, the Greek god in "Apollo" is wildly triumphant, almost flying out of the picture, as a foot steps out of one backdrop into another. By contrast, Marsyas in "Last Judgment" is a ghostly and blurred figure. Behind him is a large X formed by the assembled portraits of nightmarish faces that fill the rest of the image.
These assemblages may seem radically different from the still lifes. But both draw their inspiration from Old Master subjects, and both are visual deceptions that reveal themselves only if the viewer takes the time to stop and look.
"D. W. Mellor: In Situ" remains at the Yancey Richardson Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, through Feb. 20.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 28; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2221 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin). 

* "ANOTHER DAY IN PARADISE," starring James Woods and Melanie Griffith. Directed by Larry Clark (R, 101 minutes). From the director of the bruising and ominous "Kids," this vibrant, unapologetically seedy road movie is a virtual day at the beach. Mr. Clark's second feature may not have the sting of his first, but it comes closer to establishing him as William S. Burroughs with a swooping, pivoting movie camera, bringing bizarrely innocent enthusiasm to material that might otherwise ooze druggy shock value, and making decadence as basic as the weather. Mr. Woods, as a junkie, thief and absurdly unlikely father figure, revels in this full-throttle role (Maslin).
 
"AT FIRST SIGHT," starring Val Kilmer and Mira Sorvino. Directed by Irwin Winkler (PG-13, 128 minutes). In this overlong and often desperately banal version of a case study reported by Dr. Oliver Sacks, Mr. Kilmer plays a man whose nearly lifelong blindness was suddenly alleviated by surgery. Ms. Sorvino plays the bright-eyed New York career woman who falls in love with him, then urges him to change his once-peaceful life. But the film brings little more than case-study data to communicating how this man's restored sight affected him, or what made it a mixed blessing. Sample dialogue: "Have you ever listened to the rain? I mean, really listened?" (Maslin).
 
* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
* "A CIVIL ACTION," starring John Travolta and Robert Duvall. Directed by Steven Zaillian (PG-13, 120 minutes). This story of a David-Goliath lawsuit against industrial polluters, with Mr. Travolta first-rate as an ambulance chaser who develops a conscience, could have been business as usual in the legal thriller genre. But Mr. Zaillian's keenly observed, beautifully acted film, based on Jonathan Harr's nonfiction best seller about a case in Woburn, Mass., doesn't follow familiar formulas. It follows all the surprises and frustrations of a story that was never black and white and is all the better for its shades of gray. Mr. Duvall is outstanding as a corporate lawyer full of wily tricks (Maslin).
 
* "GODS AND MONSTERS," starring Ian McKellen and Brendan Fraser. Directed by Bill Condon (not rated, 105 minutes). In a performance that well deserves to be remembered at Academy Award time, Mr. McKellen becomes the deliciously urbane James Whale, depicting the gay "Frankenstein" director late in life. Shaken by the aftereffects of a mild stroke, this Whale finds his past coming back to greet him just as the present offers new fascination in the Adonis-like form of the gardener (Mr. Fraser, also fine), whom Whale finds mowing his lawn. This beautifully acted, witty and heart-tugging film, from a Christopher Bram book, imagines what Whale's final days might have been like while shaping a splendid character study and a droll portrait of closeted gay Hollywood. Lynn Redgrave provides ballast and comic relief as Whale's perpetually scandalized housekeeper (Maslin).
 
* "HILARY AND JACKIE," starring Emily Watson and Rachel Griffiths. Directed by Anand Tucker (R, 121 minutes). The parallel biographies of the brilliant cellist Jacqueline du Pre (Ms. Watson), who contracted multiple sclerosis at the height of her career, and her slightly older sister, Hilary (Ms. Griffiths), a talented flutist who gave up a professional career to marry and be "ordinary," is one of the most insightful studies of sibling rivalry ever filmed. Jacqueline may have won fame and glory, the movie says, but she remained a desperately needy emotional child who had to have everything Hilary had (including Hilary's husband). The film is structured like a concerto, in three movements, the last of which ends with Jackie's harrowing death in her sister's arms. The drama is deepened by a soundtrack that makes expert use of Jacqueline's signature piece, the Elgar Cello Concerto in E minor. Ms. Watson's Jacqueline flames with an almost scary intensity (Stephen Holden).
 
* "MY NAME IS JOE," starring Peter Mullan and Louise Goodall. Directed by Ken Loach (R, 92 minutes). A splendid, feisty performance by Mr. Mullan energizes this film about a recovering alcoholic trying to rebuild his life. With humor and scrappy intensity, Joe throws himself into coaching young athletes and embarking tenuously on a love affair, only to find the expected challenges to his new sobriety everywhere. Mr. Loach's commitment to delineating social issues is accentuated by the way his star breathes life into Joe and makes viewers root for his success. Special bonus: this film breaks the brogue-and-burr barrier by including helpful subtitles for the overlapping, heavily Scottish-accented dialogue (Maslin).
 
"PATCH ADAMS," starring Robin Williams and Monica Potter. Directed by Tom Shadyac (PG-13, 110 minutes). As a maverick doctor intent on making terminal patients laugh, Mr. Williams delivers a little clowning and a lot of maudlin feel-good sentiment, along with vulgarity left over from the filmmaker's "Ace Ventura" days. He also spends a lot of time being congratulated for his good works, as the film's minor players are kept busy marveling at his antics. The real-life story of this doctor may sound like a fine excuse for Mr. Williams to cut loose, but the film version proves narrow and predictable. Ms. Potter, with a nostrilly resemblance to Julia Roberts, figures in a romantic subplot with a bizarre twist (Maslin).
 
"PAYBACK," starring Mel Gibson and Gregg Henry. Directed by Brian Helgeland (R, 110 minutes). In this inept, excessively sadistic film-noir spoof adapted from the same Richard Stark novel ("The Hunter") that inspired the 1967 genre classic "Point Black," Mr. Gibson is a thief named Porter who retaliates with a vengeance after an attempt on his life. Determined to recover $70,000 that was stolen from him by a double-crossing partner in crime, he works his way up the pecking order of a crime syndicate brutally dispatching all who stand in his way. The hard-boiled dialogue is ludicrous, the storytelling clunky, the acting fair to awful, the gore ankle-deep. Credit the star with being able to keep a straight face through this loathsome mess (Holden).
 
* "THE PRINCE OF EGYPT," starring the voices of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Brenda Chapman, Steve Hickner and Simon Wells (PG, 93 minutes). First came the great expectations for this animated magnum opus from Dreamworks. Then came reality, in a film struggling mightily to balance animated whimsy and biblical stature. The upshot is an admirably worthy rendering of the Exodus story, even if Moses must initially be seen as a playful young scamp. Biblical plagues and miracles serve as special inspiration for the animators' reality-bending ingenuity (Maslin).
 
* "RUSHMORE," starring Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray and Olivia Williams. Directed by Wes Anderson (R, 93 minutes). A dryly hilarious portrait of the mogul as a young man, with Mr. Schwartzman a real find as its perfectly horrid little hero, Max Fischer. Max's prep school, Rushmore Academy, does have a faculty, but none of the grown-ups have anything like Max's natural authority. Mr. Murray is sneakily fine as the steel tycoon and Rushmore benefactor who happens to be on Max's own wavelength as they vie for the same beautiful teacher. A particular treat for its skewed, outrageously funny memories of a cutthroat boyhood (Maslin).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today, and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "A SIMPLE PLAN," starring Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 120 minutes). This onetime cult horror director makes a flawless transition to mainstream storytelling with a quietly devastating thriller. And its fine cast plays out the consequences of a harmless-sounding error in judgment that winds up leveling everything in its path. The catalyst is $4.4 million that literally falls out of the sky, and Scott B. Smith's story proves how deadly the morality of expediency can become. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale, which features an especially memorable performance from Mr. Thornton, it won't be from the cold (Maslin).
 
"STEPMOM," starring Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Ed Harris. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG-13, 120 minutes). A man's ex-wife and new girlfriend lock horns over who can be nicer to his two children, in a sudsy story made livelier by its two female stars, both in appealingly high gear. Ms. Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black to a downtown photo shoot, while the especially fiery Ms. Sarandon plays the suburban mother as mama lion. Even when the prospect of mortality looms, the story manages to maintain its big, lavish look and peculiar (under the circumstances) sense of fun. As in "Home Alone," Mr. Columbus directs with sunny indifference to reality, medical, economic or otherwise (Maslin).
 
"THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte and Sean Penn. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: no one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"UNIVERSAL HITCHCOCK." Devotees of Alfred Hitchcock probably already have the 32-cent postage stamp bearing his likeness. This year, on Aug. 13 (it is, appropriately, a Friday), they can buy a cake, light candles and wish him a happy 100th birthday, even though he has been dead since 1980. And beginning today, admirers of the master of cinematic suspense can celebrate his centennial in the best possible way, by means of a five-week 13-film series at Film Forum. Starting off with a two-week run of the 1960 "Psycho," the series will include such other classics as "Shadow of a Doubt" (1943), "The Man Who Knew Too Much" (1955), "Rope" (1948), "Marnie" (1964), "Vertigo" (1958), "Saboteur" (1942) and "The Birds" (1963). The series features all new 35-millimeter prints, a result of Universal Pictures's continuing restoration program. The series continues through March 18 at Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village. Tickets: $8.50; $4.50 for members. Screening information: (212) 727-8110 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: Despite Brisk Sales, G.M. Won't Reach Market Goals

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
General Motors' top North American executive said today that a long-promised sharp rebound in the company's market share in the United States would not be possible this year if the industry's sales continued at their torrid pace because G.M. could not produce enough full-sized pickup trucks to meet demand.
The acknowledgment of G.M.'s difficulties is an unusual example of how the prosperity of the American economy combined with low energy prices has actually created problems for some companies. G.M. simply cannot make enough big V8 engines to build all the full-sized pickup trucks it needs to meet its market-share goals at a time of near-record auto sales and record light-truck sales, said Ronald Zarrella, the president of G.M.'s North American operations. 
 G.M.'s market share has been falling for more than two decades and even edged below 30 percent last year, a serious problem for a company that has the factory capacity to supply 35 percent of the American market. Mr. Zarrella and other G.M. executives vowed late last year to reverse this long fall and set a goal of 32 percent of the market this year.
But Ronald Zarrella, G.M.'s president for North American automotive operations, told reporters at the Chicago Auto Show this afternoon that if the market remained at a brisk, seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16 million vehicles, a 32 percent market share would not be possible.
But Mr. Zarrella said low gasoline prices, which help sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, were still better than high gasoline prices, which help sales of G.M.'s low-profit cars, for which it has a lot of extra production capacity. If gasoline prices rose, he said: "There'd be positives in terms of market share and lots of negatives in terms of profitability. Given a choice, I'd prefer the profitability."
Unlike the Ford Motor Company or DaimlerChrysler A.G., G.M. still has the bulk of its factories set up to produce cars rather than light trucks, a category including sport utility vehicles and minivans as well as pickup trucks.
Mr. Zarrella also announced a new technology for dashboard-mounted air bags, while saying that some rival auto makers were selling cars with side air bags that posed an unacceptably high risk of injuring or killing small children.
G.M.'s new technology involves a sensor pad that will be inserted in the front-seat cushions on the passenger side of family vehicles over the next several years. If the sensor pad senses a child seat or a person weighing less than 66 pounds in the front seat, the vehicle's front air bag will not deploy on the passenger side. While air bags have saved the lives of 3,800 Americans over the last decade, they have killed 125 children and short adults.
Mr. Zarrella said that G.M. thinks children younger than 12 should always be in the back seat, but many are not.
Robert Lange, G.M.'s safety director, said that German luxury auto makers were installing side air bags that inflated with such force that they could injure a toddler who was not using a seat belt or a child safety seat and who was sleeping against the door. G.M.'s side air bags have been designed for a year not to inflate fully if someone is sitting in their path; they have vents that allow some of the air to escape instead.
Mercedes-Benz and BMW A.G. officials said that their side air bags were safe. They pointed out that no children had been killed by their side air bags, which Mr. Lange acknowledged.

HEADLINE: Hearst and Miramax to Split Cost of Tina Brown Magazine

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
Hearst Magazines and Miramax Films announced yesterday that they had agreed to publish Talk magazine, with Tina Brown as editor, as a joint venture.
The move will pit Ms. Brown against her former Conde Nast colleagues Graydon Carter and David Remnick in a battle for readership and advertising dollars. Mr. Carter replaced Ms. Brown as editor in chief of Vanity Fair when she left for The New Yorker. Mr. Remnick, editor of The New Yorker, was hired by Ms. Brown as a staff writer there. 
 The partnership between Miramax Films, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, and Hearst Magazines signals a shift for the giant, no-frills publisher known for producing magazines with a broad appeal like Popular Mechanics, Mr. Food and Cosmopolitan. Hearst will now be able to boast an editor known for clinking glasses at the Four Seasons and generating buzz.
Under the agreement, Hearst Magazines -- which publishes 19 magazines in the United States, including Good Housekeeping, Harper's Bazaar and Victoria -- will be responsible for the nuts and bolts of Talk: circulation, manufacturing, newsstand distribution, direct-mail efforts and subscription fulfillment. Talk Media, the parent company, which will still be owned by Miramax, will provide editorial content, advertising sales and marketing. Other divisions of Talk Media will eventually develop television programming and publish books, though details remain vague.
Hearst's partnership is limited to the magazine and its Web site. Executives on both sides of the deal said that start-up costs for the magazine would be around $50 million, costs that would be evenly shared by Hearst and Miramax. By joining with Hearst, Miramax reduces its risk in a business with low profit margins. It can also take advantage of Hearst's reader data base, economies of scale and bundled advertising packages.
Ms. Brown and Ron Galotti, Talk's publisher, both have personal equity stakes in the venture and will share in any profits, though to what extent is not clear.
Ms. Brown said that the first issue of Talk, which will sell for $2.95, would arrive in August. Ms. Brown would not discuss specific editorial content, but said that she had assembled "a staff of future stars."
She added, "Readers want intelligence and cachet, and they're the same audience that loved 'Pulp Fiction' and 'Shakespeare in Love.' " (Both movies were produced and distributed by Miramax.)
Media buyers said Talk was guaranteed to attract a flurry of attention -- "just because of who's behind the magazine," said Ellen Oppenheim, the media director of Foote, Cone & Belding New York. "The hard part is that we don't know what the continuing editorial vision will be."
With little information available to advertising agencies, media buyers are speculating that Mr. Galotti, armed with the contacts he nurtured when he was publisher of Vogue, may be going directly to the chief executive officers of companies that will advertise in the magazine.
There is also a concern among media buyers that Talk will be a direct competitor for ad pages with Vanity Fair and The New Yorker. Alan Jurmain, the media director at Lowe & Partners/SMS, said Talk would be going after "an audience -- the intelligentsia, the literati, whatever label you want to use -- where the pickings are already relatively slim."
The partnership also raises the question of differing fiscal sensibilities. Hearst is not the kind of corporation that dispenses lavish editorial salaries, nor will it send an editors' luggage overnight by Federal Express, as Conde Nast has done in the past for editors who hate carry-ons. Ms. Brown raised the bar on magazine publishing expenses at The New Yorker. By the time she left the magazine, The New Yorker was losing more money each year than when she started, but it was also generating more buzz.

HEADLINE: MCI Worldcom and E.D.S. Form an Alliance

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
In a complex transaction, MCI Worldcom said yesterday that it would sell its computer-services business to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation for $1.65 billion as part of a broader alliance between the companies that involves up to $15.5 billion in revenue over the next decade.
The agreement has four main elements. First, MCI Worldcom will pay E.D.S. $5 billion to $7 billion over the 10-year contract to run its computer systems. In exchange, E.D.S. will pay MCI Worldcom $6 billion to $8.5 billion over the same period to handle its telephone services. 
 The third part is the acquisition by E.D.S. of MCI Systemhouse, an information technology services provider in Ottawa, for $1.65 billion in cash. Finally, E.D.S. and MCI Worldcom will cooperate on offering new kinds of communications and data services, including electronic business applications.
Jeffrey Heller, the president and chief operating officer of E.D.S., said in a telephone interview that the company had been seeking a closer relationship with a large telecommunications provider for some time. "We use, in support of our customers, a lot of telecommunications services, so we need access to the latest technology in the communications business, at the lowest price," he said. "It behooves us to have a closer relationship with somebody."
Mr. Heller said MCI was the most attractive potential partner because it has its own global data and communications network and is growing rapidly. The acquisition of Systemhouse was a further benefit, because it will make E.D.S. one of the largest information technology services providers in Canada, where it has not had a significant presence.
John Sidgmore, MCI Worldcom's vice chairman, said the company had considered acquiring another systems integrator, including E.D.S., to augment Systemhouse but had decided on this deal instead. "We were trying to find a partner that could provide us with world-class information technology," he said. "It was kind of a no-brainer, picking E.D.S. We just believe on faith that they can run computer systems better than us, and I know we can run communications systems more efficiently."
Although the deal appears complex, "both companies are going to wind up doing what they do best," Mr. Sidgmore said. "Even though there are billions of dollars changing hands here, at the end of the day, each company is going to be executing its core business."
The companies said that they expected more than 12,000 employees, primarily in the United States and Canada, to move to E.D.S. from MCI Worldcom and Systemhouse. About 1,000 E.D.S. employees will be offered jobs with MCI Worldcom.
Analysts said this deal, coupled with a similar arrangement between I.B.M. and the AT&T Corporation in December, could put pressure on competitors, like the Computer Sciences Corporation, in information technology, and the Sprint Corporation, in telecommunications, to form a partnership of their own.
Separately, MCI Worldcom reported fourth-quarter earnings of $428 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, compared with $95 million, or 10 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue quadrupled, to $8 billion from $2 billion.
Analysts expected MCI to earn 22 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Results have been consolidated to reflect the merger of MCI and Worldcom last year and MCI's 19 percent economic interest in Embratel Participacoes S.A., Brazil's national communications provider.
Shares of MCI Worldcom shares rose $4.1875, to $80.4375, in Nasdaq trading. E.D.S. closed at $48.3125, up $2.4375 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: New Owners of Barney's Lack Experience

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
When Barney's Inc., the high-end retailer whose Barneys New York stores turned basic black pants into a uniform of Manhattan chic, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in early 1996, it did not take long for two types of investors to swoop in.
There were other retailers, who were itching to buy the prestigious name. Saks Fifth Avenue offered $290 million in 1997 for its archrival. Dickson Poon, a Hong Kong entrepreneur whose Dickson Concepts also owns Britain's Harvey Nichols department store, bid $280 million. Last year, the DFS Group, no stranger to luxury goods through its many airport duty-free shops, also flirted with the company, valuing it roughly the same as Mr. Poon. 
 The other interested parties were so-called vultures -- investors who acquire a distressed company's unpaid bills in secondary markets in hopes of collecting more later. The Barney's vultures ended up as its largest creditors, rejecting the bids from the retailers as inadequate.
So, as Barney's emerges from bankruptcy this month, control of the purveyor of Jil Sander suits and $300 T-shirts belongs to two vulture groups, Whippoorwill Associates of White Plains and Bay Harbour Management of New York. The Pressman family, who founded and ran Barney's for most of the century, has more or less left. Even more critically, the management team that turned the company's balance sheet around is leaving this spring.
Now that the vultures have laid claim to Barney's, what have they gotten for their money? While highly successful as buyers of distressed debt, the investors have no experience running a specialty retailer. And that won't be easy.
The company's chief executive, Thomas Shull, is departing because the new owners want a "growth chief executive," said Doug Teitlebaum of Bay Harbour. Mr. Teitlebaum and David Strumwasser, who heads Whippoorwill, together control about 70 percent of the company.
Leaving with Mr. Shull is the chief financial officer, Edward Lambert, and Paul Jen, the head of marketing, all from Meridian Ventures, a turnaround specialist. Shari Gregerman, head of stores, also left recently.
Gene Pressman, who shared the chairmanship of Barney's with his brother Bob, has packed up his office even though he has a two-year consulting contract. His wife, Bonnie, who ran the women's business, is now an executive at Polo/Ralph Lauren. Bob Pressman, who helped work out the deal with the vultures, is no longer involved in day-to-day operations. All this has drained the company of much high-octane talent.
"Vultures are much better at going in and very quickly making a decision than traditional creditors," said Jeff Manning, a managing director of Rodman & Renshaw, a New York investment bank. "But there are very few of these distressed investors who you really want to see operating your companies."
What is more, the investors now have to prove they can deliver the goods, because their deal actually valued the company at less than what the retailing bidders offered. The two bought the majority stake at $240 million, betting that a brighter future would let them unload Barney's for considerably more later.
"Dickson wanted to buy the company because he thought he could make a profit," Mr. Teitlebaum said. "We think we can make it more profitable. Why sell it at a low price and leave the future value for someone else?"
Mr. Teitlebaum originally bought the Barney's claims for roughly 30 cents on the dollar, and Mr. Strumwasser's purchases averaged about 50 cents. They expect their investment to rise substantially but, at least judging from the market for remaining trade claims -- now selling at about 15 cents on the dollar -- they are wildly optimistic.
At best, many analysts say, Barney's may not be worth much more for quite a while. Mr. Shull did much to turn around the troubled merchant. Many of its money-losing smaller stores were shuttered, leaving the company with seven stores and 11 off-price outlets. He cut the company's sizable debt and took advantage of its credit card list for marketing purposes.
"I feel strongly about the team that worked hard to create all this value," Mr. Shull said. "We shifted the priority from a focus on the image to making money."
But Barney's also faces a huge bill simply for rent. The company built its three flagship Barneys New York stores -- one on Madison Avenue, the others in Chicago and Beverly Hills, Calif. -- with the help of the Isetan Company of Japan, its partner in the 1980's. Barney's and Isetan later had a falling-out concerning who owned the stores; that dispute was at the core of the bankruptcy case.
Isetan won the dispute and is supposed to receive, in addition to some cash and a small equity stake, $15 million a year in rent -- about 7 percent of today's sales. Compared with the roughly 4.5 percent Saks pays for its rent and the 2.8 percent at Neiman Marcus, that is a hefty fixed cost for a company that relies on a strong stock market and booming economy to keep its affluent clients coming through the doors.
Already, sales at Barneys New York average roughly $575 a square foot, almost double that of most other specialty retailers. Some analysts question just how much more can be squeezed out.
Under the reorganization plan, sales in stores open at least one year are projected to grow about 5 percent a year during the next five years. Sales at existing Barney's stores grew 10 percent in 1998 -- an exceptionally strong number -- but how will the company top that? Maintaining even half that pace will be quite a challenge, especially without a new merchandising genius.
The pool of talented merchants is not terribly deep. Saks, for example, has yet to replace its president, Rose Marie Bravo, who left in 1997.
Mr. Teitlebaum said that the company could prosper without bringing in another top merchant. "You can't get caught up with titles," he said. "Barney's has a team culture. We have all the players on the field, and to me that is hugely significant."
It looks as if he will get a chance to test that thinking. None of those interested in Barney's before seem interested in buying it now.
Mr. Poon has not made new overtures and Myron E. Ullman 3d, the chairman of DFS, suggested that he saw no reason to pay more than his first bid. "I think," he said last week, "that we made a sound decision."

HEADLINE: Clinton to Propose More Generous Policy for the Disabled

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will propose a more generous policy on Friday regarding the payment of cash benefits to disabled people under Social Security, Administration officials said today.
For the first time in nearly a decade, the Government will propose an increase in the amount of money that people may earn while receiving disability benefits. 
 The limit on earnings is now $500 a month, and it has been at that level since January 1990. The Commissioner of Social Security, Kenneth S. Apfel, will issue a proposed rule increasing the limit to $700, officials said. After reviewing public comments, the Commissioner has the authority to make the change, which would take effect on June 1.
Vice President Al Gore plans to announce the proposal on a visit to Albany on Friday.
"By proposing an increase in the allowable monthly earnings from $500 to $700 a month -- a 40 percent increase -- we are enabling Americans with disabilities to make the most of their abilities," Mr. Gore said in the text of his prepared remarks.
Social Security officials said the change could help 250,000 people a year. Those who receive disability benefits are automatically eligible for Medicare after a two-year waiting period, and for many, the Medicare coverage is even more valuable than the cash benefits.
Among those who sought the change is Tipper Gore, the Vice President's wife. Since the early 1980's, she has been a zealous advocate for people with mental illness and retardation.
Martha E. Ford, a lobbyist for the Arc, formerly known as the Association for Retarded Citizens, welcomed the proposed change.
"This is an important step, long awaited, and it will help a lot of people," Ms. Ford said. "It will make a significant difference for lower-income workers who are severely disabled and need continued support."
Ms. Ford said the change would benefit many people with disabilities who work at food service jobs or at entry-level positions in supermarkets and retail stores. Disabled workers earning $500 to $700 a month are now ineligible for benefits, but could qualify under the new policy.
The Administration plans to make a similar change in a related program, Supplemental Security Income. The White House said the changes, taken together, would cost the Government $1.2 billion over five years. Social Security benefits for disabled workers now average $733 a month.
Administration officials did not suggest any specific way to pay for the added benefits but said the cost would somehow be covered in the overall context of a balanced budget.
With unemployment now at 4.3 percent, the lowest level in 28 years, many employers have difficulty finding workers, and some say they are more willing to hire people with disabilities. Because of recent increases in the minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, workers with disabilities are more likely to reach the earnings limit of $500 a month.
While people with disabilities have not generally been viewed as a big voting bloc, disability rights have won bipartisan support. President Clinton recently proposed a new tax credit and new health insurance options to help people with disabilities go back to work.
Two Republican Senators, William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware and James M. Jeffords of Vermont, have joined Mr. Clinton in supporting a bill that would expand Medicaid and Medicare so disabled people could retain their health benefits when they return to work. Former Senator Bob Dole, himself a disabled war veteran, urged Congress last week to pass the bill as a way to increase the number of disabled people who work and pay taxes.
Under Federal law, a person is said to be disabled if he or she is unable to engage in "substantial gainful activity" because of a physical or mental impairment that is expected to cause death or to last 12 months or more.
Under the current rules, if a person is earning more than $500 a month (after subtracting certain work expenses), he is considered to be engaging in substantial gainful activity and therefore not disabled.
The ultimate objective of the new policy is to help disabled people get jobs and become self-sufficient.
"If even a small fraction of the people receiving disability benefits could go to work," Mr. Gore said, "we would save billions of dollars in the long run."

HEADLINE: Blighted Promise in Zimbabwe

 BODY:
Few African countries have followed a more disappointing trajectory over the past two decades than Zimbabwe. Once a model of democracy, law and tolerance, this nation of 13 million people is becoming a fearful, militarized autocracy. President Robert Mugabe's latest diatribes against journalists and judges are particularly troubling. Zimbabwe's foreign friends, including the United States, must press Mr. Mugabe to halt this sad slide into tyranny.
The crisis began last month when Zimbabwe's army arrested and tortured two journalists who had reported a failed military coup attempt. Three supreme court justices then called on Mr. Mugabe to affirm the rule of law by reminding the army that it had no right to arrest civilians and that torture by anyone was unacceptable. Instead Mr. Mugabe defended the military's conduct, denounced the press and called on the justices to resign. 
 Independent Zimbabwe, born after guerrilla warfare and international diplomacy ended the injustices of white minority rule, at first embraced a philosophy of racial and social reconciliation. A new Constitution protected minority rights. White farmers were left on their land and even the white former Prime Minister, Ian Smith, retained a seat in Parliament. But as years passed, Mr. Mugabe grew obsessed about threats to his power and began demonizing critics of all varieties.
In the 1980's, his soldiers killed innocent civilians while crushing an insurgency based in the minority Ndebele people. Then he set out to marginalize political opposition groups and create a virtual one-party state. More recently he has turned against white landowners, student groups, labor unions and homosexuals. Official favoritism and corruption have marred his rule at home, while abroad he has sent Zimbabwean troops to prop up Congo's dictator, Laurent Kabila.
Mr. Mugabe should break off this costly and unpopular foreign adventurism and pay attention to Zimbabwe's own pressing needs, including rapidly rising food prices, severe unemployment and an AIDS epidemic now estimated to affect almost one in four adults. The growing economic pressures have brought months of unrest, to which the Government's main response has been repression. Instead of harassing potential opponents, Mr. Mugabe should, at age 74, be making room for new leaders to step forward when his term ends in 2002.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Caldor Set to Begin Out-of-Business Sale

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Caldor Corporation said yesterday that it would receive about $223.7 million from a liquidators' group that will conduct going-out-of-business sales beginning today at its 145 stores.
The $223.7 million payment is based on Caldor's estimate that its inventory is worth $495 million, the company said. Caldor, a discount chain that has been in bankruptcy proceedings since 1995, said last month that it was going out of business, shutting all its discount stores, in nine East Coast states, and putting about 20,000 people out of work. 
 The group that will conduct the going-out-of-business sales includes Gordon Brothers Retail Partners, Schottenstein Bernstein Capital Group and the Ozer Group. The prices on Caldor's merchandise will be reduced between 20 percent and 60 percent, Caldor said.
The amount Caldor is receiving for its inventory is well below the $300 million a lawyer for Caldor's creditors had predicted.
In United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan last month, Martin Bienenstock, a lawyer for Caldor's prebankruptcy lenders, said the creditors thought Caldor could get $300 million for its inventory and $300 million for its real estate.
Wal-Mart Stores has said it bid about $75 million for the rights to 13 Caldor stores, and the Kohl's Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the rights to 33 stores for $142 million.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Soars In Its Biggest One-Day Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Powered by a dramatic rebound in computer-related issues, the Nasdaq soared more than 4 percent yesterday to its biggest one-day point gain ever as investors piled back into beaten-down technology and financial shares.
In the absence of any dominating new developments, analysts cited the cumulative weight of several lesser factors and for once found a public appearance by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to be of little consequence. 
 All major gauges marched steadily higher through the session, with the blue chips of the Dow Jones industrial average posting a gain of 186.15 points, or 2.03 percent, to 9,363.46.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 30.49 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,254.04, and the Nasdaq composite index closed at 2,405.55, up 96.05 points.
"There's a resurgence of interest in the traditional growth areas," said David Dietze, the president of Point View Financial Services. "People are flocking back to the names that did so well coming off the October bottom."
I.B.M., for example, jumped 9 5/8, to 178 1/2, to pace the Dow, followed by Wal-Mart Stores, which was up 4 7/8, to 85 13/16 . Merck was up 4 1/2, to 150 3/4.
But there was also a strong appetite for new issues, with three initial public offerings more than doubling, the first such "triple double" on record, according to the Securities Data Company.
Among the reasons for the stock surge was a projection by Compaq Computer of strong sales to long-depressed Asian markets this year and a better-than-expected profit report from American International Group, an insurance company that boasts the biggest market capitalization of any purely financial company.
Compaq shares climbed 2 7/16 , to 44 13/16 , while American International rose 7 3/4, to 106 1/2.
Other analysts pointed to the approaching end of the impeachment trial of President Clinton and the no-news-is-good-news nature of Mr. Greenspan's Congressional appearance.
The Fed chairman told the House Banking and Financial Services Committee that he backed a bill that would make it easier for financial services companies to combine their businesses. He also said the move would help the nation's economy remain strong.
"I don't think there's any real reason" for the rally, said George Cohen, a principal at Cohen Klingenstein & Marks. "We just released some of the anxiety we'd built up."
But technology -- the subject of a Goldman, Sachs conference in New York this week that was said to lift the mood of specialists -- was the main attraction. The Nasdaq 100, even more heavily concentrated in computer-oriented stocks than the Nasdaq composite, leaped 5.17 percent led by gains of 6 5/16 for Cisco Systems, 4 7/16 for Intel, 5 7/8 for Oracle, 4 7/8 for Dell Computer, 2 1/8 for Microsoft, 16 1/8 for Yahoo and 12 7/16 for Amazon.com.
"There's a tremendous appetite on the part of investors to keep playing the growth story," said Eric M. Wiegand, a senior portfolio manager at First Union in Philadelphia.
The Nasdaq gain of 96.05 points was the biggest since the index was first compiled in 1971. This came just two days after the index's third-biggest point decline.
Among banks and other financial companies, American Express, Merrill Lynch and Charles Schwab each jumped 4 points or more.
Oil stocks were about the only prominent losers, with Royal Dutch Petroleum reporting worse than expected profits and Salomon Smith Barney cutting its 1999 estimate for Exxon, which fell 2 3/16 , to 70 3/8.
The strongest new issues were Healtheon, which marketed 5 million shares at 8 and closed at 31 3/8; Verticalnet, which sold 3.5 million shares at 16 and closed at 45 3/8, and Prodigy Communications, which sold 8 million shares at 15 and traded as high as 32 before closing at 28 1/8.
Two other initial public offerings were largely neglected. Gabelli Asset Management's 6 million shares edged up to 17 13/16 , from 17, while Korn/Ferry International's 11.75 million shares wound up at 13, a point below the offering price.

Bond Prices Unchanged
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Bond prices were unchanged yesterday after the highest yields in three months drew investors to the Treasury's sale of $10 billion of new 30-year debt, capping $35 billion of United States note and bond sales this week.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Surge in Low-Income Apartments in the Bronx

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
Some of the last vacant lots on streets in two neighborhoods of the South Bronx are filling with rental apartment buildings for people earning no more than $24,000 a year.
Among the new buildings are three projects recently completed or under way that together will produce 242 studio to two-bedroom rental apartments, each with 450 to 850 square feet. The units, which will rent for $380 to $580 a month, are in buildings not far from the East Tremont Avenue shopping district, on Hughes and Crotona Avenues in the Belmont section and on Jennings Street in Crotona Park, 15 blocks away. 
 The projects, each six to nine stories high and estimated to cost between $9 million and $12 million, are being developed by the Atlantic Development Group of Manhattan. They are being kept affordable to low-income tenants through a combination of Federal, state and city programs; one important element is the city's 421a tax certificate program.
Under this program, builders of modest-income housing receive transferable tax abatement certificates from the city for each low-income unit they build, certificates that can be sold to developers of market-rate housing in mid-Manhattan. By buying the certificates, the market-rate developers can reduce property taxes on their new buildings.
The strong luxury housing demand in Manhattan has helped to spur residential construction in lower-income neighborhoods. "The 421a certificate program expands the building boom in the city by leveraging the demand for market-rate housing to stimulate the production of needed low-income housing," said Russell A. Harding, president to the New York City Housing Development Corporation, which arranges financing for city-assisted housing.
For instance, proceeds from the sale of the certificates have helped finance about a dozen low-income projects that his agency alone worked on in the last year. Those projects together are to produce 805 low-income rental apartments, of which 545 units are to be in the Bronx, including the 242 rentals Atlantic is developing.
"The reality is that the huge demand for one-bedroom apartments that rent for $2,500 a month in Manhattan enables us to build the same size apartment in the Bronx and rent it out for $500," said Peter Fine, a principal at Atlantic Development.
Still, making the economics work in building new housing for those with lower incomes requires several financing sources. To build its three Bronx projects, which total about $29 million, Atlantic received $18 million in tax-exempt bond financing through the Housing Development Corporation and sold Federal tax credits amounting to $10 million to corporations or individuals who use the credits to reduce their income-tax liability. Atlantic then sold 1,200 tax certificates from the projects, raising $18 million to repay the construction loan. The company also invested $1 million of its own equity into the projects.
"It is like a giant jigsaw puzzle," Mr. Fine said. "The art is figuring out how to make all the pieces jibe."
The three new buildings are taking shape on what not long ago were empty, rubble-strewn lots. Atlantic bought two of the lots at a city auction and the third from a private owner, said Marc Altheim, another Atlantic principal.
In the last several years, more than 1,000 for-sale and rental units in one- to three-family homes have risen in the area. The projects are part of New York City's New Homes program, whose sponsors include the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the nonprofit New York City Housing Partnership, which serves as an intermediary between the city and private developers. Hundreds of additional units are planned for the neighborhoods.
A new elementary school opened on Arthur Avenue, two blocks from Atlantic's recently completed 72-unit building at 2111 Hughes Avenue, between 180th and 181st Streets. And a public field at the corner of Hughes Avenue and 181st Street is being refurbished.
Those factors encouraged Atlantic to move forward with its projects, Mr. Altheim said. He said 1,400 people responded to the lottery held last June for apartments in his company's Hughes Avenue building. Tenants started moving into that building earlier this month.
Among them is Diosa Santana, 45, who relocated from an apartment she shared with her daughter elsewhere in the Bronx to a studio in the building, ending her 18-month search for a new place to live.
Miss Santana, who works at a printing company in downtown Manhattan, said she had been frustrated by her search because most of the apartments she looked at were out of her economic reach. At one point, she said, she even considered renting a furnished room. "Now, I can breathe a little easier," she said of her new apartment. "It's safe and comfortable and gives people like me who don't make a lot of money an opportunity."
Mr. Altheim said lotteries would be held in April for apartments in the other two buildings that his company is constructing and expects to complete early this fall. One, with 86 units, is at 2130 Crotona Avenue, at the corner of 181st Street; the other, with 84 units, is at 950 Jennings Street, between Hoe and Vyse Avenues.
The community sponsor for all three projects is Health Industry Resources Enterprises, or HIRE, a local nonprofit organization. "The appearance of the new buildings enhances the neighborhoods, where there is a lack of decent housing for low-income tenants," said Alfred Argano, the group's executive director.
All three rental structures have been designed by the Manhattan architectural firm of Meltzer/Mandl and are clad with brick and a stuccolike material called drivet. Each building will have such amenities as an interior courtyard and community and laundry rooms.

HEADLINE: Parachute for Pilots

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
The thousands of American Airlines pilots who have called in sick as part of a messy labor standoff have adopted a time-honored union tactic -- a sort of strike without striking.
For the angry workers, such a tactic has some advantages. For one thing, it enables unions to shut down much of their employers' operations when they would otherwise be barred from striking under an existing contract, as is the case with the American pilots. 
 And, yes, there is another big advantage: While calling in sick, the pilots, members of the Allied Pilots Association, continue to get paid, something that would not happen if they went on strike.
"If it works, it's great," said Julius Getman, a labor law professor at the University of Texas. "All unions are looking around for ways to apply pressure that don't involve the dangers and losses of strikes."
While the sickout seems to be working well so far for the pilots' union, it has one major downside -- it greatly inconveniences and angers passengers, who, of course, are the lifeblood of any airline.
Union sickouts occur perhaps as frequently as an influenza outbreak. Every few years, New York City police, knowing they are barred from striking, catch the "blue flu." Last Christmas, several hundred flight attendants at Trans World Airlines called in sick. And several American Airlines pilots recall taking part in much smaller sickouts during the last two decades.
"It's as old as the hills," said David Walkowitz, a labor historian at New York University. "It's a way of trying to get around government or contract restrictions that would be imposed on strikers."
Fed up that hundreds of pilots have called in sick since Saturday, American Airlines, a unit of AMR, persuaded Judge Joe Kendall of Federal District Court in Dallas to order the pilots on Wednesday to return to work. But the airline and many passengers were stunned yesterday when 2,400 pilots of the airline's 9,200 phoned in sick -- the most of any day since the job action began -- forcing the cancellation of about half of American's flights.
This escalation pointed to another advantage of using sickouts. It is often hard for courts to punish union leaders for fomenting such job actions because sickouts often continue even when union leaders officially ask that they be stopped.
"Labor history demonstrates that sometimes when you violate a judge's order, that helps to build solidarity," Professor Getman said. "Pilots are guys who are basically tough guys. If this injunction builds the union's militancy, it's not at all in American Airlines' interest."
The pilots have called in sick primarily because they are angry about American's recent acquisition of Reno Air, a small Western airline, and the time American plans to take to integrate Reno's operations into its network. But the American pilots have longstanding complaints that previously culminated in an attempted strike two years ago.
Representatives of the pilots' union are expected to appear in court today to explain why the union is not in contempt of Judge Kendall's order. Late yesterday, the union issued a strong plea calling on the pilots to return to work.
"The pilots association is urging all of the pilots in compliance with the temporary restraining order to return to work if they're not sick," said Tom Kachmar, a union spokesman who is also a Dallas-based 767 captain for American. "As far as what each individual pilot is doing, I can't speak to that."
Some labor analysts and American Airlines managers have suggested that the union leaders may be giving a stream of winks and nods to encourage a continued sickout -- something the union denies. Behind the scenes, some company officials are saying a union vice president, Brian A. Mayhew, is responsible.
But Michael Boyd, chief executive of a Colorado-based consulting firm that once advised the union, said: "The union leadership cannot control its rank and file. At this point, it's the grass roots. The company's trying to say that it's Brian Mayhew, that he's the Darth Vader. That's just an orchestrated attack."
Among labor experts, there is agreement that it would be difficult for Judge Kendall to find individual pilots in contempt of his order. The reason: the airline might have to provide proof that pilots who called in sick were actually healthy.
If this tactic is so successful, why is it so rarely used? Most unions have the right to strike and feel no need to resort to sickouts. And the tactic often flops because not enough members are willing to take part.
Several labor experts said shrewd unions tried not to overuse the sickout tactic because it did severe damage to customer relations, thus hurting business and perhaps endangering union members' job security.
Since Saturday, tens of thousands of American passengers have had their travel plans disrupted.
"There's always a downside," said Mr. Boyd, the aviation consultant. "Guess who gets the short end of the stick -- the customer. You can imagine people saying, 'We have summer vacation coming up and we're going to fly United instead.' That's the long-term hurt of this."
