HEADLINE: Hopes for Improved Ties With China Fade

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Seven months after President Clinton's return from a picture-perfect trip to China, the promise of a new era in Chinese-American relations has faded, leaving the Administration grappling with an unexpected round of repression of human rights in China and a mounting perception in Congress that Beijing is threatening American security interests.
The high expectations set by Mr. Clinton in China have run up against a pessimistic tone set by political forces in both countries that Administration officials say are more intent on confrontation than cooperation. 
 Instead of showing signs of progress in its policy of "constructive engagement" with China, the Administration is facing a squall of China-bashing in Congress.
Even American business, which the Administration's China policy has particularly tried to assist and the loudest advocate of closer ties, is complaining about Beijing's new restrictions that the Administration has been unsuccessful modifying.
Stung by a bipartisan Congressional inquiry's findings that China stole sensitive American military technology, Administration officials say they are warily waiting for even more explosive details expected to be announced in March in a declassified report by the members of Congress who headed the inquiry.
And later this month, the Pentagon is expected to send to Congress its long-delayed classified report on security questions in the Taiwan Strait.
Officials and experts who have had sections of the report read to them said the Pentagon would find that in the early 1990's China had 60 missiles pointed at Taiwan but that since then the number has more than doubled. In three years, it predicts, China could have more than 600 missiles on its side of the strait.
That assessment, another Administration official said, is sure to create a "a new wave of calls about the China threat," in the region.
In the face of those obstacles, the Administration says its policy of "constructive engagement" still holds.
In the next two months, before a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on April 8, the Administration will be working hard to find some issue on which the two nations can find common ground, most likely the possibility of China's admission to the World Trade Organization.
Even that common ground may be elusive. As the Chinese economy suffers from slower growth, rising unemployment and stalled economic reforms, the incentive for the Chinese to make trade concessions so they can join the trade organization has diminished, economists say.
"The Administration thought after the Clinton trip that it had come to some tolerable modus vivendi with China," said Jonathan B. Pollack, a defense strategist at the Rand Corporation who recently visited China. "But it doesn't run very deep, there's a clear sense that the underpinnings are very fragile, and there's a very clear potential for a real reversal in the relationship."
The most immediate thorn for the Administration is how to deal with the regression in China's human rights policies in the last two months.
Administration officials argue that they never expected continued improvement in human rights after Mr. Clinton left China in July and that there is "no quick fix," as Harold Koh, the Assistant Secretary of State for human rights, said recently.
But the long prison sentences of 11 to 13 years imposed on three democracy campaigners in December took officials here by surprise.
"Obviously we were are unhappy about the arrests and have said so publicly, and from the President on down privately," said Samuel R. Berger, the President's national security adviser.
Traditionally, the clearest path for the Administration to register its objection to such a crackdown is to sponsor a resolution condemning China at the annual meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva. That is an annual opportunity for countries to record their disquiet at China's human rights policy in a forum that the Chinese authorities take seriously despite its relative obscurity.
Last year, in the face of a seemingly improved human rights climate in China and to the gratification of Beijing, the Administration decided for the first time since 1990 not to offer such a resolution.
But now, in what an official described as almost "insurmountable" pressure from Congress, the Administration is in the midst of a heated debate about whether to reverse last year's course and condemn the Chinese for the crackdown. Such a reversal could be embarrassing for Mr. Clinton, who at the end of his China trip said, "China has the right leadership at the right time."
The White House opposed moving against the Chinese in Geneva, Administration officials said, but became alarmed when a moderate Republican, Representative Doug Bereuter of Nebraska, chairman of the International Relations Subcommittee on Asia, said there would be an "explosion" in Congress if the Administration stayed quiet at Geneva.
Mr. Berger said the White House was now looking at what recommendation to make to Mr. Clinton about the Geneva conference, which starts on March 22 and runs until April 30. Inconveniently for the Administration, Prime Minister Zhu's visit to Washington is scheduled for the middle of the Geneva gathering.
On national security, the Administration faces a confluence of issues that may only intensify the problems in the relationship with China.
At the top of the list is the Administration's proposal, which China has vehemently criticized, to push forward plans for developing a theater missile defense system with Japan, South Korea and possibly Taiwan. The system, which is still in the design stage, has been promoted with new urgency by the Administration since the surprise firing by North Korea of a missile that flew over Japan and into the Pacific in August.
The Administration says the system would protect Japan and South Korea from North Korean missiles, but Taiwan's Government has shown interest in being part of the system, an interest the Administration has not discouraged.
The Chinese have interpreted the recent push on the theater missile defense system as hostile to their interests. A Pentagon official suggested that this was hardly surprising, since the system would affect the "heart of their military posture."
The coming release of a Pentagon report on the system, requested last year by Congress, is likely to heighten the debate. The Chinese have already raised the issue in a way that does not please the Administration.
During a visit to Washington in January, a senior Chinese arms control official, Sha Zukang, warned the Administration that pushing ahead with the missile defense system would sink any chance of China's joining a major international mechanism for controlling the spread of missile technology, the Missile Technology Control Regime. Nations that belong to the regime are bound not to export missile parts.
Mr. Sha made the warning at the same conference at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace where Mr. Berger announced that Washington would like China to join the control regime this year.
From the Administration's point of view, the brightest picture for achieving some progress with the Chinese in time for the Prime Minister's visit appears to be paving the way for China's entry to the World Trade Organization.
Urging China to make concessions so it can join the world's most important trade organization has been the focus of Mr. Clinton's efforts in the last three years to open China economically and politically.
But Western economists assert that this is one of the most inopportune times to be moving China toward the trade group. Instead of easing market access, American corporations complain, China has been tightening the rules for Western investors in the last few months, particularly in telecommunications.
And to belong to the trade organization, China would have to make such fundamental changes as freeing up the distribution system of roads and warehouses, which are now almost entirely in the hands of the military. The American business sector's frustration with the Administration's lack of progress at furthering investment in China is actually as much a frustration with the Chinese who refuse to be as market-oriented as some in business expect.
Mr. Berger said that the Administration wanted to persevere with the W.T.O. issue and that another delegation from the United States Trade Representative's office would go to China soon. He said that even though China was going through economic dislocations, the Chinese would also like to be part of the World Trade Organization before the Taiwanese, who are close to membership.
But he also acknowledged that the Chinese had to face the reality that the only way they could win membership was to make enough concessions to allow United States market access to China and to adhere to the rules of the organization.
"We've always said we would be flexible, but it must be an agreement that is justifiable on market grounds," he said.
Otherwise, Mr. Berger said, there is little chance that Chinese membership will be approved by Congress.

HEADLINE: Judge Rejects Pre-emptive Guilty Plea in a Murder Case

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
Siding with prosecutors, a Dutchess County judge yesterday rejected an attempt by the defendant in a serial murder case to plead guilty and avoid the death penalty.
The judge, Thomas J. Dolan, ruled that the attempt by Kendall L. Francois to plead guilty before the prosecutor announced whether he would seek the death penalty was a premature and unlawful action that would undermine the judicial process. 
 The judge also suggested that if the plea were allowed to go through, he would be endorsing "a race to the courthouse" to enter a guilty plea and "a loss of any meaningful plea bargaining."
Mr. Francois, an unemployed school aide, was arrested last September and charged with murdering eight prostitutes and hiding their decaying remains at his home in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He later confessed to the crimes. And in December, he tried to plead guilty -- with a maximum sentence of life without parole -- before prosecutors even announced whether they would seek the death penalty.
But William V. Grady, the Dutchess County District Attorney, asked the judge to reject the attempt to plead, saying that it was contrary to the spirit of a fresh ruling by the State Court of Appeals that voided most of the plea-bargaining provisions in the state's death penalty law.
Given the tendency of judges to defer to prosecutors in procedural matters relating to criminal cases, the ruling by Judge Dolan did not shock anyone. In a statement, Mr. Grady said that his office was pleased, and in an interview, Randolph F. Treece, a lawyer for Mr. Francois, said that he was disappointed but not surprised. He said he was considering appealing the judge's ruling.
Even without the element of surprise, though, lawyers and legal scholars had been talking for weeks about the issues raised by Mr. Francois's attempted plea, saying that the case was not only a test of the Court of Appeals' recent ruling but that it also exposed weaknesses in the state's death penalty law.
New York is the only state whose death penalty law carries a different maximum punishment for a plea bargain and for a conviction trial. Given that, the Court of Appeals, in considering several unrelated cases, ruled on Dec. 22 that the death penalty law unfairly encouraged defendants to plead guilty rather than risk a death sentence by going to trial.
The next day, Mr. Francois's lawyers tried to enter a guilty plea to all 17 counts of murder and assault in the deaths of the 8 women.
The plea, his lawyers said, was based on their reading of the Court of Appeals ruling to mean that a defendant could plead guilty to the maximum sentence, without prosecutorial consent, before the 120-day window in which prosecutors were given to decide whether to pursue the death penalty had expired.
And many lawyers -- including the president of the New York State District Attorneys Association -- hinted that they agreed with that interpretation.
But Mr. Grady disagreed, and he announced on Dec. 24 that he would seek the death penalty.
In yesterday's ruling, Judge Dolan -- who, prior to his election in 1992 had worked for 20 years as an assistant district attorney in Dutchess County -- dismissed the defendant's "narrow, technical interpretation" as one that would render existing law "totally ineffective and meaningless."
As a result, the only time it would be possible for Mr. Francois to plead guilty would be if -- and only if -- the District Attorney decides to seek the death penalty and then later withdraws that notice, Judge Dolan wrote -- a set of circumstances that is a remote possibility.
Opponents of the death penalty said that they were discouraged, even baffled, by Judge Dolan's decision, saying that it would be even more difficult for murder defendants to receive a fair trial.
"The judge is turning legislative intent totally on its head, and he is turning the logic of the Court of Appeals on its head," said Ronald J. Tabak, president of New York Lawyers Against the Death Penalty, who added that the judge had misinterpreted the Appeals Court's decision.
In Poughkeepsie, meanwhile, reaction was muted, and somewhat apprehensive about the prospect of a trial.
Many relatives of Mr. Francois's victims, for instance, had urged Judge Dolan to toss out the plea, saying that they wanted to see Mr. Francois tried and executed. But Patricia A. Barone, whose daughter, Gina, was one of Mr. Francois's victims, earlier wrote to Judge Dolan urging him to accept the guilty plea to "stop all this publicity" and avert a protracted trial saturated with grisly details.
Yesterday, Ms. Barone seemed resigned about the judge's decision. "It's all right, it's done," she said. "He has his legitimate reasons and I had mine. I had the interests of people who are alive at heart, rather than revenge for Gina's death."
She added, bitterly, that she would never attend Mr. Francois's trial.

HEADLINE: Big Insurer Posts 14% Increase in Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
American International Group Inc., the largest United States insurer by market value, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings grew 14 percent, driven by profit from derivatives trading and other financial services traditionally dominated by securities firms and banks.
Earnings without gains on investments rose to $989.7 million, or 94 cents a diluted share, from $870.8 million, or 83 cents, in the period a year earlier. Its stock climbed 8 percent, its biggest gain in almost four months, as the New York-based company's profit exceeded analysts' estimates. 
 The company's chairman and chief executive, Maurice Greenberg, has turned American International, an insurer founded in Shanghai in 1919, into one of the world's biggest financial companies by getting into businesses like trading derivatives that hedge against changes in interest rates and currency values, and leasing aircraft.
Shares of American International rose $7.75, to $106.50, in trading of 4.7 million shares, more than twice the daily average in the last three months.

HEADLINE: Boston Scientific to Eliminate 2,000 Jobsas It Cuts Capacity

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NATICK, Mass., Feb. 11

 BODY:
The Boston Scientific Corporation will eliminate 2,000 jobs, or 18 percent of its work force, over the next year as the company cuts capacity duplicated by its acquisition of Schneider Worldwide.
The changes will cost Boston Scientific about $62 million, mostly in severance and related expenses, company officials said today. 
 About $36 million of the costs were included on the company's books in the purchase price of Schneider. The remaining $26 million will be taken as a charge in the fourth quarter. Earnings for Boston Scientific are due out later this month.
It was not immediately clear whether a total of 2,000 people would lose their jobs, or if some of the positions to be eliminated are already empty. The company currently has 11,000 employees.
A spokesman for the company did not immediately return telephone messages.
Boston Scientific paid $2.1 billion for Schneider Worldwide, a former unit of Pfizer Inc. that makes devices used to unclog arteries. The purchase was announced in June.
At that point, it was the 11th purchase Boston Scientific had made since 1995, and brought the total amount the company spent on acquisitions during that period to $5.6 billion.
Boston Scientific had not been without problems, however.
In November, the company's stock fell 11 percent in a single day after officials announced they had discovered accounting irregularities with a Japanese subsidiary.
Shipped products were being improperly recorded as sales, totaling $40 million to $50 million in the nine-month period ending Sept. 30, 1998. An additional $40 million in shipments were improperly recorded in earlier periods, company officials said.
Further, the Justice Department has been investigating clinical trials of a heart device that was marketed and later recalled by Boston Scientific.
Company officials said they were cooperating with the investigation.
Boston Scientific is a medical technology company that develops and manufactures diagnostic and therapeutic devices.

HEADLINE: Yet Another Day of Canceled Flights Troubles Travelers and Tourist Officials

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The tourist industry's high hopes that accompanied the court order issued Wednesday requiring pilots of American Airlines to return to work were dashed yesterday, as the airline was still forced to cancel nearly 1,200 flights -- many to popular holiday and vacation resorts in Florida and the Caribbean.
Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport resounded with the sounds of happy travelers bound for ski resorts in Colorado and other Western states, but American flights to warm-weather destinations were canceled left and right because many pilots continued to call in sick. 
 At John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York, hundreds of American ticket holders waited in line, some as much as eight hours, in fading hopes of getting away for the holiday or a vacation.
"There is absolutely no customer service," said Sandra Lowe, who arrived at Kennedy with her husband and two daughters at 6 A.M. to catch an early plane to Barbados for a family reunion. Five hours later, Ms. Lowe was still waiting in a virtually immobile line, fatigued and annoyed.
Would she fly American again? "I would avoid it at all costs," Ms. Lowe said.
John Hotard, a spokesman at American's parent, the AMR Corporation, said that 1,170 flights had been canceled, but declined to specify which routes had been affected.
But he said, "I can tell you there have been many cancellations of international flights, including flights to the Caribbean, from New York and Miami."
Other airlines said that they would continue to honor American tickets to the best of their ability, but that their own flights were rapidly filling with normal holiday passengers and American customers looking for alternative flights.
"There are almost no seats left to South Florida," said Todd Clay, a spokesman for Delta Air Lines, "but if people are flexible and determined, they still might be able to get where they want to go."
Trans World Airlines added two flights on Tuesday and Wednesday between New York and Santo Domingo and Puerto Plata in the Dominican Republic, accommodating 400 American passengers.
Even if they have empty seats, rival airlines said they would accommodate only those American passengers holding tickets that had not been acquired using frequent-flier miles. And American customers who are assigned seats on other airlines will be eligible to receive frequent-flier miles only from the host airline.
Still, frequent-flier miles were probably not foremost on the minds of travelers milling around many major airports, expecting to take American flights. At Miami International Airport, for example -- where "canceled" appeared on the information boards for American flights to Puerto Rico, Grenada, Jamaica, Mexico City, the Grand Caymans and many Central and South American nations -- the line of passengers hoping to fly to Mexico and the Caribbean was so long that it collided with the lines for domestic check-in, around the corner.
Bernice Wynter, a nurse from Lauderdale Lakes, Fla., was in that line hoping to arrive in Barbados for a wedding. "I got to Fort Lauderdale airport and the flight was canceled, so they sent me here," she said. Like many other American passengers, Ms. Wynter appeared more resigned and frustrated than angry.
Some of American's five daily nonstops from Dallas to New Orleans were also canceled, just as the city's two-week Mardi Gras celebration was building to its Fat Tuesday peak, now four days off. Hotels there reported few cancellations, according to Beverly Gianna, a spokeswoman for the city's tourist bureau, largely because many of the estimated 350,000 visitors to the city during the carnival drive there. Moreover, the dominant carriers in New Orleans are Southwest Airlines and Continental Airlines.
While American flights to San Juan were canceled, the carrier's regional airline, American Eagle, has continued to operate from San Juan throughout the Caribbean. Its pilots belong to a different union.
Still, Michael Youngman, the executive director of the Caribbean Tourism Organization, called yesterday's cancellations "really bad news." Almost all the 33 member governments in the group, which include Mexico as well as the tiny island of Saba, rely heavily on tourism from the United States. Most are also heavily dependent on American and American Eagle, which account for almost 70 percent of the region's air traffic.
Asked about the sickout's economic impact on the Caribbean, Mr. Youngman replied, "By next week I should be able to tell you, but with everything changing by the hour, it's impossible to know now."
Jean Holder, the secretary general of the organization, was scheduled to take an American flight on Wednesday from Barbados to New York for a series of meetings, but managed to switch to BWIA International at the start of the sickout. Finding it necessary to return to Barbados tomorrow -- when most scheduled flights are sold out or canceled -- he was able to find a seat on a British Airways Concorde, only the second Concorde flight ever from the United States to Barbados.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Pluralism Under Golden Arches;
From Abroad, McDonald's Finds Value in Local Control

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

DATELINE: OAK BROOK, ILL., Feb. 11

 BODY:
In Austria, Indonesia and South Korea, McDonald's sells Big Macs and Happy Meals. But its Vienna franchises also contain "McCafes," which offer coffee blended for local tastes. In Jakarta, the McDonald's menu includes rice as well as french fries. And in Seoul, the burger chain sells roast pork on a bun with a garlicky soy sauce.
That combination of a globally recognized brand with a flexible menu that caters to local palates has helped McDonald's navigate the global economic turbulence that has knocked most of the other big corporations operating around the world way off course.
For the 15th consecutive year, the McDonald's Corporation has achieved solid growth in its international division, which now accounts for nearly 60 percent of corporate profits. No other American multinational has enjoyed such consistent success abroad, particularly lately amid the dizzying plunges in local currencies and economic activity in much of Asia and Latin America. McDonald's says a large part of the reason it has done so well is that its operations overseas are run by local residents who are attuned to changing economic conditions and consumer tastes. 
 Now, McDonald's is testing a variation on the theme that "all business is local" in the United States, where since the mid-1990's the fast-food giant has been wrestling with a dramatic and widely publicized fall from grace. And after a period of growing concerns over declining food quality, shrinking market share and a generally falling stock price, profits at McDonald's appear to be on their way up at home as well as abroad.
Indeed, after a few years of fumbles, Wall Street analysts say there are signs that McDonald's is climbing back -- in large part following the course charted abroad -- by decentralizing marketing and decision making.
Senior executives now say they are committed to more local control, and what Jack M. Greenberg, the new chief executive, calls a "shared vision" of the future.
"You can't manage 25,000 restaurants in a centralized way," Mr. Greenberg said in an interview at the company headquarters here in this Chicago suburb. "Many decisions need to be decided closer to the marketplace; you have faster decisions that way."
Two weeks ago, when McDonald's reported its fourth-quarter and year-end results, foreign sales and profits were strong, up about 10 percent, despite widespread weakness overseas. In the United States, the improvement was even more striking. Operating profits were up 13 percent, more than double what they were in 1997 and the best yearly gain since 1985.
While McDonald's still has plenty of problems, investors have become increasingly optimistic. Its shares have soared 63 percent the last year, closing at $82 today, up $2.125.
"I think they've turned a corner," said Mitchell Speiser, who covers the fast-food business for Lehman Brothers. "They have culturally, operationally and strategically turned the corner."
Yet the new approach carries its own set of quandaries. For instance, some analysts say that in reinventing the company, McDonald's runs the risk of scrambling the formula dreamed up by the late Ray Kroc. That formula gave McDonald's uniform quality and unified marketing themes, such as "You Deserve a Break Today," and a consistent and distinctly American batch of winning products that came to be symbolized by the Golden Arches.
McDonald's officials may also face an uphill battle as they try to meet their goals of improving profits by 10 to 15 percent a year the next five years, analysts say. After all, McDonald's is already a $35 billion company with more than 12,400 restaurants in the United States alone, and stiff competition is coming from Wendy's, Burger King and even unlikely competitors like the Carl's Jr. hamburger chain in California and a reviving Jack-in-the-Box.
What Mr. Greenberg, the 56-year-old former accountant who took over as chief executive in August, would most like to reverse is a lengthy series of corporate miscues that began in the mid-1990's, when McDonald's was trying aggressively to expand its operations with big promotions.
New products, like the Arch Deluxe, flopped. New promotions, like "Campaign 55," a deep-discount program that was supposed to hark back to the Eisenhower era by offering 55-cent burgers fizzled. Burger King and Wendy's began to gain market share. And McDonald's food was widely seen as subpar, ranking in one food quality taste test not that long ago just below Hooters, and, in one customer satisfaction survey, just ahead of the Internal Revenue Service.
In mid-1997, the company dropped its lead advertising agency, Leo Burnett & Company, in favor of Omnicom Group's DDB Needham unit, which created the "Did somebody say McDonald's?" campaign. And last year, the company elevated Mr. Greenberg from the head of United States operations to chief executive.
Since then, sales at restaurants open at least a year have improved substantially, the company said. And after slipping in 1996 and 1997, McDonald's share of the fast-food market has reached its highest level in a decade, 43 percent of the market, according to Technomics, a market research firm in Chicago.
A new McDonald's is emerging, analyst say, that helps explain its improved standing in Wall Street circles. Since Mr. Greenberg took over, the more flexible cooking system is generating somewhat higher customer satisfaction. And strained relations with franchise operators have improved.
"This is a different management style," said Paul Saber, chairman of the National Leadership Council, a group that represents franchise operators. "Jack's attitude is to get to know owner operators and their issues; he's brought a spirit of working together."
A sense of denial about McDonald's failings appears to have been replaced in recent months by an almost ritualistic desire to confess past sins. "In retrospect, we lost our way back in mid-1994." Michael Conley, the company's chief financial officer, said in an interview last week. "We were trying to drive the company almost exclusively with national advertising."
Mr. Greenberg reorganized the company's domestic operations into five divisions. He gave owners of McDonald's independent franchises a more collaborative role in marketing and advertising and a say in the menu. The company has also agreed to pay half the cost of what McDonald's calls its "Made For You" food preparation system. The new system, which is not available at all outlets, is arranged to keep bread, lettuce, onions and other ingredients fresh and allow McDonald's assembly line process to accommodate new menu items.
The company also slowed its growth in the United States, where rapid expansion led to concerns about cannibalizing existing McDonald's outlets.
Unprofitable, low-volume satellite operations in places like Wal-Mart stores were closed; faster drive-throughs, cleaner stores and better food quality are high priorities, executives say. And it is all in the spirit of inclusiveness and decentralization, the backbone of foreign operations.
In McDonald's international division, local managers and franchise operators have long had substantial control over how they do business. The locals create a supply infrastructure within each country or region; everything is financed in the local currency. And a great deal of attention is paid to local customs, like food tastes.
"Our strategy is to be as much a local business as possible," said Jim Cantalupo, head of international operations. "We don't run Spain out of Portugal."
That decentralization allowed local managers in Indonesia to add rice quickly after the currency collapsed in 1997, which made french fries -- its main imported product -- much too expensive. And it has paid off in other places hit hard by global market forces.
"We've got a lot of experience dealing with down markets," Mr. Cantalupo said. "We've dealt with six Government economic plans in Brazil."
While other multinational companies like Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble suffered sharp earnings declines in 1998, McDonald's -- despite a dip in Asia -- still posted operating profit gains of 9 percent overseas. "International is the locomotive here," said Dean T. Haskell, an analyst at Everen Securities in Chicago.
Though pleased with 1998 results, Mr. Greenberg knows that one strong year is just one strong year. He says the company is hardly complacent.
"We've got a lot of hard work ahead," he said.
At the same time, the company has become more attuned to Wall Street, buying back a big chunk of its own stock and announcing a 2-for-1 split last month, which investors applauded.
Still, one advertising executive, who agreed to speak only if he was not named, said that while McDonald's had righted itself financially, it might have lost some of its marketing bravado. The company has pinned its hopes on Teenie Beanie Baby promotions and Disney movie tie-ins. "The market's only as loyal as the next Beanie Baby promotion or the next Disney movie," he said. "What happens when the movies flop? Does everyone run to Burger King for Rugrats cups?"
Some analysts also question whether McDonald's brand loyalty among older customers has begun to wane and whether the recent rise in profits was simply a minor tuneup on a motor that may have passed its prime.
"They certainly have more outlets and more distribution with the lowest price points," said Mr. Haskell of Everen. "But more and more people are looking for variety and quality. The quick drive-through is becoming less of a factor."
Mr. Haskell and others cite the success of Starbuck's coffee, Einstein Bagels and other more specialized food chains.
But Mr. Greenberg and other executives say they are responding to such concerns. In tune with its decentralized foreign operations, McDonald's is experimenting more actively with new sandwiches and foods in regional tests in hopes of re-creating the success of the Egg McMuffin, which was born in San Diego, and the Big Mac, which took root in Pittsburgh.
The Big Extra, which some say is like a Burger King Whopper, was tested in the Northeast and is now being offered nationwide. The McFlurry, a soft ice cream with candy, spread across the country last year. A salad that comes in a plastic container that customers use to shake up their dressing is in tests as McSalad. And there are additional products in the works.
"We have more things in test now than at any time in my 24 years here," said Mr. Conley, the chief financial officer.
The company will experiment and innovate, officials say. But while decentralized operations are the new mantra, McDonald's, executives say, will still be McDonald's.
"Decentralization doesn't mean chaos or anarchy," Mr. Greenberg said. "The things that make McDonald's distinct are going to be there. Those things aren't negotiable."

HEADLINE: AMERICAN AIRLINES SNARLED AS PILOTS DEFY COURT ORDER

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

 BODY:
Defying a Federal judge's order to end their protest and return to work, more pilots called in sick at American Airlines yesterday, forcing the carrier to cancel more than half of its flights and insuring that its operations would be crippled during the Presidents' Day holiday.
The disruption at American, which entered its sixth day, continued to upset the plans of tens of thousands of travelers and businesses around the world. The airline, the nation's second largest, said that it had already canceled 500 flights scheduled for today, a number that it said would most likely rise, because planes are out of position. Passengers will have fewer alternatives because most airlines are expected to be full. Page C4. 
 American filed a motion for contempt in United States District Court in Texas yesterday, contending that the Allied Pilots Association, the union that represents American's 9,200 pilots, had not complied with Judge Joe Kendall's order on Wednesday to end the sickout. A hearing in Dallas is scheduled for 10 A.M. today.
"We are confident that the judge will be satisfied that we are doing what we have to do to comply with the order," said Rich LaVoy, the union's president.
Union representatives and the airline also met yesterday to try to negotiate an end to the dispute. Brian A. Mayhew, an American captain who is vice president at the union, said that limited progress was made on one issue but several core issues still needed to be addressed. The two sides are scheduled to meet again this afternoon.
American said that the number of pilots calling in sick rose to 2,400 yesterday from 2,295 on Wednesday. Normally, 400 pilots are out sick. As a result of the absences, the airline was forced to ground 1,170, or more than half, of its 2,250 daily flights, compared with 1,000 on Wednesday.
The pilots, many of whom are embittered after years of poor labor relations at the airline, are angry about the way American plans to integrate Reno Air, a small Airline in the West that it bought in December for $124 million. American has said that it intends to take a year to 18 months to merge the two carriers. The pilots want the integration to go faster, and they want Reno Air pilots and their members paid as if the integration were already completed.
Some pilots began calling in sick on Saturday after negotiations between the union and the airline broke down. More joined in, quickly escalating the number of canceled flights before American went to court on Wednesday.
"From the numbers it doesn't appear that those pilots who have called in sick are complying with the judge's order," said John Hotard, a spokesman for American Airlines.
But the union said that it was in full compliance. After giving the judge's order an ambiguous endorsement early yesterday in a telephone message to members, the union issued a stronger statement later yesterday, saying that it did not "authorize, ratify or condone" a sickout or a slowdown. "We further instruct all pilots to resume their normal working schedule and to otherwise comply with Judge Kendall's order," it added.
Even with the stronger language by the union, it was still difficult to determine how many pilots would return to the cockpit. "That is what the leadership has to say," said one pilot on the sick list who insisted on anonymity, referring to the union's order to return to work.
Federal regulations require pilots to take themselves out of the cockpit if they are sick, suffering from stress or otherwise not fit to fly. Many veteran pilots have dozens of sick days that allow them to stay on the sick list and still get paid.
Some of the protesting pilots argue that the court order applies only to the union's leadership, not to pilots acting on their own. But Chris Gangemi, a labor lawyer in the Chicago office of Winston & Strawn who often represents management, said that was not true. "It would be surprising if the court would tolerate this continuing injury to the public under the fiction that the union has no control over the situation," he said.
During Wednesday's hearing, Judge Kendall asked Sandy Denison, the lawyer for the union, "Are you actually standing here telling me the pilots are sick?" Mr. Denison responded, "No."
Estimates of the financial damage to the AMR Corporation, American's parent, rose with yesterday's canceled flights. Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst at Paine Webber in New York, said that the sickout would reduce AMR's revenue for the quarter by $82 million to $110 million and cut its earnings by 25 to 40 cents a share if American's operations began returning to normal today. He also said that the company might lose an additional $50 million in lost bookings from customers who switched to other airlines. The consensus estimate for AMR's earnings for the quarter was $1.17 a share before the disruptions began.
American officials estimate that it would take two to three days to return operations to normal. The sickout has left many planes out of position for their normal routes, which is why the airline is predicting more cancellations regardless of what the pilots do.
Even if the pilots return to work today, a settlement between the union and the company will be needed to begin to break down the pilots' mistrust of management. Many pilots trace their ill will to the reign of Robert L. Crandall, AMR's former chairman and chief executive who retired in May.
"He was such a tough person to deal with he created his counterpart in the union," said one pilot not on the sick list who spoke on the condition that his name not be used.
Donald J. Carty, Mr. Crandall's successor, began his tenure pledging to improve management-labor relations and make American a happier place to work. He has tried to allay the pilots' fears that acquiring Reno Air is a ploy to lower pilot pay rates at American, pledging that he is committed to bringing Reno Air's pilots under the union's contract.
But in a short time Mr. Carty has managed to alienate even those pilots who are critical of the union's hard-liners. "I am really shocked," said the pilot who has not called in sick. "I would hope that the company would do more in the way to negotiate. I like Carty. He is a likable guy, but he is just as tough in his own way as Crandall was."

HEADLINE: Nickel-and-Diming on a Tax Break

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Flirting With a Buy Order for $1 Trillion in Stock" (Week in Review, Feb. 7): Projections of 6 percent to 7 percent returns over the next 75 years are based on the history of stock earnings over the the last 75 years. But forecasts of the Social Security trustees, upon which expectations of a long-term trust fund deficit are based, predict a 50 percent slowdown in economic growth. If growth slows, so do profits, stock prices and dividends. A stock market return of 3.5 percent, not much more than the returns to Social Security, is more consistent with the trustees' forecast. 
 If the economists you cite are right, growth and stock earnings will be higher. But so will Social Security payroll tax revenue. In that case, the trust fund's deficit will shrink substantially, making it unnecessary to risk playing the stock market to raise more revenue.
 
JEFF FAUX
Pres., Economic Policy Institute
Washington, Feb. 8, 1999

HEADLINE: Stronger Military Without the Draft

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Draft Isn't the Answer" (Op-Ed, Feb. 10): 
 Some people have painted the recent shortages of military personnel as symptomatic of the younger generation's lack of civic commitment. The real problem, however, lies in Congressional misuse of the military budget. If a small portion of our considerable defense expenditures were used to raise military salaries, then entry into the armed forces would once again present a viable alternative for young people entering the civilian economy.
Instead, politicians funnel billions of dollars into the production and maintenance of unnecessary hardware, which serves only to enrich their constituencies. Responsible use of money, not reinstitution of the draft, will strengthen our national defense.
 
JOSEPH MOLDOVER
Easton, Pa., Feb. 10, 1999

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE SCENE -- CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;
A Long, Long, Long Day Before the Verdict

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
"I'm O.K., but my butt's getting flat," said Senator Frank H. Murkowski who is big and bluff like his home state of Alaska.
"It's an awful long day," he said, lumbering back to the trial cloister as the impeachment deliberation hours dwindled toward a verdict. 
 Down the corridor, Senator Robert F. Bennett, Republican of Utah, sounded vaguely like someone trapped in a building: "I'm doing just fine. I drink lots of water and move around a bit."
There were moments today when the Capitol countdown to the verdict in President Clinton's trial offered all the historic aura of a bus terminal. As on other recent days, bystanders were more likely to quote not the founding fathers but Richard D. Llamas, the unemployed carpenter arrested a week ago when he rose in the gallery and shouted down to the senators: "God almighty, take the vote and get it over with!"
Lingering in his Senate hideaway after a formal trial recess, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, sat in a wing chair and slowly described the court scene. "It's going on and on," he said. "And on and on," he continued, the "on" sounding a New England-nasal dirge. "And on and on and on and on."
With a can of Diet Coke resting on his thigh, the Senator sat back and wondered about his court colleagues. "I hope the secret doesn't leak out that I'm not down there," he said, fully masking any regret.
In a passing corridor scene, Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, asked no one in particular, "What is today? The eleventh?" He was signing a Senate autograph sheet for a tourist clearly wise in the provenance requirements of marketable historic artifacts. "It was my day on the treadmill," the Senator mused happily as he signed, speaking of aerobics, not impeachment.
Down the hall, Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, first said "no," then "yes" when asked if the task grew tedious. "It is tedious if you look at it minute to minute," he conceded, "but not in terms of its historic meaning. The deal is either he's thrown out of office or he's not: That's all that counts."
In 1868, when the Senate court wrestled through long, doubt-crazed deliberations for the one-vote acquittal in President Andrew Johnson's impeachment trial, the waiting period was excruciating and a source of great enterprise among newspaper correspondents and other Capitol workers.
"Wagers figuring up an enormous total were laid on the issue," Francis A. Richardson, a trial correspondent, later recalled of the tense speculations about the momentous question of whether the nation would see its President banished from office. Without benefit of focus group or public opinion poll, W. W. Johnson, a Presidential secretary, won thousands of dollars when President Johnson "escaped by the skin of his teeth," in the regretful words of one of his antagonists, Senator Charles Sumner.
Today, no one in the Capitol was offering even long-shot perfecta odds against the widely anticipated verdict of acquittal in President Clinton's trial. The only really open question stirred not a sous of action: whether the Senate Republicans, considered certain to fall short of the necessary 67 votes to oust Mr. Clinton, might embarrass House Republican prosecutors further by not mustering even a simple majority on either impeachment article.
"The aftermath will be the aftermath; I'm not really concerned about it," said one Republican, Senator Connie Mack of Florida.
The day was beautiful outside the Capitol, a balmy foretaste of spring. Six hours after first gathering, a few senators emerged into the sunlight on a coffee break to wander and stare, as if in deliberation of life's undeniable power to regenerate.
"You can't help but like Bill Clinton," admitted Senator Burns, as he walked past the television camera pen on the Capitol lawn, talking gently. "I mean, just think had this thing not come along in his Presidency -- the talent he had has pretty much been squandered. And that's the real sadness of the whole thing."
The Senator did not discuss his eventual verdict as he ruminated on finding himself and his colleagues in the extraordinary position of settling the President's fate.
"I just got a feeling the Senate's here not to be a weathervane but a compass," he said, lingering beyond the Capitol.
"I think we followed the Constitution as the founders would have us," Mr. Burns said, addressing the fact that there is more than one politician's legacy at stake in the trial. "I think the founders are still speaking to us today. You get a feeling every now and then that we will test the generations to follow us on their degree of dedication that we are a land of laws and not of men."
The Senator suddenly laughed out loud. "I ran for the office and everything that goes with it," he said. "And we've got it all -- the good, the bad, the ugly."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S TRIAL: THE POLITICS;
Republicans Respond Angrily to Reports of Clinton Vow

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Top Republicans today pounced on reports that President Clinton wants to seek retribution at the ballot box against those who have pushed for his impeachment.
"This is the height of arrogance," said Representative Christopher B. Cannon, a Utah Republican and one of 13 House prosecutors in the impeachment trial. 
 Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, said that instead of vengeance, the President should be worrying about "leaving an eensy-weensy, itsy-bitsy better legacy than he has so far."
"It's a sad day if revenge is the order of the day," Mr. Hatch added. "If I were the President, I'd worry about rehabilitation."
And Jim Nicholson, national chairman of the Republican National Committee, criticized Mr. Clinton's electoral mission in the most searing and personal of terms.
"Unlike you, I've seen real combat," Mr. Nicholson said bitterly, as if speaking to the President, "and you'll have to get by me first."
Mr. Nicholson, a decorated Army Ranger who served in Vietnam, reflected the longstanding cultural wars that seem to lurk just beneath the surface of the partisan impeachment battle. More broadly, he reflected the Republicans' anger that the politically adroit Mr. Clinton, who avoided the draft in the 1960's and is on the verge of avoiding conviction in the Senate, would outmaneuver them once again.
Stirring these sentiments was a report today in The New York Times that Mr. Clinton was committed to an all-out campaign to take back the House, both to rescue his political legacy from the yearlong impeachment ordeal and to exact revenge on those Republicans who he believes dragged out the process. On Friday, the Senate is expected to acquit Mr. Clinton of charges that he committed perjury and obstructed justice.
Advisers to the President said today that he was furious that word had leaked of his private ruminations, which counter his publicly expressed desire to work with Congress. Several said he was trying to ferret out the source of the report.
The White House press secretary, Joe Lockhart, did not deny the report but cast doubt on it by saying there were "thousands" of so-called advisers to the President who purported to know his frame of mind but spoke only anonymously.
Mr. Lockhart said the Administration was "a little bit smarter" than to campaign on a personal vendetta against the House members who prosecuted the case.
"I can't think of a worse, more dumb strategy than going after people based on whether they were a House manager or not," he said. "You look at the House managers, and the vast majority are in safe seats or unopposed seats."
The article said that Mr. Clinton was particularly angry at the managers but noted their safe seats.
Mr. Lockhart continued to advance the White House view of the unfairness of the House proceeding, which ended Dec. 19 in support of two articles of impeachment. "It seemed at times more based on a partisan agenda than a search for what happened here and a search for the truth," he said.
Aggrieved Republicans, who have sunk in the polls as Mr. Clinton has stayed high, were quick to leap at the notion that Mr. Clinton appeared far from the "gloat-free zone" that Mr. Lockhart had previously asserted the President would inhabit.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said, "It is deeply troubling that the President views closure of this constitutional process as an opportunity for revenge."
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said: "The President has to have contrition. He can't have a get-even attitude. I don't know if he does, but he shouldn't. Any effort to get even just keeps the poison in the body politic, and it will spread."
Even the Senate chaplain was moved to comment. "This is a time neither for gloating over victory nor grimness over losing, but rather a period for grief for all that has brought us to this day," Dr. Lloyd H. Ogilvie, the chaplain, lamented in his prayer as the Senate convened.
Thomas Mann, an expert on Congress at the Brookings Institution, said Republicans had good reason to feel exasperated and angry. They lost House seats in the last election and lost a Speaker and a Speaker-designate while Mr. Clinton has managed to survive and thrive, in part because of a booming economy, in part by cleverly co-opting Republican issues.
"Look at his ability to really destroy their wedge issues," Mr. Mann said. "Now it's the Democratic Party that's good on welfare and crime and fiscal responsibility and even taxes. It's an amazing achievement for a man who has been personally under siege throughout his Presidency and who has widely acknowledged flaws."
As for the Republicans, he said, "they are not only scarred with the tar of impeachment, but they look and they find they don't have any agenda. It's inevitable they will look for openings, for signs of hubris, of revenge, of anything that will give them an ability to change the subject and begin to regain some of their lost ground."
In an overt effort to do so, many in the House took the high road in discussing the President's mood, saying they were sticking to their knitting. "We've got our work to do," said Representative Kay Granger, Republican of Texas. John Feehery, a spokesman for Speaker Dennis Hastert, said, "People want us to get to work on their business, not on political business."
Others, like Representative Jack Kingston, Republican of Georgia, said the party had to prepare for the full power of another Clinton campaign. "It's payback time, and payback time is hell," Mr. Kingston said. He said the President was a "savvy, hardball politician, and you've got to fear his ability and respect it."
Mr. Nicholson, the party chairman, vowed vengeance on the avenger. He said his party would match the Presidential effort in every district in the country, and he said the Republicans whom Mr. Clinton had designated as targets should be proud of their votes on impeachment.
"Far from being ground under the heels of Bill Clinton's tawdry effort to celebrate his impeachment trial," Mr. Nicholson said, "these men and women will be rewarded by the people they represent and remembered as giants."
A few Democrats seemed chagrined by the President's desire to unseat his accusers. Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said Mr. Clinton should be part of the necessary healing after Friday's vote.
"It's very important that the President play a critical role in conveying to people a measure of understanding what he has put the country through," Mr. Kerry said.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said he was "taken aback" by today's Times article. "It was so personal," he said of reports that Mr. Clinton plans a crusade against his accusers. "But I think it's probably overstated. It's human nature, I think, for him to want one of his legacies to be to help Democrats regain the House and Senate. That would be his strong motive."

HEADLINE: Parents of Shooting Victim Question Pace of Inquiry

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS

 BODY:
The parents of Amadou Diallo, the unarmed West African immigrant shot to death by police officers in the vestibule of his Bronx apartment building last week, gave public thanks yesterday for the sympathy they have received but expressed ambivalence about the city's handling of the investigation into their son's death.
In her first interview since arriving from Guinea after the killing, Kadiadou Diallo, Mr. Diallo's mother, said she was upset by the pace of the investigation into the killing. 
 "What I condemn is these police officers are still on duty," she said, referring to the four officers who fired 41 shots into her son.
Her statements, in an interview at the office of the Rev. Al Sharpton and later at a news conference, capped conciliatory gestures from city officials and expressions of unalloyed anger from black and African leaders who complained that the death of the 22-year-old street vendor is evidence of systemic problems in the police force.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani again moved to fend off criticism that his response to the shooting has been insensitive. He reached out both to the Diallo family and to a group of African immigrants. But the Diallos and their entourage could not agree whether to even meet the Mayor to accept his condolences and some people who attended the meeting with the immigrants' group, the United African Congress, came away with a tepid response to Mr. Giuliani's overtures.
The fallout also extended to Police Commissioner Howard Safir, who sat through an hourlong tongue-lashing from City Council members over police training.
By day's end, the focus was on Mrs. Diallo, who was soft-spoken and composed despite days at the center of intense news media attention. She said that despite her frustration, she believed the investigation into her son's death would be fair. "It is the land of justice, America," she said.
But she and her former husband, Saikou, who arrived in New York City from his home in Vietnam on Wednesday night, appeared more hesitant about the motivations of Mr. Giuliani, who said yesterday that he wanted to offer his condolences to the family in private.
"If he has something to say, he can say it," Mrs. Diallo said with a shrug during the interview in the office of Mr. Sharpton, has been acting as the family's spokesman.
Mr. Giuliani, who has been trying to balance a desire to express compassion for the family and to defend his police force from allegations of racism, said he did not want any encounter with the Diallos to become "a media circus." He added, "I will do what is appropriate and what the family feels is appropriate."
A face-to-face meeting between the Mayor and the Diallos had been scheduled for last night, but it was called off at the last minute because Mrs. Diallo was exhausted, the Mayor's office and representatives of the Diallos said.
Mr. Sharpton, who has organized two large protest rallies against police brutality in the wake of the Diallo shooting, earlier said the only Mayor that the family would meet was former Mayor David N. Dinkins. They did, when Mr. Dinkins showed up for the news conference at Mr. Sharpton's National Action Network in Harlem to offer his sympathy.
It was not clear whether the Diallos and the Mayor would meet privately. In the lobby of the Diallos's hotel last night, Mr. Sharpton smiled and shrugged when asked whether the meeting between the Mayor and the family would take place.
Mr. Giuliani is scheduled to attend a memorial service for Mr. Diallo today after the Muslim noon prayers, at the Islamic Cultural Center of New York City. Mr. Sharpton said the family planned to return to Guinea with their son's body on Sunday or Monday, and he said he is considering the family's request to accompany them.
As Mr. Diallo's parents crisscrossed the city in a melancholy tour of the places their son worked, prayed and lived, City Hall continued to weather the sometimes harsh reaction to the police killing.
Mr. Safir returned from a five-day trip to Los Angeles to a withering barrage of criticism from City Council members, who said they told him the Diallo killing was evidence of persistent problems in the police force.
The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said he and the Council's black and Hispanic caucus complained to Mr. Safir that the department has not prepared its officers to deal with immigrants and minority groups. There was general agreement, he said, "that there is something wrong that needs to be fixed."
Similar complaints about the Police Department's sensitivity to the diverse cultures, languages and needs of the city's immigrant groups were made by African leaders at a meeting with Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Safir.
Sadique Wai, president of the United African Congress, based in Brooklyn, said his group wanted the city to hire more African-Americans and to pay more attention to their social, political and economic needs.
"The next step is integrating us into this society and making crystal-clear that we are going to be part of this society and we are going to be respected," said Mr. Wai, an immigrant from Sierre Leone.
Ben Otunu, associate publisher of Black Star News, who also attended the meeting, said the Mayor and Mr. Safir expressed compassion for the Diallo family but stopped short of saying the police officers were wrong to shoot the unarmed vendor.
"I guess that's perhaps where people feel maybe he is not entirely sincere," Mr. Otunu said. He added that "the Mayor's demeanor is such that he does not come across as a very friendly person."

HEADLINE: Feeling the Push Of Managed Care;
In Syracuse, Doctors and Patients Adjust As H.M.O.'s Make a Late Appearance

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
It was the kind of experience Dr. William Lindsey had dreaded.
The doctor, a general surgeon, sat on one side of a meeting table protesting a decision by United Healthcare to pay him almost $100 less for each colonoscopy he performs under that managed care plan. The reduction, Dr. Lindsey said, would cost him $30,000 this year. 
 On the other side of the table, Dr. Lindsey recalled, sat the representative for the health maintenance organization, nodding, assuring Dr. Lindsey that his services were valued, but refusing to pay him a penny more for the procedure.
Like a poker player holding a pair of threes, Dr. Lindsey, 45, knew he was beaten. The boom in health maintenance organizations that swept most other American cities more than a decade ago has finally come to Syracuse. United Healthcare and other plans like it are enrolling more of Dr. Lindsey's patients, and he cannot just walk away.
"There is no real way to argue with them," Dr. Lindsey said recently, still seething two weeks after the meeting. "Basically, they tell us to take it or leave it. Alone, I don't have any say."
Until recently, Syracuse doctors did not have to pay managed care much mind. While much of New York had belatedly joined the H.M.O. surge, Syracuse had largely avoided it because the local economy, made up mostly of midsize companies, was not particularly appealing to managed-care companies. Those companies often seek to have a quick and substantial impact on a new market by signing up a few large employers.
But as the pressure increases on managed-care companies to find new markets, the status quo in Syracuse has begun to change: in the last three years, these companies have enrolled increasing numbers of people here.
For patients, this trend has meant adjusting to a new way of getting care and paying for it. For doctors, feeling control of their practices slipping from their grasp, it has meant using the experience of colleagues in other cities as a guide to challenging managed-care companies. Their solution has been to organize in unionlike associations.
"We don't need a middleman to manage health care," said Dr. Paul Kardjian, a urologist in Oneida, a suburb east of Syracuse. "We are smart enough to do it ourselves."
Syracuse, with a population of 164,000, is a quiet place dominated by Syracuse University and surrounded by dairy farms. It is a city where most people are proud to call themselves conservative, even old-fashioned, and where concepts like managed care seem newfangled and are viewed with suspicion.
Born and raised in Syracuse, Bill Nesfeder, a union representative at the New Venture Gear plant, expressed a typical view. He has been employed at the plant, which produces auto parts, for 35 years, he said, and he has been enrolled in Blue Cross and Blue Shield for about as long.
The health plan has served him well, he said. He can go to any doctor he wants, whenever he wants, and if he is sick, insurance pays the full bill. Insurance does not cover routine visits, however, including annual checkups.
Sometimes, he said, he has problems getting Blue Cross to cover certain medical expenses. But the freedom of choice, he said, is worth the trouble.
"It feels like we are moving into socialized medicine," said Mr. Nesfeder, 62, the benefits representative for the United Automobile Workers, Local 624. "A lot of people are joining the H.M.O.'s because they don't have to pay nothing. Well I'm not looking for a free ride in life."
He pointed to a stack of blue folders about as tall as his coffee mug. They are complaints, he said, from employees about the kind of care they get, and all the rules they have to follow. Views like that helped keep managed-care enrollment low in Syracuse for years.
In addition, the city has not had a glut of hospitals or doctors, so there was little need for health care providers to court managed-care companies in the hopes of securing more customers.
Three years ago, only 14 percent of Syracuse residents with health insurance were covered by health maintenance organizations. That number has grown to 19 percent, according to a report by the Center for Studying Health System Change, a research group. The figure is still low compared with the national average of 32 percent, but heading upward.
The shift toward managed care is clear at New Venture Gear. Over the last five years, benefits administrators said, many employees have switched from Blue Cross to Prepaid Health Plan, the H.M.O that the company uses. Five years ago, company officials said, less than 1,000 of the 3,000 hourly employees were enrolled in Prepaid. Today, more than 2,000 are in the plan, with most saying they have switched because the costs are lower and more services are covered.
Ed Wierzbicki, who has worked at New Venture Gear for 22 years, said he switched to Prepaid four years ago, after the birth of his first daughter, reasoning that a newborn would need numerous trips to the doctor.
Two years later, it was Mr. Wierzbicki, 47, who needed medical attention. He began having trouble breathing through his nose and developed intense headaches. His doctor recommended surgery to open his nasal passages. But Prepaid, Mr. Wierzbicki said, would not pay for the surgery, calling it an uncovered cosmetic procedure, nor would it allow a second opinion from a specialist.
Mr. Wierzbicki said he took aspirin by the handfuls as he and his wife, Karen, fought the managed-care company's decision. A year and a half later, after State Health Department officials began investigating, Mr. Wierzbicki said, Prepaid allowed him to get a second opinion.
"What they did was just awful," Mrs. Wierzbicki said. "They made us jump through all kind of hoops. Meanwhile, my husband was suffering terribly. They cared more about money than about his pain."
The new doctor determined that the breathing problems were caused by heavy goggles Mr. Wierzbicki wears for work, and ordered him to get a lighter pair. The change has made all the difference in his condition, Mr. Wierzbicki said.
Yet, despite his conflict with the H.M.O., Mr. Wierzbicki said that he has decided to remain in Prepaid because it costs so much less than Blue Cross.
Dr. Dennis Nave fumed when recalling the times he has prescribed certain medications to patients, only to have a health maintenance organization refuse to cover them and offer what he considers inappropriate alternatives.
"The insurance companies have gotten between the patients and the doctors," he said. "It has created a monster. It's time to try things a new way."
In the expanding movement by physicians to regain control of their practices, doctors in Syracuse have decided that the way to fight back is by joining together. Some 90 percent of doctors in the city have formed independent practitioners' associations. Known as I.P.A.'s, these groups are often likened to unions that allow physicians to act as a collective unit to negotiate contracts with health insurance companies, giving them more leverage at the bargaining table.
But, unlike doctors' unions, these associations do not limit doctors to membership in only one association, and doctors who disagree with the terms of a contract signed by their association can disregard the agreement and make their own deals.
There are four major independent practitioners' associations in Syracuse, with sizes ranging from 350 to 850 members. Administrators of national umbrella groups for such associations estimate that there are more than 3,000 I.P.A.'s across the country. A report by the Center for Studying Health System Change noted that the associations in Syracuse had grown faster than those in most other parts of the country.
"What we are looking for is to give physicians back the ability to make sure that they are giving their patients the kind of care they need," said Dr. Robert Corwin, a pediatrician and medical director at Healthbest, an association with 850 doctors. "In our negotiations with H.M.O.'s, we remind them that they are an insurance company, and that they are not responsible for providing health care. Those decisions must be left to us."
Some of the insurers, he said, "walk away." Others stay and negotiate, and in some cases, the doctors have won significant concessions.
After almost eight months of negotiations last year, Healthbest won a contract with the giant managed-care company Kaiser Permanente that would have restored to doctors the power to make referrals for their patients without getting the company's approval.
A spokesman for Kaiser Permanente's northeast division, Tim Riley, said that for the doctors at Healthbest, the contract was a "feather in their cap." After the Syracuse negotiations, he said, Kaiser Permanente decided to give all its Northeast physicians the same referral powers.
Lured by the ease of signing one contact that covers a large group of doctors rather than establishing their own community networks one doctor at a time, officials at Kaiser and other H.M.O.'s in the region said that they welcomed independent practitioners' associations.
Mr. Riley said his company had decided to put off its entry into the Syracuse market for now because a drop in earnings has forced it to focus on its current markets. But he said the company was excited, not offended, by the prospect of working with doctors in Syracuse. If Kaiser eventually decides to enter the Syracuse market, the contract with Healthbest will still apply.
Last month, Healthbest took its next step toward physician independence by beginning to market its own health plan directly to employers that have at least 200 employees.
"Physicians became a nonplayer at the table," said Dr. John Wight, a primary care physician affiliated with Healthbest. "Employers and insurance companies worked out their deals without doctors. These I.P.A.'s are the best chance we have for getting our place back at the table."

HEADLINE: 9 Gun Makers Called Liable For Shootings

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
For the first time, a jury has found that gun manufacturers are liable for shootings with illegally obtained handguns because their marketing practices fostered illegal gun trafficking.
In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, which legal experts called a test case for a wave of suits that have recently been filed against the gun industry, the jury found yesterday that 15 of 25 firearms makers named in the suit had been negligent. The suit was brought on behalf of victims in seven shootings. Of the 15 manufacturers found negligent, 9 were liable in at least one of three of the shootings -- two of them fatal -- in the New York City region in recent years. 
 The jury found that those nine manufacturers were collectively liable for the shootings -- even though it was not proved what brand of gun had been used in any of the cases -- because they oversupplied states with weak gun laws, which led to illegal sales in those with strict regulations, like New York.
The jurors found liability where it had determined that the companies' practices had been a "proximate cause," or a substantial factor, in the shootings.
The jury sent notes to the judge five times during its six days of deliberations, saying they were deadlocked. Judge Jack B. Weinstein responded to one note by telling the jurors that they were not to consider "the implications of your decision on others outside the courtroom."
"You must decide the case based on the evidence heard here and the law as I gave it to you," he said.
In what appeared to be a compromise verdict, the jury awarded no damages to relatives of the two homicide victims in the three shootings where it found liability. It found only that the surviving victim was entitled to $3.95 million in damages -- though, given the intricacies of the case, he would collect only about $500,000 under the verdict.
The jury also found that in four other homicide cases that were part of the lawsuit, none of the 15 companies found to be negligent overall were also shown to have had a proximate cause in the killings and therefore none of those 15 were held liable in those slayings. It was not clear last night exactly what factors the jury used to determine proximate cause.
The verdict was hailed as a victory by both sides.
Lawyers for the plaintiffs, and the plaintiffs themselves, said it was a major victory for the growing effort across the country to hold the gun industry liable for bloodshed with illegally obtained firearms, much as lawsuits have sought to hold the tobacco industry liable for deaths and illnesses caused by smoking.
"We held 15 of the 25 liable for negligence," the chief lawyer for the plaintiffs, Elisa Barnes, said after the verdict, which took a half hour to read and required a 42-page form to deal with all the issues in the suit.
But lawyers for the gun manufacturers held that the overall verdict was a victory for the companies because there was no finding of damages for six of the seven shootings that were involved in the suit.
As for the finding that the plaintiffs said was a major part of their victory -- that 15 of the 25 companies involved in the verdict had marketed and distributed their products negligently -- one of the industry lawyers, James P. Dorr, said that that finding involved "issues that are more appropriately submitted to legislatures."
Another lawyer for the companies, John Renzulli, insisted that "there's no rhyme or reason to this jury's verdict -- it makes no sense." Other lawyers on the industry side held that the verdict was the result of compromises by a jury that had clearly agonized over the case during a week of deliberations that, their own notes to the judge said, had been stormy at times and had led to several threatened deadlocks.
Lawyers for the gun companies said they would ask Judge Weinstein to throw out the verdict on the ground that it was the result of inappropriate compromises within the jury. Lawyers for the plaintiffs said they would ask the judge to assess damages in the two homicide cases where the jury had found that negligent marketing and distribution by some of the companies had been a proximate cause of the killings but had refused to assess damages.
There were nine companies that were found to have negligent practices and were also found liable in one or more of three shootings in the case: American Arms, Arcadia Machine & Tool, Beretta U.S.A., Bryco Arms, Colt's Manufacturing, Glock, Phoenix Arms, Sigarms and Taurus International Manufacturing.
Six other companies were found negligent but not liable for any of the shootings: Calico Light Weapons Systems, Freedom Arms, International Armament (doing business as Interarms Industries), Jennings Firearms, K.B.I. Inc. and Sundance Industries.
The plaintiffs were relatives of six people killed with illegally obtained handguns in New York City and Yonkers and a Queens teen-ager who survived a seventh shooting with a bullet still lodged in his brain. It was the teen-ager, Steven Fox, who was awarded damages.
The judge had ruled at the start of the monthlong trial, without giving a reason, that the jurors' identities would be kept from the parties in the case and the public. The move had not been requested by either side.
Most of the jurors left the court in cars with Federal marshals, but one of the jurors who walked out the front door, a man from Long Island, said the deliberations had been "very difficult."
"Some didn't like guns and some did," he said of the jury. "That's why it took so long."
The outcome of the trial is expected to be assessed not only by the firearms industry and gun control advocates but also by lawyers for Chicago and other cities that have recently filed, or plan to file, suits making similar arguments against the gun industry, much as states have sued cigarette makers.
Still other suits, filed by cities like New Orleans and Miami, are based on a different argument: that the gun makers have failed to include sufficient safety devices in their products. All the cities' suits are intended to recoup law enforcement and hospital costs stemming from gun violence.
In only one of the shootings was a gun recovered. But Ms. Barnes, the plaintiffs' chief lawyer, told the jury that this "simply doesn't matter." She and her trial colleagues -- Denise Dunleavy, Michael S. Feldberg and Marc E. Elovitz -- asserted that the gun makers made no attempts to keep their products from falling into criminal hands, like requiring wholesalers not to supply dealers suspected of selling the weapons to questionable buyers. "They don't care," Mr. Feldberg declared of the manufacturers.
And the plaintiffs accused the gun makers of oversupplying dealers in states with weak gun control laws or weakly enforced laws, particularly in the South. Many of the excess guns, they said, end up in the hands of illicit traffickers who resell them to criminals and youths in states with strong gun laws.
An expert for the plaintiffs, Lucy Allen of National Economic Research Associates, based in New York, testified that 90 percent of the handguns in crimes in New York State had recently come from other states, and nearly half from five states: Florida, Georgia, Virginia, North Carolina and Ohio.
A dozen lawyers for the gun makers denied that their clients oversupplied states that had lax laws on the sale of guns. They said there was stronger legitimate demand in the South for guns.
One industry lawyer, Mr. Dorr, told the jury that the gun makers could not control the "outlaws" who illegally trafficked in guns or who misused them in crimes, once licensed dealers legally made the first sales of the weapons. "There has been no evidence that negligence by any manufacturer was the proximate cause of these shootings," Mr. Dorr said, calling the plaintiffs' case "smoke and generalities."
