HEADLINE: Battle-Tested Sharpton Slips Into Familiar Role

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Just before the evening news the other night, the parents of Amadou Diallo, the West African street vendor shot dead by plainclothes police officers last week, walked up to microphones to offer their first extended public remarks about the death of their son. The setting was a second-floor auditorium up a scuffed flight of steps in Harlem. And the host, wearing a crisp gray three-piece suit and clearly enjoying this latest bustle at his Harlem headquarters, was the Rev. Al Sharpton.
It was perhaps inevitable. In the 15 years since Mr. Sharpton took up the cause of one of the four black youths shot by Bernard Goetz, he has developed a network of supporters, an articulate public presence and a command of politics and media that few other figures in New York can rival. As was clear again yesterday, as Mr. Sharpton assumed a prominent role at Mr. Diallo's memorial service, that arsenal has established him as arguably more influential than any black leader in the city, including those who have been elected to public office. 
 Mr. Sharpton said in an interview that he has never imposed himself into any of the half-dozen racially charged police cases with which he has been identified since the Goetz shootings in 1984, including this one. "I would not have contacted them," Mr. Sharpton said. "I feel that is ambulance chasing. I am not an ambulance chaser: I am the ambulance. People call me."
There was no need for Mr. Sharpton to chase anyone, indeed. Other Guinean immigrants called Mr. Sharpton after Mr. Diallo was shot last week, just as other Haitian immigrants called him after allegations that Abner Louima was assaulted in a Brooklyn police precinct in 1997. There are no other black leaders who are quite as well known, or have proven themselves quite as resourceful, as Mr. Sharpton. That has never been as clear as this week, when a bereaved family from another continent turned to Mr. Sharpton for help in dealing with a tragedy in New York.
The Diallo shooting has illuminated Mr. Sharpton's strengths -- and some of his weaknesses -- in racially charged situations. In the nine days since Mr. Diallo died in the Bronx, in a barrage of 41 police bullets, Mr. Sharpton has been able to assemble large crowds, on short notice, for rallies. He has brought in a network of people, including fund-raisers and lawyers, to help the Diallo family. And once again, by design or not, he has become the face of the opposition to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, serving as the Diallos' guide to this alien terrain as they rejected offers of financial assistance from the Mayor.
In the process, Mr. Sharpton, who for many New Yorkers will always be remembered as the unquestioning advocate for Tawana Brawley, has opened himself to the suggestion that he has turned an unknowing family's plight to his political advantage, putting them at the center of what is, in effect, a tug of war between Mr. Sharpton and City Hall. But there has been little criticism of Mr. Sharpton on this count so far.
"He has a genius for this," said Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor whose relations with Mr. Sharpton have thawed somewhat since Mr. Koch left Gracie Mansion. "He has the respect of the black community. He can deliver a picket line of large numbers when he decides he wants to. He's very quotable. And he's very smart."
Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat and a senior black elected official in New York, said that Mr. Sharpton had captured the role of "providing safe cover for people who have been victimized."
By contrast, Mr. Rangel said, it was more complicated for established black leaders -- the Congressman offered himself and former Mayor David N. Dinkins as examples -- to fill the role. "You know it and I know it: We have not gained the credibility that Sharpton has in case after case," Mr. Rangel said. "Why should they go to a local politician, especially one who is out of office?"
There is clearly more than a little envy among officials who have run successfully for office -- Mr. Sharpton has been a candidate, but has never won -- over his success at establishing himself as such a visible leader in New York. That is all the more the case because Mr. Sharpton, as Mr. Koch noted yesterday, has been associated with some incidents that would probably be devastating for an elected official, most infamously, his defense of Tawana Brawley.
Mr. Rangel, while praising Mr. Sharpton, said that he had been helped by what the Congressman described as an absence of leadership by other religious figures in the city on the Diallo shooting; to some extent, Mr. Rangel said, Mr. Sharpton had stepped into a void. At the same time, though, Mr. Sharpton has managed this week to bridge a large swath of New York political real estate. He was able to go from having lunch with Mr. Koch to appearing at a news conference with Mr. Dinkins standing behind him.
What is more, Mr. Sharpton has managed, with a few dissents, to present himself as a leader of a group of New Yorkers that is more politically, economically and ethnically diverse than ever: from old-line black Democratic leaders in Harlem, to the new groups of immigrants that are now jockeying for a place on New York's landscape, to prominent black business leaders who had once shunned him.
"When someone calls me, I don't have to gear up," Mr. Sharpton said. "They know when they call me that I have a staff that deals with this every day. I can walk into a situation and in five minutes say that we'll provide financial help. I can get on the media, I can get counseling."
Mr. Sharpton has become something of a self-perpetuating political force. Salimatou Diallo, a home-care attendant whose 12-year-old son knew Mr. Diallo on the street (and who is not related to Mr. Diallo), urged Mr. Sharpton to intervene in the case because she had seen him on television. "I told him that somebody was killed and we need him to come uptown to help," she said.
Within a day of being alerted, Mr. Sharpton arranged a news conference to draw attention to the case.
Last Saturday, during his regular Saturday morning address to the National Action Network, the organization he founded in 1991, Mr. Sharpton announced plans to hold a rally in front of Mr. Diallo's home in the Bronx on Sunday. These Saturday addresses draw 300 people even on a quiet week, and are broadcast on the radio. And 1,000 people turned out, on short notice, for the Sunday demonstration, encouraging Mr. Sharpton to call for a rally the next day at Foley Square.
As soon as Mr. Diallo's mother arrived here, Mr. Sharpton enveloped her; on his advice, she declined Mr. Giuliani's offer for city money to cover her expenses for accommodation and travel. It was, at least in part, a gesture that immediately undercut Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Sharpton moved her to another hotel -- the Righa Royal in midtown, where he held his primary night celebration when he ran for mayor in 1997.
Finally, Mr. Sharpton introduced the Diallo family to one of the best-known lawyers in the country, Johnnie Cochran. "Reverend Sharpton," Mr. Cochran said yesterday, "is one of a kind."
For his part, Mr. Sharpton said he had patterned his career after that of the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Jr. And that, he said, accounted for his success in New York. "Let's face it: If Secretary of Transportation Rodney Slater walked down 125th Street, people wouldn't know him," Mr. Sharpton said, referring to the black Arkansan President Clinton appointed to his Cabinet. "But everybody would know Jesse Jackson. I do in New York what Jesse Jackson does in the nation."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Man Charged in Killings Of Two Outside Tavern

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY

 BODY:
An unemployed Freeport man who told a tavern full of drinkers that two men had just been shot outside was charged yesterday with the men's murders, the police said.
The man, John Pierotti, 44, was arrested on Thursday a few blocks from his home and a mile from the scene of the Dec. 23 shootings, outside the Dragger Inn in Baldwin. Witnesses had reported seeing him talking to the victims shortly before they were shot, said Detective Lieutenant Frank Guidice, commander of the Nassau County homicide squad. 
 According to the police, the victims, Gerard Kennedy Jr., 36, and Willis Frost, 41, both carpenters who lived in Baldwin, had left the bar at around 1 A.M. and were sitting in a van when Mr. Pierotti knocked on the driver's-side window. The two men had seen Mr. Pierotti before: he came to the bar from time to time to sell used tools and other items he had found while picking through garbage, Lieutenant Guidice said.
An argument between Mr. Pierotti and Mr. Frost led to a fight, Lieutenant Guidice said, which ended when Mr. Pierotti shot him once in the chest. Mr. Kennedy, a volunteer firefighter in Freeport, tried to run but was shot once in the head, he said.
He said that Mr. Pierotti then went inside the bar and to announce that two men were dead outside, and the police were called. But Mr. Pierotti quickly drew suspicion, Lieutenant Guidice said. Told by officers that his car, which was parked across the street from the van of the two dead men, had to be studied for evidence, he abruptly left. A murder weapon has not yet been recovered.

HEADLINE: Finding Your Manners;
A Lost Generation of Executives Needs Help at the Business Table

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Judith Re joined her guests at the round banquet table, delicately placed her napkin on her lap, and began telling horror stories. There was the executive who routinely took her shoes off under the table, then lost one. The man who sneezed directly over the soup course. The woman who wiped her mouth with a piece of pita bread and then ate it. (Economical, perhaps, but not socially savvy.)
While her anecdotes did not exactly strike fear into her guests, they did remind the 11 men and women why they paid $275 apiece to attend her business etiquette class at the Ritz-Carlton on a recent evening. 
"Ladies and gentlemen, we're talking about breaking bread with your clients," said Ms. Re, an etiquette consultant who has cured many corporate executives of bad table manners. "We're talking about turning that restaurant into your board room."
Ms. Re, who has taught manners to children at the Ritz-Carlton for 12 years, began the one-night executive etiquette classes this year to help the increasing number of adults who come to her with questions about business meal propriety.
"The economy has become very full, and because of that, the people are doing a lot more entertaining," she said. "People want to sharpen their entertaining skills. What's happening is, people know everything there is to know about their business. That's what they've done well; they've learned their skills, and they're great at it. Now they want to master this. They want to make sure they're putting their best foot forward."
"In the 80's, people didn't have the same kind of feeling," she said. "They'd say: 'You must be crazy, Judith. We just have money and that's all that counts.' "
It pays to have the gift of manners these days. Corporations are seeking out consultants in savoir-faire to train their employees. Etiquette schools that once catered only to children and diplomats have started offering courses with such titles as "Business Etiquette for the New Millennium." One five-year-old consultant group in California, called the Workshoppe, finds a wealth of clients in the socially awkward executives of Silicon Valley.
M.B.A. candidates at Daniels College of Business at the University of Denver are required to attend an etiquette dinner, while the Massachusetts Institute of Technology runs a not-for-credit charm school each January. Ms. Re, who learned her manners at her parents' dinner table, says graduate students whose parents came of age in the 1970's had things other than p's and q's to mind, like the Vietnam War and the sexual revolution.
Modern times demand new rules, too. As Ms. Re's class supped on olive-crusted sea bass and filet of beef with caramelized shallots, the director provided lessons in pager protocol, cell phone etiquette and avoiding liability.
Paul Sullivan, a investment company director, said he took clients out to dine three or four times a week but still has shortcomings at the table.
"I still get confused about whether my salad fork is the one to the left or the right," he said as he practiced setting a table in a class exercise.
Anne-Marie Maguire, who works at Charles River Ventures, a venture capital firm, managed to prop her serviette into an M-shape, proclaimed it "good enough," and marched off to the soup course.
Ms. Re started her instructions with the basics. A Madeira consomme with truffle shavings is eaten by swiping the spoon from the 6 o'clock position to 12 o'clock. ("Seven to 1, that doesn't work?" Mr. Sullivan joked.) No blowing or slurping, please.
What to do when a dessert fork hits the floor? Or a glob of black tapanade plunks onto the white table linen? Mercifully, much of the success of the meal rests on the white-gloved servers, who quickly retrieve and replace the fallen fork and immediately swipe clean the mess with a sterling table scraper.
All pretty standard, right? Even those who think themselves well mannered were taken aback when the teacher advised against ordering alcohol at a business lunch.
"Ladies and gentlemen, I'm sorry," she said. "You don't drink wine on someone else's clock."
If a client has a questionable amount to drink, she said, "Please make sure that when the server is right next to you, turn to that person and ask, 'Would you like me to get you a cab?' " In acknowledgment, the word "liability" was murmured around the table.
(This being a dinner, and the Ritz being the Ritz, wine is served with each course.)
As the intermezzo of cassis sorbet was served, Ms. Re reminded her students to turn their beepers to silent at a meal and excuse themselves if they must return a page. Cell phones should be left behind, she said. If the client decides to take a call during the meal, she suggested continuing to eat, but more slowly. If the call continues for 10 minutes, "then you know you're in trouble," she said. "You've lost them."
"Do you eavesdrop?" she asked devilishly. "Of course."
Ms. Re's adult students can be even more nervous than her preteen pupils, timidly asking things such as whether it is all right to eat the entire spear of asparagus, or just the tip. (Ms. Re loves the whole thing.) But by the time they sipped the dessert wine (the fourth of the evening) the students had begun to rattle off questions. Is it allowable to switch between the American style of eating and the European style?
"I still feel like I'm eating upside down," Ms. Maguire said, as Ms. Re showed her how to use the knife to "escort" some garlic potatoes onto the back of her fork. Either style is acceptable, but no switching back and forth.
Are there certain foods that should not be ordered at a business lunch?
"I wouldn't order the 12-ounce burger with the au jus dripping off it," Ms. Re said. Linguine with clam sauce is her own nemesis.
Tonight's dessert, peach a la Ritz, was a challenge all its own: a mousse garnished with a foot-high triangle of chocolate lace. Rather than risk toppling the tower off the plate, most guests ate around theirs.
Although corporate attire had been requested, Ms. Re, dressed in a long-sleeved, toe-length black dress accented with a gold pin, was not out of place.
"I set the rules," she said when asked where she finds her etiquette knowledge. "I also listen to the pulse, everything from riding the metro trains to when you're traveling on an airplane. You're very visual, and you ask people questions, and that's what I do." She does not do color analysis or grin-and-greet classes, and no, she does not read Ann Landers.
A successful business lunch, she said, is all about making the client feel taken care of. If a client suggests a particular restaurant, go there in advance to choose the best table for conducting business. You can present your credit card to the maitre d' in advance, to save any confusion about who gets the bill later. Choose a seat that allows you to keep eye contact with the server, but gives the client the best view. If the guest has a coat or valet ticket, ask for it and pay the tip. Don't discuss business as soon as you sit down, but let the conversation flow naturally.
Many people say the time of the power lunch is past, that people are too busy to have lunch outside the office. For Mr. Sullivan, the business meal is a way to break through the "wall of technology."
"If it's just voice mail and just phones and our product is a little better than their product," then there's little to set the company apart, he said. "But if I can make that personal contact. . . ."
Ms. Re added: "Out technology is growing at such a fast pace that I don't think people have time to think. And I don't blame the people. I blame the technology."
"There's just got to be a choice about what you bring over into the millennium," she said. In fact, she mused, the Internet could be a good way to spread the gospel of etiquette.
For now, she sends each student off with a booklet of her rules. In it, she reminds them not to use long words when short ones willdo, and if they do not know how to pronounce the name of a wine, it is fine to order it by its number on the menu.
"The only way in which you can overdo it, ladies and gentlemen," she said, "is when you're pretending you're something you're not."

HEADLINE: Raking Muck

BYLINE: By Ellen Carol DuBois; Ellen Carol DuBois's most recent books are "Harriot Stanton Blatch and the Winning of Woman Suffrage" and "Woman Suffrage, Women's Rights."

 BODY:

TO KEEP THE WATERS TROUBLED
The Life of Ida B. Wells.
By Linda O. McMurry.
Illustrated. 400 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $30. 
 L inda O. McMurry's important new biography, "To Keep the Waters Troubled," tells the story of an extraordinary American who would have been at the very summit of our national pantheon except for two things: her sex and her race. But then again, being born into a society that promised individual freedom and personal power, just not to blacks, not to women and above all not to black women, was the source of Ida B. Wells's remarkable story.
Born in a Mississippi town just before emancipation, Wells (1862-1931) knew intimately the explosive combination of promise and disappointment that constituted freedom for African-Americans. Her hopes for lifting herself by education were cut short by a yellow fever epidemic that killed both her parents. Fearful that new, coercive state apprenticeship laws would take away her younger siblings, she committed herself instead to keeping her family together, facing not only the obstacles of an increasingly repressive white society but, even more, of heading a household without a man's protection.
Things only got worse when she moved to Memphis in 1881. In one of many fine localized accounts of post-bellum African-American life, McMurry, a biographer of George Washington Carver, describes this boomtown of the New South, where freedmen and immigrants fought over economic resources and political power. There, Wells became a journalist, one who was blessed (or cursed) with an extraordinary "ability to articulate outrage" against racial injustice. Praised as the "Princess of the Press," she was also ridiculed by rival black male journalists for "trying to be pretty as well as smart."
Wells vaulted to national prominence by daring to confront the issue of lynching. In 1892, a white mob dragged Tom Moss, a friend and black shop owner, out of the city jail, where he was being held following a shootout, and murdered him. Lynchings were on the rise in the South, and Wells became determined to protest them. In a newspaper that she co-owned, she published a series investigating and documenting the Southern lynching epidemic.
But her boldness went farther. She exposed as false the most common justification for these lynchings: that they were necessitated by sexual "outrages" committed by black men against white women. Perhaps only a woman could have spoken out effectively against these charges, but doing so exposed Wells to attacks against her sexual character. Her willingness to talk openly about rape and interracial sex kept her from succeeding the aging Frederick Douglass as "leader of the Afro-American race," the most respected Negro in the United States among whites. This role went instead to a man and a nonmilitant, Booker T. Washington.
In 1893 Wells fled the South, never to return, and relocated in Chicago, where for the first time in her life she turned to other black women for allies. Wells organized African-American women in Chicago to demand the vote and, once won, to use it effectively. Still, political differences and personality clashes combined to embitter her about what she regarded as the failure of other black leaders, female as well as male, to stand by her.
The one exception was Ferdinand Barnett, a man of similar militancy and complementary temperament, whom she married in 1895. Here, too, Wells broke new ground by maintaining a high level of public activity while raising six children. Her youngest daughter, Alfreda Barnett Duster, repaid her mother's dedication by striving for 40 years to get Wells's unpublished autobiography, on which McMurry draws heavily, into print.
This is a fine biography, one that will reward even those readers who already know something about Wells's accomplishments. McMurry does not condescend to her subject by ignoring her flaws or romanticizing her life. Instead, by evoking the complex humanity underlying an extraordinary record of public achievement, she does genuine honor to Wells.

HEADLINE: Inventing History

BYLINE: By Paul Mattick; Paul Mattick, the author of "Social Knowledge," is finishing books on political economy and modern art.

 BODY:

THE ESSENTIAL
GORE VIDAL
Edited by Fred Kaplan.
988 pp. New York:
Random House. $39.95. 
 Gore Vidal hasn't just written a lot, and he doesn't just write very well. His character and his thinking are complex, even contradictory, in ways that keep 30-year-old texts as fresh as his latest writing -- sometimes fresher. He's a living dialectical synthesis: a populist patrician; a ruthless critic of politics who ran for public office; a patriot who is an expatriate; a mocker of pop culture who spends a lot of time in Hollywood; a ferociously educated person who scorns academics; a gay man who refuses not only identification as "a homosexual" but the validity of the category; a paragon of post-modernity dedicated to the power of the "master narrative" of national history; a writer determinedly of our time with a bibliography that is 19th-century in its varied magnitude.
Fred Kaplan, the author of books on Carlyle, Dickens and Henry James, must accordingly be congratulated for the job he has done in distilling Vidal's writing for "The Essential Gore Vidal." He has dealt adroitly with the six novels chronicling American political history from the Revolution to the end of World War II; allotting the most space to the national turning points covered in "Burr" and "Lincoln," he includes just enough of all six to give both the flavor of each and a sense of the character-centered narrative that connects them. His care appears again in the choice of essays: a book review or a personal meditation suddenly reveals the source of a scene in a novel or another take on one of its central themes.
For example, in "Myra Breckinridge," a 1968 camp classic following a film-buff transsexual's conquest of Hollywood and the only novel included in full, the eponymous heroine states her mission as "the destruction of the last vestigial traces of traditional manhood in the race in order to realign the sexes, thus reducing population while increasing human happiness and preparing humanity for its next stage." Three years later, Vidal concludes an essay defending women's liberation by explaining that the "new restiveness" of the 70's reflects a "new desire to exist not as male or female but as human. It is very simple: we are breeding ourselves into extinction." As often with him, Vidal's idea is less convincing in the essay than in the novel, where it's a facet of a literary character's lunatic genius. Asserted without evidence or argument, it reads as the doctrine of a crank. Furthermore, as Vidal himself observes, population control doesn't seem to be what's actually on women's minds (or on those of the gay men and women whom, in a related essay, he sees as serving the same end). But Vidal is rather ready to be the voice of the historical necessity shaping insufficiently aware ends, a sort of homespun Hegel. A man free to judge the comparative worth of Socrates, Buddha and Confucius (the subjects of his novel "Creation") will not hesitate before explaining the true significance of feminism. On the other hand, a writer so devoted to combating the pretensions of the great monotheistic religions knows very well what the compulsion to spread The Truth can lead to: he has made Myra both mad and the carrier of his doctrine.
Admitting the risk inherent in his literary ambition, Vidal so identifies his maniacal heroine with himself as to have her express his views on the possibilities of contemporary fiction. "The novel being dead," she writes, "there is no point to writing made-up stories. Look at the French who will not and the Americans who cannot. Look at me who ought not. . . . Nevertheless, I intend to create a literary masterpiece in much the same way that I created myself, and for much the same reason: because it is not there." One need not read Vidal's 1967 critique of French theories of the nouveau roman -- though it's well worth doing so -- to see in this an announcement of his mature method.
Masterpieces are "not there" today because our moment is "post-Gutenberg and pre-Apocalypse," Myra says: the society that produced the novel as its pre-eminent literary form has led with its generalized corruption and mechanized inhumanity to the obsolescence of literature, whose place is taken by the movies and their idiot-box offspring. Yet Myra, who dedicates her life to the realization of the mythical archetypes of humanity in the films of the 30's and 40's, is a compulsive writer. So is Vidal; but his stories too are not made up -- that is, they are based on history, that of the classical world (as in "Julian" and "Creation") or of the United States.
It's different with the novels Vidal calls "inventions," like "Myra Breckinridge," the apocalyptic vision "Kalki" and the tour de force entitled "Duluth," set in a city located between the Great Lakes and the Mexican border, its motto proclaimed in neon on its tallest building: "Love it or loathe it, you can never leave it or lose it." A deadly serious and hilarious spoof of both American life and post-structuralist criticism, "Duluth" moves between the relative reality of the main story and novels and television shows within it, following the principle that "when a fictive character dies or drops out of a narrative, he will then -- promptly -- reappear in a new narrative, as there are just so many characters -- and plots -- available at any given time." In his essay on the nouveau roman, Vidal the semiotician explains that "by their nature, words are imprecise and layered with meanings -- the signs of things, not the things themselves." As such, they provide a bridge between different orders of reality, like the fiction-littered relationships in Duluth's boudoirs and the passionate novels, set in "Regency Hyatt England," by Duluth's leading romance writer. An even wider stretch is bridged in "Live From Golgotha," in which the memoirs of St. Timothy, St. Paul's boyfriend, are disrupted by the late-20th-century schemes of Japanese and American video corporations to televise the crucifixion of Jesus.
The inventions belong to the post-Gutenberg present; the historical novels preserve narrative ideals of the past. Vidal's ambition has been to trace the development of the United States from republic to empire, as a revolution and civil war fought in the name of freedom created a Federal power that as servant of the business class produced a globe-straddling system "in which men of property can do well and the others are on their own." Vidal brings out the tragic aspect of this tale most vividly in his moving depiction of the Civil War's political and human costs. But he insists as well upon a comic aspect, most sharply in following the self-seeking machinations that are the stuff of national politics; along the way, his chronicle traces the merger of politics and mass media. Hearst already "showed us how to invent news"; the movies "get into people's dreams." The Union Lincoln saved has turned itself into Myra Breckinridge's hall of mirrors.
For all the sympathy for the ruled classes evoked by the title of an early essay collection, "Homage to Daniel Shays," Vidal keeps his focus on the rulers of our world. Commenting on Suetonius' "Twelve Caesars," he insists on "the role of the individual in history," and the individuals he has in mind are those who can exert their will on societies. Grandson of a senator, stepkin to Jackie Kennedy, Vidal the populist and hater of empire is also capable of suggesting, in a 1986 essay, that the United States and the Soviet Union should ally to survive economically in the face of "the Sino-Japanese axis." The crackpot economics is less striking than the identification with America as political and economic entity.
Perhaps the best key to Vidal's productive contradictions is his portrait, in "Julian," of the fourth-century Roman Emperor, nephew of Constantine, who rejected Christianity to return to the old gods and defended the empire against its barbarian enemies while promoting personal liberty and public morality. Was something along these lines, mutatis mutandis, what Vidal had in mind when he left his literary plow, however briefly, to run for Congress in 1960 and for the Senate in 1982? These attempts were failures, as they had to be for a candidate who was on record as a vigorous critic of Christianity, who had called for unity between gay people and Jews as persecuted minority groups, and who ran -- in California -- against the military budget and for increased social services. This was probably lucky for Vidal, who would have strutted the Congressional boards, exploiting the camp aspects of American politics, at the cost of endless frustration or distasteful compromise. It was certainly lucky for us, as it left him free to sit in his Italian homes writing the stories and essays -- amusing, moving, provoking, always worth reading -- that Fred Kaplan has made it easy to look at and think about again.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4792 words

HEADLINE: The Disciples of Discipline

BYLINE: By Susan Bolotin
<BLB>A tough-parenting movement is telling permissive baby boomers they've been doing it all wrong, and John Rosemond is the pro-punishment Spock.; Susan Bolotin is a writer who lives in New York.

 BODY:
We all know them, if only by caricature. The parents who devote hours each night to the ritual of their children's bedtimes. The children with roomfuls of toys who complain of nothing to do. The parents whose phone conversations are really interruptions interrupted by conversation. The children who won't do their homework unless their parents are nearby. The parents who intervene on their children's behalf whenever a teacher delivers a bad grade, a rebuke, a punishment. The children so incapable of dealing with frustration they explode in rage whenever something goes any way other than theirs. The parents who acknowledge their children's fury; "I see you're angry," they say, until they, too, become so frustrated they cannot reprimand except by screaming. The children who think of no one but themselves. The parents who think of no one but their children.
 These are the parents, and these are the children, whom John Rosemond would expunge from the national fabric. Among an ever-growing group of usually conservative, often Christian givers of authoritarian child-rearing advice, he is the expert of the moment, largely because of a recent public dispute with T. Berry Brazelton over the timing of toilet training. But Middle America saw his day coming long before the potty wars hit the papers. Twenty years ago, Rosemond ("Train them by 2!") was a family therapist in Gastonia, N.C., with an occasional article in the local paper. Today, his weekly column appears in about 150 newspapers. His practice boarded up, the 51-year-old Rosemond wanders the country eight months of the year, the Johnny Appleseed of discipline, putting on nearly 250 shows annually. He publishes a bimonthly magazine, Affirmative Parenting. He operates a Web site. And his eight books, which have sold a total of more than a million copies, have experienced a 30 percent increase in sales over each of the last two years. There's more in the works: an infomercial to market a "take it home" effective-discipline kit; a series of nine hourlong programs being developed for possible placement on PBS; a series of "news" segments to be marketed to television stations. In the fall of '99 you'll even be able to take a cruise with John Rosemond. And when you return home, if he has done his job, you will, in his words, "fling open the door and say, 'Hey, kids, things will never be the same!' " 
It wasn't a cruise, but they came mostly two by two, as hopeful of salvation as the animals to Noah -- young married couples, women walking with the shared gait of friends. They came by the hundreds, across the lawn, down the sidewalks, heels clicking against the pavement, not talking much, up the steps to Wichita's Century II Convention Center. They came with the purposefulness of disciples, ready to receive the wisdom being handed out that day. And they were not disappointed. Though John Rosemond's posture is stooped -- think John Lithgow on a bad-back day -- his manner is straightforward, unambivalent. Part of that authority must come from familiarity with his material. Not only does he repeat three basic talks hundreds of times a year, but he also uses the same anecdotes in his shows that he uses in book after book. ("People don't notice," Donna Martin, his former book editor at Andrews McMeel, tells me later.)
"Are you the kind of parents who tell your kids to pick up their toys and then leave the room?" Rosemond asked. "Or are you the sort who wants to have a warm and fuzzy relationship going with the kid?" His disdain turned to parodic soprano: "I know, let's make a game of picking up the toys. The person who gets the most will get a bowl of ice cream after supper.' "
 Rosemond moved on. "If you punish your child," he advised, "he will hate you. He won't talk to you for three days." Beat. "It's a blessing. Take a vacation."
 The crowd laughed and clapped. They felt "empowered" -- a word I heard to this side of nausea -- by Rosemond. He may have been telling them they were jerks, but he was also telling them that they could change.
 They could realize that rearing kids is "a no-brainer." They could learn to ignore the "mental-health professionals who have convinced us, with the assistance of the media, that we were all raised in pathological, dysfunctional families." They could forget everything they've ever heard about building self-esteem in children. They could see their children as "direct descendants of Adam and Eve" and, as such, "inclined to mischief." They could start confronting their children every time they misbehaved, and then they could punish them. They could put their marriage at the center of the family. They could stop worrying about their relationships with their children and accept the challenge of leadership. They could make their children happy by making them well behaved.
 John Rosemond has not always thought such thoughts; indeed, the story of his transformation is proof that there really is no conservative like an ex-drug-taking, rock-and-roll-playing liberal. This is how he tells it: His parents divorced when he was 3; when he was 7, his mother remarried, to an older man who moved the family from Charleston, S.C., to Chicago. The marriage was marked by violence, first verbal, then physical. ("I wasn't traumatized by it, just scared to death.") His stepfather believed all emotions should be kept under wraps. ("When I cried over something, it was 'I'll give you something to cry about,' even if I was crying because I got beat up by the neighborhood bully.") When Rosemond was 15, he went to live in Georgia with his father, a golf pro, who gave him his own apartment. ("This was not good for me.") He finished his high-school years in Chicago. ("My mother moved into her own room with a bolt lock and her own refrigerator.") He then went to Western Illinois University, where he eventually received his master's degree in psychology.
 While there, he played in a rock band. He did a lot of drugs. He sported red hair down to his shoulders and a fatigue jacket with a flag sewn upside-down on the back. But after he was married -- he was 20; his bride, Willie Herman, was 19 -- it was time to get a job, at a community-health center in the mountains of North Carolina.
 Their son, Eric, was born in 1969. At first, John and Willie followed the advice of the "nouveau parenting experts" they despise these days. But their son's rambunctiousness and Willie's second pregnancy (Amy, their second child, is now 26) combined to make them reconsider. "Eric's behaviors were going to destroy our relationship," Willie recalls. The Rosemonds came to understand that Eric needed discipline of the old-fashioned kind, and the conversion began. ("This is Eric," Rosemond says, introducing me to his son. "His career," Eric adds, laughing.)
 As Rosemond's attitudes toward child rearing solidified, his politics turned toward the right. These days he cannot abide no-fault divorce; homosexual parenting; Selma Fraiberg's "The Magic Years"; sex-education programs; Thomas Gordon's Parent Effectiveness Training program; homework planners ("a source of codependency" between the overinvolved parent and the irresponsible child); single parenthood by choice; the inclusion of spanking in definitions of child abuse; TV; and Hillary Clinton and Marian Wright Edelman ("ultraliberals, leftists, socialists").
The Rosemonds' home in Gastonia is Country Living perfect -- sampler pillows, stenciled walls, racks and racks of pipes, George Washington hanging over the fireplace. But when Eric and his wife, Nancy, walk in with their two little boys, ready for a lovefest with Grandpa, it takes on the aura of a stage set. The afternoon feels rehearsed, and everyone in the cast -- including me -- knows his or her part. Eric ("I don't read the books, I don't read the articles") is there to scoff at Dad. "So, do you think he seems harsh, like not a fun person?" he asks me right off, laughing. "Well, I tell people he can dole out punishment with a smile on his face." Nancy casually but firmly minds the children, while Willie soothes any queasiness Rosemond's beliefs about women might engender. Rosemond is the well-rehearsed pro.
 Here he is, in nutshell version.
 * Parents should stop worrying about developing self-esteem in their children. If held accountable for their behavior and allowed to experience hardship and frustration, children will develop self-esteem on their own. Mothers, in particular, he says, are guilty of rushing in the minute the child begins feeling unhappy or distressed. "If there are two words that underlie self-esteem," Rosemond says, "they are 'I can.' Well, I was in a school recently. I walked into the boys' bathroom. Above the mirror, there was this sign that said, 'You are now looking at the most special person in the whole world.' This isn't self-esteem. This is narcissism. Today's child justifies anything. Bill Clinton is a prime example. He grew up with a single mother who told him his excrement didn't stink."
 * Spanking is fine, if done swiftly, occasionally, privately, in anger but not in rage, with the hand, on the rear.
 * Attention Deficit Disorder is not genetic -- as much as parents (who don't want to think it's their fault) and professionals (who want to continue treatment forever) want it to be. "Every 2-year-old has A.D.D., because the left temporal lobe is not sufficiently developed," Rosemond claims. Parents who pay attention to their children's proper brain development -- by shielding them from electronic media, making them focus on adult authority figures and expecting them to finish tasks -- cause this innate A.D.D. to disappear.
 * Toilet training should occur by the age of 2; otherwise, a child will become a spoiled brat. Here's how it's done, on the now-famous three-to-five-day plan: "You take their clothes off. You put the potty where they can see it. When they have an accident they scream, because they hate it running down their legs. Every time you hear them screaming you put them on the potty." Carpet cleaning is the final step.
 * Chores are essential. By their teens, children should be doing all kitchen cleanup, most of the housework and the lion's share of the laundry.
 * All disobedience, no matter how small the infraction and even if followed by an apology, must be punished. The punishment should be unpleasant, memorable and inflicted at a time that is convenient for the parent.
Rosemond talks like this until dusk, indefatigable, cool, even when I ask if it might be easier to get his point of view across if he separated it from his religion ("nondenominational Jewish-Christian," by his description) and his politics: "People need to understand that conservatives did not politicize parenting in America, that the people who did are people like Hillary Clinton and Marian Wright Edelman."
 I didn't know then that Rosemond has his eye on a possible run for the House of Representatives, but the information wouldn't have mattered; my role in our stage play does not include a debate about who politicized the family, how Hillary Clinton and Marian Wright Edelman came to be linked at the hip or why he's polarizing the debate. But the lighting is perfect -- dim, shadowy -- for a third-act confession: I tell Rosemond I'm a liberal, a feminist, a Jew. Child-rearing advice that evokes the Bible, even the Pentateuch, makes me uncomfortable.
"I've heard this before, almost always from Jews," Rosemond says, a crescendo in his voice. "My mother married a Jewish man, Julius Goldberg," he explains, "and they imposed their religion on me -- you know, Baruch ata, Adonai Eloheinu, melech haolam, borei peri hagafen. I could do it by rote in my sleep." To hear the blessing over the wine come at me out of the North Carolina darkness throws me. And it throws Rosemond, too. "I wore the yarmulke every Friday night," he contends, as if I am going to dispute his memory. "I respect all those traditions, but it's a little bit mystifying to me how people have these knee-jerk reactions."
 He's right. It is very easy to respond reflexively to someone still angry at his parents' religion; to someone who tells people to ignore the advice of experts while marketing himself as one, albeit of the aw-shucks variety; to someone who extols the virtues of the 50's family while admitting he was reared "in a bizarre family environment" -- the latest chapter of which is a rift with his mother so deep they haven't spoken in 10 years.
 It is also very easy to find other people willing to take on Rosemond. According to the executive director of the North Carolina Psychology Board, Martha N. Storie, the board investigated a complaint brought against Rosemond in November 1987; after an informal hearing early the next year, a reprimand was issued. In September 1995, after the board received another complaint, Rosemond voluntarily entered into a consent order, which stipulated that a state supervisor review his columns prior to publication. (Rosemond, who first told me of these incidents, says the first complaint referred to a column in which he said there was no evidence that putting a very young child into therapy was efficient either in time or money; the second complaint was a response to his advice to the family of an 18-month-old who had been sexually abused. He told them to forgo therapy for her, since she would never remember the incident anyway. His descriptions of the columns, which he stands by to this day, are generally accurate. They have been excised from the archives on his Web site.) Much more recently, Grace Reef, director of intergovernmental relations for the Children's Defense Fund, told me that Marian Wright Edelman has never worked on any legislation to make spanking illegal, as Rosemond claims, and that the C.D.F. knows nothing about any program that would mandate a visit to every new mother to assess her ability to mother, as Rosemond inveighs against. I'm sure I also could have found sociologists more than willing to label his thinking on women sexist. ("Women don't want men to be more involved, they just want them to be more at their beck and call.") But it seemed too easy.
 Besides, writing Rosemond off might suggest I don't recognize anything of my family in the ones he criticizes. I do, and have to admit that my husband and I have recently made subtle Rosemond-inspired shifts in our child rearing. Now when we say, "This is our car, and we are listening to 'All Things Considered' " -- that ultimate line in the sand -- we mean it. Our kids, age 10 and 13, look at each other, roll their eyes and mutter, "Brainwashed in Kansas."
 The people who adhere to Rosemond's philosophy would laugh at that -- for more than the obvious reason of our general wussiness. Their families had once been out of control, their children more headache than pleasure, but that's history. As Amanda Riley, a mother of two from Danbury, Conn., tells me, hearing Rosemond speak three years ago "rocked" her world, though the change in parenting style was not easy at first. "My daughter did not get that there were consequences for bad behavior," Riley recalls. "Since then, I haven't tried anything from Rosemond that hasn't worked. He's kind of like a religion to me. What he says is gospel."
 Juli Thompson, a mother of four from Kingston, N.H., is completely hooked on Rosemond -- "he turned me into a Republican" -- and visits his online chat room throughout the day. She, too, jokes that "Parent Power" is her bible and that she is a John Rosemond disciple.
 Riley and Thompson, like the other Rosemond fans I spoke to, were almost frantically gung-ho. But I don't want to discount their testimony any more than I want to discount Rosemond's. I know too many parents whose desperation is overwhelming, who have been so influenced by the "liberal" side of the debate that they now need permission to get tough. Indeed, I got the sense in Wichita that much of the audience had come hoping that Rosemond would make them feel O.K. about making their kids feel bad. Anna Kelley, a mother of three, certainly had. Just contemplating changes for her middle child, a 12-year-old boy with learning disabilities and A.D.D., filled her with hope, but when I called a few weeks later to ask how things were going, uncertainty had crept into her voice.
"If A.D.D.'s not genetic, how can two kids you raise the same way turn out so differently?" she asks. "Don't tell me TV is to blame. Still, we are getting all the TV's out of the house. Another thing we're going to do is to throw responsibility for homework back on him. He can repeat the grade, but something has to change."
 It sounded good, but not quite as if it was going to happen. "My husband, he's a nice person," Kelley finally says. "He wants to explain things. It's not that he doesn't want to do this. He can't. Is this something everyone can do? I think it takes someone like Rosemond. Confident. I could never be confident like that."
One of the items Rosemond hawks at his shows is a T-shirt with the slogan "Because I Said So," and an unquestioned, completely confident and predominantly male authority is central to his teachings. But that is where he and a large portion of parents, educators and psychologists part company.
"Generation by generation, there has been a tendency in the United States for parents to wear their authority in less authoritative ways," E. Anthony Rotundo, a historian at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., and the author of "American Manhood: Trasformations in Masculinity from the Revolution to the Modern Era," tells me. In the 1700's the father was the boss, with children occupying the bottom rung of the family hierarchy -- an economic position cemented by their being born tainted by the sin of Adam. But by the 19th century, children had come to be seen as innocent, and women as morally pure. That model has endured until recently, when, as Rosemond would explain it, the secularization of America wreaked such havoc that the more skeptical assumption about human nature has regained some footing. Even so, the more liberal model drives Rosemond nuts. He abhors it -- as the root of misplaced parental guilt (he claims parents think, If a child misbehaves, he's probably acting out some family dysfunction) and, much more essential for him, of what he calls "the whole self-esteem movement."
 Diane Ruble, a professor of psychology at New York University who studies self-esteem and development, can't figure out exactly what Rosemond means by a "self-esteem movement." But she suspects she knows his targets: people who focus on self-esteem as a goal rather than as a by-product of competent behavior. And she and many other people working in the field would now agree that self-esteem enthusiasts went too far when they suggested that children should be made to feel good no matter their effort or motivation. "If you bask in feeling good," Ruble says, "you never accomplish anything." Children should take pride in their accomplishments, not in the mere fact of their own existence.
 Isn't that simple common sense? Well, John Rosemond is a die-hard champion of common sense, often asserting that all parenting advice can be broken down into a series of aphorisms. "I'm going to give you enough rope to hang yourself." "You paddle your own canoe." "You can't get something for nothing."
 But what, I wonder, about that other maxim: "Don't hold a grudge"?
 And that's what troubles me most about Rosemond. I respond to some of what he says, but not to how he says it. "Gotcha!" he seems to bellow, delighting in every punishment doled out. And while research has shown that children turn out best in families in which parental demands are enforced, that is true only if the punishment is not punitive; loosey-goosey parenting may not work, but neither does "seeing and not hearing" children. Besides, where does the fun in rearing children get factored in? Where is the acknowledgment that complexity is not necessarily bad? Where is the intellectual adventure that comes from helping kids learn to discriminate between legitimate and bogus authority?
 My time with Rosemond has helped me develop a theory. I call it, in homage to the sociologist Arlie Russell Hochschild's "second shift" (the work a woman does after returning home from her paid job), "the third shift." But unlike Hochschild's work of scholarship, my theory is based on that grand journalistic standard: myself and a couple of friends.
 Somewhere along the line, my female friends and I took on, unasked, a "third shift" -- the job of family-happiness manager, juggling not only lessons and games and school events and nights out with adult friends, but everyone's emotional well-being, articulated or not. This is a thankless and exhausting task, particularly if it includes eradicating frustration and boredom from children's lives while simultaneously making sure they feel good about themselves. I accepted this work, without thinking much about its consequences, until I met Rosemond. And then it came to me like a nightmare. He might worry I was turning my children into the Bill Clintons of tomorrow. But I had another concern: what if I was rearing them to be Monica Lewinskys -- young adults who don't want jobs where hard work is expected, who turn petulant when they don't get what they want, even when what they're looking for is their own happiness.
 That realization -- that your kids can't grow up unless you let them do it for themselves -- is what I'll take away from this Rosemondian adventure. Or, as the man says, "You can't get something for nothing."
Emily Goldberg, a retired plant biologist, widowed last summer at 74, is as delighted as any proud mother to talk about her successful son. "He was a very nice little boy," she remembers. "Outgoing, accepting, very bright." But didn't he misbehave horribly? I ask, hoping she'll elaborate on some of Rosemond's own stories of his childhood. Didn't you and your husband tell him he would repeat the seventh grade if he got in trouble even one more time? "I have absolutely no memory of that." But what about spanking? "Julius didn't get along with anyone," she says of her second husband. "There was constant verbal abuse -- but he was not physically abusive." Well, certainly you put your marriage at the center of the family. "It's not biologically natural to put marriage at the center of the family!" she exclaims. Perhaps you say that because of your difficult marriage; after all, as your son told me, you slept in your own locked room. "John must have slipped off his track," Goldberg mutters. "Julius and I shared a double bed."
 What had I expected? Mother and son haven't spoken in years. ("It was over a piece of bedroom furniture," Rosemond told me. Goldberg's version: "He defrauded me of a piano.") Who can know who's telling the truth? And in the end, does it matter, particularly when compared to Emily Goldberg's cynicism about her son? "I'm very surprised he's become conservative," she says. "I think it's because the money is on the right. But I would not be caught dead reading a right-wing tract on how to raise a child.
"The rigidity of John's ideas about religion and raising children," Goldberg says in closing, "is the rigidity of a person who's come up against the hard truth of society: you can't change anyone. You can thank your ancestors, or you can curse them." Or, I think, you can pretend they just don't matter.
 Our conversation makes me sad. I am no psychiatrist, so analyzing it feels inappropriate, but I can't help thinking that the origins of this mother-child rift are more concrete than a piece of furniture could ever be. On one side of the chasm stands the son, the impassioned moralist, arguing that bad behaviors -- and bad memories -- can be eradicated through sheer will. On the other is the mother, the scientist, coolly insisting that no amount of scrambling can free a person from his biological destiny.
 It's true. You really can't get something for nothing.
 
The Disciplinarians
Parenting styles -- and parenting advice -- fall into three basic camps. Permissive parents try to reason with their children, demanding little, responding in an almost collegial way to their desires. At the other extreme are authoritarians, who see obedience as a virtue and their word as law. In the middle are authoritative parents -- firm but fair, valuing both autonomy and respectfulness. While John Rosemond and others in the back-to-basics camp can't agree on what labels to attach to themselves -- indeed, it's interesting to note that their politics range from moderate to conservative -- they agree on this: they all see themselves as necessary correctives to a pendulum that has swung too far toward the permissive.
 The academic dean of this group is William Damon, director of the Center on Adolescence at Stanford, a Ph.D. in developmental psychology and author of "Greater Expectations: Overcoming the Culture of Indulgence in Our Homes and Schools." A defender of the virtues of authority and an outspoken critic of those who give children too much freedom and autonomy, Damon thinks Rosemond, while "simplistic" at times, is "an important counterbalance to 90 percent of the people out there who have led" others "down the garden path." On the sensitive subject of spanking, Damon votes "no."
 Kevin Ryan's favorite topic is character development. And, he maintains, one way of developing character is through corporal punishment. Ryan, the director of the Center for the Advancement of Ethics and Character at Boston University and a Ph.D. in education, says "children are not born civilized." The parental job is to make sure that they become civilized -- by enforcing table manners (from the time kids sit at the table), establishing regular chores (from the age of 3) and punishing as needed. Spanking is "an age-old human teaching tool"; isolation and the denial of privileges are other punishment options.
 The name of Anne Cassidy's book -- "Parents Who Think Too Much" -- pretty much sums up the position of this journalist-critic: Parents read too many books (though presumably hers is an exception), place too little faith in their own instincts and allow their lives to revolve around their children to too great an extent. Cassidy says she thinks to spank or not to spank is a private decision. "Do as I say, not as I do," is a more-than-appropriate phrase now and then, Cassidy insists -- and if you don't, go to bed without your supper.
 James Dobson, who holds a Ph.D. in child development, is the grandfather of punitive parenting. His book, "Dare to Discipline," published in 1970 and reissued as "The New Dare to Discipline" in 1992, has sold in excess of 3.5 million copies. His call-in radio show, which these days is more about conservative politics than child care, is carried on more than 4,000 radio stations worldwide with a listenership of 3.5 million; some 2.5 million people receive his Focus on the Family newsletter, which is published in Colorado Springs. Dobson believes in spanking "under certain circumstances," says a spokeswoman, and thinks teachers should be allowed to administer corporal punishment; another option he recommends (for occasional use only) is the squeezing of the trapezius muscle between the neck and shoulder. "The shoulder muscle is a surprisingly useful source of minor pain," he points out. Dobson is a Christian; his premise is that children identify their parents, and especially their fathers, with God. Within that context, it would seem strange for parents not to demand respect.
 Much newer to the fray are Gary and Anne Marie Ezzo; a former pastor at Grace Community Church in Sun Valley, Calif., and his wife, who is a registered nurse, run Growing Families International, a for-profit organization "to provide resources that instill biblical principals for families." They are also the authors of a series of controversial Bible-based parenting curricula, including "Growing Kids God's Way," which has been used worldwide by more than one million parents. These are their basic recommendations: First-time obedience is expected; directions or commands are given once. Babies are fed on a schedule, left to sleep through the night by eight weeks and toilet trained between 18 and 24 months. Children are held accountable for "accidents" after two and a half years and should clean up themselves and their soiled clothing. Spanking is fine, beginning at 18 months, preferably with "a small piece of flexible leather or plastic to create a sting," says a spokesman; prior to that, parents can squeeze or swat a baby's hand.

PUB-DATE: February 14, 1999

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1930 words

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
A Playground For Technology's Arts of Illusion

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: KARLSRUHE, Germany

 BODY:
ART museums are tangible links to history, filled with stone and canvas dossiers attesting that human aspiration and conflict were as compelling in Titian's and Hokusai's time as in our own. As the traditional notion of reality fractures, and it becomes possible to imagine living in a culture that is largely illusion, the museum might be a bulwark against the loss of both past and present, or so says Hans-Peter Schwarz, director of the Z.K.M./Center for Art and Media here. In a book called "Media/Art/History" (Prestel), he writes: "A museum must always remain that impressive place where one can assure oneself of one's own reality and of the material reality of the historical and artistic evidence of history. It is perhaps the museum that can provide one of the last refuges for the sensual scrutiny of reality, particularly in this age of total simulations."
This might be considered an odd viewpoint for a man who heads the first and biggest museum of media art anywhere, a museum dedicated to simulation, hybrid arts and confounded perception. Yet even the Media Museum may come to seem like a bastion of old-fashioned direct reality if such visionary notions as "neural museums" implanted on chips in visitors' neck muscles are someday carried out. 
 The Media Museum is one part of the Center for Art and Media Technology (Zentrum fur Kunst und Medientechnologie), an institution that has no exact parallel in the world and not even a recognizable echo in America. Founded in 1989 and opened to the public in October 1997, the Z.K.M. has more than 48,000 square yards of usable space. It houses, in addition to the museum, an Institute for Visual Media, an Institute of Media and Acoustics, a media library, a media theater, a Museum for Contemporary Art and, under different direction, the State Academy of Design and the Municipal Gallery of the City of Karlsruhe.
Today's world is already a media-scape, with television following travelers onto planes, fashion shows on monitors in department stores, buildings flashing news and advertisements, and sports contests, rock concerts and political events reproducing themselves in real time on large screens for the benefit of those attending in person.
Artists have been trying to come to terms with the newer technologies since the early 1960's, when Nam June Paik compressed a television signal to a thin line on the screen and called it "Zen TV." The techniques of electronic art were largely pioneered by science and engineering museums years before art museums were interested, but by now most good-size art museums have at least exhibited individual pieces. In 1995, the media artist Bill Viola represented the United States at the Venice Biennale, and Gary Hill's interactive installation took the main prize there.
Still, collections and permanent displays are prohibitively expensive and require huge spaces, and most such art is seen principally at technology fairs and congresses. Enter the Z.K.M. and its few smaller peers, chiefly the Ars Electronica Center in Linz, Austria, which opened in 1996, and the InterCommunication Center in Tokyo, open since 1997.
Touring the Media Museum is like roaming an electronic theme park, a futuristic playground for grown-ups where miniature theaters, videos and oversize images morph, dance, respond to questions and urge visitors along on fictive journeys. Theme parks, incidentally, have been major players in the electronic field, where the entertainment industry is a driving economic force. Electronic games are now a $10 billion market worldwide, and designers and manufacturers in search of opportunity have made major contributions to the software and hardware of interactive applications. It could even be argued that the most prominent electronic artists are the generally unsung special-effects people for film and the graphic designers for Pac Man, Pong, Doom, et al.
At the Z.K.M., an installation called "World of Games," collected and developed by the Center, serves as both history and encyclopedia. And a day at the media museum, stocked with machines that manufacture unrealities, near-realities and super-realities, is the cutting-edge way to have that old-fashioned experience called fun.
The visitor can ride a stationary bicycle through Jeffrey Shaw's "Legible City," where all the buildings are letters of the alphabet, or touch what in this case are actual plants in Christa Sommerer and Laurent Mignonneau's "Interactive Plant Growing," making magical plants spring up in response on the screen. At the table where Masaki Fujihata has projected "Beyond Pages," an illustrated book makes a real lamp light up when a picture of a light switch is tapped with a pen, or causes a door projected on a wall to swing and a naked child to run in and out when a pictured doorknob is touched.
In Pierre Dutilleux and Christian Muller- Tomfelde's "ArchitectureMusic Labor," a visitor with headphones can hear the precise differences between the way Beethoven sounds in a cathedral, a Roman amphitheater, a bedroom or a cylindrical or a spherical space. Or one can hear how jazz, or snoring, or a flushing toilet, sounds in those same spaces.
The museum is both an education and a delight, though by no means does everything answer to that description. (Technology-oriented art has already amply proved that it can be ponderous, poky and dull.) The museum's system of labeling is hopeless; it is often hard to tell which exhibit is which. Though even art ought to be user-friendly, the programs for a few of the installations are difficult to decipher for anyone over 15, and a good many exhibitions were on the blink the day I was there. I have seen the future, and it does not always work.
Yet this museum makes clear how radically the traditional stance toward art has already been changed, with participation elbowing in on centuries of observation. In practice, this newly active role proves relatively circumscribed, as viewer-determined changes are almost always within programmed parameters. Such art also demands large quantities of time, negating the viewer's (if that's still the right word) expectation of control over how long to spend with a work of art. Video art alone can take irritating amounts of time before a viewer can tell if it's worth looking at. What's more, participation is seldom communal, except sometimes on the Net; one person at a console may be interacting with a machine but is not exactly sharing an esthetic experience with a friend.
The Z.K.M./Museum for Contemporary Art, which owns some 500 pieces, almost all from the last two decades, offers plenty of traditionally made art, yet it, too, has an uncommonly high proportion of media-related work, and these pieces outshine the paintings and sculpture on view in almost every instance. In Fabrizio Plessi's "Cariatide," a column of bricks sits atop a monitor with a video image of a brick wall, making a deft comment on the underpinnings of reality. Steina Vasulka's "Borealis" engulfs the visitor in sound and mirrored images of waves or stones that are seen first in painful close-up and then suddenly cascading down.
The Contemporary Museum will eventually become a separate unit and the Z.K.M. will concentrate on media art and research, but at the end of next year, a Collectors' Museum will open with a kind of parallel history of traditional art: shows from six private collections featuring art that dates from Rauschenberg and Warhol to the present, in old-fashioned mediums like paint.
THE Institute for Visual Media invites artists from around the world to work in its labs with high-end equipment for anything from a couple of days to a year. Bill Viola did his first interactive piece, "Tree of Knowledge," there. The institute also develops hardware and software tailored to artistic needs.
The Institute of Music and Acoustics, which occupies a blue glass cube built onto the Z.K.M.'s front facade near the entrance, offers composers and performers opportunities to work with the latest technologies and will foster research into the creation of new instruments (and doubtless new sounds). The composition program was established jointly with the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics at Stanford University.
The digital era has encroached on the age of mechanical reproduction in more areas than imagery; as Johannes Goebel, director of this institute, writes in "Media/Art/History," "Even sounds are no longer produced mechanically using muscle power, but indirectly, electronically."
The media library is compiling a comprehensive collection of contemporary music, which so far includes a digitized archive of electronic music, chiefly from the 1950's to the present; more than 500 videos spanning three decades, the first collection of its kind in Germany, and approximately 20,000 books and CD-ROM's on art of this century.
The media theater puts on public performances once or twice a week, ranging from lectures to concerts (electronic and otherwise) to traditional film to theater.
The Center is situated in an old industrial section of Karlsruhe, in a converted munitions factory, an immense building with open interior spaces laced with steel trusses, pipes that run up three stories to skylights and cantilevered stairways. Dr. Gerd Schwandner, the acting chairman and general manager, likes to think of the Center as a kind of disarmament program and happily points out that the new, neighboring office building of the federal attorney general is quite dwarfed by his institution. "You can see how culture is estimated in Germany," he says. "This country has the highest per capita expenditure on culture in the world. Hong Kong comes in second."
He says that the media arts have created the first global arts scene, and not only on the Net: just about everyone in the field knows everyone else. The number of artists is still relatively small, they all need to know the same things, they all attend the same conferences, and many pass through the Center at one point or another, often meeting at the media festival.
Appropriately enough, the Center itself has a global reach, with access to its home page on the Web (www.zkm.de) established in German, English, French, Spanish, Chinese, Japanese and Alsatian. It is providing expertise to Baptist University in Hong Kong, which is sending a few students to Karlsruhe, and, in addition to exchanging professors and staff with the faculty of science at Chulalongkorn University, in Bangkok, will also set up a multimedia center there. Yet another partnership is being arranged (with the Walker Hill Art Center) in Seoul, South Korea, to convert an established museum into one that emphasizes media. The Center has already collaborated twice on exhibitions with the Guggenheim Museum in SoHo.
The Z.K.M./Media Museum is surely the only museum in the world that has ever commissioned a video game, then put it on display. Though many of the installations ask hard questions about serious issues, the museum simply brushes aside the barrier between art and entertainment.
The historian J. Huizinga once wrote: "It is a general phenomenon that the idea which works of art give us of an epoch is far more serene and happy than that which we glean in reading its chronicles, documents, or even literature. Plastic art does not lament." Centuries from now archeologists sifting through the ruins of the Z.K.M. may think that this troubled century believed art was one game and technology another, and life was lived to play them.

HEADLINE: Cuba and Freedom

 BODY:

To the Editor: I have read "Cuba Draws the Curious, Despite the Law" (Jan. 31). Whatever justifications are raised for banning United States citizens from traveling to Cuba are negated by the law's blatant hypocrisy. 
 If the trade embargo on Cuba is a statement against Fidel Castro's restricting the freedom of Cuba's citizens, what kind of example is set when the United States restricts the freedom of its own citizens to travel where they wish? (I grew up in the United States, but currently teach fifth grade at the American School of Quito, Ecuador.)
 
ANTHONY SALM

HEADLINE: The View From/Fairfield;
Lawsuit Over Parking Stalls a Town Center's Redevelopment

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WHEN the Fairfield Store -- a clothing store occupying what was considered the best location in the Fairfield Center business district -- closed in 1996, neighboring merchants along the Post Road and town officials viewed it as the beginning of a transition. They also saw it as a wake-up call for serious economic revitalization.
For as long as anyone could remember, the Fairfield Store, at the intersection of the Post Road (U.S. 1) and Reef Road, was the anchor store for the whole Fairfield Center commercial strip, the hub upon which the fortunes of many other businesses turned. Without it, many feared the business district would slip into decay, as so many others have. Naturally, the future use of the Fairfield Store building was of great interest. 
 It looked as if the problem was solved in June when Fairfield's zoning board approved a plan by a local developer to consolidate the two properties that the Fairfield Store had occupied and construct a two-story retail and office structure that would house several nationally known stores.
But the development plan has gone awry over Fairfield Center's shortage of parking, and the disagreement of an opponent whose court challenge of the zoning approval has brought the project to a halt.
"Right now we're a dead town," said Frank Mercurio, owner of Mercurio's Market, directly across the street from the Fairfield Store building.
Had the project gone ahead as planned, it would be nearing completion now. Instead, empty stores punctuate the street where several have closed, and many of the survivors report sluggish sales. They say their holiday numbers were 25 to 38 percent below what they were before the Fairfield Store closed, according to Robert Bilek, executive director of the Fairfield Chamber of Commerce. "This one person is now holding up this major project," he said.
The one person is Doug Munson, a real estate broker who sued to stop the development saying it lacked the required parking under the town's zoning regulations and that a planned parking deck would harm the character of the neighborhood behind it. But Mr. Munson said that his real complaint is about what he called "corporate welfare."
In order to approve the development, the Town Plan and Zoning Commission allowed Starwood Ceruzzi, the development company, to retain the Fairfield Store's existing non-conforming number of parking spaces, and further reduced the required number by applying several other regulatory technicalities. Thus, the new development was approved with 289 parking spaces, although Jack Curran, Mr. Munson's lawyer, said the regulations really require 323.
Mindful of the chronic shortage of parking in Fairfield Center, town officials convinced the developer to agree to build a parking garage, and then license 65 of the parking spaces for the use of shoppers who wanted to go to other stores or to restaurants. "In a sense, this is like a subsidy," explained Sherri LaFleche, Fairfield's director of housing and economic development.
Mr. Munson, whose real estate office is next to the site of the parking garage, said he doesn't like the parking garage, and likes even less that the town's taxpayers will pay to help build it. "I'm opposed to the town paying for someone's private investment," he said.
He also said that town officials really want the parking garage to alleviate a shortage of parking spaces at the nearby Fairfield railroad station. "There's absolutely no planning in this town," Mr. Munson said. "They fly by the seat of their pants."
"This has nothing to do with railroad parking," said Ms. LaFleche, although she concedes that that is a problem.
Fairfield, says Ms. LaFleche, has the second busiest railroad station in Fairfield County, second only to Stamford, and the traffic flow to and from it is so congested that adding more station parking is undesirable. Instead, the town wants to build another station near the Bridgeport city line.
The subsidy of the parking garage is intended simply to help get a valuable piece of commercial property back in use, and not for some ulterior motive, she said.
The economic consequences of the lawsuit have hurt the town's business image, according to Mr. Bilek. "It has to do with how people perceive our town," he said. Because Fairfield Center isn't doing well, it reflects on the whole town as not a good place to do business.
But John Ceruzzi, vice president of Starwood Ceruzzi, said Fairfield might be in a enviable position, because many national retail chains are looking for affordable alternatives to Westport or Greenwich. The lawsuit has caused some of his prospective tenants, whom he wouldn't identify but characterized as household names, to look elsewhere, but he added, "They would like to get into Fairfield."
He called the Fairfield Store property the "premiere location in Fairfield." It is next to a town green and on the corner of a major road to the beach. The combination of that location and a new building, he said, would bring in premium rents for four to six retailers and two or three service company offices on the second floor.
In the meantime, merchants in Fairfield Center have had to make the best of it. Mr. Mercurio said he has noticed a decrease in his lunch business as the result of the Fairfield Store and others closing, but he said he wasn't hurt as much as some others.
The closing of the Fairfield Store came just as many business leases expired. The combination of rent increases and the loss of their anchor store proved fatal to several retailers, such as a vegetable market and a shop catering to inline skaters.
Spencer Schwartzbach, owner of Fairfield Stationers, which, like Mercurio's Market, is across the street from the Fairfield Store, said he shifted his business to printing services and office supplies, and created a Web site so that customers could order their office supplies over the Internet, to compensate for the loss of walk-in sales.
But Mr. Schwartzbach said he doubted that things would ever again be like they were when the Fairfield Store was open. He said that people just refuse to shop in Fairfield Center, browsing from store to store, like they used to.
Mr. Munson said that if he lost his case, which goes to trial in Superior Court on Thursday, he would appeal, to the state's Supreme Court if necessary.
"He can keep this tied up for years, as long as his pocketbook can handle it," observed Mr. Schwartzbach. He said he thought Mr. Munson was wrong for holding up Starwood Ceruzzi's development. "This is the best that's on the table," he said. "You have to go with the best you have."
Originally, Mr. Munson was joined in his suit by two other businessmen, but they have since dropped out after meeting with the developer. Some have speculated that Mr. Munson was holding out for a settlement but he said that he has turned down an attractive settlement offer.
Mr. Bilek noted that the lawsuit has cost Mr. Munson some friends. "Some of these people," he said of the Center's business owners, "were really close to Doug."
Mr. Munson said he is strongly opposed to the town's subsidizing private development and concerned that the entry of national retailers might alter the character of the town. "I'm seriously considering running as an independent for First Selectman," he said. "They're trying to change our town and make it a big corporate thing."
