HEADLINE: In the Region / Westchester;
Westchester and Putnam Post Record Housing Sales

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
BOTH Westchester and Putnam Counties posted records last year in residential sales and resulting dollar volume, according to figures released late last month by the Westchester County Board of Realtors.
In Westchester, where records were reported for a third successive year, there were 9,967 sales with an aggregate value of $3.3 billion. That represents an increase of 17 and 24 percent, respectively, over the 1997 figures of 8,504 sales worth $2.6 billion. 
 In Putnam, there were 2,425 sales totaling $755 million, increases of 36 and 47 percent, respectively, over the 1997 figures of 2,189 and $655 million.
"We're really part of a national phenomenon" said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Board of Realtors, whose members represent both counties. "Westchester and Putnam just have a greater amount of improvement, as far as volume of business, in all property categories."
Mr. Mercurio attributes the sales pace to the health of the economy and low interest rates.
"This is indicative of continued consumer confidence, not so much in Westchester itself, but in New York City," Mr. Mercurio explained. "Job growth in Westchester has been anemic and the office vacancy rate is high. If you looked at the economy of Westchester alone, you'd be hard-pressed to explain the residential numbers. But it really represents the fact that people who work in the city are now ready to make the move to the suburbs."
One distinguishing feature this year, for all property categories, except condominiums, is that average prices in Westchester increased by 7 to 8 percent from the prior year.
"This is the first real appreciation we've seen," Mr. Mercurio said. "In past years, prices have just kept pace with inflation, but these increases are beyond that."
In the detached-house category, which accounts for 67 percent of all sales, the median sale price was $320,000, up 7 percent over 1997. The median price of a two- to five-family house was $215,000, up 8 percent from the prior year, as were co-ops, which sold for a median price of $79,698. Only condominiums, with a median price of $162,500, saw no appreciable increase in price.
The price increases are largely due to a greater number of buyers selecting higher-priced properties, Mr. Mercurio said. "Most of these buyers are coming from New York City," he said. "Because the market is so good there, those buyers are able to sell their co-op apartments and are buying the most expensive properties."
CAROLINE SHEPHERD, regional manager for Coldwell Banker's Previews luxury homes marketing division, said she had noticed a great deal more activity in higher-priced homes.
In the New York area, Coldwell Banker recorded 367 sales of homes priced over $1 million, a 32 percent increase over 286 the year before. The average sales price increased from a record $1.5 million in 1997 to $1.6 million in 1998.
Nationally, the increases were even more dramatic. In 1998, Coldwell Banker participated in closings on 4,305 properties priced over $1 million with a total sale volume of $7.32 billion. That represents an increase of 78 percent in the 2,421 properties sold in 1997 and an 84 percent increase in the dollar volume of $4 billion the previous year.
In Westchester, the highest-priced house sold by Coldwell Banker in 1998 was a five-bedroom, five-bath colonial in Bedford, for $4.4 million. The highest price in 1997 was $2.4 million for another house in Bedford, Ms. Shepherd said.
All of this sales activity has had a sharp effect on the number of homes on the market. By year's end, Westchester's inventory of 4,634 residential properties was 25 percent below 1997's level of 6,203. Putnam County's inventory fell to 830 properties last year, down 23 percent or 1,072 from the year before.
"Inventory is definitely down," Ms. Shepherd said, "and not only for high-priced properties, but for all houses."
This often manifests itself in bidding wars, according to Arline Dahlman, manager of the Katonah office of Randolph Properties.
"Katonah is so hot now that houses are selling almost immediately," Ms. Dahlman said. "With its art galleries, museums and quaint streets, it seems to be very popular with young families, who want a sense of old-time comfort."
Recently, a four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath colonial farmhouse came on the market for $429,000, and immediately had eight offers. "It wound up selling for $25,000 more than its list price," Ms. Dahlman said.
When Heike Schulte and Peter Fraenkel, who live in Manhattan, decided to look for a house in Westchester they said they were shocked at the competitive atmosphere.
The couple looked for a year before finding a three-bedroom colonial for $314,000 in Dobbs Ferry. They closed three weeks ago.
"One time we saw a $300,000 house we liked," Ms. Schulte said. "Then five people bid on it and the price went up to $340,000. At one point, we almost gave up and said, "We just can't afford to move.' "
As a result of the lack of inventory and higher prices, many buyers have been opting for more affordable options by looking north to Putnam County. "As Westchester benefits from New York City, Putnam benefits from Westchester," Mr. Mercurio said.
ONE Putnam development in Kent, called Sparrow Ridge, started in 1996, and is now two-thirds sold out, according to Lenard Thylan, president of Thylan Associates in Manhattan, which is developing the project.
Sparrow Ridge has 116 units, with two-bedrooms and two-and-a-half baths, some with den and basement, priced from $163,900 to $210,000. "The fact that it's in Putnam and that I bought the land at exactly the right time enabled me to offer an affordable product," Mr. Thylan said. "In Westchester these homes would cost $50,000 to $75,000 more."
When Jill Roberts and her husband, Don, a mail carrier for the United States Postal Service in Bedford, were looking to move out of their co-op in Yonkers, they couldn't find anything they wanted in their price range in Westchester. So they looked in Putnam and will soon be moving into Sparrow Ridge. "It had everything we wanted -- privacy, a garage, a fireplace," Ms. Roberts said. "We never expected and didn't want to leave Westchester. I've lived in Yonkers my whole life."
Living in Putnam will mean that Ms. Roberts, who works as a executive secretary for Coca-Cola in Hawthrone, will have a longer commute. "It will be 33 minutes instead of 12," Ms. Roberts said. "But we really had no choice. There was just nothing for us in Westchester."
Since sales began at Sparrow Ridge in 1996, prices have increased 10 percent, Mr. Thylan said. "We're getting all ages," he said. "This kind of housing appeals to young families and empty nesters. I wish I could do more of it, because the market is there, but unfortunately there's no buildable land left."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property / New Jersey;
After a Lull, a Comeback for Morris County Offices

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
SLEEK new corporate buildings are again sprouting in Morris County, which blossomed into one of the state's larger suburban office markets during the construction boom of the mid-80's.
The boom was muted by the subsequent recession, but the push to develop, albeit at a slower pace, resumed two years ago and is now gaining momentum. 
 Work on projects under way, recently completed or about to begin currently totals more than 1.6 million square feet, according to Associated Realty, a commercial brokerage in Parsippany. Several of the buildings are being put up "on spec" -- without signed leases in place for any of the space. The "spec" projects under construction include a 350,000-square-foot building nearing completion in Parsippany, a 203,000-square-foot structure under way in Madison and a 220,000-square-foot, two-building complex about to be started in Morris Township.
In addition, three build-to-suit projects totaling 910,000 square feet are being developed for specific users.
Most of the construction is taking place in proven locations, along highway corridors and in existing corporate parks in the eastern half of the county, an established business address. As such it picks up essentially where the rush to build offices left off earlier this decade, said Thomas A. Reilly, senior vice president at the Teaneck office of CB Richard Ellis, a national commercial brokerage. "The market is craving some new buildings," Mr. Reilly said. "The difference is that they are taking shape at a much more cautious rate."
The caution stems from the overbuilding a decade ago. Financing for speculative projects today also is tight and became even tighter after the stock market slide last August rattled nerves on Wall Street, industry professionals said.
About three-fourths of the county's 23 million square feet of office space was built in the mid-80's. So when the recession hit the county was left with a surfeit of space, which raised the office vacancy rate d to 33 percent at its peak in 1991 and slowed construction through 1996.
Since then New Jersey's healthy economy and job market has encouraged companies to grow, helping to absorb much of the excess space. Brokers say Morris County is now one of four markets in the state where space is tight enough, rents have risen high enough and demand is strong enough to justify new construction. The others are Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront, the Princeton Route 1 corridor in the center of the state and the Interstate 78-287 corridor in Somerset County.
The demand for space in Morris County is coming mostly from local companies -- including insurance, financial, pharmaceutical and telecommunications concerns -- expanding or consolidating, said Eric N. Witmondt, president of Associated Realty.
"These represent not only growth moves but a flight to quality," Mr. Witmondt said.
Some companies, he added, are also relocating to the county, which continues to be bolstered by a location that provides access to major highways as well as to labor.
State Farm Insurance, for example, recently announced that it would relocate its northeastern regional headquarters from Wayne in Passaic County to Parsippany. It will build a 400,000-square-foot complex, jump-starting development of the Center of Morris County, a 90-acre office park just south of the intersection of I-80 and I-287 that eventually will contain 850,000 square feet of office space.
AS of the end of the year the vacancy rate in the county was 13.2 percent, down from 13.6 percent a year ago, and the vacancy rate for Class A space was 9 percent, down 9.2 percent. At the same time overall average annual asking rents have risen to $23.26 from $22.24 and asking rents for prime space increased to $25.51 from $25.15, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
With large blocks of prime space limited, some growing companies, like Newcourt Credit Group, have sought out build-to-suit opportunities in the county. The Toronto-based financial services firm will relocate its United States headquarters from Parsippany to Hanover when the first 272,000-square-foot building of a three-building, 750,000-square-foot complex on 80 acres off Eden Lane is completed in 2000. The developer of the more than $80 million complex is Eden Wood Realty Group of Whippany.
Explaining Newcourt's choice, Robert J. Ingato, its executive vice president, said there were few existing suitable buildings to choose from and fewer still that fit his company's expansion needs. Newcourt, he said, plans to double its New Jersey workforce, now about 1,000 employees, in five years, adding that staying in the area will enable his company to retain existing employees and attract new ones. Mr. Ingato said Newcourt would lease the first structure at the complex for 15 years and had options to lease the other two buildings.
The county's tightening market has also encouraged developers to proceed with projects on speculation. But, the difficulty in obtaining financing for such projects "will keep demand in balance with supply and the market at a status quo at least through next year," said Donald P. Eisen, executive managing director for the New York area at Cushman & Wakefield, another national commercial brokerage.
The largest speculative building in this round of development is Morris Corporate Center IV, a 350,000-square-foot structure nearing completion in Parsippany. The building is the latest addition to Morris Corporate Center, a 135-acre business park at the intersection of I-80 and Route 202, where 1.5 million square feet of an eventual total of 2.2 million square feet has been developed and is fully leased.
Given that and the low vacancy rate in the county, Peter Eppie, senior vice president at SJP Properties off Parsippany, the park's developer, said:
"We are confident this building will continue the park's proven track record since no other building of this size, quality or location will come on the market in the next 18 months." The company is developing the building, reported to cost $70 million, in partnership with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, based in Newark.
Mr. Eppie said discussions were under way with a few users for either all or half of the space in the building, adding that rents would be competitive. (Grubb & Ellis says that similar space in Parsippany rents for $26.71 a square foot.) As soon as a significant portion of the building is leased his company plans to start construction on another 350,000-square-foot structure, which would complete the park, he said.
AT Park Avenue at Morris County, a 90-acre corporate center on Park Avenue in Florham Park, construction is winding down on the last of four speculative buildings. That 175,000-square-foot building -- like the other three, which are of similar size and among the first to rise in this development wave -- is nearly fully leased. When finished it will complete the 1-million-square-foot park, half of which was built before 1991.
"We had the right product at the right time," said Mark Yeager, president of the commercial group at Gale & Wentworth, a real estate services and investment company in Florham Park that developed the four buildings for the J. P. Morgan Investment Company in Manhattan, the park's owner.
Encouraged by that response Mr. Yeager said his company, in partnership with Morgan Stanley, the Manhattan-based investment banking firm, which is not part of J. P. Morgan, has started or will soon start construction on two other speculative buildings in the county.
One, a $40 million, 203,000-square-foot building, is rising on 20 acres within the 184-acre Madison Township portion of Giralda Farms, once the estate of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge. The former estate now has headquarters for major corporations such as American Home Products, Schering-Plough and Atlantic Mutual Companies. By midsummer the partners also plan to start a $30 million, 175,000-square-foot building at their Center at Morris County in Parsippany, where State Farm Insurance intends to build its new regional headquarters.
Mr. Yeager said it was the right time to build given that "the dynamics of the real estate market are still strong and the supply of space is being absorbed and will remain stable because of the strict financial governance on new development." Rents at both buildings, to be completed by the second quarter of 2000, are expected to be in the $24- to $26-a-square-foot range, he said.
In Morris Township, Schenkman/Kushner, based in Bridgewater, has begun transforming 36 acres off Mount Kemble Avenue, also Route 202, and not far from I-287, into a 220,000-square-foot, two-building business park. The developer is using its own equity and bank financing to build the more than $40 million project, known as Mount Kemble Corporate Center.
"There's always a risk with speculative construction, but with the tremendous demand for quality space in this market it's a risk worth taking," said Jeffrey Persky, vice president at Schenkman/Kushner. To capture that demand, he added, "You can't sell from an empty shelf."
Mr. Persky said the two buildings, which have been designed to accommodate one or several tenants, are to be completed by the end of the year. Annual rents are expected to be $24 a square foot.

HEADLINE: The Secret Ingredients of Enduring Romance;
First, Start With Friendship. Second, Add the Rest

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

 BODY:
WHEN she was 19, Vickie French had a set of secret criteria for prospective dates and mates. "A guy had not only to be romantic and fun, he had to be nice to my little sisters," she recalled recently. "I figured, if the romance wore off, I'd still have a nice person."
A tall, square-jawed young man named Stephen Morris handily passed the test. Today, the Morrises -- he's 55, she's 53 -- have a 32-year-old storybook marriage that might sound saccharine if they were not so genuinely nice and down-to-earth about it. They are each other's best friends and confidants, they said, talking late into the night about the frivolous and serious; helping each other through life's inevitable crises. "When my father was dying, I could come home from the hospital and climb into bed with this person who was my rock; I could relax and feel safe," Mrs. Morris said. 
 Nor does their life lack romance. As a joint Valentine's-anniversary celebration (they were married Feb. 18, 1967) they will have a candlelight dinner at a restaurant near their Katonah house. Even ordinarily, candlelight flickers for dinner in the dining room. The bedroom, with its vast bed, cathedral ceiling and chintz draperies on windows overlooking an eight-acre spread, could be the honeymoon suite in a country resort. "Romance doesn't have to fade," Mr. Morris said. "If you cultivate it, you can keep it forever."
Despite the much discussed frequency of divorce in Westchester and elsewhere, the Morrises are not alone. True, they are blessed with a particularly pleasant-sounding life: he is president of Arbitron, a media-information company in Manhattan; she pursues her passion for art as a trustee in charge of development at the Katonah Museum. Their two children are grown and involved in careers of their own. Their home is surrounded by gardens they tend together. But regardless of financial or professional status, it seems that couples whose relationship is built on friendship fare well in marriage.
Statistics, of course, provide only a limited amount of information -- and are surprisingly hard to come by. The 1990 United States Census Bureau count is the most recent available for the total number of married people in Westchester; in that year, there were 203,500 married men and 206,583 married women living in the county, Noreen Preston, economist with the county Department of Planning, said. (The discrepancy derives from spouses living out of the county.)
In terms of the number of new marriages, the most recent figures available are from 1996, when there were 6,665 marriages (and 2,497 divorces and 17 annulments) in Westchester, according to Frances Tarlton, spokeswoman for the State Department of Health.
But in an admittedly tiny and strictly unscientific survey of a number of happily married couples, mental compatibility ranked highest in the list of must-haves for a successful marriage. Marriage and family therapists, like Dr. Jody Shachnow, clinical social worker at New York Presbyterian Hospital-Cornell Behavioral Health Care, Westchester Division in White Plains, say "a good fit emotionally" is paramount. "In the best marriages, minds tend to fit like pieces in a jigsaw puzzle," she said. "They don't have to match on every issue, but they need to mesh."
Joyce Levin, who practices family and couples therapy in White Plains, said: "Married people need to talk to and listen to each other. The most common complaint I hear is lack of emotional intimacy."
Interestingly, the requisite cerebral and emotional -- as opposed to merely physical -- connections often seem to be there from the very beginning. Dr. Shachnow said that most compatible couples love to retell the story of how they met and, frequently, how they spent hours and hours just talking.
"We had this one bench on campus, at Knoxville College in Tennessee, we called it our bench, where we'd sit and talk, all the time, day after day," Dedrian Vandiver, a 28-year-old medical receptionist, recalled. She and her 29-year-old husband, David Vandiver, a mathematics and physical education teacher and basketball coach at R. J. Bailey Elementary School and Woodlands Junior and Senior High School in Greenburgh, live with their 9-year-old son, D'Andre, and 3-month-old daughter, DeJah, in a high-rise apartment building in Greenburgh.
Sitting amid the things they have amassed in a year and a half of marriage -- African art posters, figurines of jazz musicians, a blond wood armoire she particularly likes -- she remembered her husband's marriage proposal. "I kept telling him, 'Don't propose to me unless you have a ring.' We'd taken this vacation in the Poconos, and I was sitting in the Jacuzzi in our room. All of a sudden, he gets up, runs to get something. It's this ring in a box. He kneels down at the edge of the Jacuzzi and before he could get the words out, I shouted, 'Yes.'
For Mr. Vandiver, the most important thing about marriage has been a sense of permanence and togetherness. "When our son was born, I made a vow to myself, I was going to get to Dedrian and do it right," he said, observing that she was initially the one reluctant to get married. "I believe that being married, having a good family structure, is exceptionally important. Dedrian and I complement each other; we understand each other's moods. This is very important: being married to someone you really love and who really loves you, knowing you have someone in your corner, someone you can turn to and trust, other than your mom."
As in anything else, when problems arise in a marriage, they range from terribly big to seemingly trivial. Dr. Shachnow, the clinical social worker, said children, money, sex and in-laws are major areas of contention. Ms. Levin said that bad bouts of alienation can be set off by a spouse forgetting to take out the garbage.
The Morrises, who said they rarely argue, said they learned to "develop common interests" to minimize certain differences in style. "Both of us started with the expectation that this was going to be a lifetime thing, and with the knowledge that at times it would require work," Mrs. Morris said. "He was from Oyster Bay, L.I., from a family of four boys, very practical, lots of inherited furniture, chintz that did not shine, the same Harris tweed coat and family photos for several generations. I was from a family of three girls, where everything was pretty and fancy and we loved art and museums. We both taught each other a lot."
Bob and Toni Henry, who are 74 and 69, respectively, and have been married 50 years, early on figured out how best to complement each other. "I let her take care of the finances," Mr. Henry, who ran a milk-delivery company, said. Mrs. Henry added with a laugh, "He ran the business and brought home the money, and I apportioned it out."
The Henrys, who live in a compact brick split-level house in Valhalla, believe that being in a milieu where they feel comfortable has enhanced their life together. Mr. Henry grew up in Valhalla (his father founded the R. B. Henry Milk Company) and Mrs. Henry grew up in White Plains; both went to White Plains High School although they did not meet until shortly after they had graduated. After they married, they lived in a series of houses in Valhalla. Their friends were neighbors, firefighters, police officers, teachers and shopkeepers.
"We had barbecues, cookouts, we went to each other's homes all the time," Mrs. Henry said. "Among our closest friends, the 12 couples we were closest to, there has not been one divorce. We lived in the kind of neighborhood where every mother fed, dressed and put her children out in the street to play with neighborhood children; it was that safe and close knit."
Things are considerably more complex these days. Sally and Bill Frank, who have been married 13 years, find that many of their waking hours revolve around their 10-year-old daughter, Alex, and 8-year-old son, Andrew. Mr. Frank, 50, is chief operating officer of Cognitive Arts, an educational software company based in Manhattan; Mrs. Frank, 43, works as an account executive for Harrison Edwards, a public relations concern in Bedford Hills. When they got married, they lived in Brazil, then Palm Beach, Fla. Now they are settled in Pound Ridge, in a handsomely restored 200-year-old farmhouse with wide-plank floors and the original fireplace and dutch oven.
Their existence seems like that of the ideal busy late-90's family, yet they have consciously had to work on making time for the children and themselves as a couple. Alex and Andrew are active in all the usual suburban extracurricular activities -- baseball, ice hockey, basketball, soccer -- plus Alex and Mrs. Frank ride horses. The couple have "excellent communication in all areas," they said. Even when he is traveling, he feels the need to call and talk to her several times a day -- but the one thing they wish they had more of was time. "We feel it is crucial to have lots of time with the children," Mr. Frank said. "For example, I love golf, but I've pretty much given it up. On weekends, I want to do things with the kids -- sports, shopping, barbecues, whatever."
It is time well invested, Mrs. Frank said. "This is a truly good marriage, and because the children spend so much time with us, they see that -- they sense it and feel it -- they see the essential give-and-take of a good marriage."
In the case of the Henrys, even the best marriage can be tested by tragedy. On March 23, 1974, their 20-year-old son, Robert, was killed in a car accident. For several years, Mrs. Henry said, they "moved like robots" around each other, not saying much, damming up their grief with silence. Finally, their daughter, Joanne, begged them to face their feelings. "It's something we'll never get over, but it did help us to begin talking about it together," Mrs. Henry said.
Indeed, death is something that even the most contented couples -- perhaps particularly the most contented couples -- have a hard time confronting. "Being happily married makes the thought of getting older easier," Mr. Morris said. "On the other hand, I have moments of thinking, What if something were to happen to her first? You're joined at the hip and the thought of getting unjoined is . . ." His wife took up the thought. "We'd like to go together when the time comes -- just go up on a cliff and disappear together."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Art From Africa
An exhibition of art from three distinctive areas of the African continent may be seen at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through April 18. Some 64 sculptures and masks created by the Dogon of modern-day Mali and Burkina Faso; the Fang, from Equatorial Guinea, Southern Cameroon and Gabon; and the Songye, who live between the Sankara and Luabala rivers in what is now the Republic of the Congo, have been lent to the museum from private collections. Many of the pieces have never been shown in public. 
 The sculptures, depicting human figures, sometimes with animal characteristics, were commissioned by leaders or individual members of the community to be placed at altars or shrines as a means of communication with the spirit world. Masks were key components of costumes used in rituals and ceremonies.
Unlike western art, the African works were never done as an end in themselves, but to serve some special purpose -- a rite of passage, the promotion of human fertility, advancement in rank or status, or to assure a good harvest.
Related lectures and films are scheduled through February and March, and two children's programs will be offered. One will take place today at 3 P.M., when African Horizons, a musical group, will perform in costume on authentic instruments. The concert is suitable for children in grades 1 through 5. Admission is $5.
The museum, off Exit 3 of Interstate 95, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5 and Sunday from 1 to 5. Admission is $3.50 for adults, $2.50 for children 2 through 12, and adults over 64. The number for more information is (203) 869-0376.
 
The First President
Myths, legends and facts about George Washington will be explored in a lecture called "Of Cherry Trees and Wooden Teeth: Parson Weems' Popularization of Our First, Great President," tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Stamford Historical Society.
Joshua Lane, the society's curator, will discuss the national obsession with Washington that flourished during the 19th century, illustrated by engravings and ephemera from the society's archives.
The Historical Society is at 1508 High Ridge Road, and people who arrive at 7:30 will be treated to cherry tarts and coffee. Admission will be by commitment to join the society. For more information: (203) 329-1183.
 
Fun With Art
James Grashow is a man who enjoys his work, and those who see it have just as much fun. An exhibition of his anthropomorphic buildings, house plants, animals and what-have-you, is on view at Art/Place, the gallery in the westbound Southport train station, through March 7. This is one show that children as well as adults can appreciate. The artist is represented in several museums, including the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan.
Viewing hours are on Wednesday through Sunday from noon to 4:30. For more information or directions: (203) 255-9847.
 
Heading for Broadway
"The Civil War," a new musical opening on Tuesday at the Shubert Theater in New Haven, prior to a Broadway opening scheduled on April 22 at the St. James Theater, is described as "an emotional landscape" of the conflict rather than a litany of battles and political strife.
The music was composed by Frank Wildhorn, who provided the score for the Broadway productions of "Jekyll and Hyde" and "The Scarlet Pimpernel." Mr. Wildhorn was also a co-writer of the script with Gregory Boyd, artistic director of the Alley Theater in Houston, and Jack Murphy.
Under the direction of Jerry Zaks, the 26-member cast interprets a wealth of source material including letters, diaries, newspaper accounts, speeches by Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass, and the poetry of Walt Whitman. In adapting such diverse references, the writers have focused on recreating the stories of actual people who fought in the war and those whose lives were affected at home.
The show will run through March 7, with performances scheduled Tuesday through Thursday at 7:30, Saturday and Sunday at 2 and 8, and two additional matinees this Wednesday and March 3 at 2.
The numbers for tickets, priced from $28 to $60, are (800) 228-6622 or (203) 562-5666. The theater is at 247 College Street.
 
Rebellious Lawyers
Sister Helen Jean Prejean, author of "Dead Man Walking: An Eyewitness Account of the Death Penalty," will be the keynote speaker at the fifth annual Rebellious Lawyering Conference to be held on Saturday at Yale. Sister Prejean's lecture will be presented at 6 P.M. at the Yale Law School, 127 Wall Street in New Haven.
The conference will open on Friday, from 7 to 9 P.M., and continue through Sunday, with panel sessions slated on Saturday from 9 to 5:30 and on Sunday from 9 to noon.
Nearly three dozen university faculty members, lawyers, directors of legal defense and education centers, children's advocates, international economic and human rights officials, representatives of American Indian communities, Federal court judges, environmentalists and others will serve on the panels. Prevailing themes will be "Rebellious Lawyering in Rural Communities" and "Trying Times in Criminal Defense."
Registration costs $10. For more information: (203) 432-1325.
 
Art at Silvermine
A four-part exhibition opening today at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan features the work of James Jackson Burt and his father, David Burt; "Heart's Desire," a collection of love-inspired works by member artists; a kinetic installation with music by Robert Hepner, who will discuss his work today at 4 P.M.; and paintings by Gregory Amenoff. All the exhibits will remain through March 14.
"Remembering James Jackson Burt: Reviewing David Burt," pays tribute to two major forces in the local art scene, both longtime members of the guild. James Burt, who took his own life last May at the age of 43, after a losing battle with depression, was a founder of the Stamford Loft Artists' Association.
David Burt, also a member of the Loft Artists, is a former trustee of the guild and helped organize theguild's annual Art of the Northeast juried competition, for which he served as co-chairman for many years. Both men were influenced in producing their metalworks by David Burt's father-in-law, an inventor and structural engineer.
Robert Hepner's "Hat Factory" takes its name from his grandfather's hat factory in Danbury, but it uses the hat as a metaphor for the assembly-line aspects of suburban life, like the endless line of cars inching over the highways.
The galleries are open on Tuesday through Saturday from 11 to 5, and Sunday from 1 to 5, at 1037 Silvermine Road. Admission is $7. A reception is to be held today from 2 to 4. For more information: (203) 966-5617. ELEANOR CHARLES
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Keeping an Old Synagogue Alive

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN 

 BODY:
THE synagogue at the south end of Orchard Street in New Haven is peeling in spots, and the surrounding lot needs trimming, but anyone driving by Congregation Beth Israel, with its marbled glass windows and Moorish overtones, can get a glimpse of its past glory. Sam Teitelman had his bar mitzvah at the synagogue in 1935 and can remember, probably better than anyone, the standing-room-only crowds on the Sabbath, holy days and other celebrations.
"This place was often filled to the gills," Mr. Teitelman said on a recent tour of the building. "There would be days when we had 1,000 people upstairs and 200 below and people waiting to get in." 
 Like most of the old members, Mr. Teitelman, 75 years old, moved out of the neighborhood years ago but continues to care for the Orchard Street shul, like it was an old and devoted friend. Inside the sanctuary, he runs his hand over a marbled wall etched in Hebrew with the names of members from when the synagogue was built in 1925. He pauses midway down a long column. "Here," he said, "this is my father's name."
Years have passed since members held regular services. The congregation is Orthodox, which restricts members from driving on the Sabbath. Most of the 100 or so members live in other parts of the city or surrounding suburbs and attend synagogues nearby, yet they continue to pay annual dues of $70 to Beth Israel. A few members still live in walking distance and on most weekdays meet in the basement banquet hall to hold a morning service, which requires 10 adult males to be in attendance. But for the most part, the sanctuary and corridors ring only with echoes of a time when the synagogue and its neighborhood stirred with the rhythms of Jewish life.
Over the years, there has been debate -- sometimes heated -- about the synagogue's future. Some have suggested putting the building up for sale. Mr. Teitelman, who is not alone, will hear none of that. "This is a building that deserves to be preserved," he said, his voice swelling with emotion. "We will never sell this. Never."
In recent months a congregational committee has been formed to devise ways of preserving the synagogue and establishing it as a monument to Jewish history in New Haven. Others, including some historians, say the synagogue's significance reaches beyond the city's boundaries. An architectural survey released in 1991 by the Connecticut Historical Commission examined 46 synagogues in Connecticut built between 1840 and 1940; Congregation Beth Israel was among the highlights.
"We were very astonished," said Mary Donohue, an author of the survey, referring to her visit to the synagogue in the early 1990's along with other historians. "To find the interior intact and all of the original artifacts in place, makes this synagogue one of a kind in Connecticut." She said that of the 46 synagogues in the survey, a third remain in Jewish hands. Others are now either cultural centers, businesses, churches or private homes. Many have been stripped of their religious symbols. Jewish families have been in Connecticut since the 17th century, but major waves of Jewish immigration did not begin until the middle of the 19th century when German Jews were escaping social and economic oppression.
In 1843, the Connecticut legislature granted Jews the right to worship freely. By the late 1880's, some 3,200 Jews had settled in New Haven and established several Orthodox synagogues.
From 1890 to 1924, New Haven experienced another wave of Jewish immigrants; most were refugees from Eastern Europe and Russia. Many of the newcomers settled in the Oak Street neighborhood bordering downtown, which became known as the Oak Street ghetto.
Mr. Teitelman's family was part of that second wave. They arrived from Ukraine in 1922 and his father opened a kosher meat market. The neighborhood was one of crowded tenements, kosher delicatessens, butchers, bakeries, luncheonettes, clothing stores and pushcarts. Bearded men and shawled women walked on the congested sidewalks.
"There were some Polish and Italian people living in the ghetto, but it was predominantly Jewish and the language of the streets was Yiddish," he recalled.
Inside Teitelman's Meat Market the floors were covered with sawdust to absorb the grease, and the walls lined with cutting blocks and meat hangers. "I rarely saw downtown New Haven," he says. "There was no need to. Everything we needed was right there."
Congregation Beth Israel, established in 1913 over a shop, thrived with the steady influx of immigrants. Twelve years later the synagogue on Orchard Street opened. The shul had columns crowned with acanthus-leafed capitals on either side of the main door, and rounded-arched windows on the side, reflecting the Colonial Revival style of the time.
Yet the architect also incorporated features reminiscent of Eastern European shuls, like the Moorish-style domes topping twin towers in the front of the building, a balcony overlooking the interior sanctuary where the women were seated, and a central raised platform in the sanctuary where the Torah was read.
In 1926, a synagogue women's group raised money to buy an Ark, where the Torah is kept. The synagogue's crystal chandeliers, bronze lamps and symbolic etchings made the synagogue the pride of the neighborhood.
But as the years went by and members prospered, they moved to other areas of the city or to the suburbs. Irish and Italian immigrants and African-Americans who had migrated from the South beginning in the early 1940's took their place.
In 1959, an urban renewal demolition effort began and it eventually razed the Oak Street neighborhood, including many of its synagogues. Today, passers-by see only a long urban meadow between the frontage roads extending the Oak Street Connector at York Street to Ella Grasso Boulevard.
Abraham Jochelman was not raised in the old neighborhood; he arrived in New Haven in 1967, long after the area's demise. Yet he is just as impassioned as Mr. Teitelman about preserving the Orchard Street shul. For centuries, Mr. Jochelman said his family lived in a town near Vilnius, Lithuania. During World War II his parents and two brothers, along with some 250 members of hisfamily, were murdered after Lithuanian soldiers rounded up 8,500 Jewish residents, marched them 30 miles east of the city, shot them and threw their bodies into mass graves. Mr. Jochelman, who was 20 at the time, said he was not shot but thrown into one of the graves and covered with dead bodies. He escaped that night along with his brother and some cousins.
"It was 1942, a very cold winter," he recalled tearfully while sitting at his kitchen table in the Westville section of New Haven. "We ran across a frozen river and through the woods. Farmers gave us food along the way. One hundred miles later we made it to my grandfather's."
Later he said he and his brother were forced into a ghetto where thousands of Jews were murdered along with gypsies and Italian prisoners of war. His brother died in the carnage, Mr. Jochelman said, but he managed to escape to Russia.
After the war he and his wife, Zoia, moved to Poland, then to Israel. In the late 60's they moved to New Haven. Historical records show that of the 250,000 Jews living in Lithuania at the beginning of the war, some 220,000 were murdered by Nazi forces.
In 1992, Mr. Jochelman returned to Vilnius for the first time since the war. He took along his granddaughter, he said, "because I wanted her to see how it was." They began their pilgrimage in Vilnius and drove 150 miles through 20 towns toward the Russian border. He showed a visitor a photograph of the two of them standing at a memorial, where his family was killed.
"When I was a boy all those towns we visited were Jewish and there were shuls in every one of them," he said. "Now most of the Jews have gone and I saw not one shul."
Upon returning to New Haven, Mr. Jochelman said he resolved to help save the old synagogue on Orchard Street. Not only does it resemble the Eastern European shuls he knew as a boy, he said, "it is also a symbol of the old people who came before us. We have to keep the shul alive to remember our fathers."
While most of the core members of the synagogue are in their 70's and 80's, a few younger men, who attended the synagogue as children, have recently renewed their memberships.
"They call me the kid," said Murray Trachten, a New Haven lawyer, who at 60 is one of the youngest members of the congregation. Raised a block and a half away on Greenwood Street, Mr. Trachten had his bar mitzvah at the shul and his father was a longtime member. Mr. Trachten recalled the day of his father's funeral in 1981 when the funeral car procession drove past the Orchard Street shul. "Someone inside turned on the lights to show respect," he recalled. "I'll never forget that."
Last October he returned to the synagogue for the 85th anniversary of the founding of the congregation. Around 200 people attended. It was the first time in years, Mr. Trachten said, he had stepped foot inside the building. As he stood on the platform in the sanctuary to make a speech, he said he couldn't believe what he saw.
"Absolutely nothing had changed since I was a boy," he said. "The platform and bimah table, even the cloth on the table, was intact. It was like walking into a time capsule."
He is part of the committee trying to decide the future of the synagogue. Like Mr. Teitelman and Mr. Jochelman, he is hoping to keep the building in its original state and under the control of the congregation, but admits that given the ages of most of the members it may be difficult.
Nevertheless he said, "I can't imagine New Haven without the Orchard Street shul. That would end a whole part of my life."

HEADLINE: A South Bronx Very Different From the Cliche

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
FEW urban areas have ever had a worse image than the South Bronx in the 1970's, with hundreds of buildings abandoned, stripped, burned and rotting. The neighborhood became a synonym for disaster -- a warning, perhaps, of where cities might be heading.
That wasn't very long ago, but in parts of the South Bronx it seems like another century. Where surreal decals of flower boxes and window shades once adorned burned-out buildings, those derelict structures have been renovated and real people with real furnishings have moved in. The population is growing, not falling. Artists, antique stores and other businesses, symbols of growth rather than decay, are arriving. 
 South of 169th Street, in the part of the South Bronx closest to Manhattan, lie neighborhoods like Hunts Point, Mott Haven and Port Morris, areas that were particularly stricken by abandonment and crime. Now, many streets are unrecognizable.
Crime rates are significantly lower, and like many other urban areas, parts of the Bronx are beginning to be transformed. In the last 11 years, 57,000 units of housing have been built or rehabilitated in the borough as a whole.
While none of the residents would argue that no more improvements are needed, the ascent of these neighborhoods is all the more astonishing in the light of where they began. But the area's image has still not recovered, and people who work and live there say that visitors are still shocked at the extent of the revival.
On a two-block stretch of Bruckner Boulevard, a street infamously immortalized by Tom Wolfe in his novel "The Bonfire of the Vanities" as a threatening place, charming antique stores have been popping up, and above them, renovated apartments rent for $1,000 a month. The antique district also fills two blocks on adjoining Alexander Street, and with a zoning change last year allowing mixed commercial and residential uses, the value of the buildings, available just a few years ago for less than $50,000, has tripled.
Over in Hunts Point, new houses and apartment buildings have replaced the weeds that thrived in abandoned shells. On Manida Street, where two-story, century-old town houses with rounded facades survived the difficult years, a group of artists are living and working to create a vital cultural life, through the Point Community Development Corporation, at Manida and Garrison Streets.
In the next few months, the Point plans to take over 9,000 square feet of space in the nearby American Bank Note Building, a windowed structure on Garrison Street with large, open interior spaces and panoramic views of Manhattan. The space will be home to the dance troupe founded by Arthur Aviles, a modern dancer who performed for some years with Bill T. Jones. The Point also plans to begin renting studio space in the building to artists.
Within walking distance, a huge outpost of ABC Carpet and Home, one of the most stylish stores in Manhattan, doubled its space three months ago at 1055 Bronx River Avenue and began offering the same kind of merchandise sold at its other stores, luxurious sheets, antiques, and oriental rugs, but marked down between 30 and 90 percent. Some customers come from the South Bronx, but the vast majority drive in from Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey, lured by easy access from the Bruckner Expressway, the Bronx River Parkway or the Cross Bronx Expressway, and free parking.
Throughout the South Bronx, residential and commercial projects are being built; loan rates are more affordable in the economy as a whole, but even more important, banks are making loans at rates comparable to those in other regions.
"There was a risk penalty applied to people buying buildings in the Bronx," said Harvey Rottenberg, a partner in NYMC Capital Corporation in Manhattan, which lends money to businesses. Experienced investors in commercial properties and multifamily buildings could get money at competitive rates, he said, but many borrowers less experienced and less able to demonstrate stable cash flow were paying between one and five percentage points more on their loans.
More private money began flowing to the Bronx about two years ago, he said, when big national lenders looked at the borough without prejudice and realized it had strong occupancy, retail and transportation.
"Frankly, we're surprised by the amount of business we're seeing out of the Bronx," he said. In just one year, from 1997 to 1998, he said, his company's loans for investments in the Bronx rose by 400 percent. The flourishing of the South Bronx, he said, is part of the borough's overall economic improvement. In the South Bronx, he estimated, his company lent almost $10 million last year, for projects that included a live chicken market and a beverage distributorship.
There is so much activity that "it is hard to walk two blocks in either direction without seeing construction," said Neil Pariser, senior vice president of the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, known as Sobro. Groups that have renovated buildings taken over by the city for nonpayment of taxes are running out of opportunities for that kind of renewal, Mr. Pariser said. "It is now difficult to find a space to convert," he said. "You can't find a city-owned building that's vacant for rehab. We don't have tons of buildings anymore."
With new housing established or under construction, the focus is shifting to development of real estate for commercial and industrial purposes. Opportunities offered by the Bronx will be examined in a three-session seminar sponsored by the Steven L. Newman Real Estate Institute of Baruch College beginning March 16 at the college.
But many problems still remain in the South Bronx, including a higher than average unemployment rate and a lower than average income in most households. It is not in immediate danger of becoming a chic area. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, who grew up in Hunts Point, jokes about the criticism from those who fear gentrification in any guise.
The people who have moved into the new buildings of the South Bronx, Mr. Ferrer said, "are not folks that can even remotely be described as the gentry." They are working people with household incomes of about $55,000, with one member employed as, perhaps, a secretary, and the other perhaps as a corrections officer, he said.
But the vitality in the South Bronx is so unmistakable, and the improvements so profound, that even though there is much to be done, people who never expected to return have been lured back.
PEOPLE like Majora Carter, who is in the process of acquiring the house on Manida Street where she now lives. Ms. Carter returned to the neighborhood where she grew up in 1995, when she was getting a master's degree in creative writing at New York University and found there wasn't enough money for rent in Manhattan and tuition. Because of the compatible people she found in the neighborhood, artists, writers and others with a lot of energy and optimism, she has decided to stay.
It was, she said, something she could never have anticipated. "The Bronx was burning," she said. "I didn't want to be here."
Also back is F. Maximo Soba, who works as a salesman in the furniture section at ABC while he studies historic preservation at Mechanics Institute in Manhattan. He never intended to return to a place with such unhappy memories, he said, a place where his mother suffered from drug addiction, contracted AIDS and died.
He fled as soon as he could, he said, moving to Manhattan, to Brooklyn, and eventually to Puerto Rico, where he ran a gallery and store selling antique Spanish furniture. When the roof literally caved in on the operation, he went back to his grandmother's home in the South Bronx three years ago, to regroup.
Like Ms. Carter, he found the area so changed he decided to stay, and last year moved into a town house floor-through on Manida Street with three bedrooms that rents for $750 a month -- a price, he said, that wouldn't even get him a studio in Manhattan.
Unlike some sections of Brooklyn, the South Bronx is not overflowing with elegant old brownstones awaiting upwardly mobile bargain hunters. Much of the housing originally constructed in the South Bronx consisted of five-story walkups. A lot of the new housing has been built with subsidies and is restricted to tenants with relatively low family incomes.
The vacancy rate in the South Bronx is very low. Apartments of any kind are hard to find and tend to be passed around by word of mouth, not advertising. But when they can be found, there are great bargains, such as floor-through apartments in charming old town houses, like Mr. Soba's, that on average rent for $750 a month.
There are hundreds of town houses, for instance, in Mott Haven between 134th and 144th Street, as well as on Alexander Avenue between 138th Street and 141st Street, many of them architecturally charming and just one subway stop north of Manhattan. But they are not frequently available for sale. Sid Miller, director of the Haven Heights Group, a real estate brokerage on East 138th Street in Mott Haven, said that many town-house residents show no interest in moving even though their properties are rising in value. This week, for instance, he closed on a deal for a brownstone on East 138th Street that sold for $155,000, a typical price for a house in relatively good condition with architectural details.
Mr. Miller began selling real estate in the South Bronx 10 years ago, he said, thinking it would be the next hot area. The influx he anticipated did not happen, in part because homeowners do not seem interested in leaving, despite the "scent of money," he said.
It is a comment often made about people who didn't flee the South Bronx in the 1970's: They have hung on, and they don't plan to go even if they have the means to do so. The Bronx is being restored primarily by the people who lived through the grim time when landlords were torching their own buildings for the insurance money.
"The Bronx at one point was ashes," said Delmas Vernon Cole, the assistant director of Nos Quedamos, which in Spanish means "We are staying." His group, which is building housing for middle-income people in the South Bronx, was created by residents who successfully fought a city plan in the early 1990's to bulldoze 35 blocks east of Yankee Stadium. "People stood up and created an organization," he said. "They decided to stay. That spirit alone is pulling up the South Bronx," The changes in the neighborhood are "incredible," Mr. Cole said, but they are not yet reflected in public perception. "I think it is starting to change," he said, "but when you say the South Bronx, it's still a very negative image."
For Mr. Cole, a lifelong South Bronx resident who received a bachelor's degree from New York University and a master's in urban planning from Harvard, it isn't just a place that nearly burned to the ground.
"I remember another Bronx," he said, "before the Cross Bronx Expressway. I remember beautiful neighborhoods where people knew everybody. It was an ethnically mixed and diverse neighborhood."
But then the massive highway construction that broke established communities apart helped spark a process of urban decay, Mr. Cole said, followed by a middle-class exodus to places like Co-op City, in the north Bronx, and the suburbs beyond. "By the end of the 70's you could walk six blocks in any direction and you wouldn't see a light. It was like being in a ghost town," he said.
Now that housing has been built, and filled, he said, the place needs the services that attract and keep the middle class, such as good garbage collection, good schools, good parks and good air.
A SMALL but appealing commercial strip lies around Bruckner and Alexander, in the southernmost part of the South Bronx, where antique dealers and artists have moved in. The first ones arrived about seven years ago, but more are coming all the time.
Sunny Tillery, who opened Tigris & Euphrates at 79 Alexander Street last June, said that business in her antiques store has been "fantastic." She imagines the area eventually being like Greenwich Village, or SoHo. "It has that potential and flavor," she said. To speed it along, she said, she hopes to open an Italian restaurant in her building. "People are looking for things to eat when they come over," she said.
Much of the development in the area has been pushed by Sobro, which plans to work next on the revitalization of the south side of Bruckner so it resembles the restored blocks on the north side. Annual commercial rents vary, but the average in that area is probably between $15 and $20 a square foot, Mr. Pariser said. "We need food," he said. "We need cafes. And I think we're going to have it."
Although it doesn't have any of the amenities of the Village or SoHo, the antique district does have a key advantage: It is incredibly geographically convenient. Although the expressways that were cut through the Bronx may have destabilized neighborhoods, they now make it easy for people to shop there. Denise Cruz, co-owner of the Custom Design Studio, an upholsterer that has been at 47 Bruckner Boulevard for four years, said that customers come from Westchester and Connecticut as well as Manhattan because transportation is so easy.
Paul Chapman, the senior executive vice president of ABC Carpet and Home, said that customers come to his store from everywhere in the region and that the South Bronx's central location could make it a fertile area for development by big outlet stores.
"I picture a Secaucus here," with its outlet stores, he said. Mr. Chapman, a native of the South Bronx, said that security is good in the area, and he is dismissive of those who fear crime there. "I've had more cars stolen in my New York location," he said.
As in other parts of the city, businesses benefit from a general drop in crime. Detective Robert Butler, a community affairs officer for the 41st Precinct, which includes Hunts Point and Longwood, said that both drugs and prostitution still exist, but less so.
"It's a lot better now than it used to be," Detective Butler said, better even than just two years ago.
The different feeling about crime shows up in all kinds of ways. Josephine Infante, executive director of the Hunts Point Economic Development Corporation, said that businesses in the area's industrial park never used to put signs out because they figured they would be stolen. Now, she said, "everyone puts out signs."
Just as the area around Bruckner and Alexander stands out as a retailing oasis, the enclave over at Hunt's Point is one of artistic ferment. It is drawing people who grew up in the neighborhood as well as people from outside.
Marsha Trattner, who teaches metal sculpture at the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan and lives on the Lower East Side, was working on a sculpture at the Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens when she heard that the people at the Point were looking for artists to work on a sculpture garden at the Hunts Point Avenue subway stop on the No. 6 line. She built "Pipe Dreams" for them in a space at the Point, and after it was erected she decided to stay on, renting an outdoor studio space from the Point and offering blacksmithing workshops to children in the neighborhood.
She finds the place supportive and invigorating. "I have this automatic community here of people who have an interest in my work and are encouraging," she said.
She has talked to her artist friends about her work, but when she says she is working in the Bronx, she said, "they say, 'Oh, that's so far.' " It takes her about 50 minutes to get there from the Lower East Side, she said, but somehow, to people in Manhattan, the area is psychologically much farther away.
And in one way, she said, it is very different -- a way that is beneficial. "I feel like I've found a haven here," she said. "Partly, it is the actual cityscape up here. Things are more spread out. You have a sense of the sky. And there's so much excitement up here. People are hungry for invention."
THE Point recently bought its building from Max Blauner, who also owns the old American Bank Note Company building on Garrison Street between Tiffany and Barretto, which covers 365,000 square feet and is six stories at its tallest point. It is only half occupied, mainly by companies in the textile business. The Point and Mr. Blauner have nearly reached agreement for the Point to rent the 9,000 square feet, partly for Mr. Aviles's dance company and partly to be sublet to artists in increments of 400 square feet for $375 a month.
Paul Lipson, executive director of the Point, said he had also just received $12,000 in grants to develop a business plan to open a Latin jazz cafe and club at the corner of Garrison and Hunts Point Avenue, in a lovely building with a semicircular facade typical of the area. Since it began five years ago, the Point has nourished a number of business and artistic enterprises, including a theater, hip-hop classes and a partnership with the International Center of Photography that offers classes to local children and adults.
Still, progress in the amenities that make a neighborhood more than just housing can be tough, and is uneven.
Eddie Torres is the director of the visual arts program at the Longwood Art Project at 965 Longwood Avenue, between Beck and Kelly Streets, an area distinguished by a number of historic homes as well as a new Police Athletic League building. The center has been offering free working space to artists, and organizing shows, but financing has become too difficult to obtain, and people have been reluctant to travel to shows in the South Bronx.
The center's last exhibition in the space will start Feb. 27. Beginning in June, it will become a cyber gallery and will provide computers so local artists can make and show work on the Internet.
Luis A. Rivera, a Bronx native and a real estate lawyer with an office in the Throgs Neck section, said that young, upwardly mobile black and Hispanic residents, like their counterparts with other ethnic backgrounds, still gravitate to Manhattan, to neighborhoods like Chelsea.
The next step, Mr. Rivera said, is to make the South Bronx, so close to Manhattan, more appealing to a large range of people. The area's renewal, he said, has been mostly of the "meat and potatoes kind."
Now, he said, "life style and social opportunities have to catch up."

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
Yelling 'Fire' in an Empty Voting Booth

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: WOODBRIDGE

 BODY:
Are you planning to vote in the fire district election on Saturday? If your answer is, "What election?" you are not alone.
"For fire elections you almost have to beg people to vote," said Martin Snyder, a retired Woodbridge firefighter. "I have no idea why. It's like the board of education. They don't turn out for them either." 
 Another little-known fact: in just 80 of the state's 566 municipalities there are 188 fire districts -- or autonomous governmental entities run by a board of five commissioners that impose taxes for fire protection. The fire districts draw up their own budgets, which, along with the election of commissioners, are put to voters on the third Saturday of every February. This year, that day is Feb. 20.
Historically, turnout for these elections has been about 3 to 5 percent of eligible voters, according to the Department of Community Affairs, even though the budgets can be in the millions of dollars.
In some areas like Bergen County, fire departments are mainly financed and run under the local government rather than in fire districts. Fire districts are more common in other areas, like Cape May County.
And in just one town, Woodbridge, in Middlesex County, there are nine fire districts, the highest number in any municipality in the state, said Roger Potts, chairman of the New Jersey Association of Fire Districts.
Last year, according to Mr. Snyder, who is also the president of District 1 here, only about 700 people voted.
The reasons cited for poor turnout are hardly surprising: a lack of awareness, apathy and the timing. After all, how many people want to slog to the polls on a Saturday in a month when the weather is at its worst?
A bill that addresses the problem has been introduced in the Assembly by Michael P. Carroll of Morristown. If it passes, elections for fire districts and boards of education will coincide with the general election in November.
But Assemblyman Carroll said he did not see much chance for passage, adding that one day it might become law as part of a larger drive for property tax reform. "It ticks off enough people," he said, referring to fire commissioners, "so it must be a good idea. But I would be surprised if it moved this year."
Fire districts came into existence as early as 1879 as a way of providing fire protection in sparsely developed areas, said Michael Pane, a Hightstown lawyer who is an expert on local government.
As time passed, municipal officials were happy to hand the expensive task of fire protection over to fire districts. This is especially true today under laws that put a limit on municipal expenditures, he said.
A municipality can create a fire district at the request of at least 5 percent of the registered voters, or 20 legal voters, whichever is greater, and can abolish it the same way. The local government has no control over a district's operation, even though it collects taxes for the district. The only oversight comes from the state Department of Community Affairs, which reviews fire district budgets as it does municipal budgets.
Having a fire district "spreads the political liability," Mr. Pane said. "The irate taxpayer, upset at the increased costs of government in the first place, gets to vote on the fire district budget, and since it is crafted by the district fire commission, the municipal governing body can say, 'We'd like to help, but we have no control.' "
The situation gives ammunition to those who, like Governor Whitman, argue that property tax bills are high because of too many layers of government.
Another disadvantage, Mr. Pane said, is that fragmentating firefighting services is inefficient. "I think that autonomy is always undesirable in terms of coordination and planning," he said.
But defenders say the districts provide efficient and cheap service.
"If town hall gets involved," Mr. Snyder said, "they might want to cut the department and you get less service."
At the end of a recent meeting -- which went unattended -- Mr. Snyder and the other commissioners said they had run the district economically, cutting the tax rate by one and a half cents per $100 in the assessed value of a house, from 37.87 cents last year to 36.04 cents this year. They have also realized savings, they said, through joint purchasing agreements with other districts for things like insurance and fuel.
Mr. Potts, a commissioner in South Brunswick, said the amount to be raised by taxation in his district this year was $527,000. The tax rate is three cents on $100, which means that the owner of a $150,000 house will pay a $30 fire tax, he said.
"That seems pretty reasonable for providing fire protection," he said . "I think people have felt the districts are operating efficiently."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Yuca Chips With Your Back Rub?

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL; Seth Kugel lives in Washington Heights. He is working on a guide to guessing what country your taxi driver is from.

 BODY:
CORPORATE mergers are all the rage these days, but what's in it for me? Mobil and Exxon get together, I'm buying the same gas at the same price. Bankers Trust combines with Deutsche Bank, I'm still paying a $1.50 surcharge at the A.T.M. Siebe and BTR join to form the world's largest maker of industrial controls and, well, it's been a long time since I bought any industrial controls.
By contrast, the Roy Rogers/Dunkin' Donuts/Pizza Hut hybrid in Times Square has real value added: a burger for me, deep-dish pepperoni for you, crullers for everyone! These fast-food grease meccas dot the urban landscape, from the Taco Bell/ Pizza Hut on 14th Street to the Baskin Robbins/Dunkin' Donuts on 181st. Since New Yorkers crave convenience, treasure their 12 weekly seconds of leisure time and thrive on multitasking, it's surprising more local business owners have not caught on. Here are 10 suggestions for merging other well-known Manhattan establishments. 
 1. Real Estate Broker/99-Cent Store: The most common emotion people feel in a real estate office is despair: after all, you've just signed the lease on a $2,400-a-month apartment with no sunlight, then tacked on $3,000 in broker's fees to the sleazeball who's been lying to you for months. What you need is a quick bargain to allay the financial panic: how great would it be to pick up some 99-cent duct tape and pizza cutters and be back on road to liquidity? New arrivals can say "Well, I'm paying $1,600 for a 200-square-foot studio, but the no-name laundry detergent in this city sure is cheap."
2. Papaya King/ Sleepy's Mattresses: The trade-off for a great, cheap meal at a Papaya King stand is that you have to eat it standing up, bumping elbows with some highly dubious characters. Would that hot dog with sauerkraut and Mango Delight not taste better while relaxing on a king-size Sealy Posturepedic?
3. Barnes & Noble/Equinox: What do you do in Barnes & Noble? Sit on the floor and read. What do you do in Equinox? Sit on a bike and wish you had something good to read. In the combined version, members could get in their workout while choosing the right book to get over a relationship, cook eggplant or learn Chilean history.
4. Berlitz Language Centers/La Caridad: The biggest complaint about foreign language classes is they don't give you real world experience. With Chino-Latino La Caridad Restaurant as the classroom setting, however, you're all set. The Asian-Cuban staff speaks English, Spanish and Chinese. Finish class, then practice ordering arroz con pollo in Mandarin.
5. Roman Catholic Church/Reform Judaism: With so many interfaith couples around the city, why not a citywide chain of interfaith houses of worship, where couples can travel together to pray? The primary economy of scale is that the organizations can share Old Testaments.
6. Art Gallery/Petland: New Yorkers may be sophisticated and trendy enough to appreciate the fine works displayed throughout SoHo and Chelsea. Still, there are those of us (including children under the age of 10, and me) who do not get it and never will. We hate going to art galleries, but might consider accompanying a loved one if we could play with the puppies. A tropical fish tank at the Guggenheim wouldn't be bad either.
7. Breakfast Vendors/Blockbuster: What's the worst part of renting a video? Finding time to return it. If you already stop by the super-convenient muffin-donut-bagel-selling guys who maniacally stir coffee as they man the sidewalks outside office buildings, imagine if you could just drop off your video as you picked up your breakfast. The stands also would have a reason to stay open in the afternoon, renting movies to people as they head home from work.
8. Great American Back Rub/Bodega: What could be more relaxing than a back rub at this citywide massage chain? Well, how about a back rub with your choice of snack foods at arm's reach. Feel the tension melt away while you satisfy a craving for papaya nectar and yuca chips.
9. Manhattan Car Tow Pound/Dr. Zizmor: Getting your car back after it has been towed is a stressful experience, liable to make even the most clear-skinned develop a pimple or two. Dr. Zizmor's dermatology clinic, famous for its subway ads, would do well by strategically placing its offices in areas of high breakout potential. Dr. Z might also want to consider a mobile office on the Lexington Avenue subway line.
10. Chinese Takeout/Film Processing Store: These two can save startup costs by sharing the back-lit photo displays: "Hey look, there's Uncle Nick in the Bahamas, right next to the House Special Lo Mein for $5.95!"

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Ms. Siegel, Mr. Brecher

 BODY:
Stephanie Lynn Siegel, the daughter of Dr. Sharon Siegel and Dr. Bernard Siegel of Malibu, Calif., is to be married this afternoon to David Joel Brecher, a son of Dana Brecher and Dr. Herman Brecher of Baltimore. Rabbi Joel Rembaum is to officiate at the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Hotel.
The bride, who is 31, will be known as Stephanie Siegel Brecher. She is a corporate counsel in Santa Clara, Calif., to the Bay Networks subsidiary of Northern Telecom, the telecommunications equipment manufacturer. She graduated from Princeton University and received a master's degree in international relations from the London School of Economics and Political Science. The bride also received a law degree from the University of California at Berkeley. 
 Her father, a pediatrician, is the president of the Community Medical Group in Calabasas, Calif. The bride's mother, a retired pediatrician, neonatologist and pediatric nephrologist, practiced in Canoga Park, Calif.
The bridegroom, 33, was until last month a senior litigation counsel in Washington at MCI Worldcom. He graduated from Duke University and received a law degree from the University of Pennsylvania.
His mother is an employment coordinator at the Jewish Vocational Service in Baltimore. His father is an internist with the Northwest Primary Care Group in Baltimore; in 1997 and 1998, he was the president of the Baltimore County Medical Association.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Fast-Track Economy: A Rocky Global Road

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD 

 BODY:
IT dazzles the elite who gather annually atop the snowy hills of Davos and defies gravity in the canyons of Wall Street. But America's supercharged economy has become excessively lean and mean, according to a new book by Edward Luttwak.
In "Turbo Capitalism: Winners and Losers in the Global Economy" (Harper Collins, $26), Mr. Luttwak acknowledges that the American-led free market is creating lots of new wealth. But he argues that such an economy -- highly privatized, deregulated and in the midst of globalization -- also brings peril. 
 This unfettered American capitalism of the last decade doesn't travel well, he writes. Yet it is spreading to other countries, raising the specter of financial ruin, in Asia and elsewhere, or social unrest. At home, meanwhile, the turbocharged economy is moving too fast to pick up the poor or to reassure an anxious middle class. With the spread of downsizing, white-collar job security is vanishing, he writes, bringing some unpleasant cultural consequences. And the poor? They're going to prison.
The author, whose last book about economics was "The Endangered American Dream" (1994), is not the first person to worry in print about what some consider runaway capitalism. We've read before about the winner-take-all society, an alienated "flexible" work force and manic debt-fueled consumerism.
But Mr. Luttwak, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, has written an original, provocative book that takes up all these questions at once, and more. (When did you last read about the link between economic policy and the telling of dirty jokes?)
Mr. Luttwak believes that some form of "controlled" capitalism -- like the regulated and protected American economy that lasted from 1945 to the 1980's -- is a better choice for most of the world than the untethered variety that has held sway since the days of Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher.
(There are exceptions, he says. He believes that post-Communist economies should be only lightly regulated, and while he laments "the criminalization of the Russian economy," he holds that it is part of "the natural evolution of the capitalist animal.") It is dangerous for the United States to globalize its mostly unregulated capitalism, he argues, because it is exported without the two distinctly American forces that balance its power at home: an aggressive and activist legal system and an enduring Calvinist tradition.
Bless those infamously "greedy" private lawyers, he says, for bringing lawsuits that oblige corporations to curb dangerous products and blatant discrimination in their ranks. Bless, too, the eager staff lawyers of the Government regulatory agencies that remain -- the tax bloodhounds, the securities-law enforcers, the antitrust troops. (Without taking a stand on the current Microsoft case, he argues that in other countries, a Bill Gates would not be answering antitrust accusations in court. Instead, he would be subsidized in Italy, protected in Japan and "a life peer in the House of Lords" in Britain.)
AND what is capitalism without Calvinism? Trouble, Mr. Luttwak writes, somewhat cynically.
In America, earned wealth is still viewed as a virtuous accomplishment, says the author, a native of Romania who was educated in Europe and the United States. But the rich, he says, know that they must not enjoy themselves too much. (Frequent seminars at Aspen are O.K.; frequent romps on the Riviera are not.) Limiting conspicuous consumption helps legitimize wealth, he says, and cuts down on envy and "its political and even violent expressions."
Calvinism, with its emphasis on self-reliance, also persuades the unsuccessful in America to blame themselves, not the system. In other nations, people tend to be less quiescent when a huge gap opens between rich and poor, he observes.
In the United States, the unfettered economy is creating breathtaking efficiencies, the author notes. But the "creative destruction" of outmoded industries is happening too quickly for all the displaced employees to be re-absorbed. It's a myth that the Microsofts and Intels of the world will create enough new jobs, he argues, even if all laid-off workers could be retrained for them.
Mr. Luttwak supplies statistics showing the widening gap between the nation's rich and poor, a theme he has struck before. For most Americans, wage increases are held in check in part because monetarism has become a religion in America, he argues, with central bankers playing God and any hint of inflation demonized.
His most provocative theory, a stretch but spun out engagingly, holds that our current ultra-free-market economy is creating an "illiberal democracy" in America: Displacing its economic resentment onto others, the middle class is clamoring for stricter laws and more severe prison sentences, including the death penalty. The rebellious (non-Calvinist) poor, he writes, are thus being conveniently locked away under harsh anti-drug laws. The increasingly anxious middle class is also embracing what he calls the new Calvinist "prohibitions" -- against overeating and other unhealthy pleasures, against flirting or telling off-color jokes in the office. Only shopping is safe from censure, he notes wryly.
Mr. Luttwak offers few solutions, but he does call for the return of some regulation.
"Corporations are not moral entities," he writes; "they exist to earn profits, and so it should be." But governments, he says, should temper capitalism "on behalf of the citizens they are supposed to equally represent."
