HEADLINE: About New York;
A Mother: Young, Single And Heroic

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
WHO says a superhero needs rippling muscles to beat back the forces of evil? Does the crusader really need a cape to soar through the heavens and come to the rescue? For that matter, who says he has to be a he?
Katherine Arnoldi has spent years drawing the crash-bang adventures of a skinny heroine whose only costume is a black skirt and striped top. Her superheroine has a sidekick -- her infant daughter. She also has plenty of close calls with death -- working among toxic chemicals in a factory or being beaten by an abusive boyfriend. Her story is about the daily down-to-earth hassles and heroics of a teen-age single mom. But as in any good comic book, her heroine finally gets her chance to fly. So what if she doesn't duck into a phone booth for a quick change? All she needed was her college acceptance letter and she floated off the page. 
 "The Amazing 'True' Story of a Teen-age Single Mom" (Hyperion) is mostly her own tale of becoming a single mother when she was 17 in the early 1970's. The graphic novel recounts the shame others heaped on her, the dreary jobs she took to support her daughter, and her brushes with bad bosses and boyfriends. At its core is the story of her own unyielding -- though at times barely sustained -- hope and courage that allowed her to come into her own in college. It is a message she now spreads in occasional visits to programs for teen-age mothers around the city where she shares her story and book with young women who had to put aside their childhood dreams.
"I thought only rich people went to college," she said. "Sometimes I say my book is a support group you can hold in your hand. I'm just grateful it's in a lot of hands that are maybe isolated."
Ms. Arnoldi, 46, started her book in the mid-1980's, when she was living on the Lower East Side with her daughter, Stacie, after she graduated from the University of Arkansas and began working at different jobs. Her own faith in education had already prompted her to start visiting high-school equivalency programs with stacks of college application forms and college guides.
"A lot of times I would give them the forms and the women would tell me, 'Yeah, but I have to go now,' " she recalled. "They would get up and leave. So I felt maybe if I told them my story it would be different."
She started handing out copies of scenes and pages from her book, which was then a work in progress. In her drawings, as in her life, there were times when faith and hope looked like tiny compartments in her brain, almost squeezed into insignificance by more mundane or pressing concerns.
"There was more room in my brain for the names of the people in the 'Beverly Hillbillies,' " she joked. "Why did hope live? I didn't feel worthy. But I knew my daughter was worthy. I brought that up and held it in front of me."
She raised her hand to her face.
"I moved forward, like this," she said. "Here's my child. I know my child is worthy. I think I trusted that."
She persevered to see Stacie graduate from college and become a research assistant who is applying to medical school.
But she had less success at first with publishers, who passed on the book, thinking there was no market for it. "Oh, the country's 25 million single mothers are not a market," she said. "To me, that's just stupidity. If single mothers decided to boycott Pampers, people would take notice."
PEOPLE are noticing Ms. Arnoldi now. She figures somebody has to speak on behalf of mothers who have been vilified in the national debate over social policy. If policy makers want to talk about individual responsibility, she said, what about the responsibility of colleges and the government to offer adequate day care and housing for single mothers?
"Single mothers have been portrayed as welfare queens without any personal responsibility," she said. "Like, it wasn't the savings and loans that caused the recession. It was single moms."
A baby was making goo-goo sounds recently, as Ms. Arnoldi shared her story with a group of single mothers studying for their high-school equivalency diplomas at a Bronx community center. The young women told her they wanted to study computers, child care, business.
Ms. Arnoldi handed out copies of her book. Then she helped the young women fill out postcards that they would send to colleges asking for application forms. Behind her was a poster. It read, "Anyone Can Be a Leader."
"For 20 cents you can change your life," she said as she handed out the postcards. "It changed mine."
She sounded just super.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Air Fares to Europe Are Cheap And May Stay Low for a While

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
With international business travel weakening because of the economic slowdown overseas, and with more flights scheduled across the North Atlantic, most major airlines have aggressively cut fares to Europe, exceeding in many cases their previous winter sales.
New Yorkers can get flights to London for as little as $228 plus tax round trip, for example, while San Franciscans can go to Paris and back for $348. The sharply discounted air fares are being offered in dozens of American cities for travel to a variety of European destinations. 
 The number of destinations is indeed more extensive than ever, airline officials say, and the period for which the fares are valid extends far beyond the few weeks typically available in winter sales.
"In 29 years with the company," said John W. Lampl, a spokesman for British Airways, "I've never seen fares so low so early as this year, or for travel so long into spring."
The driving force behind the discounting is overcapacity. Despite strong demand throughout most of last year, when many trans-Atlantic flights were added, the airlines now find themselves with too many seats to fill in the slow winter season.
"With all that capacity when business travel to Europe is declining, you can just about name your price," said Michael Boult, a vice president at Rosenbluth International, the travel management company.
And air fares for leisure travelers may remain low, at least in the short term, as a result of the labor dispute between American Airlines and its pilots. After a weeklong disruption of its flights because of the pilots' sickout, American, part of the AMR Corporation, is expected to introduce bargain fares on both international and domestic flights, to try to lure back passengers. American currently offers a range of discount fares, including a $248 round trip from Chicago to Paris.
British Airways set off the latest discounting late last week, with fares as low as $228 round trip to London from New York, Newark, Boston and Philadelphia, and similar deals from 18 other United States cities. Round trip to London from San Francisco or Denver is $328, while round trip to London from Los Angeles, San Diego or Phoenix is $358. Travelers have until next Wednesday to buy these tickets, and they must depart by March 31 and return by April 30.
Most United States airlines have matched or almost matched, British Airways. United Airlines, part of the UAL Corporation, is offering such round-trip fares as New York to London for $228, San Francisco to Paris for $348 and Los Angeles to Amsterdam for $398. Discount fares at Continental Airlines include New York or Newark to Paris for $248 and to Rome for $298. Among the fares from Delta Air Lines are Los Angeles to Paris flights for $358. All such tickets are not refundable, the prices do not include taxes and restrictions apply.
The trans-Atlantic discounts have their roots in part in the economic troubles in Asia and South America. Although Europe is not in recession, many American businesses have cut employee travel worldwide, and several airlines have reduced or eliminated flights to Asia and redeployed those planes to Europe.
United Airlines, for example, which has extensive routes to the Pacific, had an 8.8 percent increase in trans-Atlantic traffic last month over January 1998, but its capacity across the Atlantic grew 14.9 percent, partly because it had added planes to its European routes that had previously flown to Asia. Other airlines made similar moves last year and did not cut back on flights in the slower winter season.
Last month, Virgin Atlantic briefly offered $198 round-trip fares between New York and London. "Those fares obviously speak to a lot of capacity in the market," said Gareth Edminson-Jones, a Virgin spokesman. Virgin's current fares, available through next Wednesday, are $228 from New York or Newark to London and $328 from San Francisco or Los Angeles to London.
Trans World Airlines has $298 round-trip fares between Washington and Madrid and between Dallas/ Forth Worth and Paris; tickets must be purchased by this Friday. The regular 21-day advance-purchase fares on the routes are $820 and $640, respectively. T.W.A. appears to offer the most generous terms, allowing travel as late as April 30.
Last week U S Airways offered $298 round-trip fares from Philadelphia to London or Amsterdam, and $398 from Los Angeles to Madrid.
There may be discounts this summer, airline officials say, possibly in August, when business travel slows for the traditional European vacation season, but the discounts will be modest if the American economy remains strong. Joseph Buhler, chairman of the European Travel Commission, recently forecast that almost 11.6 million Americans will visit Europe this year, more than half of them this summer, topping last year's record of 11 million.
The Asian economic crisis is not the only reason for excess capacity. Because almost all airlines had high passenger loads to Europe last summer and fall, and because the struggle for market share over the heavily traveled Atlantic is particularly intense, most airlines either did not bother to reduce the number of flights, or cut just a token few.
One reason the airlines miscalculated, perhaps, was that no firm figures were available on the cuts in corporate travel. But harbingers existed. A survey in October of 450 of the Fortune 1,000 companies, done by the National Business Travel Association, found that 56 percent had cut the number of employees who travel, and that they planned to reduce overall travel 17 percent. "Some airlines didn't believe us," said Norman Sherlock, the association's executive director, "but they do now."
In an effort to show that its fares are a bargain, T.W.A. dusted off some fares from the past. "When we introduced our trans-Atlantic service in 1946," Mark Abels, a T.W.A. spokesman said, "the New York-to-Paris round trip cost $675 -- the equivalent of $5,273.34 now.
Mr. Boult of Rosenbluth has in his office a 1957 advertisement for Pan American's new Clipper service -- $453 for a round-trip economy flight from New York to London, $489 from New York to Paris. "That was a lot of money then," he said.

HEADLINE: Investment Group Buys The National Enquirerand Star Magazine

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
A Manhattan investment firm has purchased the company that owns The National Enquirer and Star magazine and hired the head of the nation's third-largest magazine publisher to run and expand it.
The investment group, Evercore Capital Partners L.L.C., headed by former Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman, announced yesterday that it had acquired the publications for $294 million from American Media Inc., and that David J. Pecker, the president and chief executive officer of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines, a unit of Lagardere Group, would head the company and receive an equity stake. American Media is a public company whose two biggest stockholders are the venture capital firm Boston Ventures and MacFadden Holdings Inc. 
 Mr. Pecker's goal, along with his new partners at Evercore, is to extend the National Enquirer brand to an array of new ventures that may include more television programming, new magazines -- such as Enquirer spinoffs for teen-agers and Hispanic readers -- and on-line services. The company owns Country Weekly and The Weekly World News.
The move comes after years of declining circulation for The Enquirer as Americans have begun to see reporting that might once have been considered salacious or sensational appear in mainstream publications.
The National Enquirer has a circulation of 2,300,000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, down from its 1977 high of 5 million.
The news weekly regularly runs articles about celebrity diets and hardly an issue goes by without some sort of swipe at Monica Lewinsky ("Monica's Gay Secret -- Shocking Report From Inside the White House"), but in a quest to raise a sagging circulation, it has tried to run more legitimate articles. Steve Coz, the editor of The Enquirer, said yesterday that he had tried to make the weekly newspaper more appealing to readers, most recently asking Roseanne Barr to guest-edit the newest issue. Ms. Barr once guest-edited an issue of The New Yorker.
The transaction included the assumption of $473 million in debt.
The venture is not without financial risk. American Media's total revenue for the nine months ended in December was $222.2 million, of which advertising was $16.9 million, or a relatively small 7.6 percent. Operating income for those six months was $43.2 million, but the company had $35.6 million in interest expense and $8.3 million in taxes. The company had net income of $569,000, down from $6.8 million in the period a year earlier.
Bishop Cheen, an analyst who follows the company for First Union Capital Markets, said American Media had failed to move aggressively in the changed news environment. "They were going to buy Canadian tabloids, go down to Mexico," he said. "But they never did anything with the company. So they shouldered the costs of newsprint without any economy of scale. And the ad economy has been great, but they didn't participate because advertising is such a small part of its revenues."
Mr. Pecker called The Enquirer and Star "the two most undermarketed and underpromoted newspapers in this country."
In his decade as president of Hachette magazines, Mr. Pecker earned something of a reputation as an enfant terrible with an arduous eye on the bottom line. He cut editorial staffs, slashed budgets and offered deep discounts to choice advertisers. He posed for photographs astride motorcycles or with cigars dangling from his lips. And during his tenure, he built the magazine publisher into a competitor in the American marketplace, promoting Elle magazine in such a way that it has leaped over Harper's Bazaar and now trails only one women's magazine, Vogue, in both circulation and advertising revenue.
Mr. Pecker began several divisions within Hachette, including Hachette New Media and Hachette Productions, which produces films like the Isaac Mizrahi documentary "Unzipped" and television programming. And he attracted a burst of publicity by introducing George, which is edited by John F. Kennedy Jr.
The purchase is Evercore's second as a private equity investor -- its first was a company that sells insulation products -- so it is clear that it could use Mr. Pecker's assets as a magazine publisher. Mr. Altman is one of the firm's three founders and continues to be a partner. He did not return a phone call to his home seeking comment. Mr. Pecker would not disclose the percentage of his equity stake.
Mr. Pecker's colleagues at Hachette were surprised, but one executive said that Mr. Pecker has long been looking for a move that would give him private equity. "Hachette is a very closely held company and there's no chance of ownership," one Hachette executive said.
Mr. Pecker will leave Hachette on March 31. Following his departure, the day-to-day operations of Hachette Filipacchi will be overseen by Daniel Filipachhi, the chairman of Hachette Filipacchi Magazines. No successor has been announced.

HEADLINE: Political Landscape Altered, Labor Sees Gains for Its Agenda

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 16

 BODY:
With their supporters among Republican moderates likely to play a more forceful role in the new Congress, union leaders who are gathered here for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s winter meeting predicted today that labor would make substantial gains this year in advancing its legislative wish list.
The labor leaders say the narrowing of the Republican majority in the House to five votes will give their pet proposals, including a higher minimum wage and a patients' bill of rights, a better chance than in the two previous Congresses since the Republicans took control in the 1994 elections. 
 "I think we can get more done this year," said Peggy Taylor, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s chief lobbyist. "With the margin so close in the House and the Democrats feeling so strong and the Republicans so desperate to get something done in this Congress, I think there's a lot of opportunity."
The labor leaders, meeting here for four days at the Fontainebleau Hotel, have put forward a long list of legislative goals that range from the eminently attainable to the highly improbable. Among them: an increase in the minimum wage to $6.15 an hour, from the current $5.15; a requirement that part-time workers be paid the same hourly rate as full-time employees doing the same work; the hiring of 100,000 additional teachers to reduce class size, as proposed by President Clinton, and defeat of the Republican proposal that would create individual retirement investment accounts within the Social Security system.
With the Republicans' majority in the House now trimmed, and with Republican moderates reaching out to labor, union officials predict that Congress is unlikely to throw them on the defensive as in the last two years. In the last Congress, Republicans not only pushed, unsuccessfully, for legislation to limit labor's ability to use dues for political purposes but also held investigative hearings on a variety of unions, especially the teamsters.
"Our hope is there'll be less need for defensive work," John J. Sweeney, the federation's president, said in an interview. "Our hope is we'll be able to pursue a pro-active agenda.
"If the Republicans have some sense and want to turn things around a little bit," Mr. Sweeney said of the party's political fortunes, "they'll be looking for some pieces of legislation. The question is whether they want to deal with it seriously or just as face-savers. If they're willing to deal with it seriously, then, fine, we want to be at the table when it comes to a working-families agenda."
Randy Johnson, vice president for labor policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said in a telephone interview that unions still faced tough going in a Republican-led Congress. "A more realistic estimate of what will happen is gridlock," Mr. Johnson said, "although there'll be a few minor victories on their side, like the minimum wage."
Labor unions hope to win a minimum-wage increase this year or next, as they did in 1996, when many Congressional Republicans, feeling vulnerable in an election year, voted for it. "In a very successful economic period," Mr. Sweeney said, raising the minimum above the current $5.15 "is a way of showing that workers should share in the economic progress."
Corporate lobbyists maintain that a higher minimum wage will raise business costs and so cause employers to lay off low-paid workers, or at least hire fewer of them.
"The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is clearly going to run with it because it's a terrific political issue," Mr. Johnson said. "Unfortunately the vast majority of economists agree that raising the minimum wage destroys jobs. But the workers who will lose jobs get lost in the politics of the issue."
Mr. Johnson conceded that unions would probably also gain some limited version of a patients' bill of rights. That legislation would give members of health maintenance organizations greater rights to use emergency rooms and to appeal H.M.O. decisions, and would bar "gag rules" by which managed care companies limit what doctors can tell patients about treatment alternatives.
But labor officials say their chief legislative priority is to strengthen Social Security and to kill the Republican proposal for privatizing part of it with individual accounts. Tonight the federation sponsored a town meeting in Miami where dozens of retired union members attacked the proposal.
"Having those accounts is going to end up costing more," because of administrative expenses, "and it ends up taking money away from benefits," said Sandra Feldman, president of the American Federation of Teachers and chairwoman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s social policy committee. "And where there are people who are less sophisticated about making investment decisions, they might lose their money and be left without a safety net."
As for other issues, several unions are pushing trade legislation. The steelworkers, for instance, want tougher restrictions on unfairly priced imported steel. And labor officials say President Clinton might push again for fast-track trade legislation, whose renewal was blocked by unions last year on the ground that it risked a loss of American jobs to countries that did not bear the costs of the kinds of labor and environmental protections that prevail in the United States. But Mr. Sweeney said he thought Mr. Clinton might submit a reformulated proposal this year to include labor, human rights and environmental provisions favored by the union movement.
"I think the President has gotten the message," he said.
Another issue is part-time workers. Union officials have voiced frustration in recent years that despite an economic boom, the percentage of American workers with health insurance and pensions has dropped, especially among part-timers. Concerned that workers who do not hold permanent, full-time jobs are getting short shrift, the labor federation is pushing a bill to require that part-time workers receive the same hourly pay as full-time employees doing the same work. In addition, the federation wants a law requiring proportional benefits for part-time workers -- that is, an employee who works 20 hours a week, say, would be guaranteed half the pension of someone working 40 hours a week.

HEADLINE: Arts Agency Plans to Spread the Money Around

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton's proposed budget, delivered to Congress on Feb. 1, included an increase of more than 50 percent in appropriations for the National Endowment for the Arts, and in two speeches here this week, the new chairman of the agency, William J. Ivey, discussed publicly for the first time his plans for spending the extra money. Mr. Ivey was appointed to succeed Jane Alexander, whose stormy tenure ended in October 1997.
Mr. Clinton's $150 million request for the endowment represents a $52 million increase over the current budget for the agency, which has been embattled throughout the 1990's and was until last year targeted for dissolution by Congressional conservatives. 
 Some $50 million of the added money is earmarked for Challenge America, a project addressing lawmakers' concerns that the endowment's support has been unevenly distributed around the nation and that its financing for individual artists whose work many conservatives found offensive came at the expense of improving access to the arts for all Americans.
On Tuesday at a luncheon for business leaders and arts administrators at the Chicago Economics Club, and that evening at a public address at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Mr. Ivey said that Challenge America would target money for programs in five areas: arts education, youth at risk, access to the arts, cultural and heritage preservation and community arts partnerships.
"It does coincide with the Congressional agenda," Mr. Ivey said in an interview, "but it is also a completely legitimate program of activities for the agency to take on."
The request for added funds comes when partisan antagonism in Washington is at a peak. Mr. Clinton's proposed budget has already been criticized by some Republican lawmakers as a return to what they have called big-government liberal spending. A substantial increase in arts funding, a sensitive issue in Congress since 1989 despite the endowment's relative insignificance as a budget item, could raise hackles again.
Asked if the President's budget request was realistic, Mr. Ivey said: "It's hard to tell. Now that we seem to be in general agreement about the survival of the agency with flat funding, the question is whether significant opposition will crop up as we try to move forward. There will always be criticism of and opposition to the endowment," he continued, "but my sense is that the bipartisan center will support an increase."
The new funds would be distributed in four ways:
* About 1,000 communities in underserved areas of the country would receive grants of between $5,000 and $10,000 for specific arts projects.
* About 150 arts institutions would receive grants of between $50,000 and $150,000 for programs to expand their community involvement.
* Between 10 and 20 unspecified partnership programs involving national arts organizations and Federal agencies would receive funding.
* $20 million would go to state agencies for arts education, regional touring programs that bring performing arts to underserved communities, after-school arts programs and organizations devoted to folk art and cultural heritage preservation.
In addition, Mr. Ivey said, next year the agency will ask Congress for additional funds to help stabilize arts organizations with support for their own endowments, technological and management consulting and new programs for developing individual and corporate philanthropy. The details of that request will depend on a study of arts organizations that the agency is conducting.
The National Endowment's current budget is $98 million, down from a high of $176 million in 1992. In 1995, when Republicans assumed control of the House of Representatives, they marshaled their outrage over endowment grants that in the late 1980's supported controversial works, like Andres Serrano's photograph of a crucifix immersed in urine, and slashed the agency's budget by 40 percent for the next year, planning to dissolve it entirely. The Senate kept it alive.
But last year the political attitude toward the agency changed for several reasons: Congress had curtailed the endowment's ability to give grants to individual artists, some conservatives had been satisfied by the budget cuts, and last June a Supreme Court ruling upheld a 1990 law requiring the endowment to consider "general standards of decency and respect for the diverse beliefs and values of the American public" in its grant making. In July the House approved this year's budget, ending the threat of dissolution.
In his sold-out address at the museum on Tuesday, Mr. Ivey received a warm welcome but also a reminder that his position as the nation's leading advocate for the arts is not without political pressure from both sides.
Four leading arts administrators in Chicago also spoke at the event -- Abena Joan P. Brown, president of the ETA Creative Arts Foundation; Carlos Tortolero, executive director of the Mexican Fine Arts Museum; Nick Rabkin, program officer at the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, and Robert Fitzpatrick, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art.
The administrators said the endowment, under Ms. Alexander, had submitted too easily to Congressional pressure. "I can only hope that the last shall be first," Ms. Brown said. "And the arts have been last for too long."
Mr. Tortolero added: "The arts have been playing not to lose, and we have to play to win."
All four said the endowment needed to re-enter the business of making grants to individual artists, the sentiment that received the loudest applause of the night.
Mr. Ivey said the time was not quite at hand for that, but that he had "unwavering" support for the endowment's eventual return to grants for individuals.

HEADLINE: Argentina Looks for a Way to Stem Illegal Immigrants

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 17

 BODY:
With the economy slowing and street crime rising, President Carlos Saul Menem has introduced a series of bills to Congress to stem the flow of illegal immigration from Bolivia, Paraguay and Peru.
Congressional debate on the legislation has not yet begun, but the bills have already created tensions between Argentina and its poorer neighbors. And they have prompted criticism from the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church and human rights groups that the Government is unleashing a xenophobic campaign to make scapegoats out of poor, defenseless people. 
 But by raising an issue with widespread appeal, the ruling Justicialist party may succeed in putting the opposition on the defensive in a presidential election year.
The debate over the bills also highlights the growing rate of migration of peasants and workers across borders throughout South America, raising a potentially potent and divisive issue in not only Argentina, but also Chile, Uruguay and Venezuela.
The new laws would impose fines up to $500,000 on individuals or companies who employ illegal aliens. They would give the Interior Minister the power to deport any alien sentenced to more than two years in prison. Anyone arrested for helping foreigners enter the country illegally would be subject to prison sentences of 5 to 20 years.
Statistics about illegal immigration here are imprecise, and the Government and private groups disagree on the dimensions of the problem. But experts seem to agree that the Argentina has recently seen an increase in the immigration of poor Bolivians, Paraguayans and Peruvians, a phenomenon that dates from at least 30 years ago. Some analysts have estimated up to a million Peruvians live outside Peru, mainly in the United States, Argentina and Chile.
According to the latest Argentine census figures, the number of Paraguayans here increased, from 154,000 in 1960 to 250,000 in 1991. In that period, the number of Peruvians increased, from 5,100 to 16,000. Experts say the trend is accelerating as the regional economy slows in response to the Asian and Brazilian financial crises.
In the northern provinces, migrants frequently do backbreaking work like picking cotton and strawberries. In the cities they shine shoes and do other odd jobs. The alien migrants are rarely unionized, and they are generally paid much less than Argentines.
An opposition Congressman, Juan Pablo Cafiero, has called the move to tighten immigration laws "a racist campaign." He added, "What they are trying to do is blame our social problems on the immigrants."
According to Mr. Cafiero, the 70,000 or so immigrants in the Buenos Aires metropolitan region make up less than 2 percent of the workforce, so they cannot be blamed for an unemployment rate has risen slightly over the last month, after decreasing under the previous year. He said 2.5 percent of those found guilty of crimes were foreigners.
In explaining the need for new measures, Hugo Franco, a senior official in charge of immigration control, said the Government was merely interested in "protecting legal immigration and fighting illegality."
Officials said at least 60 percent of those arrested for petty crimes in Buenos Aires in recent months were foreigners. Critics contest that estimate and note that foreigners make up a much smaller percentage of the prison population.
President Hugo Banzer of Bolivia has publicly expressed concerns that the new proposals will generate anti-Bolivian feelings and asked for guarantees that the rights of Bolivian immigrants will be respected.
"We want Argentine authorities," Mr. Banzer said, "to prevent abuses and deportations."

HEADLINE: Starts of Homes Up; Factory Output Rises

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
New-home construction starts rose in January at the fastest pace in 12 years, bolstered by strong gains in the South and West, and factory production increased for the fourth month in a row.
Starts rose 3.8 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.804 million houses, the Commerce Department announced today. Analysts expected housing starts to decrease 2.4 percent last month. December starts rose a revised 5.1 percent, previously reported as a 3.5 percent gain. 
 "There are no signs of a slowdown" in housing, said Anthony Chan, chief economist at BancOne Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio. "Strong unemployment, low interest rates and high consumer confidence are coming through loud and clear."
That combination is also spurring output at the country's factories and utilities. Unexpected strength in manufacturing -- the weak spot in the economy -- last month helped offset a slump in mining production, Federal Reserve figures showed.
Factory production rose one-tenth of a percent last month after a similar gain in December. Overall industrial production was unchanged in January as gains at factories and utilities offset a slump in mining. Industrial production rose two-tenths of a percent in December.
With builders struggling to keep pace with record sales, the jobless rate hovering at its lowest level in a generation and inflation microscopic, the world's largest economy is poised to extend its almost nine-year-old expansion, already the longest in peacetime history.
January housing starts were the strongest since a 1.833 million pace in December 1986. Housing starts totaled a revised 1.616 million last year, up 9.6 percent from 1.474 million in 1997 and the highest since 1987, when they stood at 1.621 million.
Analysts had expected a decline in home starts because snow and ice storms gripped the Midwest and heavy rains fell in the Northeast during early January, according to a national weather summary provided by the Department of Agriculture.
Starts in those regions did decline. Still, starts in the South raced ahead at the fastest pace in 13 years.
"There's a consistency of demand that I wouldn't expect to be going away soon," said James P. Zeumer, vice president of corporate communications at the Pulte Corporation in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., before the report. Pulte is one of the nation's largest home builders.
Shares of Pulte and other home builders rose after the statistics were released. The Standard & Poor's index of home builders, which is a barometer of the industry, increased rose 3.5 points, to 181.25. The index comprises Pulte, the Centex Corporation and the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation.
"The good times continue to roll on," said Robert I. Toll, chairman and chief executive of Toll Brothers Inc., the nation's leading builder of luxury homes.

HEADLINE: East Timor Seems Suddenly to Be on Verge of Independence

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
For almost a quarter-century, relations between Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation, and the United States -- as well as the rest of the outside world -- have often stumbled over the fate of half of an impoverished island so small and so remote that even many Indonesians would have trouble finding it on a map.
But with the utterance of a few words last week by Indonesia's new President, the territory, East Timor, suddenly appears to be on the brink of independence. That has left the Clinton Administration and other governments puzzling over how to respond to Indonesia's turnaround. 
 Indonesia, on the verge of economic and political collapse as a result of the Asian economic crisis, seems eager to be rid of East Timor, a former Portuguese colony that was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in the mid-1970's over international protest. Since then, the territory's name has become a rallying cry for human rights campaigners.
"We don't want to be bothered by East Timor's problems anymore," Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, said last week. "If someone asks me about East Timor, my suggestion is, give them freedom. It is just and fair."
While welcoming the move toward independence for the 750,000 people of East Timor, Administration officials and foreign diplomats say that if the break with Indonesia is too sudden, it could lead to chaos and even civil war as Timorese factions maneuver for power.
While the vast majority of the population is thought to favor independence, East Timorese who oppose independence have formed small armed bands to fight to keep the territory part of Indonesia, with weapons provided to them by the Indonesian military.
"The Indonesians can't just pull out and expect it to be normal there," said Stanley O. Roth, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. "Any viable solution in East Timor must avoid the type of bloodshed that occurred in 1975, when Portugal withdrew."
Portugal abruptly pulled out of East Timor that year after nearly four centuries of colonization. Indonesia quickly invaded, and declared East Timor a province in 1976. The western half of the island, a former Dutch territory, was already part of Indonesia.
International human rights groups have long accused the Indonesian military of a campaign of killing and torture to enforce the annexation of East Timor. Human rights groups say up to 200,000 East Timorese have died since 1975 as a result of human rights abuses or fighting with Government forces.
President Suharto, who resigned under pressure in May after more than three decades in power, insisted that East Timor would forever remain part of Indonesia.
But his former Vice President and successor, Mr. Habibie, recognized that East Timor had helped turn Indonesia into a ripe target for human rights activists, and that rights abuses there by the military were damaging diplomatic and trade relationships at a time when Indonesia was desperate for international help.
"Indonesia is burdened with enough troubles now, without East Timor," said Daniel Lev, an Indonesian specialist at the University of Washington. "This is a very sensible decision that will work in Indonesia's favor. This would relieve Indonesia of an international burden and the international criticism it has faced since 1975."
Earlier this month Mr. Habibie agreed to remove the long-jailed leader of the East Timorese independence movement from prison and place him under house arrest.
He also ordered Indonesia's Foreign Minister to meet at the United Nations with his counterpart from Portugal, which is still recognized by the United Nations as the territory's administrator, to discuss greater autonomy or independence for East Timor.
The fear, Administration officials and foreign diplomats say, is that Mr. Habibie may move too quickly, and that East Timor may find itself granted full independence from Indonesia before it is ready to govern itself, and with the territory awash in guns. Mr. Habibie has said he wants the issue of East Timorese autonomy resolved by the end of this year.
In testimony last week in Congress, Mr. Roth said the State Department had received "numerous reports that the Indonesian Army has been arming" anti-independence militia groups in East Timor.
He said the United States welcomed a recent statement by the Indonesian Government that it would would support an effort to disarm the groups before a withdrawal of Indonesian troops.
But human rights groups wonder whether the military, concerned that independence for East Timor could inspire independence movements elsewhere in the vast, ethnically diverse Indonesian archipelago, is trying to encourage turmoil.
Rights groups have called on the Indonesian Government to allow the United Nations to station monitors in East Timor -- and possibly even peacekeeping troops -- to observe a transition to independence and to prevent outbreaks of violence among East Timorese factions and the Indonesian military.
"We feel it's urgent that there be an international presence on the ground to prevent further escalation of violence," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, Washington director of Human Rights Watch Asia. "For this process to have any kind of transparency, any kind of credibility, it would obviously help to have some kind of U.N. presence."

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Presents Republican Plan for Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The Republican chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees Social Security provided the first details today of his approach to shoring up the retirement system, saying that he planned to introduce legislation that would create private investment accounts but insulate retirees from the risks of the stock market.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. of Florida, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee's Social Security Subcommittee, said the plan would use a large portion of the Federal budget surplus to finance the investment accounts. 
 Although members of both parties have made specific proposals on Social Security, the Republican leadership has so far been reluctant to endorse a particular approach, calling on President Clinton instead to present a detailed package as the basis for negotiations.
Mr. Shaw said his plan, which will be the starting point for the bill most likely to reach the House floor later this year, would still have to be reviewed by his party's leaders. But he said his approach had the general support of most House Republicans, and his willingness to outline legislation could mark the beginning of a more intense debate over how the nation should deal with pressures facing the social welfare system as the population ages.
Republican leaders have agreed with Mr. Clinton that 62 percent of the projected Federal budget surpluses, or $2.7 trillion over the next 15 years, should be set aside to help put Social Security on firmer financial footing as the baby boom generation approaches retirement. While there is no assurance that the surpluses will actually materialize, both parties are counting on them to minimize or eliminate the need for benefit cuts or tax increases.
But the two parties are far apart over how to use the money for Social Security. Mr. Clinton, backed by nearly all Democrats in the House and most in the Senate, wants to use the money to pay down the national debt and earmark the savings for Social Security.
Members of both parties are skeptical that they can reach agreement on an issue that is so politically sensitive and brings out the deep ideological differences between them, especially in the aftermath of the impeachment trial and with the 2000 elections looming.
Mr. Shaw's approach, while still in tentative form and lacking many of the details that would determine its fate, would use the surplus to help individuals buy stocks and bonds for private accounts that would be part of the Social Security system.
Mr. Shaw said he believed most people would do better under his plan than under the current system. But he said his plan would set a guaranteed benefit level that all retirees could count on even if their investments performed poorly. Mr. Shaw did not provide details on how the guarantee would be financed, and it was not clear whether the plan would allow a benefit equal to what current retirees receive, or if the level would have to be reduced.
He said the plan would also make private investment voluntary, at least at first, permitting people intimidated by the stock market to opt for the guaranteed benefit.
Mr. Shaw described his approach even as Mr. Clinton was holding an event at the White House to develop support for his approach.
In addition to using the bulk of the surplus for debt reduction, the President's plan calls for the Federal Government to invest a portion of Social Security's reserves in the stock market in an effort to generate higher returns. These reserves are currently invested in a low-yielding but safe form of Treasury bond.
Mr. Clinton's plan rejects the creation of individual investment accounts within the Social Security system, but calls for the use of tax breaks to help finance new savings accounts for low- and middle-income people as a supplement to Social Security.
"The Republican leadership has said that generally it supports setting aside 62 percent of the surplus until we save Social Security," Mr. Clinton said today. "That's good and I appreciate that."
But, Mr. Clinton added, "That's where the agreement ends."
Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economic adviser, said the Administration had "real skepticism" about individual investment accounts, but said Mr. Shaw's proposal could be constructive.
"To the degree that he's putting his own specific ideas into the debate rather than simply launching critiques, that's a positive step," Mr. Sperling said.
Both the White House and the Republican leadership have pledged to work together to see if a bipartisan deal on Social Security is possible this year. Speaker Dennis Hastert will meet with Mr. Clinton next week to discuss the issue. But so far there have been no efforts by either side to negotiate.
Without any changes, the system will run short of money to pay all promised benefits starting in 2032.

HEADLINE: A Deal on Lockerbie

 BODY:
More than a decade after 270 people died in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, reasonable arrangements for trying the two Libyan intelligence agents accused in the case at last seem to be falling into place.
Under a plan put together by the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, would send the two suspects to the Netherlands for a trial under Scottish law. If convicted, the Libyans would serve their sentences in Scotland. Whatever the outcome of the trial, U.N. economic sanctions against Libya would be suspended and, in all likelihood, permanently shelved. 
 That formula would leave many American grievances against Colonel Qaddafi unresolved. But it would allow justice to be belatedly done in the Lockerbie case. First proposed by Libya several years ago, the idea of a trial in a neutral country under Scottish law was accepted by the United States and Britain last summer. Colonel Qaddafi then raised new questions, but now appears ready to proceed, persuaded by the personal diplomacy of Mr. Annan, with crucial help from President Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia. They persuaded the Libyan leader to accept the idea that the two suspects, if convicted, would have to serve their sentences in Scotland, although they could receive regular visits there by Libyan diplomats.
Colonel Qaddafi has not yet severed his ties with terrorism, remains an outspoken opponent of peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors and is trying to develop biological and chemical weapons. But agreement to turn over the Lockerbie suspects could be a sign that he is tiring of his role as an international pariah. If so, he might be induced to take further steps toward diplomatic respectability.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Software and Computer Shares Lead Widespread Decline

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by software and computer companies, which fell in the wake of weaker-than-expected sales from Dell Computer and Hewlett-Packard.
By most standards, Dell's fourth-quarter numbers, released after the market's close on Tuesday, were exemplary: a 49 percent jump in net income but sales growth of "only" 38 percent. 
 The revenue number was a disappointment because Dell had reported average quarterly sales growth of 56 percent over the previous eight quarters.
Some analysts had predicted Dell's sales would fall short of its performance over the last two years, and the stock fell sharply on Friday and again on Tuesday. It tumbled another 7 3/16 yesterday, to 81 9/16 .
Since the close on Feb. 11, Dell, the best-performing stock in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the last three years, has declined 20 percent.
Evidence that a market leader had stumbled spread through the technology sector and spilled into the overall market, clipping prices of everything from blue chips to small company stocks.
On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues outnumbered those that advanced by nearly 2 to 1. Volume on the Big Board was moderate, at 735.1 million shares. On the Nasdaq, just more than 900 million shares changed hands.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 101.56 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,195.47. The S.& P. 500 fell 17.84 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,224.03. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies was battered, dropping 6.86 points, or 1.7 percent, to 389.54. For the year, the index is down 7.7 percent.
But the biggest declines of the session were recorded by stocks that make up the Nasdaq composite index.
Nasdaq fell 64.96 points, or 2.8 percent, to 2,248.91. Since Feb. 11, the Nasdaq has declined 6.5 percent, its biggest three-session loss since October 1998.
"There are a lot of reasons for the market to get hit, and virtually no reasons for it to go up," one stock trader said. "At best, I think we will tread water between 9,100 and 9,400 on the Dow. But I would not be at all surprised to see it take a little hit and go through 9,100."
John Manley, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said "strong pressures" are working on stock prices, some positively, others much less so.
"The Fed is trying to keep the financial system from imploding, but economic growth in significant portions of the world, including Europe and Latin America, is slowing," he said.
"More than ever," he added, "the United States is affected by what is happening overseas. The market action over the past five days has been markedly affected by what is happening in Japan."
In this country, the recent rise in Japanese interest rates has not only pushed up bond yields but also shown that stocks are vulnerable to an increase in interest rates. Bond prices rose slightly and yields fell for a second day yesterday, and the improvement helped many interest-sensitive bank and financial company shares.
But that development did nothing to stem the decline in high-flying technology shares.
Hewlett-Packard was the worst- performing component of the Dow, shedding 2 3/8, to 68 1/8. Like Dell, Hewlett, the world's second-biggest computer maker, reported a slowdown in its fiscal first-quarter sales growth and said sales were likely to be lackluster for the rest of the year. Traders chose to concentrate on the slower sales and ignored earnings that beat analysts' consensus estimates by 9 cents a share.
Other computer manufacturers also got punished.
I.B.M. lost 2, to 170 1/2. And Compaq Computer fell 1 13/16 , to 41.
Among other leading technology companies, Microsoft slumped 6 1/4, to 150. Cisco Systems lost 3 15/16 , to 95 1/8. And Sun Microsystems fell 6 3/8, to 94 1/16 .

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bond Prices Rise
 Bond prices rose yesterday for a second day as declining commodity prices and a Federal Reserve report showing no pickup in industrial production bolstered expectations for subdued inflation.
The drop in commodities, including gold, "points to low inflation," said Barry Evans, who helps oversee $10 billion of bonds at John Hancock Funds in Boston, including some Treasuries purchased yesterday. "That's better for bonds."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32 , to 99 4/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.31 percent, from 5.34 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: San Francisco Settles Lawsuit On Desegregation of Schools

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17

 BODY:
The San Francisco school district has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit by Chinese-American students seeking to end the city's school desegregation efforts based on race.
The settlement, which received preliminary approval from a Federal district judge on Tuesday, would eliminate racial and ethnic quotas that have been enforced at San Francisco schools for 15 years. 
 It would also prohibit assigning any of the district's 62,000 students to a school, class or program solely on the basis of race or ethnicity. The San Francisco Examiner reported today that the school district might adopt a system of preferences for children facing personal and economic hardship in a new assignment plan that would go into effect in the fall of 2000.
The schools superintendent, Bill Rojas, said the district could insure integration without using race by redrawing school boundaries to include children from a variety of neighborhoods or giving enrollment preferences to poor and otherwise disadvantaged children, The Examiner said. That might result in students who live in public housing, or qualify for free or reduced-price lunch or whose parents never graduated from high school, having a better chance at winning a place in a competitive school than a child from a well-educated, middle-class family.
Under the settlement, the ban on racial and ethnic admissions would have to be drafted by mid-March and would take effect this fall for students in kindergarten and the sixth and ninth grades, as well as for students new to the district. It would cover all students the following year.
The settlement leaves the district's overall desegregation efforts under court supervision through 2002. That means the district should continue receiving $37 million a year it is now given by the state for remedial and enrichment classes and other programs to eliminate the effects of segregation, said Anthony Anderson, an associate superintendent.
Judge William Orrick of Federal District Court here, praised the school district, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the plaintiffs for bringing the case to a "successful and peaceful solution" and avoiding a potentially divisive trial, which was to have started on Tuesday. He gave preliminary approval to the settlement, and scheduled a hearing on final approval for April 20.
The enrollment ceilings that will be phased out limited the enrollment of any single racial or ethnic group to 45 percent of the student body at a school, and a 40 percent limit at alternative or magnet schools. The limits were part of a desegregation program, approved by Judge Orrick in 1983, that settled a 1978 discrimination suit by the N.A.A.C.P.
The settlement does include a provision that would allow the N.A.A.C.P. to return to court to ask for a desegregation remedy if schools become segregated, said Daniel Girard, the lawyer who represented the plaintiffs.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Providing Legal Cloaks for a Topless Club

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
IT'S in the nature of a lawyer to object, so maybe it is not surprising that Mark J. Alonso, who has been defending the topless bar Ten's so creatively, has a problem.
"Dodge" is the word that's bothering him -- as in ducking or skirting the law. And as Mr. Alonso came up with the very clever idea of getting around the city's crackdown on adult establishments last summer by having Ten's admit minors, thus removing itself from classification as an adult establishment, it seems appropriate. That loophole, after seven heady months for Mr. Alonso, was declared invalid last week. 
 Prompting the question:
In all honesty, how long did Mr. Alonso think he would get away with that minors dodge? He doesn't mind if the reporter calls it a dodge?
"I mind," he says.
An example follows of Mr. Alonso's thinking, convoluted but impressive. Mr. Alonso does not, as they say in the theater -- which has been known to encompass law -- once break character and laugh.
"Do you jaywalk?," Mr. Alonso asks. "O.K., so when you cross at the corner is that a dodge? Every time I pay my taxes, I'm using a dodge to avoid evasion of taxes? All we did was do exactly what the law said, by placing ourselves outside of it by not excluding minors."
Dizziness requires one to take a moment. Certainly Mr. Alonso would agree that not excluding minors goes against the spirit of the law.
"If you accept that the intent of the law was to close topless nightclubs, then yes, it runs counter to the spirit of the law," he says. "But the intent of the law was to eliminate adverse secondary effects caused by adult establishments, and anyone who knows the neighborhood Ten's is in -- the 20's, Chelsea -- knows most secondary effects were caused by Limelight and the clubs that cater to a younger crowd." Ten's attracts older businessmen.
Another tack from Mr. Alonso: "This is a constitutional argument." He invokes the Constitution so often you think you're in the offices of the A.C.L.U.
It's been quite a merry run -- at least for Mr. Alonso, who gives every indication of enjoying this fight.
Last November, Justice Stephen G. Crane of State Supreme Court in Manhattan upheld Mr. Alonso's argument that the club could not be defined as an adult eating and drinking establishment "if it does not exclude minors."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called the ruling "one of the jerkier opinions that comes out of being overly legalistic."
The National Law Journal called Mr. Alonso "a sharp lawyer."
Two weeks ago, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court overturned that decision. The police padlocked the club, and Ten's was shut down for all of a week.
Then Judge Crane permitted Ten's to re-open, because the club had complied with city law by limiting adult entertainment (i.e., topless dancers) to less than 40 percent of its floor space. In the rest of the space, the patrons (male) could dance with women in evening gowns at $20 a dance.
IT'S the old dime-a-dance concept, adjusted for inflation," Mr. Alonso says. "If you're there, a couple of businessmen alone, and you want to sit with a couple of beautiful women, ask them to dance to Frank Sinatra, you can. I went with my wife and it was one of the more pleasant times I've had in a nightclub in seven or eight years. The men enjoy it immensely. It's a chance to interact with the woman as a real date. As opposed to an object."
Mr. Alonso, who is 43, was reared in Greenwich Village and educated at Grace Church School and Trinity High School, and later the State University at Stony Brook and Fordham University Law School. His father, who had grown up in Spain, ran a speakeasy in New York during Prohibition, then was the owner of Granado's Restaurant, on MacDougal Street. Mr. Alonso's first love was music; he performed in and wrote the score for an Off Broadway show when he was in high school. A photo from the production is in his midtown office; interestingly, most of the performers are nude. Mr. Alonso is not.
The legal career, according to Mr. Alonso, happened almost by default. "I found that I had a natural talent for argument," he says. "It was pretty close to the only thing I was good at."
Mr. Alonso specialized in business law, and became involved with topless clubs for the first time in the late 1980's. The clubs now represent perhaps 15 percent of his business. Being the man who represents Ten's has had no impact on his personal life, Mr. Alonso says, though he is disturbed at the way some may perceive him.
"The biggest misimpression of me is that we're just topless lawyers," Mr. Alonso says. "The other is that this is some sort of loophole, when in reality it is very, very sound constitutional law."
He talks about the New York City of his youth: of taking a date to see the Broadway show "Hair" when he was 14 and suffering no great psychic harm from the nude scene. He talks about New York now.
"I have a vision of the city which is very different from the Mayor's bottom line," Mr. Alonso says. "I think it thrives on diversity and opportunity for everybody. I believe the Mayor has done tremendous things in certain fields, but ultimately his vision of the city is a suburban mall with high-rises."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why Robbing Peter to Pay Paul Makes Sense in the Federal Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress are finding all kinds of suspicious elements in President Clinton's budget plan.
Pointing to page 389 of the President's budget, Representative Wally Herger of California, a Republican member of the House Budget Committee, accuses Mr. Clinton of proposing to increase the Federal debt by more than $1 trillion by 2004. According to this argument, a budget that the Administration boasts would use trillions of dollars over the next 15 years to buy back Government bonds held by the public in reality digs a deeper financial hole. 
 Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, says the plan will put a "large burden on our children and grandchildren, who will have to repay this debt."
Administration officials and many outside analysts say the accusations are factually correct but substantively misleading.
Mr. Herger asks, "If, as the Administration claims, the budget is balanced and saves Social Security, why is Federal debt still rising?" The answer also lies on page 389 of the budget, two lines below the figures he focuses on. The table shows that under the Clinton plan, Federal debt held by the public -- or external debt -- falls to about $3.3 trillion in 2004 from about $3.7 trillion today. But, as Republican critics note, total Federal debt rises to about $6.8 trillion from about $5.6 trillion during the same period. Total debt equals debt held by the public (external debt) plus debt held by Government agencies or trust funds (let's call that internal debt).
The two debt figures move in opposite directions because the President proposes to use a large share of surpluses to buy back Government bonds held by the public. External debt would fall. The President would then, in effect, deposit the purchased bonds in the Social Security and Medicare trust funds. Internal debt would rise, because the bonds represent loans from the trust funds to the Treasury. Some day the trust funds would return those bonds for cash.
So which side has the better economic case: the Democrats, who point to falling external debt as a virtue, or the Republicans, who point to rising internal debt as a vice?
External debt -- borrowing money from the public -- has real economic consequences. It siphons dollars from savers and, therefore, private capital markets. Private investment drops. Depending on how the Government uses the borrowed money, the drop in investment could slow economic growth.
Internal debt siphons no money out of the economy. It draws down no private saving or investment. For one agency to lend money to another agency is akin to taking $20 out of one's right pocket, depositing it into the left pocket and reimbursing the right pocket with a $20 I.O.U. The internal loan does not change the person's financial status one iota. One can still spend $20.
By running down external debt and running up internal debt, the President leaves more money in private capital markets. Indeed, his plan nearly wipes out external debt, lowering it from almost 45 percent of gross domestic product today to about 7 percent in 15 years.
Internal debt climbs under the plan: The right pocket of the Government owes the left pocket a whole lot more money.
Yet Mr. Archer looks at these trends and cries foul on behalf of his grandchildren. The Administration's defense comes in two parts.
First, its budget would not raise Social Security spending by a nickel now or in the future. Retirement benefits are determined by statute, not by the size of the trust fund. If Mr. Clinton never added a bond to the trust fund, the Government would still owe retirees money that, if otherwise unavailable, would have to be raised by borrowing or taxing. The bonds add no burden on future taxpayers.
Second, the Administration's budget projections show large overall surpluses even during the years when the Social Security trust fund will be returning bonds to the Treasury for cash. The surpluses, if they materialize, guarantee that the Treasury would have enough cash to redeem the Social Security bonds and still pay for other Federal programs. Mr. Archer's grandchildren will not have to pay extra taxes. Nor will the Government have to invade private capital markets.
There are reasons to question the President's plan. Should Congress pledge money to Social Security based on guesses that Federal surpluses will materialize in the future? Should Congress, by piling up bonds in the Social Security and Medicare trust funds, give those programs first call on general tax revenue? After all, the political consensus behind Social Security rests in part on the fact that it has its own source of money, the payroll tax.
But Republican criticisms cast the issue in a different light. "Debt is debt, and no matter how classified, our children and grandchildren must repay," Mr. Herger says.
This, says the Administration, reflects fundamental confusion. All debt is far from the same. External debt can be cancerous. Internal debt is benign. There is no more need to drive down internal debt than there is for one's right pocket to repay one's left pocket.

HEADLINE: Behind the Curtains of Boston's Best Neighborhood, a New Elite

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Feb. 17

 BODY:
They call Louisburg Square (pronounced Lewisburg, please, not Loueeburg) the most prestigious property, the most exclusive enclave, the most treasured trophy address in Boston. They call it the heart of Beacon Hill, that slope of brick-paved, gas-lighted lanes once a bastion of Boston Brahminism.
But peep into the town houses here -- or rather, into their real estate records -- and Louisburg Square suddenly comes to represent the exact opposite of old Boston. 
 For on the little square where names like Cabot and Appleton still dominated a generation ago, a transformation is complete: from old Anglo-Saxon to new ethnic names; from shabby gentility to $3 million price tags on town houses without garages that allow passers-by on snowy days the unusual sight of a billionaire or two clearing off their cars.
Most important, descendants of old shipping and merchant banking fortunes that defined Boston for generations have ceded possession of thesquare to largely self-made captains of the high-tech, financial and other industries that are reinventing the city.
The changing of the guard on Louisburg Square mirrors other transitions from blue blood to new blood, from old money to new money, urban scholars say: Pacific Heights in San Francisco, or, to a lesser extent, Society Hill in Philadelphia or the lakeside Gold Coast in Chicago.
"You could call it turbo-gentrification," the sociologist Alan Wolfe said, borrowing from a new book on the super-charged economy, "Turbo-capitalism."
But other scholars and participants describe it as a sort of de-gentrification: A process in which meritocracy, or marketocracy, periodically triumphs over breeding in forming an elite. For a city's own good, if it wants to avoid economic atrophy, the new money had better triumph, historians say.
These days, "young people and people with ideas and people who like the tumble and tide are attracted to Boston and San Francisco and Chicago and New York" and a few other spots, said Kenneth T. Jackson, an urban historian at Columbia University.
"I think that St. Louis, New Orleans, maybe in some ways Memphis, are cities that had an older elite that wasn't as open to new people," Mr. Jackson said, "and I think all those cities suffered a little bit."
Here in Boston, the effect of the old money's accession to new is felt in subtle ways: the clutter of construction trash bins and trucks on Beacon Hill and in the tony Back Bay, as new owners spend millions on interior renovations; the increasingly diverse trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra or the Museum of Fine Arts; in talk of the city's economic and cultural vibrancy, and a sense that the old Brahmin monopoly on financial and social power, like the Irish monopoly on political power, has given way to something more open and complex.
On Louisburg Square the change comes into clear relief. These days, neighbors say, they cannot name a full-blown Brahmin left in residence. The current owners of the 27 town houses that line the square include Chris Gabrieli, a son of immigrants who made millions in software and is now a venture capitalist; Robin Cook, a self-described "poor boy from Queens" who bought his house after writing "Coma," the best-selling novel; Peter Lynch, the Fidelity investment guru; Alan Friedberg, retired chairman of Loews Theatres; Thomas Stemberg, who built the Staples office supply chain, and Amos Hostetter, who built Continental Cablevision.
Several of the new residents are ensconced not only in their own paneled libraries but in philanthropic activities once mainly the province of Brahmins.
Mr. Hostetter is widely said to be about to start the biggest private foundation in Boston. Mr. Gabrieli has a family foundation and oversees a public-policy center. Mr. Lynch announced this week that he and his wife were giving more than $10 million to Boston College's school of education.
"It's not like it used to be, when your name had to be something and your background had to be something," said Mr. Friedberg, the retired Loews chairman, who serves on several boards. "Now it's more a question of, are you a valuable asset? Not just in terms of money, but are you a straight shooter, are you willing to roll up your sleeves and work?
"I think the game rules have changed. It's not about whether you have the right ancestors, it's who you are."
Who you are also affects to some extent how you direct your money, Mr. Gabrieli said.
"By and large, it's somewhat less toward traditional culture and arts -- though that's not to say there's no giving there, there is -- and more heavily toward education and opportunity," he said. "It's very entrepreneurial."
Mr. Gabrieli added: "These people, myself included, are entrepreneurs. The pitch that XYZ museum has been around forever and deserves a new generation of stewards is less appealing -- not that it should be, because those are great institutions -- but it's less appealing than, 'Here's a new idea that could really transform something and really needs some drive behind it.' "
The social transformation of Louisburg Square began to take on steam in the late 1970's, said Thomas Townsend, a real estate broker and authority on the Hill. Old Brahmins' departures and deaths opened the way to owners with a new kind of money.
Now, at the end of the century, the strong economy and restored city chic are bringing Beacon Hill renewed glory. Its impeccable preservation, central location and community spirit have combined to make it a neighborhood so hot that a former carriage house is for sale here at nearly $2 million.
As recently as 1970 the Louisburg Square town houses sold for around $100,000. The first Beacon Hill sale to crack $1 million came in 1984 on Louisburg Square, real estate agents say. Though a handful of more modest rental units and condominiums remain, recent sales have exceeded $3 million and $4 million.
On "the Hill," where the sweep of historical memory spans the two centuries since it was built up by developers who also sliced off its top, the influx of mega-rich appears to evoke mixed feelings. No one seems to mourn the isolationist side of the Brahmin reign, or the crumbling Boston of two or three decades ago that dropped prices and sent families fleeing to the suburbs.
And the strong sense of history prompts obvious parallels: Karen Cord Taylor, editor and publisher of The Beacon Hill Times, pointed out that Charles Bulfinch, the famed architect and developer whose gems, like the State House, crown Beacon Hill, was something like the Donald J. Trump of his day. And who were the original Beacon Hill residents but entrepreneurs who happened to be in shipping and import-export and banking rather than technology and media?
"They were the nouveaux riches and arrivistes of their day," she said.
Still, the arrival of this new wave is bringing some consternation along with the welcome for billionaire blockbusters.
Henry Lee, scion of a Brahmin family and longtime resident of a house that looks out on Louisburg Square but is not technically a part of it, said that many of the new rich residents are laudably generous to community causes like the Friends of the Public Garden, which he heads. But he worries, he said, that "money is a terrible destroyer of architecture."
"Poverty is a great preserver," Mr. Lee added. "One thing I do deplore is that an awful lot of people have moved into houses on Louisburg Square and elsewhere and gutted them."
Some houses may have needed gutting, said Mr. Cook, the novelist, who discovered the dirty little secret of Louisburg Square when he moved in: The houses were largely built by developers rather than by owners, and their grandeur sometimes hides "pathetic" construction flaws that require major repairs like new foundations.
Still, Mr. Lee and others are concerned about architectural treasures being thrown out with the 19th-century heating systems. And there seems an element of psychological discomfort as well.
"I sometimes am a little appalled to look out and realize three or four billionaires are living on Louisburg Square, let alone millionaires," Mr. Lee said, sounding dryly amused. One recent Christmas, he said, he saw a Porsche with a fat red ribbon around it parked on the square -- "probably a stocking present."
Nonetheless, perhaps the most striking thing about the square's social transformation is that, aside from the fanciness of the cars parked on the dedicated spots that other Beacon Hill residents would kill for, its appearance is virtually unchanged, preserved under glass by powerful rules and even more powerful public sentiment that Beacon Hill's beauty lies in its historical integrity.
Its little park, often compared to those in London and locked to all but the residents, seems as unchanging as the houses' understatedly grand facades. The replacement of the octogenarian residents who dominated 20 years ago by younger mega-rich, Mr. Cook said, has meant a new collective willingness to fix the lawn and the fence and the road but not to make any major changes -- such as putting in the fountain he proposes.
For the octogenarians, he said, "spending more than $10 was anathema." Now, he said, "people are probably willing to spend money but everyone's a boss -- so they don't want the fountain unless it's the way they want it."
In a way, Mr. Lee said, the new mega-rich of Louisburg Square are not really a change, either, but only the continuation of a cycle.
"After all," he said, "class in America has always been wealth. In Boston, it got to be a little bit more than that because Bostonians invest their money very prudently and lived simply and therefore could pass it along from generation to generation".
But, he said, 'All these things are only a matter of time. It only takes two generations to get smug."
